fields.headline: Real Madrid 0 - 0 Man Utd
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Campo, Karanka, Carlos, McManaman, Helguera, Redondo, Savio, Morientes, Raul. Subs: Illgner, Dorado, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu, Ognjenovic, Aganzo.

Man Utd: Bosnich, G Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs, Cole, Yorke. Subs: Van Der Gouw, Butt, Sheringham, P Neville, Cruyff, Solskjaer, Silvestre.

Referee: Gilles Veissiere (France)

After leaving Real Madrid and the Spanish press guessing as to whether the most on-form Welshman in English football will be playing tonight, Alex Ferguson has finally announced that Ryan Giggs is fit and will start. Real Madrid will be encouraged that Morientes has been passed fit, but the Spanish side will be without Nicloas Anelka (banned), Fernando Hierro (injured) and Guti (suspended).

1 United kick off and play it back before Karanka puts the ball into touch for a United throw. Morientes stretches his legs and forces a kicked clearance from Bosnich.
2 United look calm and collected as they pass the ball around for confidence in the intimidating atmosphere of the Bernabeu.
3 Scholes has an early attempt at feeding Ryan Giggs but Campo is wise to the move.
4 Morientes gets away from G Neville on the left and finds Savio who advances to the edge of the area before seeing his shot blocked.
6 McManaman picks up the ball deep on the right and finds the advancing Slagado just inside the United area, but his right-foot shot is saved for a corner by Bosnich. Comes to nothing.
9 Real starting to look lively and create the first chance of the match. Raul slides through a pass to Morientes who, after being forced wide, gets a yard away from Berg and crosses for McManaman to head over. A great chance for Real.
15 United having trouble gaining a foothold in this game and have hardly been out of their own half. Real come close again after a sustained period of possession on the edge of the United area allows McManaman to rifle a shot carelessly wide.
16 United win a corner after finally breaking out into the Real half. Beckham takes but Real 'keeper Casillas claims.
17 A swift break by United ends with Cole blasting a shot high into the crowd.
21 Raul almost opens the scoring for Real with a left-foot shot from just outside the area that has Bosnich saving to protect his face if nothing else.
24 All Real at the moment as Savio and Morientes combine for Moreintes to drive in a low shot - Bosnich gets down well to save.
26 Cole misses a sitter; Stam heads on a cross and Cole gets up well in the Real area to guide a header just over the bar.
29 The constant pressure from Real has eased in the last ten minutes allowing United to create chances... and waste them.
30 Yorke breaks down the left and plays the ball square to Beckham but his deep centre fails to find Cole on the edge of the area.
31 Roberto Carlos winds up his legs and has a crack after a McManaman corner falls to him 20 yards out. One spectator on the lower tier was lucky to escape with his head.
32Roberto Carlos is shaping up as a major threat. After another run from deep he cruises around the area before unleashing right-foot shot that curls wide of the right-hand upright.
34 Bosnich is forced to go one-on-one when he saves from the feet of Morientes.
36 Booking Irwin after a foul on McManaman.
36 Roberto Carlos lines up to take a free-kick from 25 yards out but Savio steps up to take and blasts into the crowd.
40 Another run from deep by Roberto Carlos opens up play for Real. He takes the ball past the half-way line before releasing Morientes who continues into the area before losing possession.
43 Real still piling on the pressure but United counter-attack and almost take the lead after some fancy footwork by McManaman is broken down and the break created by Keane. Giggs breaks down the left, looks up and sees Beckham racing away on the right. Real are exposed at the back as Giggs passes for Beckham to find Cole on the edge of the Real area, but Cole's shot goes wide by a foot.
45 Almost a goal when Cole is called offside after drilling the ball into top rght corner from 10 yards. Half-time. Real have had more chances but United may rue their missed opportunities to get valuable away goals.

46 Real kick off and Redondo wins a free-kick just outside the United area. Roberto Carlos drills in low through the wall but Bosnich gets his ample frame in the way. Ominously for Real, Roberto Carlos is limping after taking the free-kick.
48 McManaman drifts around the area before passing for Savio to shoot wide. McManaman takes the resulting corner and Bosnich claims after a deflection loops the ball up dangerously over the six-yard box.
52 United put pressure on the Real goal and Scholes comes close with low shot that drifts wide of the far post.
55 United have pushed up slightly and are denying Real the amount of possession that they enjoyed in the first half. Nevertheless, it is Real who create the next chance when Savio blasts a shot through the middle to force Bosnich to the ground yet again.
56 United break down the left but Beckham fails to get on the end of Irwin's fine deep cross.
58 G Neville races away on the right and gets in a cross to six-yard box but there is no United player to meet it.
60 Real break with Morientes and the ball finds its way to McManaman deep on the left. He cuts inside and crosses into the area but fails to find a Real player.
62 Real win a free-kick near the corner flag, Savio takes, United clear, McManaman lays off to Morientes but United finally clear.
63 Roberto Carlos breaks on the left and cuts inside the area before shooting wide.
64 Booking Giggs races away through the middle and United find themselves playing three against two before Giggs is cynically brought down 20 yards out by Karanka. The ref reaches for his pocket but finds only yellow. The free-kick is perfect for Beckham - left of centre - but he drills it straight at the wall.
69 Bosnich almost beaten when Helguera gets up to meet a Savio corner and manages to squeeze the ball just past the far post
71 A series of crisp, angled passes takes United to the edge of the Real area; Keane passes to G Neville who has made good ground on the right, but Karanka intercepts and knocks the ball into touch off the legs of the United player.
75 Substitution Sheringham on for Yorke, Baljic on for Salvio. Giggs and Yorke almost get on top of each other in the Real area as Beckham delivers a centre that Yorke can only put wide of the far post.
78 Play now evenly matched as McManaman scampers through the middle of the park to relase Baljic on the right.The latter's long-distance shot flies off into the crowd.
80 Intense pressure from Real as Raul releases Morientes in midfield with a superb pass. Morientes then finds McManaman who holds off Berg, drifts out to the right and delivers a cross to the six-yard box. Savio shoots high for Bosnich to make another vital save.
81 Substitution Butt on for Scholes
83 McManaman's turn to miss a sitter. Running on to the six-yard box, he shoots low but Bosnich blocks with his legs to kill off the chance. Should have scored.
85 Substitution Ognjenovic on for Morientes.
87 Substitution Silvestre on for Irwin
88 Neither team is showing signs of sitting back, even if the tempo has slowed somewhat. Roberto Carlos forces a corner on the left but shaggy-haired defender Campo fails to raise his locks sufficiently to reach the ball.
90 United enjoying some good spells of possession in the dying moments with Beckham particularly eager to leave his mark on the match when he shoots high into the crowd. Roberto Carlos makes a late break down the left and streaks away from Sheringham. His cross finds Ognjenovic at the far post but the substitute fluffs his shot seconds before the referee blows for full-time. An entertaining encounter that should make for a lively return match at Old Trafford. Many chances for both teams and on another night, with Cole feeling lucky, United could have come away with a couple of valuable away goals. As it is, they have a Schmeichel-esque performance from Bosnich to thank for keeping a clean sheet.

webTitle: My boss told me to leave when I spurned her advances

fields.headline: My boss told me to leave when I spurned her advances
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

Two weeks into working at a law firm my new boss started to make approaches to me. I explained to her that I was marrying my fiance this year but this didn't deter her. In the end, the rejection hurt her pride and she started to insinuate that I was gay. I fell behind in my work because I couldn't concentrate, so she said she wanted me out. I was happy to leave.

I had to leave the country. The legal profession's a close knit community, and my old boss is a female of high standing, so I had no choice but to look for work out of England. I have found out that she has been responsible for other people leaving because of her unprofessional behaviour. I can't prove the above. But I do know that she has sullied my name.

The solution

You could sue for constructive dismissal on the grounds of sex discrimination (if you had been a woman, you would not have been forced to leave). This would involve taking your former boss and company to an industrial tribunal and such proceedings should normally be started within three months of leaving the post. You should contact ACAS (their local public enquiry point number will be in your phone book) for advice on how to proceed.

However, you would need some evidence and this could be the problem. Did you keep a diary, tell other people, seek medical help or have anything at all to use as evidence? You will definitely need something and the more evidence you can supply, the stronger your case. Such evidence could be as basic as a log you kept of comments made to you, but witnesses to the harassment would be very beneficial.

If you do not feel you can prove anything then you have no choice but to start again abroad. But learn from your bad experiences. In future, log anything that happens which you might need to use as evidence. Keep dated diaries, try and encourage the offender to write incriminating notes or emails - you could even secretly record the unwelcome advances.

Once you get a foot back in the door, you should be able to put this nightmare behind you. And, I have no doubt that this nasty woman will get her comeuppance one day.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Dark heat untouched
fields.standfirst:
Gil Shaham/Akira Eguchi
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Gil Shaham/Akira Eguchi
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
There are several young, American-trained violinists on the concert circuit at the moment, and it takes more than a dazzling technique to stand out. In Gil Shaham's case it is the huge, generous tone that he draws from the instrument that impresses above all. It's a formidable sound, liberally applied, yet offset by a daringly tiny, superbly controlled pianissimo for which his bow seems barely to touch the string.

This was very much a programme of two halves, with the "serious" stuff before the interval and several frothy party pieces afterwards, a showcase for Shaham's nonchalant brilliance. We had to be content with just two extended works, JS Bach's Sonata No 3 in E and Prokofiev's gargantuan First Sonata.

Shaham's intention to give an unfashionably unauthentic reading of the Bach was evident in the first few notes of the concert. The opening phrase was bold and loud, played with plenty of vibrato. Violin and keyboard are equal partners in this work, and by the second of the four movements Shaham was demonstrating that he could also provide a restrained yet lively accompaniment to Akira Eguchi's neat piano melodies.

Prokofiev's F minor Sonata is on a completely different scale. This chamber work remains one of his bleakest, most profound and most revealing scores. Shaham has the technique and style to perform it well; most importantly, he knows how to make a phrase sound angry or impassioned without letting his sound get ugly or restricted. His remarkable dynamic range was fully explored, from the subdued semiquaver runs that Prokofiev described as "a wind in a graveyard", to the rich, broad forte of the first-movement melody. Yet although this was a full-blooded reading with plenty of feeling, Shaham doesn't seem able just yet to touch the dark heart of the work. His performance was involving, but left behind a sense of depths unexplored.

The second half began with Bartok's Rhapsody No 2, based on eastern European folk tunes, a spirited work which had Shaham stamping and almost dancing as he played. The rest of the programme got progressively easier for the listener as it got more difficult for the soloist, ending with that old violin chestnut, a fantasy on Carmen (in this case, excerpts from three different pieces glued seamlessly together), that drew the desired ovation from the audience. But if Shaham is going to be a truly great recital artist he'll have to rely on musicianship rather than on pure display.
***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: The best of the 90s
fields.standfirst:
City of Birmingham SO/ Simon Rattle
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.trailText:
City of Birmingham SO/ Simon Rattle
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.body:
The last programme in HearNow, aka Towards the Millennium, Simon Rattle's decade-long pilgrimage through the music of the 20th century, was unveiled before a well-nigh capacity audience, who had faithfully come along to a concert in which all of the music was composed in the 90s. In London, where audiences tend to be both more suspicious and more blasé about contemporary music, the response to the series has been increasingly patchy but in Birmingham there has been wonderful support every year.

In the last tranche of concerts there have been premieres as well as revivals of major scores - two of each in this programme. Tippett's The Rose Lake, completed in 1993, and Ligeti's 1990 Violin Concerto (with Tasmin Little as the assertive soloist) were cheek by jowl with new works by Hans Werner Henze and Simon Holt.

The Tempest is the first movement of Henze's Tenth Symphony, which Rattle and the CBSO are scheduled to premiere complete in two years' time. Despite the title, and the composer's repeated connections with Shakespeare in his recent works, this music carries no literary associations. "Noise and movement of wind racing along with the enchafed flood," says Henze, was the only image he had in mind when writing this big-boned rondo scored for orchestra with quadruple wind and six horns. At times it seems over-scored; even Rattle couldn't make all of the detail count, though the fleet scurrying figures and purposeful harmony have the well-made quality that Henze puts in to his orchestral writing. It is a great vehicle for an orchestra on top form and the CBSO delivered it immaculately.

Holt's Sunrise' Yellow Noise, though, is explicitly literary; a soprano setting of Emily Dickinson's poem from which the title comes is one element in the 12-minute piece. But it is more than a simple text-based work. The vocal lines are embedded in the teeming fabric of curious hollowed out colours from a band without violas and cellos; the voice disappears for long stretches, as the orchestra takes off on glittering, tangled excursions of its own. Holt's sound world is utterly distinctive, his ideas indelible. Lisa Milne's singing was so compelling, so secure and lustrous, that one longed for more of it. Henze's work is just a starting point, but Sunrise' Yellow Noise could be made the beginning of a much larger work too; Holt has never written with such confidence for the orchestra before.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Bumbling rock god
fields.standfirst:
Julian Cope
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Julian Cope
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
It has been a long time since Julian Cope could be described merely as a singing psychedelic mystic eco-warrior. His channels of interest are so endlessly forking and vigorous these days, that you can't pigeonhole him as just another pop polymath, stretching his canvas only because a leg-up from his music career allows him to (a la Jarvis Cocker). Following his guide to neolithic Britain and the second instalment of his autobiography, Cope's latest project is Cornucopia, which packs the electronic burps of Coil, the inclement blues of the Groundhogs, the Krautedelia of Ash Ra Temple and the bubblegum metal of Braindonor into one weekend. The event would have Cope's intergalactic-pastoral aura all over it even if he wasn't performing.

Playing to an audience equally divided between misfits and musicologists, Cope proves over two solo sets that his literary and neolithic hobbies haven't taken the edge off his showmanship. He's unique in that he manages to sit somewhere between self-effacing, self-righteous and self-mocking without being egoless and bland.

When he "rocks out" on Sleeping Gas, accompanied by a drum machine and the Royal Festival Hall's ancient organ, the song - sinister and dangerous on record - is suddenly absurd, but to describe it as pure novelty would be ignoring the heart that Cope wears on the sleeve of his big girl's blouse. Similarly, a Mellotron and voice-only Great Dominions loses its mandatory spongy ambience, yet it doesn't matter.

What we're really here to see is what Sounds writer Mark Cooper once momentously described as "the aesthetics of embarrassment". Unlike his old mate, Echo and the Bunnymen's Ian McCulloch, Cope isn't an all-out rock god. Neither is he a bumbling fool who deludes himself into thinking he's a rock god. Rather, he's a bumbling fool who knows he is deluding himself into thinking he's a rock god, and, precisely because of that, ends up making a good one.

fields.headline: Somerfield attracts Budgens' top executive
fields.standfirst: Budgens
fields.trailText: Somerfield yesterday announced that it had managed to lure John von Spreckelsen, the highly successful chief executive of rival supermarket Budgens, to take over as executive chairman.
fields.body:
Somerfield yesterday announced that it had managed to lure John von Spreckelsen, the highly successful chief executive of rival supermarket Budgens, to take over as executive chairman.

The 57-year-old German national will join Alan Smith, the chief executive of Punch Taverns, who has just been made chief executive of Somerfield.

The move has triggered speculation that German discount retailer Rewe Trading, which holds a 28% stake in Budgens, now may be poised to invest in Somerfield.

It also puts a question mark again over the future of the Kwik Save supermarkets which have played a major role in Somerfield's recent poor share and financial performance.

The shake-up follows announcements last week that Somerfield had broken off talks with potential bidders and was ousting its chief executive, David Simons.

Somerfield's acting non-executive chairman, Lady Louise Patten, will remain a non-executive director. She said: "We feel that Somerfield can look forward to the future with renewed vigour."

Mr Von Spreckelsen, who will join the company on May 2, himself refused to be drawn on his plans for Somerfield arguing more details would be made available at the July results meeting.

The market reacted with surprising indifference to the move with Somerfield shares down p to 54p and Budgens down 1p to 72p in line with a falling market.

But analysts said it would prove a highly significant filip for the company. One said: "Von Spreckelsen is one of the best people around. Somerfield needs good management and this is a man with a very good track record."

Somerfield shares have plunged from a 465p high in July 1998 down to an all-time low of 50p last month. The £1.4bn acquisition of Kwik Save two years ago started the rot and its market share has fallen 1.4% over the past 12 months.

Mr Von Spreckelsen went into Budgens in 1991 when it was at a similarly low ebb and has transformed it from a company worth £22m to one worth five times that amount. Before this he is credited with transforming German supermarket chain Kafu-Wasmund.

fields.headline: Microsoft faces break-up
fields.standfirst: Systems failure:  Anti-trust ruling against Gates wipes billions from share price
fields.trailText: A US judge found Microsoft guilty of violating anti-monopoly laws last night in a historic legal decision that could change the landscape of the computer industry and end in the world's largest software company being broken up.
fields.body:
A US judge found Microsoft guilty of violating anti-monopoly laws last night in a historic legal decision that could change the landscape of the computer industry and end in the world's largest software company being broken up.

Fears that Microsoft would be found liable for its anti-competitive behaviour had already wiped about £50bn from the company's market value before Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson delivered his verdict late yesterday.

The 15 per cent decline in the company's share price also cut about £12bn from the personal wealth of Bill Gates, the company founder. Such a steep decline in what had been the world's most highly valued company had a seismic effect on US technology shares. The Nasdaq composite index fell 349 points, its fifth biggest percentage loss ever, as investors worried about further lawsuits and uncertainty.

Mr Gates, who had led efforts to settle the dispute with the US government and 19 US states, said he believed Microsoft had "a strong case for an appeal". He said: "The principle at the centre of this case is very important for the economy. The lack of [government] regulation of the software industry has been key to its success to date."

Joel Klein, the head of the Justice department's anti-trust division, described the ruling that Microsoft violated the Sherman Act as a "landmark" in the history of US anti-monopoly powers. The ruling, he said, demonstrated "that no company, no matter how powerful or how successful, can refuse to play by the rules."

Yesterday's ruling offered little comment on potential penalties for Microsoft's behaviour. The settlement talks broke down largely because of a lack of trust on the government's side over whether Microsoft would comply with any remedy short of a break-up.

Mr Klein said the department was committed to finding a remedy that put an end to Microsoft's "widespread and persistent abuse of monopoly power".

Judge Jackson is expected to call for further court evidence before ruling on a penalty in several months' time. Microsoft will then appeal. Judge Jackson yesterday found that Microsoft had violated the law by using anti-competitive means to maintain its stranglehold on the personal computer industry.

He also found that the company had unlawfully bundled its Internet Explorer to Windows, the company's software which is used on more than 90 per cent of the world's computers. Microsoft had broken state, as well as federal, laws.

He wrote: "Only when the separate categories of conduct are viewed, as they should be, as a single, well-coordinated course of action does the full extent of the violence that Microsoft has done to the competitive process reveal itself.

"Microsoft placed an oppressive thumb on the scale of competitive fortune, thereby effectively guaranteeing its continued dominance in the relevant market."

Microsoft said most of the ruling was not unexpected and pointed out that the government had failed to convince the judge that its marketing arrangements with computer manufacturers constituted unlawful dealing.

Yesterday's ruling, by finding Microsoft to have abused its monopoly position, will be used by more than 100 lawsuits already filed against the company which allege that Microsoft overcharged individuals. Damages from such lawsuits can be punitive, or three times their actual value.

Several Wall Street analysts sought to ease investor fears yesterday. Rick Sherlund, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, warned investors that they would need to have a "thick skin" to deal with the fallout. "Any good news on the suit may be a year away as a result of the appeals process," he said.

fields.headline: Byers takes more Rover flak
fields.standfirst:
Minister accused of doctoring accounts of meetings with BMW executives

Rover
BMW
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers last night gave a clear hint that he planned to punish the car industry over price-fixing as he came under more fire to explain how he could not have foreseen that BMW was planning to pull out of Britain.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers last night gave a clear hint that he planned to punish the car industry over price-fixing as he came under more fire to explain how he could not have foreseen that BMW was planning to pull out of Britain.

The car unions also intervened, claiming that Rover would be broken up within weeks, putting pressure on Mr Byers to increase the level of government aid - set at £130m - to retrain the Longbridge workforce.

Forced to make an emergency statement in the Commons by speaker Betty Boothroyd, Mr Byers insisted that BMW had only questioned whether it would go ahead with investment in the planned "R30" model in Longbridge if EU funding was not forthcoming.

Recalling a conversation with BMW's chairman Professor Joachim Milberg in December, Mr Byers told parliament: "I did say that the grant aid was going to be subject to an investigation. It would take four to five months... In reply [BMW] said that was disappointing.

"The conversation was all about investing in the R30 model, which is the new investment which they had planned for the Longbridge site." Following the conversation, claimed Mr Byers, BMW worked with the government to make a submission to the European Commission on February 24 in support of European aid.

"Most importantly, they continued with their investment in the Mini... up until just a few weeks ago, the Mini assembly line was actually being put in place at the Longbridge plant and it's still there. So clear indications that BMW were committed to Longbridge."

However BMW maintained it had questioned whether the whole Longbridge plant could survive, but denied it had ever told Mr Byers that it would close its British operations. In an interview over the weekend Prof Milberg, poured scorn on Mr Byers recollection of events.

He said he was "extremely doubtful" by the beginning of December that Rover could go on. "Around the 20th, I called Mr Byers and told him that Rover was in critical survival mode - in serious trouble."

Shadow industry secretary Angela Browning accused Mr Byers of doctoring his accounts of meetings with senior BMW executives over the past four months. She again demanded the full civil service notes of the Byers BMW meetings ahead of tomorrow's grilling of the cabinet minister by the trade and industry select committee. "It is his incompetence that has added to the turmoil this company finds itself in today," she said. "He knew it and he blew it."

The trade secretary also came under attack from Tory MP John Redwood over reports that ministers are set to call for price cuts in the wake of a monopolies and mergers commission report into price-fixing in the car market.

The minister responded by saying the government would respond by Easter but added: "We will put the interests of consumers first for the simple reason that strong and assertive consumers build strong companies - that's the US experience, it needs to be the British one as well."

A dyed-in-the-wool Blairite, sources say Mr Byers will survive the grilling, but the speaker was clearly unhappy that the trade secretary briefed the press about details of his meetings with BMW executives after being challenged for details of them during parliamentary questions last week.

fields.headline: T-Online float price alarms investors
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
T-Online
AOL
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom sent technology stocks tumbling yesterday when it announced a lower than expected price range for flotation of T-Online, its internet service provider.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom sent technology stocks tumbling yesterday when it announced a lower than expected price range for flotation of T-Online, its internet service provider.

The German telecom group said it would sell 10% of T-Online for between €26 and €32 a share, well below expectations of €50.

The group has come under pressure from institutional investors who have balked at the higher price, even though T-Online is the world's largest ISP after America Online.

"The mania for this sector has been fading for a while, but the price set for T-Online has really come as confirmation that operators are no longer going to get the same kind of price as before for their internet activities," one Paris analyst said.

"Until now it was mainly the marginal players that were af fected but T-Online is well positioned and has lots of clients - very far from being a start-up."

Professional investors are becoming increasingly concerned about the high valuations being given to internet stocks and companies with net interests.

Industry experts said Deutsche Telekom wanted to make sure T-Online's shares did not fall after flotation, as a number of internet issues have recently. The group was concerned by the 10% fall in three days in stocks on Nasdaq, the US market with a high proportion of technology listings.

Yesterday's announcement undermined the share price of Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom, which is considering floating some of its internet operations. Lagardère, the French media and missiles group which acquired 6% of T-Online when it sold its Club Internet ISP to the German group, was among the other companies whose shares fell sharply as the market put a for sale sign on a wide range of "new economy" stocks.

Despite the disappointing price range, T-Online will be one of Europe's largest internet flotations with an initial stock market value of €20bn.

Surveys have indicated that one in five Germans wants to buy shares in the company which will be listed on the country's Neuer Markt stock exchange from April 17.

Deutsche Telekom said the 850,000 T-Online subscribers who had filled in a satisfaction questionnaire would have a better chance of being allotted shares. T-Online has 5.3m subscribers.

About 8m of the 100m shares on offer are reserved for Deutsche Telekom employees.

Ron Sommer, Deutsche Telekom's chairman, said the price range would not be increased if demand for T-Online shares started to outstrip the number available.

webTitle: Minister calls for boycott of Barclays

fields.headline: Minister calls for boycott of Barclays
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: A government minister has taken the almost unprecedented step of calling for a boycott of Barclays, one of Britain's biggest high street banks, in protest at its mass closure of rural branches.
fields.body:
A government minister has taken the almost unprecedented step of calling for a boycott of Barclays, one of Britain's biggest high street banks, in protest at its mass closure of rural branches.

In a move certain to stir up political controversy Chris Mullin, the environment minister, called on customers to act against the bank's "hard-hearted attitude" and praised the way in which the Welsh Assembly is planning to remove its account from Barclays.

Barclays is closing 172 branches this Friday and 4,000 branches are due to shut across Britain over the next five years, posing a growing threat of financial exclusion and the commercial viability of rural communities.

The crisis has led to unprecedented all party lobbying, as Labour and Conservatives battle to retain the rural vote.

A furious Barclays yesterday insisted it is living in a commercial environment and has to diversify if it is to survive. It refused to comment on the boycott but said it was in continual talks with the government.

Mr Mullin said the bank faced public protests and pointed out how anger over the banks' plans to charge for cash machine withdrawals had forced a rethink. "That is a demonstration that public opinion can, with a little help from the government, make a difference, even with such apparently hard-hearted institutions".

Recalling the boycott which shook Barclays in the 1970s over its investments in apartheid South Africa, Mr Mullin said he was under no illusion that "the most effective way in which to force Barclays to rethink was for customers to vote with their feet".

"That sort of popular uprising can sometimes work, when appealing to the better nature of the banks might not. I note that members of the Welsh Assembly are calling for the closure of its £3bn account with Barclays. That ought to ring a bell or two in the appropriate quarter."

Ministers are specially angry because Barclays is going ahead with its closures before the completion of a experiment in the south west of England allowing Barclays customers to use post offices as an alternative banking centre.

A Barclays spokesman defended its closures, pointing to the explosion in its internet banking, its 3,200 cash machines and 1m telephone banking customers. He claimed "history is full of institutions that failed because they did not adapt" and added the post office trial was already such a success it was likely to go nationwide.

Although agriculture secretary Nick Brown called for a boycott of French food over its refusal to lift its ban on the import of British beef, targeting a private company is almost unprecedented.

Ministers have rejected direct regulation requiring a minimum number of banks to service a particular sized community, but they believe they can use public opinion to lever change on the big banks.

They hope that by maximising the pressure on the banks they can force them into making a better deal with the post office over its plans to take on banking services.

Ministers are worried about the political backlash developing over the wave of post office closures in rural communities.

The industry minister Alan Johnson told a private meeting of MPs last week that he expected between 400 and 500 rural post offices to close in the next year, double the average number for the past few years.

He also warned that a write-in protest over the closures is likely to be the largest on record. He predicted nearly 4m signatures will be attached to various petitions to be handed into parliament a week tomorrow. An all-party community banking group has described profiteering by the major banks and the decimation of the branch network as the first major scandal of the new century.

Meanwhile Labour MPs have warned Mr Johnson that unless the government comes up with a serious package to save the network of independently run post office businesses, many marginal seats will be lost.

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.trailText: Sara Cox *** BBC Radio 1
fields.body:
Sara Cox *** BBC Radio 1

It must have seemed a neat idea for Sara Cox to sneak into the Breakfast Show studio on Friday, three days before her official launch date, and so escape the big day's nerves and hype. The only problem was that as a result her Monday morning show had that Tuesday morning feeling. The champagne had gone flat, the energy had fizzed out.

Though Cox has been bracketed with Zoë Ball as best mate and fellow laddette, in fact she's a very different poisson. Cox has none of Ball's breathless vulnerability, always evident beneath the apparent bravado, or her predecessor's desperation to be liked. And on day one (sort of), despite Cox's protestations that she was having a great time, one couldn't help discerning some ambivalence about the long, high-profile haul into which she's tied herself. Although the show purports to be zooless, with her only abetter being Rajesh Mirchandani, in fact there were moments when it sounded as though a couple of the animals had crept back in. Or was that just the sound of reinforcing chuckles from the producer behind the glass?

Mirchandani's role is pretty undefined and secondary. He reads the news and makes odd supportive remarks, but yesterday was never enough of a foil to allow Cox's own strengths to emerge. You almost wanted them to start bickering.

webTitle: Reuters foul-up adds to hi-tech stock jitters

fields.headline: Reuters foul-up adds to hi-tech stock jitters
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Microsoft
fields.trailText: Jitters over hi-tech stocks returned yesterday as London's technology index fell another 5% amid anxiety, stemming from the other side of the Atlantic, about the future of Microsoft, the sector giant.
fields.body:
Jitters over hi-tech stocks returned yesterday as London's technology index fell another 5% amid anxiety, stemming from the other side of the Atlantic, about the future of Microsoft, the sector giant.

Yesterday's trading, during which the once-soaring techmark index fell by 247 points to 4,083, followed last week's turbulence in the dot.com sector which had been propelled higher earlier this year by frenzied buying of smaller stocks by private investors.

Dealers in London said yesterday's further slide was fuelled by the fall in the US Nasdaq market .

At one stage it suffered its worst fall in points terms on record as expectations mounted that the US Justice Department would rule that Microsoft had abused its dominance in the software industry.

Such fears had allowed Cisco, its rival, briefly to eclipse Microsoft as the the world's biggest company last week.

In Europe, the picture was the same. France's Nouveau Marché index for small, high- growth stocks ended down 9.7%.

The difficult conditions for the hi-tech, media and telecoms stocks, which fuelled much of the rally earlier in the year, came amid an unprecedented four-and-a-half hour suspension of the key FTSE 100, and other UK stock market indices, as a result of technical difficulties.

In what was described as a "debacle" by City traders, Reuters, the media and information group which provides the stock prices to FTSE International to calculate a range of UK stock market indices, was forced to admit that a "communications problem" with the stock exchange had stopped it being able to provide the all-important data.

Its problems, which are now the subject of an internal investigation, also mean that thousands of City dealers who rely on Reuters prices to trade were left without information for up to 90 minutes in early trading yesterday.

Only firms relying on Reuters were affected as other firms which provide the price information about share levels were not reported to have experienced any problems.

A spokesman for FTSE International, which compiles the indices, refused to comment on speculation that Reuters might lose its contract with the firm.

"We obviously take it very seriously," a spokesman for FTSE International said, adding a detailed review would be held with Reuters to ensure such an incident could not be repeated.

The FTSE 100 index - eventually quoted for the first time at 12.34pm - fell 78 points to 6,462. It should have been updated continuously from the market opening at 8am.

webTitle: Langer onslaught comes out of the blue

fields.headline: Langer onslaught comes out of the blue
fields.trailText: Justin Langer, batting with a hitherto unseen belligerent streak, helped Australia take a stranglehold on a topsy-turvy third Test against New Zealand and move closer to their 10th straight Test win.
fields.body:
Justin Langer, batting with a hitherto unseen belligerent streak, helped Australia take a stranglehold on a topsy-turvy third Test against New Zealand and move closer to their 10th straight Test win.

Struggling at 13 for one after being set 210 to win, Langer swung the match by blasting a half-century from 42 balls, including eight fours. The new Middlesex captain, usually a stoic rather than a slashing No3, was 72 not out when bad light ended the third day with Australia 73 runs short of completing a series whitewash.

Matthew Hayden joined Langer in the counter-punch, the pair adding 83 in an hour, before he was caught at slip trying to drive Paul Wiseman. Mark Waugh then fell to a doubtful bat-pad decision off Wiseman but his brother Steve held firm until the end.

The wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist had earlier completed 10 catches in the match - an Australian first - as the Kiwis were dismissed for 229.

Chris Cairns was again New Zealand's lone star, with 10 fours and two sixes in his 104-ball 71 before being bowled by Glenn McGrath. He finished the series with 341 runs.

 Sherwin Campbell hit his maiden century, 103, in one-day internationals as West Indies continued their revival with an 87-run win over Zimbabwe at Sabina Park. The captain Jimmy Adams made 60 and took three for 19.

webTitle: Miracles are afoot as Des tries to persuade us it's business as usual

fields.headline: Miracles are afoot as Des tries to persuade us it's business as usual
fields.trailText: Would you buy a packet of fertiliser from this man? The man in question is Sir Desmond Lynam, chosen by The Scotts Company, the "world's leading manufacturers of products for do-it-yourself lawn care and gardening", to front its Miracle Gro Pour And Feed campaign.
fields.body:
Would you buy a packet of fertiliser from this man? The man in question is Sir Desmond Lynam, chosen by The Scotts Company, the "world's leading manufacturers of products for do-it-yourself lawn care and gardening", to front its Miracle Gro Pour And Feed campaign.

As do-it-yourself lawn care is not something I go in for in a big way, I have no way of knowing how miraculous the effects of Miracle Gro actually are - in comparison say to the loaves and fishes, changing water into wine, or the appearance of the Virgin Mary in a cinammon bun - but there was a time when if Des told us there were miracles afoot we would happily have believed him.

Speaking personally, I would have followed him to the ends of the earth. I might even have taken up gardening.

Ironically, it was before Des moved to commercial television when he was best equipped to deliver a convincing sales pitch. I assume The Scotts Company has done its market research to determine that Des is just the man to flog all -purpose bags of lawn care to the nation's gardeners - and in his BBC days, he certainly would have been. In fact, so avuncular and rock-solid reliable was Sir Des back then, he could probably have sold it to the nation's pastry chefs.

But now we see him on a Sunday afternoon pushing the semi-final of what we must learn to call the Axa-sponsored FA Cup and we wonder. He looked decidedly shifty, as well he might, trying to persuade us the Aston Villa-Bolton match was in the great tradition of cup semi-finals. It does not matter how many times you talk about "this famous old stadium" - and there was plenty of that - the fact remains that before lunchtime yesterday you would have been hard-pressed to find a soccer fan outside Greater Manchester or the west midlands to name the two teams taking part in the match.

The non-appearance of the holders, the long wait from the quarter to the semi- finals, and the playing of both semis at Wembley a week apart, have not so much lessened interest in the competition as dissipated it altogether, but Sir Des, whom I should like to think would give everything - the fat salary, the big fertiliser deal - to be in his rightful place next Saturday, fronting the greatest steeplechase in the world, had to pretend it was business as usual - exclusively live on ITV.

"It's another super Wembley occasion," he told us. Oh yeah? "There aren't many left at this historic old stadium, so enjoy it while you can." If he ever gets tired of selling horse manure, there's a career in politics for him. Come to think of it . . .

Fair play, though. By the end, even Des was admitting he had been selling us something of a pup. "It's taken three hours, but Villa are there," he said wearily. The high point of the semi was when the camera sought out John Gregory, and caught John Motson sitting directly behind him. "No problem with player identification for John Gregory, then," commented Clive Tyldesley, quick as a flash.

Relief for Platt
David Platt enjoyed a successful return to Gresty Road as Forest beat Crewe 3-0. Platt began his career with Alexandra, but spared them no mercy as goals from Dave Prutton and Alan Rogers (2) moved Forest five points away from the drop zone.

David Platt enjoyed a successful return to Gresty Road as Forest beat Crewe 3-0. Platt began his career with Alexandra, but spared them no mercy as goals from Dave Prutton and Alan Rogers (2) moved Forest five points away from the drop zone.

 Barnsley moved into second place with a 4-1 win at Walsall who had their goalkeeper James Walker sent off after 10 minutes. The defender Chris Marsh put on the gloves and, despite falling behind to a Paul Hall goal, the Tykes scored four in a 26-minute burst, including a brace from Mike Sheron.

fields.headline: Scotland
fields.trailText:
Accies on strike
Second Division Hamilton Academical arrived at Stenhousemuir with 11 strikers in the team on Saturday - the entire side withdrawing its labour 45 minutes before kick-off.
fields.body:
Accies on strike
Second Division Hamilton Academical arrived at Stenhousemuir with 11 strikers in the team on Saturday - the entire side withdrawing its labour 45 minutes before kick-off.

The referee Hugh Dallas had no option but to abandon the match to the chagrin of a few hundred supporters as the Accies refused to leave the Ochilview Stadium dressing room, claiming that their wages had not been paid.

Hamilton will be deducted three points but that will pale into insignificance compared to the damage done to their reputation. Although wage cheques were issued on Friday, some of the players believed they would bounce.

"Nine players who bank with the club's bankers received immediate payment," said the club's chief executive Bill Sherry. "The others declined to accept the cheques notwithstanding that funds were in place."

 Rangers' easy progress towards the title faltered slightly when they were held to a draw at Aberdeen. Cato Guntveit put the Dons ahead before a deflected shot from Barry Ferguson restored some sense of order.

fields.headline: Nationwide Second Division
fields.trailText:
Wigan clean up
Wigan and Burnley produced away wins while leaders Preston were held at Blackpool. Wigan leapfrog Bristol Rovers into second place after Neil Redfearn's third goal in two games, and an own-goal from Darren Powell brought a 2-0 win at Brentford, Wigan's fourth win in succession.

Wigan clean up
Wigan and Burnley produced away wins while leaders Preston were held at Blackpool. Wigan leapfrog Bristol Rovers into second place after Neil Redfearn's third goal in two games, and an own-goal from Darren Powell brought a 2-0 win at Brentford, Wigan's fourth win in succession.

 Burnley stayed on course with a 2-1 win at Cardiff. Steve Davis gave the Clarets the lead after 21 minutes and Andy Payton's 24th of the season increased the advantage before an Ian Cox own-goal threw the Welshmen a lifeline they failed to grasp despite playing against 10 men when Burnley's Colin Little was sent off after 73 minutes.

 An attack on Stoke City's goalkeeper Gavin Ward overshadowed Peter Thorne's hat-trick for City, which put them in front against Bristol Rovers after 10 minutes and brought the equaliser five minutes from the end for a 3-3 draw.

 Millwall could only manage a 1-1 draw at Notts County, Neil Harris's 18th of the season putting them in front after 13 minutes only for Duane Darby to level just past the hour.

 Gillingham kept in the play-off group, thanks to Steve Butler's 75th-minute winner against doomed Chesterfield.

 Bristol City made it four in a row with a 2-1 win at Wycombe, Tony Thorpe's 11th of the season putting them in front. Sean Devine equalised before Damien Spencer grabbed the winner.

 Oxford climbed out of the bottom three with a 1-0 win over Bournemouth.

webTitle: Hot head in Alice band finds a cul-de-sac

fields.headline: Hot head in Alice band finds a cul-de-sac
fields.trailText: This may or may not have been the penultimate Wembley FA Cup semi-final. The creaking old stadium may yet struggle on, milking its heritage to the last drop and trying to convince the rest of the world that it remains a magnet rather than the decaying shell we all have long known it to be.
fields.body:
This may or may not have been the penultimate Wembley FA Cup semi-final. The creaking old stadium may yet struggle on, milking its heritage to the last drop and trying to convince the rest of the world that it remains a magnet rather than the decaying shell we all have long known it to be.

Yet whatever happens, one thing is certain. In all the stadium's 75-year association with the FA Cup there cannot have been a more relieved man who has performed here than Gareth Southgate. Yet again, he was involved in a crucial penalty shoot-out and this time he won. Better still he didn't even have to take one. His smile at the end of this match was so bright, it could have floodlit Villa Park.

For many a seasoned observer, it should never have come to this. Semi-finals at Wembley, on consecutive weekends, games without recourse to replay and then decided by penalties: whatever happened to tradition?

Well, in one respect, Bolton and Aston Villa fitted in to the long, long history of cup semi-finals: this was a poor game, descending into lengthy periods of head tennis, enlivened only by a two-minute spell of post hitting in extra-time. Even the penalties failed to fry the nerves as these tests often can.

But for the fan of football's unlikelier byways, there was still much to enjoy. Without recourse to all the relevant documentation I can't be certain about this, but surely this was the first game in Wembley's FA Cup history to feature a temper tantrum culminating in the furious removal and disposal of an Alice band.

Yes, Benito Carbone lived up to every preconception of the over-emotional maverick, except the one which proposes that his skills are worth £33,000 a week. Immodestly shod in gold, Carbone did little except bask in the Villa followers' exaggerated acclaim. Maybe it was the glare from the boots, but he did nothing.

It was hard to see how he could contribute since Villa's principal tactic was to hoof the ball forward several feet above his extravagantly thatched head. With Paul Merson playing as if in someone else's boots, it was not edifying stuff.

It came to nobody's great surprise but his own that Carbone was removed midway through the second half to make room for the more robust approach of Dion Dublin. The Italian feigned astonishment when it was pointed out to him it was his name on the fourth official's board. Stamping his golden feet, he marched off in fury, kicking a bucket of water as he swished past the Villa bench on his way down the tunnel and presumably, he anticipated, straight to the airport.

Except that he had not kept up-to-date with the arrangements at Wembley and instead of the tunnel leading to refuge in the dressing rooms he found himself, like during much of the game, going down the wrong channel and faced with no-one to complain to but a couple of rubbish skips. Moments later he returned, sheepishly, to sulk on the bench.

Not that Carbone's tantrum will have worried John Gregory. He had far more to worry about in his position up in the royal box, such as the failure of any of his failures to pass the ball. Growing evermore intemperate as it became clear his side were not to break down an obdurate Bolton, he was reduced to futile yelling: "Pass it"; "Run, run", and "What is he like, that Barry?"

But that's the long tradition of FA Cup semis: never mind the quality, enjoy the result. On May 20, Carbone will be back. No doubt this time shod in platinum.

fields.headline: Beckham crosses create Hammer horror
fields.trailText: Admire them, yes. Praise them, sure. But worry for English football, too. What does it say about the Premiership that Manchester United can beat the eighth-placed team 7-1? And that, apparently, after letting them off lightly.
fields.body:
Admire them, yes. Praise them, sure. But worry for English football, too. What does it say about the Premiership that Manchester United can beat the eighth-placed team 7-1? And that, apparently, after letting them off lightly.

"I felt they let up. It looked as if they could have gone on to score more," said West Ham's keeper Craig Forrest. He should know. On his last visit to Old Trafford, with Ipswich in 1995, he conceded nine. It was a good job Sir Alex Ferguson's players were messing about.

Even allowing for West Ham's injuries, this confirmed that, when United are in the mood, few can touch them. After spending much of the season playing within themselves, they have asserted their superiority. To save Roy Keane from a repetitive trophy-lifting injury, perhaps they should be kept out of next season's FA Cup as well.

United are not invincible. But their challengers cannot match them for consistency, depth of talent or options in attack. No one has the same big-game temperament either. When United have to perform, they do. Against Leeds, Arsenal, Liverpool and Chelsea their record this season reads won four, drawn two, lost one. As West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp said: "They would probably win the Boat Race if they went in for it."

For now Ferguson would doubtless settle for a sixth title in eight seasons. As it stands, with a 10-point lead, United need four wins to confirm the inevitable.

"Some of their football in the second half was irresistible," Redknapp said. "Their movement and passing was from another level. Every time they get the ball they've got five or six options. They're never standing still."

David Beckham, in particular, was outstanding. If his boots are worth £13,800, what price a crossing and dead-ball tutorial? The free-kick he arrowed past Forrest for No6 was arguably surpassed by the centre he conjured for Andy Cole to head the third. There were others like it. "You can rarely come for anything because he whips them in six to eight yards out," Forrest said. "I can't remember a cross I could have come for." The keeper finished with a groin injury; after picking the ball out of the net so often it was a wonder he did not have back strain, too. The finishing was ruthless, mistakes punished.

"They're the best team by far I've played against," Forrest said. "Even looking at my experiences with the national side, playing against Mexico in the Azteca would be the closest thing to playing a side as formidable as this. We played Brazil away from Brazil and they weren't as good."

The frightening thing is that Ferguson believes his team will peak in the next year or so. Of his starting XI Denis Irwin alone is over 30. "They can keep producing, keep buying, do whatever they want to do," Redknapp said.

So will the Premiership become a one-horse race? "The Arsenals and Chelseas and Liverpools have got the resources to keep pushing them," Redknapp said. "They're very, very strong. There's not a million miles between them."

United may have been helped by the trip to Brazil and their absence from the Cup but no one has coped as well with the domestic-European demands. They have saved their best for the right time and will play Real Madrid at the Bernabeu tomorrow full of confidence.

Only Mickael Silvestre looks a weak link but after a shaky start, during which Paulo Wanchope put West Ham ahead, United were relentless. Paul Scholes equalised, Irwin scored after his penalty was saved and Cole headed in before half-time. Scholes completed his first club hat-trick with a back-heel flick and a penalty before Beckham's free-kick and a Solskjaer goal.

A few absent West Ham fans must have hoped the score was an April fool, but no such luck. In fact, one of the most remarkable things was that, United being United, it was hardly remarkable at all.

webTitle: Arsenal Ladies stroll to cup glory past Croydon

fields.headline: Arsenal Ladies stroll to cup glory past Croydon
fields.trailText: Arsenal's women retained the League Cup on Saturday with a fine display which was all too much for Croydon, who went down 4-1 at Underhill.
fields.body:
Arsenal's women retained the League Cup on Saturday with a fine display which was all too much for Croydon, who went down 4-1 at Underhill.

More than 1,000 spectators were present to see the Gunners lift the cup for a record sixth time and the third consecutive year. It was also the league champions' first defeat of the season.

Ciara Grant scored from 25 yards after 12 minutes to put the holders in front, but it took Arsenal until two minutes into the second half to add to it, the full-back Kirsty Pealling heading in from close range.

The England internationals Clare Wheatley and Marieanne Spacey, from the spot, wrapped the match up before the hour although Croydon's striker Tara Proctor made her mark with a fine effort from 30 yards.

In yesterday's league games Tranmere Rovers Ladies beat Reading Royals 3-1 and Everton Ladies thrashed Millwall Lionesses 5-1.

webTitle: Barca get in the groove for Chelsea

fields.headline: Barca get in the groove for Chelsea
fields.trailText: Barcelona warmed up Wednesday's Champions League quarter-final first leg at Chelsea with a 3-0 victory against Valencia, who face Lazio that same evening.
fields.body:
Barcelona warmed up Wednesday's Champions League quarter-final first leg at Chelsea with a 3-0 victory against Valencia, who face Lazio that same evening.

Winston Bogarde opened the scoring after 63 minutes and Patrick Kluivert followed up with his second double in less than a week to send the majority of the 98,000 crowd home in good heart.

Real Madrid, who host Manchester United tomorrow in their first leg, held on for a 1-1 draw with Real Sociedad on Saturday despite going one up after four minutes through the Brazilian striker Savio, back after two months sidelined with an injured knee.

But it was Madrid's 18-year-old goalkeeper Iker Casillas who stole the show, denying Sociedad on at least six occasions though Oscar de Paula did eventually get past him with a second-half header.

Lazio reopened the race for the Scudetto with a 1-0 win at Juventus to move within three points of the Turin club. Diego Simeone headed the winner in the second half, a minute after Juve's was Ciro Ferrara sent off. "I'm disappointed but not worried," said the coach Carlo Ancelotti. We don't need drama now, we are still focused and we are looking ahead with calm."

In the Turkish league Galatasaray, who host Leeds in the Uefa Cup semi-final first leg on Thursday, drew 0-0 with Erzurumspor and are now six points clear of Besiktas.

fields.headline: Nationwide Third Division
fields.trailText:
Swans miss boat
Swansea failed to capitalise on Rotherham's draw at Darlington as they were held at Brighton despite taking the lead with a Julian Alsop header only for Gary Hart to equalise. The Seagulls are now unbeaten in eight games and were given a further lift with the news that Fat Boy Slim's record company, Skint, has renewed its shirt-sponsorship deal for two seasons.

 Marlon King's second-half goal at Mansfield was enough to keep Barnet in sixth place while Peterborough's 3-3 draw with visiting Rochdale left them in fifth.

 Goals from Russell Milton and Martin Devaney maintained Cheltenham's hopes of a play-off place. It was their third successive win and kept them in front of eighth-placed Hartlepool, 2-1 winners against Exeter and whose player-manager Noel Blake opened the scoring.

 Shrewsbury slipped deeper into trouble with a 2-1 home defeat by Lincoln which was compounded by the bottom-club Chester's 1-0 win at Halifax. The two are level on points, though the Shropshire club have a game in hand. But Carlisle, with two matches in hand, are only a point clear of the duo after being thumped 4-0 by visiting Hull, who had previously scored 11 away goals in 19 matches.

fields.headline: Wolves fan 'critical' after clashes
fields.trailText: A 35-year-old Wolves supporter lay critically ill in a Coventry hospital yesterday after crowd violence cast an ugly shadow over matches in Birmingham and Bristol on Saturday.
fields.body:
A 35-year-old Wolves supporter lay critically ill in a Coventry hospital yesterday after crowd violence cast an ugly shadow over matches in Birmingham and Bristol on Saturday.

The fan suffered brain injuries during running street battles in Balsall Heath, Birmingham, before the key First Division derby between Birmingham City and Wolves. He and a man from the South Coast who was less seriously injured were placed under police guard in hospital.

Police and witnesses felt that the violence around the New Inns pub, on Moseley Road, two miles from Birmingham City's St Andrews ground, had been pre-arranged. "It seems strange that the fans clashed at this location which is some distance from the ground, so it would seem to have been organised," said Detective Chief Inspector Roger Patrick, of West Midlands police.

There were two arrests in connection with the confrontations, which involved about 100 people and spilled out on to the A435 where frightened motorists made u-turns to avoid stones and bottles raining down on the tarmac. Petrol bombs were also thrown.

One motorist said: "It appeared the violence was organised as many of the young men in and around the scene were talking on mobile phones and seemed to be directing others."

Meanwhile two Bristol Rovers fans face life bans from the Memorial Stadium for an alleged attack on the Stoke City goalkeeper Gavin Ward towards the end of the sides' 3-3 draw in the Second Division on Saturday.

"The two people concerned will never see another game at this stadium in their lifetime," said the Rovers commercial manager Rob Ellis. "We cannot and will not tolerate supporters coming on to the pitch."

Mounted police controlled a section of the Rovers fans and the game was stopped for 10 minutes after three people made their way on to the pitch. Two of them approached Ward, whose save had just denied the home side a chance of victory. Earlier he had been the target of missiles amid accusations that he was wasting time.

The outraged Stoke manager Gudjon Thordarson argued that his team should be awarded all three points under Fifa rules.

He also warned that such incidents could cost English football its goal of staging the 2006 World Cup. "If England wants to stage the World Cup, the authorities here have to clamp down as strongly as possible on that sort of incident."

webTitle: Collymore's season ends in bad break

fields.headline: Collymore's season ends in bad break
fields.trailText: From Liverpool to La Manga, he has been reviled, execrated and ostracised. Sympathy has been a commodity woefully short in supply, but yesterday there were bucketloads of it for Stanley Victor Collymore.
fields.body:
From Liverpool to La Manga, he has been reviled, execrated and ostracised. Sympathy has been a commodity woefully short in supply, but yesterday there were bucketloads of it for Stanley Victor Collymore.

Having rehabilitated himself with four goals in five appearances for his new employers, Collymore's season reached a premature and untimely end when his left ankle gave way 17 minutes into this tepid capitulation by Martin O'Neill's de-mob happy side.

As Collymore sprayed a pass from the centre circle to Robbie Savage on the right touchline, his weight came down on one side and his face contorted with pain. His cry of anguish was clearly audible above the noise of the crowd. The six minutes of treatment bore witness to the injury's seriousness and the Leicester striker left on a stretcher with his legs bound together and breathing with the aid of an oxygen mask.

The immediate diagnosis was a broken bone just above the left ankle, complicated by a dislocation of the ankle and damage to the ligaments.

"The result pales into insignificance because we feel terrible for Stan," said O'Neill. "He got his studs caught in the pitch and the greasy surface might have had something to do with it. He's obviously distraught."

O'Neill said the controversial goalscorer had shown recent signs of regaining his best form, but predicted he would be back "as good as new".

"He performed splendidly against Leeds and it's desperately disappointing. He's been terrific, I could not ask for any more - he's been pleasantly surprising in all aspects."

Collymore's bad break completed a thoroughly miserable afternoon for Leicester, in which they were given an object lesson in finishing from their hosts.

Although the scoreline was a tad flattering for the home side, they were deserved winners of an absorbing, frequently tetchy affair that leaves them with the relative luxury of being five points clear of the relegation zone.

"That was a big win for us," said their manager Jim Smith. "Now it's time we started looking at the teams above us, rather than those below us."

Craig Burley set Derby on their way with a crisp finish from 25 yards two minutes before Collymore's injury, and for all their possession Leicester exuded the air of a team which would not have scored in a month of Sundays.

With a place in Europe already secure, O'Neill's side were out-thought and occasionally out-fought by their opponents, for whom the result was always going to have a more crucial bearing.

As Collymore headed towards the Derbyshire Royal Infirmary, Leicester seemed to lose their wits along with their centre-forward and Derby profited twice with unmarked headers in first-half stoppage time. Rory Delap was the first to benefit from some negligible marking, before moments later it produced the rightwing delivery for Dean Sturridge to make it 3-0.

Even Derby, with the worst home record in the top tier, could not self-destruct from such an impregnable position. Although Leicester did get their act together after the break, any lingering hopes they had were dashed midway through the second period when Neil Lennon received the sending-off he had been spoiling for all afternoon.

The peroxide midfielder was lucky to escape with only a yellow card after a skirmish with Georgi Kinkladze late in the first half. When he rounded on the whistle-happy referee Graham Poll for his umpteenth nit-picking decision, he was given the benefit of the doubt again. But when he flouted his final warning by kicking the ball away at a Derby free-kick only a few minutes later, the referee decided he had been lenient enough. What is it they say about dumb blondes?

To compound Leicester's misery they also lost Darren Eadie, who left the field with a badly twisted ankle. With Emile Heskey gone and Collymore hospitalised, O'Neill is fast running out of strikers. "Has transfer deadline day passed?" he asked.

fields.headline: Robson's choice fools nobody
fields.trailText: If Hollywood needs to mark time until Sam Mendes returns from Covent Garden to present his follow-up to American Beauty, they could always turn to Tyneside, where the old fox, Bobby Robson, continues to direct Haway, Geordie Lad with his acclaimed shrewdness.
fields.byline: David Hopps at St James' Park
fields.body:
If Hollywood needs to mark time until Sam Mendes returns from Covent Garden to present his follow-up to American Beauty, they could always turn to Tyneside, where the old fox, Bobby Robson, continues to direct Haway, Geordie Lad with his acclaimed shrewdness.

Robson used Newcastle's last match before next Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Chelsea to contrive a selection crisis. His goalkeeper changed, both central defenders excluded, he made references to "difficult decisions about my five centre-halves" and made out he was beside himself with confusion.

Nobody believed it, or was meant to, because the inherent theme on Tyneside is that Bobby's got it sorted. Steve Harper should retain the goal keeping shirt he reclaimed from Shay Given, with the likelihood that the rested Nikos Dabizas and Steve Howey will return in central defence.

The plot is pure Hollywood. One of England's most successful managers, survivor of a major health scare, comes back to the backstreets of his youth, saves Newcastle from turmoil and achieves his final ambition, to lead them out at Wembley. If this was Hollywood, Chelsea would not stand a chance.

But his selection sub-plot did not wash. It needed Alain Goma and Helder to be pitted against something more challenging than Dean Saunders as a lone striker.

Bradford spent three days preparing for this match at a golf complex in Hexham, and it took six minutes to hit a divot, in the shape of Gary Speed's unchallenged header. But it was the final minute before Alan Shearer planted in a 20-yarder to make the game safe for United.

A brilliant save to deny Dean Windass on half-time revived memories of Harper's sole appearance on loan for Bradford five years earlier when it was Windass, then playing for Hull City, who scored in a 1-1 draw.

Revenge had been claimed, and Windass's afternoon got worse. Eight minutes from time, he received a retaliatory kick in the neck from Speed. Fearing a sending-off might rule him out of the semi-final, Speed lambasted Windass for play-acting. Windass was restrained by the physio as he gestured retribution.

Windass even got a shove on the touchline from his manager, Paul Jewell. "The last thing we wanted was a sending-off," he said. "I was just making him aware of that." It was a line delivered with a perfect hint of menace in a downbeat Scouse accent. Even Sam Mendes would have been satisfied. Football and the movies are less distinguishable every day.

fields.headline: Bolton miss out as Dublin delivers
fields.trailText: Aston Villa reached their first FA Cup final for 43 years here yesterday by a route which was both tortuous and, at least until extra-time, torturous. After two scoreless hours they finally defeated Bolton Wanderers on penalties, Dion Dublin, recently recovered from a broken neck, scoring the decisive goal.
fields.body:
Aston Villa reached their first FA Cup final for 43 years here yesterday by a route which was both tortuous and, at least until extra-time, torturous. After two scoreless hours they finally defeated Bolton Wanderers on penalties, Dion Dublin, recently recovered from a broken neck, scoring the decisive goal.

A largely forgettable but ultimately dramatic semi-final was in essence a story of one man's misses leading to another's smiles. How Dean Holdsworth, having just seen a free-kick hit a post, managed to waft the ball over an empty net after David James had left his line in the second period of extra-time only the Bolton striker knew.

Certainly Dublin, having seen a header pushed against a post three minutes from the end, had no intention of wasting his redeeming moment in the shootout, after James had saved kicks from Allan Johnston and Michael Johansen to set Villa up for victory.

Aston Villa are not the first side to win an FA Cup semi-final on penalties, Liverpool did as much when they beat Portsmouth in 1992, but they are the first to do so without a replay. Then, Portsmouth had twice bettered Graeme Souness's team and while Bolton did not quite achieve that Villa could not have complained had either of Holdsworth's shots gone in.

Two minutes previously Villa, having lost Ian Taylor to an early injury, had been reduced to 10 men following David Elleray's dismissal of Mark Delaney for two bookable fouls on Johnston in the space of four minutes. Even John Gregory, the Villa manager and hardly an Elleray fan, could not have disputed the sending-off, though the way his team reorganised with 10 men was admirable.

More admirable, to be sure, than much of what went before when Aston Villa, rather than their First Division opponents, appeared frozen by the occasion. Even the better sides can sometimes struggle to get out of the lower gears, but Villa never really played the sort of football designed to bring out their strengths.

For too long the ability of Paul Merson to run at opponents or pick out colleagues with finely weighted passes was ignored as Villa pumped high balls towards their little strikers, Julian Joachim and Benito Carbone. And when Dublin eventually came off the bench 20 minutes from the end of normal time the more effective Carbone was the man Gregory took off, despite Joachim having squandered three chances before half-time.

Carbone retired with the dignity of a three-year-old being led past the sweet counter at Tesco, flinging down his headband and kicking the trainer's bucket. At the end of the match he threw his dazzling footwear into a crowd of Villa supporters, and one had to wonder about the mentality of a striker who awards himself two golden boots to begin with.

At the outset, and for a long time thereafter, Bolton appeared to have the most likely match-winner in Eidur Gudjohnsen, the 21-year-old Icelandic striker who had scored in each of the previous four rounds. A combination of Gudjohnsen's burly physique and his ability to turn tightly with the ball gave Ugo Ehiogu a particularly difficult afternoon and so nearly brought Bolton a goal after 19 minutes.

Johnston cleverly turned in from the left before laying the ball off to Gudjohnsen, who turned between Ehiogu and Gareth Southgate and saw his shot beat James only to be turned clear by a flick of Alan Wright's head. Until extra time that was the closest Bolton came to scoring.

Despite their poverty Aston Villa could have had the match won by half-time. In the space of 12 minutes Joachim gathered an exquisite return pass from Carbone but shot too high and was then twice thwarted by Jussi Jaaskelainen's alertness in the Bolton goal.

Extra-time proved relatively entertaining because both teams were tiring and making even more mistakes. Holdsworth's howler recalled Ronnie Rosenthal, then with Liverpool, missing an empty net at Villa Park. Dublin's header would have made a better climax than his penalty had it hit the net rather than the post.

Chelsea and Newcastle United return here next Sunday to decide who will be Aston Villa's opponents in the final on May 20. At least these teams should fill Wembley - yesterday's attendance was more than 12,000 below capacity, largely because Bolton's fans had not taken up their quota of tickets.

That should be a more memorable game. Before yesterday's kick-off the PA system implored spectators not to stand on seats in their excitement. Certainly the football did its best to make sure everyone took the spectacle sitting down.

webTitle: Goal feast not enough to stave off the lean times at Everton

fields.headline: Goal feast not enough to stave off the lean times at Everton
fields.trailText: Watching Everton's performances this season has been reminiscent of Peter Cook's gag about a one-legged man auditioning for Tarzan. "Your right leg I like. A lovely leg for the role. I've got nothing against your right leg. The trouble is - neither have you."
fields.body:
Watching Everton's performances this season has been reminiscent of Peter Cook's gag about a one-legged man auditioning for Tarzan. "Your right leg I like. A lovely leg for the role. I've got nothing against your right leg. The trouble is - neither have you."

Everton fans, who continue to support the Blues in almost painfully large numbers, can have no clearer idea of what the future holds now than they did at the start of the season but are desperately hoping that the terrible, strength-sapping atrophy which has gripped the club in recent times will finally be sloughed off.

It is not easy to be optimistic on their behalf. Everton are £14m in debt while Goodison Park is literally coming apart at the seams, a fast-fading glory which is reflected on the pitch by the presence of the ageing Richard Gough and Mark Hughes.

A glance at the scoreline would suggest this was an exciting match; in truth, it was dismal.

Watford could be excused. Graham Taylor has next year's First Division promotion campaign in mind and is rightly blooding a few youngsters of considerable promise, notably Tommy Smith and Darren Ward.

That other Tommy Smith, the colossus of Anfield, looked down on Everton from the press box and shook his head at the sheer ineptitude of a once admired enemy. Goals by Moore (2) and the two Hughes, Mark and Stephen, each his first, briefly animated the fans but for much of the match they were silent, as if in a trance.

Liverpool's steady revival, and their signing of Emile Heskey for £11m, has accentuated the inadequacy of the Everton board's response to the needs of the Premiership; Bill Kenwright, having acquired the club for a rock-bottom price, must quickly broker a deal, presumably with a media group, if the Blues are to stand any chance of being competitive next season.

Otherwise there is a very real danger that Everton will go the way of Manchester City. The parallels of mismanagement and self-delusion are all too obvious.

Everton's midfielder John Collins says he may stay at Goodison Park , despite earlier suggesting he would quit English football.

"It looks like I will be staying now at Everton," said the 32-year-old Scot. "I will be talking to the manager before the end of the season and see how that goes. I have enjoyed my time here and things are generally getting better."
