fields.headline: Owen's riposte for the future
fields.trailText: As Gérard Houllier emerged from a sea of back-slappers, he allowed himself to be enticed into the world of the hypothetical by musing about what might have been if the season had started in October.
fields.body:
As Gérard Houllier emerged from a sea of back-slappers, he allowed himself to be enticed into the world of the hypothetical by musing about what might have been if the season had started in October.

Had it done so, Manchester United would not already be looking for the silver polish and Sir Alex Ferguson's stroll to another championship would have felt more like a steep uphill trek - with a pebble in his shoe.

Having started the season with about as much conviction as the Team Philips catamaran, Houllier's rejuvenated charges have been the equal of their old adversaries to the point that Messrs Ferguson and co should already be casting anxious glances in their direction ahead of next season.

Away wins at Highfield Road have been few and far between this season but this clinical dismantling of a side boasting one of the finest home records in the country was achieved with such a modicum of fuss and swagger that it provoked reminiscences of yesteryear. "At times we were extremely brilliant," eulogised the Liverpool manager. It was hard to disagree.

United may be disappearing into the sunset but, with Leeds suddenly developing a nasty case of end-of-season jitters, the prospects of a morale-boosting second spot are becoming increasingly realistic.

"I've told the players that we are coming to the most important and exciting part of the season," said Houllier. "If we stay humble, we will get the rewards."

Here, too, was the overwhelming evidence that Emile Heskey and Michael Owen are becoming au fait with each other's likes and dislikes after a few early teething problems.

Owen had been annoyed about being rested against Newcastle a week earlier and it was Coventry's misfortune to feel the repercussions. Having been let off the leash, the striker proceeded to make his opponents look like a bunch of ale-house players by helping himself to two classy first-half goals, the type of predatory strikes that make him the finest goal-getter in the land.

In previous sojourns for his new employers Heskey's contribution has been peripheral at most, as though he was suffering from an allergy to the opposing penalty area. Here, just as his dry run was threatening to turn into a drought, he seemed to have found the antidote.

The rewards duly arrived and the way he was submerged under a welter of red shirts on scoring his first Liverpool goal, loitering with intent inside the six-yard area before being picked out by Patrick Berger's free-kick, suggests the £11m striker has already ingratiated himself with his new colleagues.

Indeed, given Mike Reed's track record of celebrating Liverpool goals, one half expected to see the referee joining the delirious scrum.

fields.headline: Stopgap Myhre saves City's day
fields.trailText: Someone of influence must have been listening when the City chairman David Gold was interviewed on Radio 5 Live an hour before kick-off.
fields.body:
Someone of influence must have been listening when the City chairman David Gold was interviewed on Radio 5 Live an hour before kick-off.

Not unreasonably, Gold cursed the injuries that have plagued the club for much of the season, a catalogue of casualties that last week left him without his only two experienced goalkeepers. "It's about time we enjoyed a change of luck," he mused.

As if by magic, the loan goalkeeper Thomas Myhre and the referee Eddie Wolstenholme stepped up to oblige. Both played key roles as Birmingham boosted their chances of reaching the play-offs while Wolves did exactly the opposite.

City were given dispensation to borrow Myhre from Everton as a stopgap measure because the transfer deadline had passed.

But there are stopgaps, as Bradford City discovered with a chubby fortysomething Neville Southall, and stopgaps, in the form of this agile 26-year-old Norwegian, who made his mark early by diving to his left to smother Keith Curle's 25th-minute penalty-kick.

As for Wolstenholme, it was not his dismissals of Birmingham midfielders Martin O'Connor and Bryan Hughes in the final 10 minutes that had an effect on the result but his decision not to send off a third man, City centre-back Darren Purse, for the tackle that brought about Curle's saved penalty.

Birmingham, who were admirably determined throughout, made light of the loss of O'Connor, expelled for finally losing his cool with Kevin Muscat, as well as the departure of Hughes, who followed his skipper after collecting two yellow cards, the second for diving.

But how they would have fared had the Blackburn official dismissed Purse much earlier in the game will be a subject for animated debate down Molineux way.

"I don't like to see players sent off," said the Wolves manager Colin Lee. "But I thought there was a case for this one. The referee told me the ball was going away from the goal. As far as I was concerned it was heading for the unmarked Ade Akinbiyi and was a definite goalscoring opportunity."

That Wolstenholme opted to restrict the punishment to a yellow card ensured that, in this instance, crime definitely did pay. Not only did Myhre save the subsequent penalty, but Purse and David Holdsworth went on to form an impenetrable barrier at the heart of the home defence. "I thought we deserved more from the game and were worth a point," said Lee. With the Wolves line-up featuring a packed midfield and fronted by a lone striker in Akinbiyi, it looked as if that was all they came for.

Wolves' failure to earn one - thanks to a Holdsworth header on 53 minutes from Gary Rowett's perfectly flighted corner-kick - has left them trailing sixth-placed Huddersfield by five points and Lee favouring optimism rather than realism.

"There are six games left and anything can happen," he claimed.

The Birmingham manager Trevor Francis was upset with the sending-off of Hughes and plans an appeal.

"Nevertheless, I thought the referee did well under the circumstances," he added. Well he would, wouldn't he?

fields.headline: Saints fail the Phillips test
fields.trailText: As homecomings go, this was an education. Kevin Phillips started out as a trainee right-back with Southampton. He returned on Saturday as an England striker and the Premiership's leading goalscorer. Someone at the Dell hadn't done their homework.
fields.body:
As homecomings go, this was an education. Kevin Phillips started out as a trainee right-back with Southampton. He returned on Saturday as an England striker and the Premiership's leading goalscorer. Someone at the Dell hadn't done their homework.

"It's weird - I used to come to college just around the corner from here," he said. Asked what he was studying, the 26-year-old betrayed his only indecision of the afternoon. "I think it was sports science, but I just had to turn up."

Nothing much has changed. Phillips was a peripheral figure for much of this game, but still scored his mandatory goal, the 27th of a prolific season. His penalty earned the visitors the points and strengthened their challenge for a Uefa Cup place.

"He's single-minded," explained his manager, Peter Reid. "Defenders can never relax when the boy's around. He nearly battered Niall Quinn out of the way at one point - that's no mean achievement."

The Phillips and Quinn partnership has reaped 39 league goals this term - four more than Yorke and Cole. Southampton played three centre-backs to try to nullify the threat, but when the Moroccan Tahar El Khalej dithered, Quinn's deft lob over Paul Jones set the Black Cats en route to a first away success since November.

Marian Pahars and the substitute Matthew le Tissier should have equalised, but when Claus Lundekvam sent Kevin Kilbane sprawling in the area with four minutes to go, Phillips settled the contest. Le Tissier's late reply was scant consolation.

A second success in a week should appease the small section of Sunderland supporters frustrated by a previous 12-match winless run. "I'm not being flippant, but as a manager you have to be strong," said Reid. "I've been criticised for not buying enough, but I bought virtually every player out there today. If I'd bought Kevin Phillips for £10m rather than £650,000, people would have been happy. I can't understand the logic."

The Saints remain one win from probable safety but, after good showings against Aston Villa and Chelsea, their manager Glenn Hoddle was shaken by this setback.

"You could almost sniff this performance coming around the corner," he said. "I gave them a rollicking before the game to try and avoid it, but it obviously didn't work. We were poor - we played better at Tottenham and lost that match 7-2."

fields.headline: Gabbiadini's sodden impact
fields.trailText: David Hodgson, as a Middlesbrough player during the 70s, had the candour to reveal in a Shoot! questionnaire that his post-match routine consisted of a few pints in the pub before moving on to a nightclub.
fields.body:
David Hodgson, as a Middlesbrough player during the 70s, had the candour to reveal in a Shoot! questionnaire that his post-match routine consisted of a few pints in the pub before moving on to a nightclub.

The Darlington manager, while watching his collection of free transfers and loan signings warm down at the edge of a quite appalling surface of sand and soil, was equally as forthright on Saturday after his team had held on to a point and third place against the leaders despite having the game all but won at half-time.

"Professional footballers are having to take three or four touches to get the ball dead on the ground," Hodgson admitted. "It was like watching 20 kids chasing a Super Ball."

So bad is the pitch, which has spent much of the winter holding water as a result of a problematic sewer-spillover pipe and last season's resurfacing with an almost impermeable dry grass, that following the recent dry spell the fire brigade had to be called in on Friday to douse the bone-hard surface to try to eradicate the excessive bounce.

"I don't think the public will be too happy that we are wasting water when all year we've had a waterlogged pitch," Hodgson added. "It's cost us a lot of money but we have to get it soft so that the ball stays down. I don't think it affected us but it affected Rotherham."

Darlington, one of only three clubs in the country undefeated at home this season, were soon into their stride and the 32-year-old Marco Gabbiadini, who is holding out for a three-year deal and is the subject of £250,000 interest from Rushden & Diamonds, turned a defender and smashed the ball into the net for the 25th time this season. Glenn Naylor then doubled the lead from a yard.

"We can't afford to be giving teams 45 minutes start," said Rotherham's manager Ronnie Moore, who switched to 4-4-2 at half-time. "It wasn't really a pitch to play football on so we changed and went route one. You can see why they are unbeaten on it."

Guy Branston headed home a corner at the back post and Andy Turner soon crossed for Steve Tutill to hammer the ball past his uncertain goalkeeper. "If you offered me third place now, I'd take it," added Moore, who missed out in the play-off semi-final last season. "We've got six of the top nine to play and though the results went for us today, the sooner we get to 80 points the better."

As for Darlington, Feethams is to be relaid but outline planning permission has been granted, subject to a public inquiry, for a new 10,000-seat stadium on land near the A66 bought for £340,000 by their owner George Reynolds, the former safe blower. The sooner they can get there the better.

So bad is the pitch, which has spent much of the winter holding water as a result of a problematic sewer-spillover pipe and last season's resurfacing with an almost impermeable dry grass, that following the recent dry spell the fire brigade had to be called in on Friday to douse the bone-hard surface to try to eradicate the excessive bounce. "I don't think the public will be too happy that we are wasting water when all year we've had a waterlogged pitch," Hodgson added. "It's cost us a lot of money but we have to get it soft so that the ball stays down. I don't think it affected us but it affected Rotherham." Darlington, one of only three clubs in the country undefeated at home this season, were soon into their stride and the 32-year-old Marco Gabbiadini, who is holding out for a three-year deal and is the subject of £250,000 interest from Rushden & Diamonds, turned a defender and smashed the ball into the net for the 25th time this season. Glenn Naylor then doubled the lead from a yard. "We can't afford to be giving teams 45 minutes start," said Rotherham's manager Ronnie Moore, who switched to 4-4-2 at half-time. "It wasn't really a pitch to play football on so we changed and went route one. You can see why they are unbeaten on it." Guy Branston headed home a corner at the back post and Andy Turner soon crossed for Steve Tutill to hammer the ball past his uncertain goalkeeper. "If you offered me third place now, I'd take it," added Moore, who missed out in the play-off semi-final last season. "We've got six of the top nine to play and though the results went for us today, the sooner we get to 80 points the better." As for Darlington, Feethams is to be relaid but outline planning permission has been granted, subject to a public inquiry, for a new 10,000-seat stadium on land near the A66 bought for £340,000 by their owner George Reynolds, the former safe blower. The sooner they can get there the better.

fields.headline: Impatient Fayed lines up Tigana
fields.trailText: Judging by the warm reception for his habitual flounce along the touchline, the Fulham support's faith in their chairman remains resolute. For some of his staff, however, Mohamed Al Fayed's increasing ruthlessness in driving the west London club towards the Premiership is proving less palatable.
fields.body:
Judging by the warm reception for his habitual flounce along the touchline, the Fulham support's faith in their chairman remains resolute. For some of his staff, however, Mohamed Al Fayed's increasing ruthlessness in driving the west London club towards the Premiership is proving less palatable.

After Paul Bracewell and his backroom team became the latest casualties of the owner's impatience last week, not even the spin-doctoring of Max Clifford could stop the caretaker manager Karlheinz Riedle resorting to a little Teutonic bluntness.

"It has been a very difficult week and as far as I'm concerned, Paul Bracewell is a good person and a good manager. He should have had a full season," he said.

Riedle is clearly uncomfortable with his new responsibilities; he has moved swiftly to add Roy Evans and Alan Smith, the former Liverpool and Crystal Palace managers respectively, to his coaching staff, worried his own limited experience might prove costly.

"I'm just not interested in management. I don't know why the club appointed me - you'll have to ask them," was his response to the prospect of an extended tenure.

He may be put out of his misery sooner rather than later. The predictable speculation over Terry Venables and the more fanciful notion of Eric Cantona taking charge appear to have been put to bed. Jean Tigana, the former Monaco coach and French international midfielder, is now the raging favourite, with an announcement possible before the end of the week.

Despite his unwillingness, Riedle and his new assistants will hand over a reasonably steady ship. Geoff Horsfield's 14th goal of the season secured this win; his smart chipped finish from Steve Finnan's pass enlivening an otherwise forgettable game.

Palace looked dangerous only in a 15-minute second-half spell, during which their on-loan Finnish striker Mikael Forssell contrived to miss three good chances in quick succession.

With an eight-point gap between Fulham and the play-offs with six games left, Fayed's plans for world domination will probably have to wait until next season. Palace, by contrast, are still wondering whether they'll be around to see it.

The manager Steve Coppell still believes rescue from their crippling debt will come in the shape of the mysterious far-eastern benefactor Jerry Lim. In the meantime, their fans' fundraising efforts are nearing the £1m mark; on Saturday they numbered over 4,000 in the away end and roared themselves hoarse throughout. Fulham's travails, however entertaining, remain risible by comparison.

webTitle: Berkovic the brave puts Celtic back on track

fields.headline: Berkovic the brave puts Celtic back on track
fields.trailText: Celtic kept their unsettled fans at bay last night as Eyal Berkovic gave the performance of his season against Kilmarnock, who last won a league game here 46 years ago. But this was far from easy.
fields.body:
Celtic kept their unsettled fans at bay last night as Eyal Berkovic gave the performance of his season against Kilmarnock, who last won a league game here 46 years ago. But this was far from easy.

The visitors, trailing by two at the break, fought back on to level terms with goals from the substitute Paul Wright and Jim Lauchlan. With a linesman disallowing four Celtic attempts for offside, the game needed Berkovic to restore sanity.

He put Celtic in front again with an individual goal in the 73rd minute, then did all the hard work for Mark Burchill to seal victory. He was later carted off on a stretcher to end his most dramatic evening in Scotland.

Whatever the limitations of Kenny Dalglish, no one doubts his ability to strike terror into the hearts of players whom he considers not to be taking their fair share of responsibility. After the battering by Rangers seven days previously he reminded his players that contracts would not be dished out except to individuals who gave their all for the club.

Berkovic seemed to have taken the message on board. The Israeli ran the first half well enough and after 20 minutes his side were two goals in front, keeping those who were there happy, though the ground was far from full.

The opener came in the 10th minute when Vidar Riseth's long ball found Tommy Johnson. He shrugged off a couple of challenges before shooting past Gordon Marshall from just inside the penalty area.

The Bhoys' second owed virtually everything to Berkovic who found Lubomir Moravcik on the left and covered an enormous amount of ground to reach the return ball. Although his shot was blocked, Regi Blinker, making his first start since John Barnes left the club, rattled the ball home to ease the pressure for a bit.

webTitle: Wenger sees red again but Arsenal remain buoyant

fields.headline: Wenger sees red again but Arsenal remain buoyant
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger is so mystified about why his side are always picking up red cards that he is contemplating a booking of his own. "Maybe I should invite some referees to explain why we have so many sendings-off. Perhaps a good dinner could solve the problem."
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger is so mystified about why his side are always picking up red cards that he is contemplating a booking of his own. "Maybe I should invite some referees to explain why we have so many sendings-off. Perhaps a good dinner could solve the problem."

Knowing Arsenal's luck, the meal will end with a disagreement over who picks up the bill and Wenger will be cautioned for arguing.

On Saturday Oleg Luzhny became the 29th Arsenal player sent off during Wenger's 3 year stewardship, the seventh this season and the third in the team's last four games. It is a grim record, but as the manager pointed out, none of the last three dismissals offers evidence of a dirty streak.

Thierry Henry was dismissed for a nothing tackle against Werder Bremen, Gilles Grimandi for two yellows against Spurs, and Luzhny for ending Andreas Lund's 43rd-minute run on goal when replays cast doubt on whether the Ukrainian either touched Lund or was the last defender. But if the referee Uriah Rennie made Arsenal reach for his medicinal namesake on that occasion, the Yorkshireman did get right three other decisions for which he was roundly criticised later.

Marcus Gayle's first-half run into the area was ended by a fall not a foul - no penalty. Nwankwo Kanu was not offside for Arsenal's 33rd-minute equaliser after being put through by Dennis Bergkamp, and, near full-time, Jason Euell played the man before the ball, earning himself a red card and Arsenal a third goal from the penalty spot courtesy of Euell's victim, Thierry Henry.

Along with Kanu's earlier free header from Silvinho's corner, it completed an Arsenal comeback that, after Lund's 12th minute goal, had been sparked by their reduction to 10 men.

With resilience and organisation, Arsenal dug out their first away Premiership win since December, reinforced their challenge for a Champions League spot, and lifted the collective spirit ahead of Thursday's Uefa Cup semi-final first leg against Lens.

Arsenal have now won five games on the bounce and, with £35m reportedly about to be invested by Carlton Communications, the sun is shining again on N5. The only clouds are the back injury threatening Tony Adams' fitness for club and country plus the availability of Kanu for equally familiar reasons.

Under Fifa rules he should be released on Wednesday for Nigeria's World Cup qualifier in Eritrea on Sunday. But Wenger wants Kanu to leave on Friday after playing Lens.

webTitle: Swindon count gate as City stock up

fields.headline: Swindon count gate as City stock up
fields.trailText: "It's massive," said Joe Royle, and City's manager was not commenting on his club's potential. But he might have been for, if they beat Bolton on Wednesday, they will be in pole position for automatic promotion.
fields.byline: Adam Sills  at the County Ground
fields.body:
"It's massive," said Joe Royle, and City's manager was not commenting on his club's potential. But he might have been for, if they beat Bolton on Wednesday, they will be in pole position for automatic promotion.

Victory in their game in hand on Barnsley - the subject of Royle's enthusiasm - will put City in second place. Seven games, seven wins and they will be up: it is as simple as that.

At least it would be if their opponents in every match were stricken Swindon. They look doomed to relegation and the motivation tank is running dry. Though they kept pace with City for a while, once Mark Kennedy had scored the visitors' second, any confidence drained away.

Indeed, as quickly as City's stock is rising - they are in the black for the first time in years - so Swindon's is plummeting. Still in administration, the club almost lost their second chairman of the season last week when Cliff Puffett con sidered his position after being abused by fans over plans to increase ticket prices.

Puffett believes Swindon need to raise £1.5m in gate receipts next season to get "up and running". In the Second Division, though, there are few clubs like Manchester City. The presence of 6,000 away supporters at the County Ground ensured a season's best attendance of 12,397 and Puffett was no doubt singing "can we play you every week" in his bath on Saturday night.

It is a futile hope. While a deal to save the club is reportedly close, no amount of money will help Swindon recover the 11 points they are away from safety.

City's first-half performance will hardly have sent shivers through the Premiership. The one highlight came on 43 minutes when Paul Dickov picked out Shaun Goater, who headed home his 27th goal of the season. The win was sealed when Kennedy emphatically finished a slick move involving Dickov and Jeff Whitley. Charlie Griffin hit a post for Swindon but otherwise it was a case of City failing to bolster their goal difference. In the finishing straight this could prove crucial.

webTitle: Cities lose out in poverty league table

fields.headline: Cities lose out in poverty league table
fields.standfirst: Rural areas set to gain more funding as new index changes priorities
fields.trailText: Many deprived communities stand to lose hundreds of millions of pounds of government funding under a new nationwide poverty league table which classes some of the poorest inner-city areas as better off than rural districts.
fields.body:
Many deprived communities stand to lose hundreds of millions of pounds of government funding under a new nationwide poverty league table which classes some of the poorest inner-city areas as better off than rural districts.

A leaked document from the Department of Environment has revealed dramatic shifts in the rankings of England's 354 local authorities under the index of local deprivation.

The rankings have prompted complaints to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, whose department commissioned the review of the index, because it is used to target regeneration funds at the poorest areas.

Some local authorities accused the government of manipulating the statistics to shift funding away from London and other major cities to other parts of England.

The rankings have been released to all local authorities, but are not due to be made public until June.

The biggest losers include Leeds, which moves from 56 to 146, and Sheffield, which falls from 25 to 90. The biggest beneficiary is Easington, once a thriving Durham mining community which moves up from 52 to four.

Many London boroughs have also seen a dramatic shift. Under the old index compiled in 1998, 13 London boroughs were ranked among the top 20 most deprived areas in the country, with 19 among the crucial top 65.

Under the new rankings, only six London boroughs are in the top 20 and only 13 rank among the top 65, which together receive 80% of all single regeneration budget funding which was worth a total of £16bn over the past four years.

A high ranking on the index is also a factor in the bidding process for the new deal for communities, worth £800m since 1998 and hundreds of millions in lottery and EU grants.

The seven London boroughs that drop out of the top 20 are Brent, Camden, Haringey, Lewisham, Barking and Dagenham, Hammersmith and Fulham, and Greenwich. Brent has moved from 20 to 55 despite having some of Eng land's most deprived wards. Ealing, where many residents speak English as a second language, moves from 36 to 102 while Wandsworth falls from 30 to 138.

Five inner London boroughs - Hackney, Islington, Newham, Southwark and Tower Hamlets - remain in the top 10.

Local authorities benefiting from the new rankings include many shire districts and forming mining communities. Among them are Sedgefield, Durham, (up 68 places), Hull (up 13), Hartlepool (up 27) and Blackburn (up 16), the constituencies of, respectively, the prime minister Tony Blair, Mr Prescott, Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson, and home secretary Jack Straw.

The new index was compiled by academics at Oxford University using six indicators - income, work, health, education, housing and geographical access to services and transport - rather than the 12 used in the previous index. London authorities and metropolitan councils argue that the new index fails to recognise that cities have a mixed pattern of affluent areas and small pockets of severe deprivation.

The new index also underplays factors such as crime and ethnic minorities among whom English is often second language, while giving undue weight to factors such as access to public transport.

Gareth Daniels, chief executive of Brent, north London, said: "This is the result of strong lobbying by non-London authorities and hundreds of millions of pounds are at stake for this borough alone."

"We don't want to get into this perverse beauty contest but the realities of social exclusion and economic deprivation are apparent for all to see in large parts of greater London and it would be unfair for resources to be skewed to rural areas."

David Smith, principal research officer at Sheffield city council, said the index failed to acknowledge the scale and the depth of the problems of deprivation in large metropolitan authorities, where populations can be more than five times the size of those in shire districts.

But local authorities which benefited welcomed the rankings. Richard Robson, head of inward investment at Easington district council, said: "We have always felt the previous method was biased towards the urban conurbations. Areas like this suffer enormous economic and social deprivation."

Roger Sykes, of the Local Government Association, said: "One of the major criticisms about the index before this review was that it didn't recognise deprivation in rural areas."

A spokesman for Mr Prescott's department said: "There is a new index in preparation and it does have new methodology. We have taken delivery of the draft and are considering it in the light of comments received."

webTitle: Self-help schools thrive on a passion for learning

fields.headline: Self-help schools thrive on a passion for learning
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone Parents and teachers find a way to build on the ruins
fields.trailText: The five classrooms of the Sierra Leone Muslim Brotherhood primary school are packed solid with noisy, exuberant children. Armed with a Dickensian stick, the teachers manage to keep 120 or 140 of them sitting down on the stools or stones which they bring each morning to their dark, dusty schoolrooms.
fields.body:
The five classrooms of the Sierra Leone Muslim Brotherhood primary school are packed solid with noisy, exuberant children. Armed with a Dickensian stick, the teachers manage to keep 120 or 140 of them sitting down on the stools or stones which they bring each morning to their dark, dusty schoolrooms.

Chalk and a blackboard are the only teaching equipment most of the staff have. Some lack even that, so they scratch lessons on the wall.

Kindergarten children sing, older children repeat aloud the teacher's lessons in English and Arabic.

Across town, Our Lady of Fatima primary school has nearly 1,000 children, and new ones arrive every day, including many from six other schools. Here too, pupils are crammed into classrooms empty except for the benches or stools brought each day.

At midday, lined up in neat rows for assembly in the courtyard and enthusiastically singing Christian hymns, they could be taken for children from any school on any continent. But that these schools are operating at all is a miracle made by a group of teachers and parents.

The town of Makeni, in central Sierra Leone, has been behind rebel lines since being taken by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) in December 1998. There is no town administration, no police, no electricity, no functioning water or sanitation. Every piece of school furniture and equipment has been looted; even doors and windows have been damaged or taken for firewood. Roofs and walls have many bullet holes.

When the RUF moved in, many teachers fled to Freetown, the capital down on the coast. Others went there to try to collect salaries months overdue. Few have returned.

The schools were closed for six months, many families left, and Makeni drifted in the limbo of non-government that has been the fate of most of Sierra Leone during the eight years of the RUF's violent struggle to take power.

Even now, with a tense ceasefire holding, UN troops garrisoned outside the town, and the RUF and other armed factions sharing power in Freetown with the official government of President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, there is a power vacuum in towns like Makeni.

The Committee of Concerned Teachers and Parents formed itself to end that void, at least in education. They would teach again, no matter how big the classes had to be, so that no child would be turned away. None of them has been paid for many months; some are retired teachers who have volunteered, some are students.

Most look exhausted and extremely thin, an occasional one privately shows that they are on the verge of despair, but everyone has too much dignity to complain.

Their coordinator is George Coker, once a teacher of business studies, an orderly man who keeps records of every school reopened, every teacher and his or her qualifications, every child who returns to school, exactly as if he were working in a normal setting.

He runs the committee from a room with two battered chairs and tables. He has no transport to get across town, no funds, no pool of teachers to relieve the pressure on those facing more than 100 children every day. But he is a man still able to dream of a future for himself very different from the Makeni of today. He likes to talk of a time when he will do computer and keyboard training.

He is not the only one keeping his dreams alive. On one blackboard in Our Lady of Fatima school complicated long division and multiplication sums are written up impeccably by the dozen or more children in the top class, the ones the teachers intend should sit the country's examination for secondary school.

Those who pass will go to St Joseph's, a once-beautiful school with courtyards set un der great flowering trees on the outskirts of town.

One courtyard is now destroyed, looted and burned. In every classroom round the second square, children sit on window-sills or whatever they have brought from home, and work from books bought in the market and shared or used for the teacher to read to them.

Among them are many teenagers who were with the RUF, abducted at various times but now bent on making up the time they have lost to a life of mindless brutality.

Many of these children have come back to Makeni and found their families gone: dead, or fled to Freetown, they usually don't know. The teachers watch them with concern, wondering how they manage to live and with whom, but stand back from them: children who have lived lives no one wants to think about.

The literature class is studying from one battered copy of Things Fall Apart, the great novel by Chinua Achebe about traditional life and the encroachment of colonialism in Nigeria earlier this century. "They like it very much," says the teacher, without irony. He has chosen it for its literary qualities, not for its political message.

Like the teachers of Makeni, the peasants of Koya town, a settlement on a rocky hillside outside Freetown, have taken extraordinary steps to give their children an education. They have created a non-formal school which is a model for other deprived communities where the children are needed for daily work and where there is little or no family income.

Bangladesh's experience of non-formal education provided the pattern; teaching materials and expert advice have been given by a local group, the People's Education Association of Sierra Leone, and the UN agency Unicef.

About 4,000 people displaced by the war have settled in Koya over the years, arriving with nothing. The little houses are built over a wide area of steep hill dotted with huge black boulders. The near est formal school is three miles down the hill, small and already too crowded; the health centre is four miles away; the only water is from a stream up in the hills, a good trek away.

Few people in the community are literate. The women say that almost none of them went to school at all when they were children.

But the war, and being forced to move, changed their ideas and fired a passion for education, including for their girls. "The war was senseless and made everyone poorer, but maybe one good thing has come out of it: everyone wants their girls to learn to read," one of the village elders says in the unmistakable clipped English of the colonial days.

A parents' committee built a school with stones, and wattle cut from the hillside. They dug a latrine and flattened a football pitch. To generate a small income to pay school fees to support the teachers, the men break stones and carry them down to the main road to sell; the women have made little gardens of okra, spinach and peppers which they too sell.

One woman, Elizabeth, made soap, until in January last year the rebels entered Freetown and she, like many of the other women in Koya, saw her world collapse a second time. The RUF burned her house, soap-making tools and possessions, and killed her husband.

Packed tight into the six classrooms, separated only by open wattle partitions, are 220 children. They do a three-year course; mornings only, so they can work with their families the rest of the day. The goal is that by the fourth year they will be ready to join the formal school system.

The sound of class 1's Arabic teacher mingles with class 2's arithmetic and class 3's health education. The six teachers, one a woman, have 10 years' schooling themselves or, in the case of Ahmed, the lead teacher, 12 years.

Later this year 16 of their pupils will take the exam for secondary school (though the nearest one is five miles away). The village is prepared to build its own secondary school if necessary.

The fever for education is everywhere. "Since the war rural people came here to Freetown and saw another life," says Abraham John, the manager of an adult literacy class in a camp for displaced people on the outskirts of the capital.

Across the dusty courtyard of the camp, an old clay factory, Lucy Korwah is teaching a class of 110 displaced children with slates and chalk.

She is displaced herself. As she fled through the bush in 1991 she lost two of her children and became separated from her husband. She also lost her sister, and is bringing up three of the sister's children with her own remaining four.

There are no intact families here. A third of the children have lost their parents, and among the traumatised children in class there are former RUF child soldiers.

Nevertheless, the headteacher, Mariana Kemoh, says with quiet pride that in this primary school for the displaced all those in the top class who sat the national primary school examination passed.

webTitle: Blair declines to lead fight for schools

fields.headline: Blair declines to lead fight for schools
fields.standfirst: Read the world. The right to education
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday dashed the hopes of charities pressing him to take the lead in the campaign to achieve universal basic education in the developing world.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday dashed the hopes of charities pressing him to take the lead in the campaign to achieve universal basic education in the developing world.

Groups such as Oxfam, ActionAid and Save the Children Fund have been pushing for the prime minister to pro vide momentum in much the same way that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has over debt relief for the developing world.

But a Downing Street source disclosed yesterday that Mr Blair will not attend the world education forum in Dakar, Senegal, at the end of the month - the first such meeting since targets were set for the achievement of universal basic education 10 years ago.

The decision came as the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, today calls on all governments to work for universal education. Mr Annan, in a speech billed as the most important of his tenure, will press governments to pursue primary education for all by 2015. This is one of the UN's major goals for the 21st century.

Oxfam will today step up pressure on the prime minister by putting life-size portraits of him in its 800 shops and asking customers to sign them. The portraits will then be taken en masse to Downing Street before the Dakar forum.

The international development secretary Clare Short, who has been campaigning for universal primary education since taking office three years ago, is known to share fears that the forum could end up as just another talking shop, with no firm programme or financial backing being agreed.

A spokesman for her department said: "She is anxious that we get some momentum behind these targets. We must ensure that Dakar does not fail."

At present, about 130m children do not receive a primary school education, more than half of them in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Nigeria. The cost of educating them is estimated at £4.5bn a year over 10 years.

Ideally, the charities would want Mr Blair to go to the G8 summit in Japan in July to persuade the leading industrial nations to provide the necessary funds. But Downing Street countered that this was an unrealistic ambition, given that Japan, as the host country, will control the agenda. A key element in getting Mr Blair's support would have been his attendance at Dakar.

In addition to Oxfam's cut-out Blairs, a poster will also be unveiled in London by the three charities today saying that "education isn't working" and showing a line of people from the developing world.

It is based on the famous Tory poster used in the 1979 general election campaign, "Labour isn't working".

David Archer, the director of ActionAid, said: "We want 'education, education, education' to become a worldwide rallying cry. We call on Tony Blair to take a global leadership role to mobilise the political will and financial resources to get all children a decent education."

webTitle: Re-arming with the tools of peace

fields.headline: Re-arming with the tools of peace
fields.standfirst: The UN's call in Dakar this month for Education for All is the key to ending the poverty and wars bleeding Africa, the poorest continent. Now the promises must be turned into action
fields.trailText: Kofi Annan sounded like a latter-day Oliver Twist when he turned up in London last month saying that Africa needed more. More assistance. More technology. More investment. More access to world markets. More cooperation and partnership. But in some ways the UN secretary general's speech owed less to Charles Dickens than to Bill Clinton or to Tony Blair. The message was that change was happening and that Africa needed a hand-up, not a hand-out.
fields.body:
Kofi Annan sounded like a latter-day Oliver Twist when he turned up in London last month saying that Africa needed more. More assistance. More technology. More investment. More access to world markets. More cooperation and partnership. But in some ways the UN secretary general's speech owed less to Charles Dickens than to Bill Clinton or to Tony Blair. The message was that change was happening and that Africa needed a hand-up, not a hand-out.

"There is a sense that this is a moment when outside assistance has a real chance of bearing fruit," he said.

Mr Annan is right. There is a hard-headed business rationale, as well as a moral imperative, for supporting development in Africa. The continent is a great untapped market, containing 10% of the world's population but accounting for only around 1% of global GDP. Investment in Africa brings a higher return to American and Japanese companies than that in any other region of the world.

The fact remains that investing in Africa still looks like a high risk, because the continent is awash with poverty and riven by civil conflict. Recognition that the two are linked by a lack of decent education is the key to moving the continent forward.

Take the following fact. Half the women and a third of the men in sub-Saharan Africa are illiterate, and the numbers are growing. To a large extent it is because so little has been spent on schools that so much has been spent on guns.

The solution, according to Oxfam, is a Compact for Africa, under which $3.6bn (£2.3bn) a year would be mobilised by national governments and the international community in return for a pledge to cut military spending.

The proposal, floated in advance of the Education for All conference in Dakar this month, is supported by the World Bank, several UN agencies and the Nordic governments. "In the absence of a concerted national and international effort to resolve the crisis in education, the human foundations for Africa's recovery in the 21st century will not exist," Oxfam says.

Without such an effort, today's lost generation of children in west and central Africa will see a repeat of the civil wars which stole their youth, and may visit the same fate upon their own children.

The illiteracy rate in Sierra Leone and Liberia is 80%. The two rank with Angola at the very bottom of the UN's human de velopment index, with low life expectancy, high malnutrition and maternal mortality, and little access to safe drinking water or sanitation.

Both are emerging from almost 10 years of civil war which devastated their societies, sent hundreds of thousands into exile, broke up families, displaced more than half the populations within the countries, and ended with a tense and precarious peace.

None of this was preordained. These wars were not inevitable, but they were preventable. They were wars of underdevelopment, not primarily of resources - as is often written with reference to Sierra Leone's diamonds - nor of ideology, like the war in Angola with its roots in the cold war.

And they can not be ignored, since in an era of globalisation the regional instabil ity triggered by low-level wars poses threats of refugee flows, ecological degradation, vast costs to the UN for peacekeeping and shadow administrations, such as the one now in Sierra Leone.

Enlightened self-interest is not the only reason the west has a responsibility to these countries. There is also a moral dimension. These civil wars exploded out of intolerable inequity. Both countries were western creations, born at the end of the slave trade and set up with a heavy input of Christian missionary attitudes. They also had a heavy dependency - on the US in the case of Liberia, Britain in the case of Sierra Leone - which went even deeper than most colonial relations.

The political class in both places was an open scandal. Liberia's Firestone rubber plantations and Sierra Leone's diamonds benefited a tiny elite which showed none of the nationalist aspirations for development which marked the leadership of most of post-colonial Africa.

The west tolerated the corruption, mismanagement and appalling poverty which lay behind the men they did business with. There was a collective failure of imagination abroad, as well as internally, about the possible consequences of such under-development.

The Nobel economics laureate Amartya Sen's research on food and famine in Asia proved the link between lack of democracy and famine (so visible in the great Ethiopian famine of the mid 80s), and the converse: famine does not happen in democracies.

In west Africa the link between the revolts against the ruling elites in Liberia and Sierra Leone and the lack of education appears equally clear. Only a society with 80% illiteracy could have produced the particular horrors of these wars, with their massive use of child soldiers and the use of drugs and violent American videos to brainwash the children and their adult leaders into illusions of their own invincibility.

But to listen to children in school in Monrovia is to see the possibility of a different future. In one class for accelerated learning - which covers a six-year primary course in three years - sit boys of 17 and girls of eight to 12, determined to learn to read and write.

Many are no longer in touch with their families, and all tell stories of the devastation of their lives by the civil war. But with the war and the disruption of village life has come urban life and the images of the wider world. It has touched them with a fever for education.

They have the same dreams as children everywhere: one girl wants to be a doctor, another a nurse, a boy wants to be a teacher, another wants "to help people", and one wants to be prime minister. The headteacher is matter-of-fact about these aspirations. "Of course they can be realistic; one of my best friends is a woman doctor who first went to school at 12."

The keys to transforming education are political will and the motivation and training of teachers. Africa has seen it work. Tanzania under Julius Nyerere achieved 90% primary education in the 20 years after independence (though IMF programmes after 1985 brought a 30% decline in school enrolment). Uganda under Yoweri Museveni brought its education system back from the abyss of the Amin years which left schools looking much like Sierra Leone's do today.

The next generations in Liberia and Sierra Leone have the potential to transcend the betrayal by the adults who have left them so dispossessed, but to realise that potential they will need massive help from outside.

As Nyerere once wrote: "Education is not a way of escaping the country's poverty. It is a way of fighting it."

webTitle: Zimbabwe 'not a British colony', says Mugabe

fields.headline: Zimbabwe 'not a British colony', says Mugabe
fields.standfirst: African leader's fury over Cook's criticism
fields.trailText: The rift between Britain and Zimbabwe deepened today as President Robert Mugabe accused London of treating his country like a colony at the opening of an EU-Africa summit in Cairo.
fields.body:
The rift between Britain and Zimbabwe deepened today as President Robert Mugabe accused London of treating his country like a colony at the opening of an EU-Africa summit in Cairo.

"We are not a British colony any longer," President Mugabe said, responding to British criticism of political violence during a weekend peace march in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare. The march, organised by the country's biggest opposition alliance, turned violent when black war veterans attacked demonstrators who were protesting against the government-sponsored takeover of more than 700 white-owned farms

"Britain has no right, no right at all, to try and suggest to the rest of the world that we are a failure," he said, adding that Britain was "trying to teach us how to run our country."

Britain was planning to raise the issue of violence at the Monday-Tuesday summit, but Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, indicated that he might be willing to put it off until after the summit.

"They need help, we want to help but it is very difficult for us to help when President Mugabe insists on treating Britain as an opponent not as a partner," Mr Cook said.

Mr Mugabe's testy remarks followed blunt statements by Mr Cook yesterday, in which he criticised Zimbabwe's police for failing to protect the demonstrators and called on Mr Mugabe to honour a promise to set a date for a general election.

Fifteen people were injured on Saturday, when a 150-strong group, allegedly linked to Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF, forcefully broke up a march of 4,000 peaceful demonstrators in Harare. The row between Britain and Zimbabwe coincides with a high-level meeting to deal with Africa's total debt of $350bn, which has left many countries spending more on their repayments than on health and education combined.

"The African debt crisis has aggravated into unprecedented dimensions while existing mechanisms proved to be either extremely slack or short of easing its burden," said President Hosni Mubarak, of Egypt, who opened the conference.

As the two-day meeting attended by 67 nations opened, German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder promised "in a special sign of solidarity" to forgive some $350m in debt owed by Africa's poorest nations. Mr Schroeder said he would ask the German parliament "to release the debts of these countries completely. I am confident that the other creditor countries will follow our example, too."

Despite Germany's initiative, the debt issue will mostly be dealt with by other international institutions, EU officials said. Although the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have announced initiatives to write off debt for the world's poorest nations, progress has been slow under the heavily indebted poor country initiative (HPIC).

"We are not a British colony any longer," President Mugabe said, responding to British criticism of political violence during a weekend peace march in the Zimbabwean capital, Harare. The march, organised by the country's biggest opposition alliance, turned violent when black war veterans attacked demonstrators who were protesting against the government-sponsored takeover of more than 700 white-owned farms "Britain has no right, no right at all, to try and suggest to the rest of the world that we are a failure," he said, adding that Britain was "trying to teach us how to run our country." fields.headline: Rudolf Kirschläger
fields.standfirst: Diplomat who nursed Austria past the postwar era
fields.trailText: A sometime president and foreign minister of Austria, Rudolf Kirschläger, who has died of heart complications aged 85, was a member of the Austrian delegation that negotiated the re-establishment of his country's sovereignty in the mid-1950s, a development that was followed by the ending of the post-war allied occupation. fields.body:
A sometime president and foreign minister of Austria, Rudolf Kirschläger, who has died of heart complications aged 85, was a member of the Austrian delegation that negotiated the re-establishment of his country's sovereignty in the mid-1950s, a development that was followed by the ending of the post-war allied occupation. He was also a significant architect in the drafting of the constitutional law on Austria's permanent neutrality, a role that earned him great respect. He served two terms as his country's president, between 1974 and 1986.

After his role in drafting the constitutional law, his ascent in the ranks of the foreign service was swift. From 1956 to 1962, he was head of the foreign ministry's department of international law. The following year, the socialist foreign minister, Bruno Kreisky, appointed him cabinet chief. From 1967 to 1970, he was Austria's ambassador to Czechoslovakia, and thus experienced the dramatic events of the Prague spring and the Soviet-led invasion of August 1968.

Kirschläger ordered that the doors of his embassy be left open to those escaping the Soviets. He personally ensured that visas were issued to thousands of Czechoslovaks wishing to emigrate, throwing forms out of the embassy window to those waiting below.

On his return to Austria, he was appointed foreign affairs minister in the socialist government of the new chancellor, Bruno Kreisky, although Kirschläger remained non-partisan. After the death of the state president, Franz Jonas, in April 1974, he was nominated as the presidential candidate of the Socialist party.

Kreisky had been a key supporter of Kirschläger, despite strong opposition towards his candidacy from within senior party ranks. Two months later, after winning 51.7% per cent of the vote, he became Austria's first non-socialist - and first non-party - president since the second world war. He gained instant respect from all political quarters for his lack of party favouritism, but stood in the shadow of the domineering figure of Kreisky, who remained chancellor until 1983. At the end of his first term in 1980, Kirschläger was re-elected, this time with more than 80% of the vote.

Kirschläger was born to working-class parents in the Upper Austrian village of Obermühl. His father worked in a paper mill and was a talented organist, but both his parents died when he was still a child. His early life was characterised by poverty and, to augment a state grant, he financed his law studies at Vienna University by taking a string of manual jobs, including as a window cleaner, coal carrier and snow shoveller.

He was forced to break off his studies in 1938 following the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany, when his grant was stopped because of his reluctance to join the Nazi party.

He briefly worked as a bank clerk before being called-up. He finally completed his law studies during a long period of sick leave after being seri ously wounded, obtained his doctorate in 1940 and, in the same year, married his wife, Herma. After the war, he practiced law and joined the conservative People's party (ÖVP), only to renounce his membership in 1947. Henceforth, he remained politically independent.

Kirschläger became a senior judge in Vienna, sitting until 1954, when his diplomatic career began in the federal chancellery's foreign affairs department. Then came his post as chief of the diplomatic service's international law division.

Legally barred from standing for a third presidential term in 1986, he was succeeded by Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations secretary-general, whose election led to Austria's international isolation after Waldheim's wartime past as a high-ranking Wehrmacht officer was revealed. After studying all the allegedly incriminating documents, Kirschläger supported his successor and ruled against prosecuting him.

Kirschläger was responsible for swearing-in a government which included the far-right Freedom party (FPO) in 1983, and he recently said he considered it was correct to allow the democratically-elected FPO into the present government. But he remained deeply troubled by Austria's recent international estrangement.

In a final interview, he said: "I find it sad that we have so few friends in the world, or in Europe, to protect us from being cast simply as a Nazi state full of Nazi people." He often expressed his public regrets that the world paid little heed to the role of Austrians who had resisted Hitler - and lost their lives for it.

A lifelong Catholic, Kirschläger requested a private funeral, rather than the customary state burial. He is survived by his wife, a son and a daughter.

fields.headline: John Hosier
fields.standfirst: An apostle for music, he fired young people with enthusiasm for his art
fields.trailText: John Hosier, who has died aged 71, had a profound, bridge-building influence on music education in schools, music colleges and universities. Recognising the importance of professional musicians in the education of the young, he developed many opportunities for collaboration, and, as a tireless supporter of aspiring young professionals, his wise counsel and practical advice opened pathways to many successful careers.
fields.body:
John Hosier, who has died aged 71, had a profound, bridge-building influence on music education in schools, music colleges and universities. Recognising the importance of professional musicians in the education of the young, he developed many opportunities for collaboration, and, as a tireless supporter of aspiring young professionals, his wise counsel and practical advice opened pathways to many successful careers.

Born in Kingsbury, London, he was educated at Preston Manor school, Wembley. At St John's College, Cambridge, where in 1950-51 he was musical director of the Footlights, he switched from English to music, to study with Patrick Hadley and Robin Orr. After a short period of teaching for the British Council in Turkey, in 1953 he joined the BBC; for many years he was senior music producer for educational programmes, first in radio and, from 1960, in television, where he pioneered schools music programmes.

These skilfully adapted the practices of continental teachers, such as Carl Orff and Zoltan Kodaly, to suit the British school system, incorporating new approaches to music lessons and giving children opportunities to develop their own creative ideas. With guidance notes, the programmes supported non-specialist teachers in primary schools, who often lacked the confidence to conduct music lessons.

For his programmes, Hosier commissioned new works from leading young composers, including Malcolm Arnold, Gordon Crosse and Richard Rodney Bennett. Mini-musicals, they provided a whole term's work made up of songs and speech, accompanied on simple percussion instruments. End-of-term concerts and festivals up and down the country included performances of the repertoire in the BBC schools music programmes current at the time.

Hosier appreciated the gulf between the music used for lessons in secondary schools and that experienced by young people out of school, and made a series of programmes about music-making in the pop idiom, to which he applied his usual high standards of judgment.

In 1973, he became senior music inspector for the Inner London Education Authority, where he set about establishing firm organisational structures for the innovative work of his predecessor, Peter Fletcher. Hosier saw clearly the commitment of the young players in the London Schools Symphony Orchestra (LSSO), of which he was director, and invited professional conductors to produce challenging programmes at the Royal Festival Hall, the City of London Guildhall, and in numerous concert halls across Europe and America. He invited the winner of the John Player conducting competition, the young Simon Rattle, to conduct the LSSO in its 1976 US bicentennial concerts across America, from the Hollywood Bowl to Carnegie Hall.

Hosier also used the extensive facilities of Ilea's Ebury Bridge music centre to promote training courses for teachers, and develop links with professional musicians through concert-going schemes. Every year, he devised and presented concerts for Ilea schoolchildren by the London Philharmonic Orchestra.

In Tower Hamlets, until then an area deprived of quality instrumental teaching, Hosier started a string teaching project. Led by Sheila Nelson, it used some of the methods of group tuition promoted by the American, Paul Roland. Whole classes of primary pupils travelled to many parts of Europe to demonstrate the method and their achievements.

The annual Ilea carol festival brought thousands of pupils to the Royal Festival Hall. In planning them, Hosier drew on his BBC experience, commissioning new songs and incorporating the music of different genres alongside traditional carols.

As director of the Centre for Young Musicians, he brought together the most talented young Ilea musicians every Saturday at Pimlico comprehensive school. His inspirational leadership attracted some of the capital's leading musicians to teach at the centre, and his guidance to students ensured that many went on to study at music college.

From 1978-89, Hosier was principal of the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, London, during which time the institution attained international recognition as an innovative conservatoire. Britain's first full-time opera and jazz courses were introduced, and Peter Renshaw was appointed to direct a radical and challenging performance and communication skills course to address the role of future professional musicians. This has influenced developments in many other European conservatoires, and within professional orchestras and opera companies.

In 1989, Hosier became director of the recently-founded Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts, training musicians, dancers, actors and those in theatre, film and television arts for professional careers. After establishing this as a degree-awarding institution and major centre for the arts in south-east Asia, he retired in 1993.

Throughout his adult life, Hosier took an active part in public committee work, representing the interests of music education and judging competitions. He was appointed CBE in 1984. He composed and arranged music for the theatre, and for many radio and television programmes. His publications included Instruments Of The Orchestra, in collaboration with Yehudi Menuhin, books about music for young readers and about composition for young performers.

He is survived by his wife, the former television producer Biddy Baxter.

 John Hosier, musician and music educator, born November 18 1928; died March 28 2000

fields.headline: Greville Poke
fields.standfirst: Quiet power behind the Royal Court's defeat of theatre censorship
fields.trailText: G reville Poke, who has died aged 87, was a key figure at the Royal Court Theatre, London, when it moved from long-running, intermittent revues to provocative new plays, like Look Back In Anger, in 1956. As founding secretary, and later chairman, of the English Stage Company, he served under a succession of distinguished artistic directors and saw the ESC through many a battle in its largely unpopular, though influential campaign, to discover stimulating new works.
fields.body:
G reville Poke, who has died aged 87, was a key figure at the Royal Court Theatre, London, when it moved from long-running, intermittent revues to provocative new plays, like Look Back In Anger, in 1956. As founding secretary, and later chairman, of the English Stage Company, he served under a succession of distinguished artistic directors and saw the ESC through many a battle in its largely unpopular, though influential campaign, to discover stimulating new works.

In its defiance of official stage censorship, its war with the drama critics, its much-vaunted belief in the right to fail, and its ultimate dependence on Arts Council subsidies, the ESC led a stormy existence, which Poke weathered with good grace and even temper. Diplomatic by nature, he was devoted to discovering good drama - especially the plays of Edward Bond, author of Saved (1965) and Early Morning (1968), both banned and both acted at the Royal Court.

Poke was one of the few board members without an axe to grind. He was an addictive playgoer, whose taste was never ruled by a nostalgie de la boue . Dismissed by one fiery artistic director as "a timid and respectable ferret", he never supposed that he would one day appear on the ESC's behalf in the dock at Marlborough magistrates court.

It happened when the lord chamberlain, who in those days was still licensing the public presentation of new plays, suspected that the Royal Court was practising a ruse by turning itself into a club to perform Saved, one theme of which depicted youths stoning a baby to death. When plain-clothed policemen sneaked into a performance - without being asked for evidence of club membership - Poke as secretary, William Gaskill as director, and Alfred Esdaile as lessee, were summonsed. They were eventually conditionally discharged, and the ESC was fined £50.

Later, Poke suggested that the second performance of Early Morning should be designated a critics' dress rehearsal - for which no one paid admission. The performance was exempt from prosecution because no one had paid, and within a few months the lord chamberlain's function as stage censor was abolished.

On the question of critics, the Royal Court's attitude was to divide them. Some at the theatre thought only of the damage hostile criticism brought to the box office; Poke stood alone against attempts to suppress certain critics. If the theatre followed a policy of selected admission of the press, he reasoned, other critics would retaliate with a boycott or with indignant articles - and so it proved.

Moreover, the Arts Council - as Poke foresaw - pondered withdrawal of its subsidy because it believed that the public had a right to know what was happening to its money. Tempers flared but Poke stood firm; his advice went unheeded.

When one of the artistic directors decided to write to the critics without telling Poke what he was up to, he turned angry. The fuss nearly reached the floor of the House of Commons. A question had been arranged; and Poke feared it might mean the end of public funding. That was why, in 1970, he declined the chairmanship of the ESC, although two years later he did take up the post, when Oscar Lewenstein left the board to become artistic director.

The son of a Fleet Street magazine owner, Poke was born in London and educated at Harrow school and Cambridge University. After a long stint in the family's newspaper distribution business, he became editor of the weekly magazine, Everybody's, taking its circulation close to a million with a 1953 coronation issue.

After resigning from the weekly, he worked as a part-time publicist for the Taw and Torridge festival. It was run by Lord Harewood, Edward Blacksell, Lewenstein and the poet-playwright Ronald Duncan, and, when the four proposed a theatrical society to tour plays to festivals (with an occasional London visit), Poke joined them as secretary. Looking for funds with Duncan, the two men met the textile industrialist Neville Blond, whose father-in-law had founded Marks & Spencer. "Find me a theatre which I can buy," said Blond, "and I'll be your chairman." At a later ESC meeting, Blond passed Poke a note. "Alfred Esdaile says, would we like the Royal Court?" "Not 'arf!" Poke replied.

Poke retired as ESC chairman in 1978, but continued on the council into the 1990s and died as president of the company. His enthusiasm for the stage never waned. Nor did his readiness to work for organisations like the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts and the Thorndyke Theatre, Leatherhead, of both of which he became chairman, or the Royal Theatrical Fund, the Actors' Centre and the Richard Haines Trust, which supports drama students.

In 1947 Poke married the actress Patricia Lawrence, who died in 1993. They had two sons.

 Greville John Poke, arts administrator, born August 19 1912; died March 4 2000

webTitle: Gospels of hate that slip through the net

fields.headline: Gospels of hate that slip through the net
fields.standfirst:
John Sutherland: On the rise of a racist

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: William L Pierce is coming up in the world. The Los Angeles Times last week labelled him "the most powerful and dangerous white supremacist in America". It's not a league table one would like to head. But, as they say in America, nice guys finish last. "Dr" Pierce, as his followers call him, is no nice guy and he's now top of the heap.
fields.body:
William L Pierce is coming up in the world. The Los Angeles Times last week labelled him "the most powerful and dangerous white supremacist in America". It's not a league table one would like to head. But, as they say in America, nice guys finish last. "Dr" Pierce, as his followers call him, is no nice guy and he's now top of the heap.

Pierce is probably unique among neo-Nazism's current crop of petty Führers in having a PhD in physics. He could have been the extreme right's only rocket scientist. But, as he nobly records on his website, he abandoned the cutting edge of science "to devote himself to the service of his people".

Pierce is also unusual among neo-Nazis (and some scientists) in being able to string two words together grammatically. As "Andrew MacDonald" he has to his credit a bestselling underground novel, The Turner Diaries. This "bible of the racist right", as the Federal Bureau of Investigation calls it, chronicles an organisation which dedicates itself to the destruction of the two "Jew capitals of the world", Tel Aviv and New York.

The Turner Diaries has sold getting on for 500,000 copies since publication in 1978 - mainly by mail order from Pierce's National Alliance headquarters in West Virginia. The novel has directly inspired hate crimes, notoriously Timothy McVeigh's bombing of the Murrah Building (seven pages of Pierce's novel were found Xeroxed and highlighted in the getaway car).

On the strength of the novel's sales (immensely boosted by the Oklahoma atrocity) Pierce has funded a radio station, a lively website and a mail-order bookstore. But, like other neo-Nazi groups here, he has had no luck in recruiting the young street muscle which any insurgent political group needs.

His core supporters remain disaffected, middle-aged, rednecked, fat-bellied, ignorant white trash whose resistance is limited to belligerent bumper stickers and illiterate scrawls on men's room walls. Pierce's New World Order Comix, a publication aimed at "white high school students", featuring the exploits of "White Will and his friends", was a dreary failure. Even less successful was a race-rock opera, Call of the Blood. Somehow, Mein Kampf set to music always comes out sounding like Mel Brooks.

All this may change now that Pierce's National Alliance has bought Resistance Records. The label showcases groups such as Angry Aryans with "vicious hatecore" (their term), tracks such as Nigger Loving Whore and Niggers are always causing problems (clips can be heard on www.resistance.com). Other offerings are Blue Eyed Devils with Retribution, Berserker with Crush the Weak, White Wash with Unity through Aggression and Black Metal, whose CD is dedicated to the "downfall of the Jewish plague". Resistance proclaims its list as "A kick in the groin to all those who aid and abet the non-White filth in this country". It hopes to "ignite a revolution".

It's awful stuff, musically and morally. But it creates dilemmas for liberal America. They have given their imprimatur to rap music. Hip-hop now blasts out 24 hours a day on above-ground commercial radio. It plays on MTV and there are even courses on it as "oppression art" in advanced colleges. What is the difference between Pierce's "Resistance" and Ice Cube's regular declarations of war on the LA Pigs Department? There was a time when rap (as purveyed by NWA, or Da Lench Mob) was seen as minority music. Now, as Ice T wonderingly observes, you hear little white girls in Oklahoma crooning Me So Horny. What if Angry Aryans took off the same way? Currently, Resistance Music gets no legitimate air-time and no MTV plays. But that could change.

It would be an academic question in Britain but for the internet. The Turner Diaries and Resistance Records' offerings are, I believe, illegal in this country under the terms of race relations legislation. Britain has no First Amendment, such as protects Pierce's garbage. But HM Customs is, manifestly, impotent when it comes to control of international e-commerce in hate materials.

You can order Pierce's garbage (and worse) from amazon.com, and CDs from Resistance Records (net address above). They will dispatch them and, I suspect, UK authorities won't (can't) intercept their mail or Fedex delivery (what's it going to say on the customs declaration form - "racist propaganda"?).

Weak-kneed academic that I am, I don't have the bottle to try the experiment. But I'll be interested to hear from anyone who does. Let me know at j.sutherland@ucl.ac.uk.

webTitle: Early start fails to make Blackpool rock

fields.headline: Early start fails to make Blackpool rock
fields.trailText: A draw, Blackpool's fourth in five games, was not enough to ease relegation worries. Nor was it sufficient for Preston, top of the table but tomorrow at Wigan, their closest challengers. The only winners were the police and the 250 fans who, fooled by the noon kick-off, missed the match. It passed without incident off the pitch and on it.
fields.body:
A draw, Blackpool's fourth in five games, was not enough to ease relegation worries. Nor was it sufficient for Preston, top of the table but tomorrow at Wigan, their closest challengers. The only winners were the police and the 250 fans who, fooled by the noon kick-off, missed the match. It passed without incident off the pitch and on it.

Blackpool is the drunken capital of Britain, largely attributed to its popularity for stag and hen nights. A year ago, to preempt the regular occurrence of stags tied naked to a lamp post George Formby might have leant on, the police set up Operation Arrival. On Saturday they nipped derby fun in the bud, too.

"The noon start didn't give a good atmosphere," said Preston's manager David Moyes. "It was a poor game. You'd have thought it was two relegation sides playing." Steve McMahon, who went to Blackpool early in January, agreed up to a point: "You wouldn't think one was top and one was at the bottom."

"Three draws against top teams is excellent. If it was the start of the season I'd have been ecstatic. It was a good point but we need three. I wish I had been here two months earlier." In his three months he has taken Blackpool from 22nd to 23rd, which looks worse than it is: 18 points from his 16 games after 17 from 24.

"I'll settle for needing to win our last game," he said. That is at home to the bottom club Chesterfield. Before that they have a key game against Scunthorpe.

"The stadium is a bit run-down," said McMahon, "but it was nice to see it fullish." He has a vested interest. All gate money above a crowd of 3,500 goes to him for play ers. Saturday's 9,042 was worth a Conference ankle.

The "run-down" ground is something else; a study in dereliction, all rusting corrugation, flaking orange paint and plastic bags flapping on barbed wire. It does not even reflect the tacky thrills of glitter and kiss-me-quick. Moyes, who entered to boos and blew a kiss back, took Preston to Monaco to prepare. A shanty town would have been apropos. Development to a capacity of 15,254 starts this summer.

Clubs always reflect something; 40 years ago these were in the top tier. Both have hit the depths since. But Preston, with Sir Tom Finney as president, are flowering in new pride. Blackpool have an Oyston in the chair. Gulls circle like vultures.

Historically the match means more to Blackpool; Preston have nearer neighbours. They have been better by a golden mile this season but on Saturday their passing rhythms were lost in the scrap. Blackpool, through no fault of McMahon, reduced them to their level. Bricks are not made with only straw. At times their penalty area was a mass of tangerine slices, their spine a stick of rock with Third Division written into it. The fortune-tellers surely see a parting of ways.
