KenDavro were you this polite when you were interviewing punk bands, or did you have to come across a bit hard? TP: Dear KenDavro - thanks for your question. Well, I was brought up to be polite to everyone I meet, and I try to honour that - I certainly never had to pretend to be hard with punk bands, because I knew for certain that I was infinitely harder than all of them - I could afford to be polite, because if it came to a scrap, they would have been mincemeat. Especially that Sid Vicious , who only ever hit women and junkies. See, I grew up around a genuine hard man- my dad. So art school counterfeits never made me go ooh-ahh. I was polite to them - just as I am polite to everyone - unless I am given a reason to be impolite. But I don't go around trying to make enemies.You have to choose to be my enemy. Otherwise, I am full of love and good will... ollywicken what's your next book about? TP: Dear ollywicken - hello. I think the next book will be more of the same - more stories of sex, love and death. More stories of parents and children - more 3-hankie, 3-generation conflict, although the focus is going to be national identity more than masculine identity...but it's going to have Man And Boy in its shadow, and that makes me nervous - not because I fear that the next book will be less successful, but just because you don't want to disappoint anyone. I am aware that people love Man And Boy - not everyone, of course, because that would be impossible. But the people who like it seem to like it a lot. That's what a writer dreams of, naturally, but there's always the nagging fear that this could be it - the high point of your career. I certainly feel that it will be really difficult to top Man And Boy - in terms of sales, critical response, the lot. So I am writing the next book wanting it and needing it to be accepted by the people who love Man And Boy. That's not easy - there are two ways you can go.You can write something completely different - as Alex Garland did with The Tesseract after The Beach, or you can write essentially the same thing - as Richard Curtis did with Notting Hill after Four Weddings And A Funeral. Neither of those options are completely satisfactory - so I am looking for The Third Way : a book that the people who love Man And Boy will love, but something that stands in its own right. ollywicken Red sports car fantasy. Petite blonde wife. Child's injury provoking a change of attitude from the father. Love for father unspoken until his death....all well-trodden ground, surely. For me, the most interesting development was Harry's realisation that his trying to be a New Dad was just another form of selfishness - designed to make himself feel good rather than actually help his son. Yet you used this only as a plot twist. I was surprised you didn't explore this further. Why not? Why did you hurry past it? TP: Dear ollywicken, I know what you mean about Harry realising that his attitude to fatherhood is essentially selfish rather than selfless - but I didn't feel I needed to explore the issue further than I did, because I always wanted Man And Boy to carry its implications lightly. I didn't want to lecture because I felt there's no need. It's not about being a New Dad - it's about learning the difference between real love and some lesser form of love. It's about knowing - really knowing - that love is selfless. If you love someone for what's in it for you, that's not the real thing. You've got the red sports car bit right - but Gina is not petite!! Gina is a big girl, man!! Reread your Man And Boy, because if you think Gina is petite, you are missing the author's message!! I can appreciate that you think Harry's midlife crisis symptoms are cliches - red sports car, young researcher, awareness of parental mortality , etc - but that's what life is like, isn't it?? Men don't reach 30, 40 or 50 and dream of getting a Volvo estate - do they?? What I like about Harry is that he is always aware when he is doing something - lusting after an MGF, having a one night stand with someone from work - that many other lost souls have done before him. pintodesa Never mind about Sean Bean playing Harry. Who would play you in 'Tony Parsons: the movie'? TP: Hello again, Pintodesa...thanks for the question about who would play me in the TV movie of my life - have you seen Rogue Trader?? Ewan Macgegor does a really good Essex accent - he's right on the money. Okay, he's a bit uglier than me, but I think this tradition of authors always being played by actors who are infinitely better looking than they are is becoming a bit trite. Also, it would really impress my son if I could introduce him to the actor who plays the young Obi-Wan Kenobi. So it has to be Ewan Macgregor - who I wouldn't mind for Harry in the BBC adaption of Man And Boy, if Sean Bean is unavailable... Morcheeba I read something about how you now do martial arts and your hands are lethal weapons. Who would get the treatment if you could get away with it? TP: Dear Morcheeba, No my hands are not lethal weapons...I do Kung Fu but I am still a very small Grasshopper...I have a teacher, David Courtney Jones, whose hands are quite possible lethal weapons. Certainly his feet are - he kicked me across a room once, and it was almost a pleasure to be on the end of a kick like that - almost a pleasure, but not quite. I think the more you do martial arts, the more you realise your limitations - maybe it's a lot like learning a language - you soon learn that there's an entire universe beyond the plume de ma tante. So I am very humble about my fighting ability.I like to think that my mind is a lethal weapon... Meatloaf How many people have actually read this Man and Boy thing? (quick show of hands) TP: Dear Meatloaf, I don't know how mnay people have read Man And Boy - the book is selling around 11,000 paperbacks a week, but it has only been out for a little under a month. The hardback did 25,000 , which is pretty good, but of course a sold book doesn't mean one eader - I'm always surprised how many people have read Man And Boy. I guess that's when you know you have a bestseller. Certainly the book is doing good business - it is currently number two in the Bookseller list of bestsellers, with only Catherine Cookson (curse her!) above it. In the Sunday Times list yesterday, it was at number 4 behind Cookson, Lyn Andrews (another romantic novelist who sells by the bucket in supermarkets) and The Beach film tie-in - number four in the Sunday Times is down one place from last week, but with sales remaining steady. So it's exciting - having a bestseller is something that I can heartily recommend - you wake up in the middle of the night thinking, yes!! I'm on top of Jeffrey Archer!! Something only a few thousand people have ever been able to say... TP: Okay, it's 4.35 and time for me to go - thanks for your questions, and thank you for buying Man And Boy - this whole thing has been much more fun than I expected. Thank you and goodbye, Love, Tony Parsons xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

webTitle: The baron of Belize should reconsider

fields.headline: The baron of Belize should reconsider
fields.standfirst: Believe me, the Lords really isn't a club anyone would want to join
fields.trailText: So Michael Ashcroft's dearest wish has been granted and he is to become a peer of the realm as soon as he finds a removal company with a big enough pantechnicon to bring all his money back to England.
fields.body:
So Michael Ashcroft's dearest wish has been granted and he is to become a peer of the realm as soon as he finds a removal company with a big enough pantechnicon to bring all his money back to England. When I heard the news, I thought for a moment that the "Florida-based billionaire" (as he is always called) was to be ennobled as part of a Downing Street plot. Mo Mowlam will confirm that the backroom boys at Number 10 always prepare the way for assassination with surreptitious destruction of the victim's reputation. And, Ashcroft's elevation being so damaging to the reputation of the House of Lords, I briefly hoped that it was a preliminary to real reform. Then I remembered that real reform is not on the prime minister's agenda.

Lord Ashcroft will sit in the hybrid institution which - as a further example of its arrogant detachment from reality - now behaves as if it were legitimised by last year's tinkering. Allowing the hereditary peers to decide which of their number should sit in one of the Houses of a theoretically democratic parliament was just the prelude to a new constitutional absurdity. When I was a student I often denounced "self-perpetuating oligarchies" without being sure where they were to be found. Now, thanks to the system that allows lords to elect lords to the Lords, I am a member of one.

I have already caused great offence to some of my peers by admitting that I do not find their lordships' House immensely congenial. My aversion - for that is what it has become - intensified during the section 28 debate. It is hard to think of anything more ridiculous than an assembly, whose members are mostly prosperous, male and elderly, insisting on imposing their view of private morality on the whole nation. I should have said so during the debate - adding that the idea of the Anglican bishops adjudicating on these matters, at a time when the Church of England represents a tiny part of the population, adds impertinence to absurdity.

It was courtesy, not cowardice, which prevented me from expressing my criticism during the debate. But had I realised that Lord Ashcroft was soon to come among us, I think that I would have overcome my gentlemanly instinct. Their lordships' morale is not likely to be damaged by my ineffectual criticism when their collective self-confidence is boosted by the knowledge that a Florida-based billionaire, who also had the distinction of being Belize's ambassador to the United Nations, is so desperate to join them that he willingly endures years of humiliation while William Hague convinces the public honours scrutiny committee that the future Lord Ashcroft is not such a bad chap after all.

Nobody since the Titchborne Claimant has fought for a peerage with such brazen tenacity. Unfortunately, the argument about his suitability has crowded out an equally important question. Why does Michael Ashcroft want to be a lord? The same question could be asked of Conrad Black, another man of wealth and power who longs for the ermine. Has either of them, I wonder, any idea of what the House of Lords is about?

Michael Ashcroft may have endured his years of tax exile, heartened by the hope that one day he would spend long afternoons correcting minor drafting errors in bills which have already passed through the House of Commons. But I find it hard to picture him practising his speeches in support of the amendment - "Delete 'a' and insert 'an'," - a subject of recent heated controversy on the scarlet benches.

He may be flying home from Florida in order to enjoy the pleasure of occasionally irritating the prime minister. That is, I agree, a worthwhile activity. But believe me there are more pleasant ways of doing it than listening to speeches by Lady Young and Baroness Blatch and then voting for a change in legislation in the certain knowledge that, in a week or two, elected members of parliament will change it back into the form which they originally intended.

There is also the possibility that - recognising the state opening of parliament as the one opportunity which Lady Ashcroft will ever have to wear a tiara and full evening dress at 11 o'clock in the morning - he regards a peerage as the best way to get more use out of expensive gear. That is the excuse I always gave for the soi-disant radicals who dress up for the occasion in borrowed or hired robes. As you can see, I am running out of plausible explanations for Mr (or is it already Lord?) Ashcroft's passion. Indeed, there is only one left. I suspect that he simply likes the idea of being called "Lord" instead of "Mr".

What a pity that only generals who have won battles on foreign soil can take their titles from exotic lands. Lord Miami Beach would be just right for the latest recruit to the Upper House of Parliament.

webTitle: More money to speed up asylum process

fields.headline: More money to speed up asylum process
fields.trailText: The government is to spend an extra £23m on legal advice for asylum seekers to speed up the processing of claims.
fields.body:
The government is to spend an extra £23m on legal advice for asylum seekers to speed up the processing of claims.

In announcing the initiative Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, said improving legal advice to those seeking asylum was crucial in clearing up the current backlog where applicants have to wait 13 months on average to have their claims processed.

The money will be used to encourage solicitors to come forward to offer legal advice to refugees. Solicitors who win such contracts in London would see fees increase 8% and those elsewhere in the country would get an increase of 5%.

Similar increases are also planned in the other areas of law which have been earmarked as priority areas, including public law, mental health and community care, which will also receive an extra £23 million. Lord Irvine said in the past unscrupulous immigration advisers had created enormous difficulties in the processing of claims.

Lord Irvine said better legal advice would improve the process and the extra cash would be spent ensuring both high quality and an effective geographical spread of services to applicants. "We want to encourage quality firms into this area because it's what these applicants deserve and also because it's in the interests of the system," Lord Irvine said.

The announcement of the extra cash for legal advisers came on the first day of the controversial new support arrangements for asylum seekers which includes dispersing them to cities outside London and the southeast and the replacement of cash support with benefits in kind and vouchers. In an embarrassing blow to the government, Oxfam announced a boycott of the voucher system as a "penny pinching" measure.

Under the voucher scheme introduced as part of the new measures, the £10, £5, £1 and 50p vouchers will be given to asylum seekers instead of money to buy food, clothes and other items in certain shops. But if the vouchers are worth more than the cost of the goods, they will not be able to get the balance back in cash, only in vouchers.

Oxfam condemned the scheme as "penny-pinching" and said it would not accept the vouchers at its 840 charity shops unless the no-change clause was dropped. A single adult is expected to pay for all their essential living needs with vouchers worth £35 a week.

Other measures from the Immigration and Asylum Act coming into effect today include fines of £2,000 on lorry drivers for each clandestine immigrant found on their vehicles. Drivers are expected to search their vehicles thoroughly and step up security to prevent stowaways sneaking aboard.

Home secretary Jack Straw said yesterday that the vouchers had already been shown to work and he believed the package of new measures, including the dispersal throughout the country of the 30,000 applicants who arrive in Britain, will defuse public criticism of asylum seekers.

fields.headline: Ashcroft stirs Belize row
fields.standfirst:
Tory anger as treasurer vows to be voice for his former home
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: April 3 2000: Tory anger as treasurer vows to be voice for his former home
fields.body:
The embattled Conservative party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, last night insisted he would become "a voice for Belize" when he returns from tax exile to take his seat in the House of Lords, despite the controversy aroused by his business dealings in the Caribbean state.

The billionaire financier provoked angry protests when he declared his intention to take the title Baron Ashcroft of Belize, which critics took as a calculated snub to the unprecedented strings attached to his peerage by the political honours scrutiny committee (PHSC). He later abandoned that hope.

"Michael is clearly very attached to the country, he went to school there, spent a lot of time there. In many ways he feels responsible that so much negative has been said about it," explained his spokesman.

Mr Ashcroft, 54, returned to his Florida home yesterday after a one-day visit to an otherwise upbeat Tory Spring Forum in Harrogate.

With the row overshadowing the Conservative leader William Hague's significant attack on Tony Blair's "betrayal" of the "vast mainstream majority" of middle Britain, party officials in Harrogate denied they had leaned on Mr Ashcroft to back down.

Instead they took their cue from Mr Hague, who said on GMTV that Mr Ashcroft's sug gestion had been "a little joke he was having".

That version is not borne out by an interview with Mr Ashcroft in the Sunday Telegraph, nor by his staff's explanation yesterday.

The suggestion had been blown out of proportion, his spokesman said. "It was slightly-tongue-in-cheek kite-flying." But the sincerity of his attachment is not denied. "He wants to be an authentic voice on the debate on agricultural production and third world debt, to become a voice for them, an informal voice."

Senior Tories such as Sir Edward Heath have condemned the peerage as "a disgrace". Last night, Peter Bradley, the Labour MP at the heart of the row, called it further proof of Mr Hague's lack of judgment.

It was Mr Ashcroft's overwhelming influence on a previous government in Belize, including his role in drafting its offshore banking rules and as the country's UN ambassador, that triggered last year's uproar about the suitability of the "man who bought the Tory party" to be its treasurer.

It led to a libel suit against the Times for hinting at his involvement in laundering drug money. The suggestion was withdrawn when both sides backed down.

But it was only when the PHSC, which rejected Mr Hague's nomination last year, threatened to block him again last month that Mr Ashcroft - who has given the Tories £1m a year since 1997 - promised to return to live in the UK by Christmas and to resign his unorthodox UN post.

Such is the furtive briefing and counter-briefing on both sides of the Ashcroft peerage issue that yesterday's Tory denials were not universally believed. It will inflame Conservative indignation that the affair has been ruthlessly manipulated by Labour.

A Cabinet Office leaks inquiry was said to be under way last night to ascertain how negotiations between the normally discreet PHSC - consisting of a peer from each major party - and the Tory leadership could have been inaccurately leaked.

Tory officials are saying nothing. Others close to the case say the crucial leak came after Mr Blair wrote to Mr Hague saying that three of his nominees had been accepted by the PHSC, but that Mr Ashcroft had been rejected outright, which he had not.

That was why Mr Hague rang Mr Blair at the EU summit in Lisbon on March 23, the day of the leak. "Reports that I phoned to beg for a peerage for Michael Ashcroft are not true," Mr Hague said on GMTV. He acknowledged: "I phoned him at Lisbon and at many other places - he phones me at many other places. That is not an exceptional thing."

The row is a useful distraction for Mr Blair from jibes over his "Tony's cronies" policy on patronage appointments.

Yesterday, Mr Ashcroft reminded the Sunday Telegraph that he still holds dual nationality. "Belize runs through my bones," he said.

webTitle: Swift decisions are crucial to asylum question

fields.headline: Swift decisions are crucial to asylum question
fields.standfirst: Neil Gerrard, the MP for Walthamstow and chair of the all-party parliamentary group on refugees, believes the new support system for asylum seekers fails to address the most pressing problem
fields.trailText: Monday, 3.45pm: Neil Gerrard, the MP for Walthamstow and chair of the all-party parliamentary group on refugees, believes the new support system for asylum seekers fails to address the most pressing problem
fields.body:
The new support system for asylum seekers administered by the Home Office came into operation yesterday. At first, only new applicants at ports will be affected, but over the next few months, all new applicants will be brought into the scheme.

Under the system, asylum seekers will be dispersed around the country, where they will receive vouchers for food and essential living items, plus a small cash allowance. Accommodation will be provided on a no-choice basis.

The Home Office argues this is necessary to deter economic migrants. This in itself is an admission that the system is harsh. The fundamental argument against the proposals is that in setting up a system on the basis of deterrence it automatically penalises genuine applicants as well as those whose asylum claims are unjustified.

The news that stores participating in the voucher system will be able to keep any change due from purchases reveals a further cut in the value of the support package, which was already below income-support levels.

There is also the suspicion that two queues will emerge, with new claims being fast-tracked through the system, leaving existing claimants still waiting for long periods and local authorities having to provide for them for some time to come.

The key to dealing with asylum claims is to make decisions efficiently and within a reasonable timescale. That would be the best deterrent, since it would remove the possibility of an unjustifiable claim "buying" admission to the UK for a long period.

For the first time in several years, last month Home Office decisions on asylum claims outnumbered new claims, but it is far too early to say they are on the way to clearing the backlog, currently standing at over 100,000.

fields.trailText: Last week, Roy Greenslade accused the Sunday Times of seeking facts to fit preconceived stories. Mark Skipworth, an executive on the paper, argues that he is mistaking inspiration for invention
fields.body:
In his column last week, Roy Greenslade banged on about the creeping "tabloidisation" of the Sunday Times. His main evidence for this is to be found, he said, in articles by Christopher Morgan, the royal and religious affairs correspondent. Morgan's stories revealing the drug-taking habits of Prince William's friends, he suggests, show that the paper is pursuing a tabloid agenda since the public interest is marginal.

It must be obvious that exposing anyone who may be a dubious influence on the future king is clearly in the public interest. This is not a tabloid agenda; it is good journalism, as the rest of Fleet Street acknowledged when Morgan was shortlisted as specialist of the year in last month's British Press Awards.

Much more serious is Roy's contention - based on the unattributed remarks of three former employees - that the news desk "invents" stories and instructs reporters to find the "facts" to fit them. Leaving aside the axes that these former employees may have to grind, Roy's reasoning is flawed.

What he seems to have forgotten is that Sunday newspapers are about setting the agenda. Any Sunday news desk worth its salt has one objective in mind: to generate scoops. But scoops may take numerous forms and can be dug out by different means. There is the scoop of the political reporter or specialist correspondent - a confidential document or contact providing a tip; there's the investigative scoop won by sheer hard work; and there's the flash-of-inspiration scoop, largely the preserve of the news desk.

It is this kind of scoop that Roy mistakes for the product of invention. It is more about a news editor, drawing on his or her instincts and experience, suggesting to reporters that they pursue a particular line of inquiry which should reap rewards.

The notion that reporters are somehow forced to write stories against their will is clearly absurd. No Fleet Street hack and certainly no Sunday Times journalist would agree to put their byline on a story they did not believe in. Above all, the idea that facts are made to fit predetermined stories just does not hold water. The Sunday Times has never published anything that its executives or reporters have known to be wrong beforehand. Of course, mistakes are made, but these are rare, and speedily put right in the corrections column.

Roy likes to imply he presided over a "golden age" of news coverage. The truth is, the golden age is now. The Sunday Times has been at the forefront of the Rip-off Britain campaign, one of the most successful campaigns the paper has ever run. Its Kosovo coverage won the BPA team of the year award. This year alone, the paper has broken stories on Greg Dyke's £6m Granada share-holding, Geoffrey Robinson's alleged abuse of DTI grants and details of a secret MI6 document on a plot to kill Gadafy. Only last weekend it published an in-depth investigation into the commercial dealings of former EU commissioners which has made waves across Europe. Hardly the stuff of tabloid journalism.

Contrary to Roy's opinion, the Sunday Times has maintained its investigative traditions, deepened and broadened its front section coverage so that "news" no longer tails off after page one, and made the paper more relevant to people's lives. It has a sense of humour that was sorely lacking years ago. Above all, its strength lies in its consistency; we may not always have the best scoop of the week, but we will never tolerate a bad paper. How many of our rivals claim as much?

 Mark Skipworth is managing editor (news) of the Sunday Times

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: • Most bizarre rumour of the week yet again concerns the ferocious power struggle between ITV's biggest companies (yawn). Just when you thought it was safe to assert that either United or Granada or Carlton would end up with the upper hand, another possible outcome has surfaced. One way round the media ownership rules could see Carlton's senior management buy out its ITV franchise while flogging Carlton Productions (responsible, inter alia, for Peak Practice and the Big Breakfast) to Granada - a neat way of warehousing the airtime sales arm. What on earth Granada would want with Carlton Productions remains unexplained.
fields.body:
 Most bizarre rumour of the week yet again concerns the ferocious power struggle between ITV's biggest companies (yawn). Just when you thought it was safe to assert that either United or Granada or Carlton would end up with the upper hand, another possible outcome has surfaced. One way round the media ownership rules could see Carlton's senior management buy out its ITV franchise while flogging Carlton Productions (responsible, inter alia, for Peak Practice and the Big Breakfast) to Granada - a neat way of warehousing the airtime sales arm. What on earth Granada would want with Carlton Productions remains unexplained.

 What will Michael Brunson do next? The publication this week of his autobiography (A Ringside Seat, available in all good bookshops now) has led to several approaches from the nation's press. But ITN's former political editor has a problem: his 36-year career in television news, which has naturally ingrained in him TV's statutory requirement to be impartial, is clearly a less than ideal springboard for a new life pontificating in, say, the Telegraph. Before he's lost forever to the lucrative world of corporate advice, though, we just have two words for him: John and Humphrys. It's easy when you try, Michael.

 Rumours that Panorama is facing the axe are wide of the mark. "Even if Greg Dyke would love to [axe it], he can't in the run-up to the election," say insiders. But it could get a new editor, along with an infusion of cash to fund big investigations. Steve Hewlett, the ex-editor who scored Panorama's highest-ever viewing figure of 23m with the Princess Diana "Queen of Hearts" interview in 1995, says: "The audience potential is limited by the fact that it's a news programme, but you can hope for presence and getting noticed - not by making tabloid television but by using the tabloid popular touch in the best tradition." So, parcelling up all the Panoramas about economics, Ireland and eastern Europe and shipping them en masse over to BBC2 then.

 Sunday Business editor Jeff Randall, aka the Henry Kissinger of the newspaper industry, has spent the week emphasising to staff that he's committed to the pink paper until next February thanks to some extravagant incentives from the Barclay twins. According to his chums, the man who acted as mediator between Ashcroft and the Times seems less likely than ever to join the Wapping camp - even leaving aside the fact that Peter Stothard remains editor of the Times - and is looking to America, lured by his favourite golf courses in Florida.

 The nation's favourite Rottweiler has still to recover from the impact of devolution on BBC2's troubled Newsnight, which has been forced to agree to nightly bulletins at 11pm followed in Scotland by a separate "Newsnicht". A review of these arrangements will take place this summer but it can't come soon enough for Jeremy Paxman. Chairing an elegant and illuminating discussion between Andrew Marr and Malcolm Rifkind last week, Paxman drew proceedings to a close with praise for his contributors and the standard of debate. Then his face changed. "What a pity," he snarled, "that our Scottish viewers missed two such eloquent Scots owing to the way this programme divides its coverage." Valium for Mr Paxman, please.

 Bottles of fizz are on Channel 4 chief executive Michael Jackson from now on. Still glowing from an annual performance review of the channel's programmes (apart from TFI Friday), regarded as the best it has ever received, Jacko now has to endure the arduous task of renegotiating his contract. His three years expire in June and C4 accountant types tell us it will cost the board a rolling £450,000 a year to keep Jackson from the Hollywood career for which he is clearly destined.

 Apologies to Tom Bower and the London Evening Standard for our diary item last week. A full correction appeared in the newspaper on Tuesday.

 You can contact Maggie Brown on maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Hear me roar
fields.standfirst:
Peter Hitchens has been dumped by Talk Radio - and doubts if the BBC wants him either. What's a pundit to do?

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Hitchens has been dumped by Talk Radio - and doubts if the BBC wants him either. What's a pundit to do?
fields.body:
The BBC's monopoly of speech radio - the only monopoly it has left - is safe once more. Kelvin MacKenzie's decision to turn Talk Radio into TalkSport has ended the brief and frantic life of the UK's only independent national speech station. If you want to make or present a national radio current affairs programme, you must again do it through the BBC or remain silent. I should say here that presenting is different from appearing as a guest. I know that some Guardian readers think I appear on the BBC too much, but as a guest you are part of someone else's running order, discussing a subject chosen by someone else from an angle selected by someone else for a length of time decided by someone else.

I feel this keenly because for the past year I co-presented a unique programme on Talk Radio which, unless I am mistaken, will not find a new home on any of the Corporation's national wavelengths - where I am regarded with a sort of horror for being (gasp) "rightwing". Yet it was a successful attempt to deal with the problem of balance on radio. Instead of pretending that the programme's presenters had no opinions, we openly acknowledged that they did, and allowed them to debate directly, without a referee to get in the way.

Kelvin had originally offered me a microphone to myself but I suggested the double-headed format because I have been worried for years about broadcasting bias, and wanted to see if it could be overcome in an entertaining way. I believe that the problem has little or nothing to do with the Labour-Tory divide, and much more to do with morals and culture, marriage versus partnership, religion versus atheism, monoculture versus multiculturalism, grammar schools versus comprehensives, tolerance versus homosexual equality. It is more concerned with sex and drugs and rock'n'roll than with state ownership of the gas industry.

I always thought my Talk Radio programme worked better when I was pitted against Derek Draper - who disagreed with me about everything from the age of consent to the euro - than it did when my opponent was Austin Mitchell, whose Old Labour instincts were closer to my views than he liked to admit.

The BBC's assumption of infallibility often shows in its presenters, who honestly believe that they are being fair provided that they give equal time to Labour and the Tories, and never express any direct opinions themselves. They seem unaware that the selection of questions, the tone of voice and the assumptions behind their choice of subject are themselves conditioned by a set of opinions. They do not view these as opinions, since from university onwards they seldom if ever meet anyone who disagrees with them. These views are the assumed basis of civilised existence. You might as well try explaining to a fish that it is wet, as explaining to a BBC insider that he is biased.

This creates another curious effect. Because the BBC believes itself to be the cultural and moral mainstream, it tends to pick outside presenters who suit its world view and sideline those who do not.

I like a lot of BBC radio. Despite its bias, it justifies the licence fee by itself and helps to keep alive the idea that we are a nation, divided on many things but united by a common family feeling. It continues to assume a level of education and intelligence in its audience which most TV programmes do not.

It might well say that this quality has been allowed to survive precisely because speech radio - unlike TV and music radio - has not been forced to chase ratings in competition with commercial rivals. There is something in that. But if it wishes to keep this unique privilege, then surely it must also accept unique responsibilities, which it currently spurns, to speak for the whole nation rather than just the part of the nation which it prefers. What Lord Reith called the "brute force of monopoly" may have defended it against crass commercialism, but it has also allowed it to close its mind to an important strand of opinion.

If it cannot reform itself, and open its mind to the idea that there are intelligent and decent people who do not share its assumptions, then it has no right to that monopoly, and it must expect growing demands for a new independent national speech station to challenge it.

 Peter Hitchens is a columnist for the Express and the author of The Abolition of Britain

fields.headline: His masters' choice
fields.standfirst:
Greg Dyke today unveils his new BBC, and his de facto deputy. Maggie Brown and Janine Gibson uncover Mark Thompson, a man who would have made it under any regime, and how to survive the shake-up

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke today unveils his new BBC, and his de facto deputy. Maggie Brown and Janine Gibson uncover Mark Thompson, a man who would have made it under any regime, and how to survive the shake-up
fields.body:
It was an otherwise unremarkable September afternoon at the 1997 Royal Television Society convention in Cambridge when Mark Thompson's career was made. All the biggest names in broadcasting were gathered, the BBC's digital plans had been unveiled by John Birt and the hushed assembly waited to hear from one of the corporation's biggest names, Alan Yentob.

But Yentob had broken a tooth on an unscheduled toffee, so instead it was the relatively junior exec Mark Thompson who stepped up to speak, unscripted, about the essence of BBC values. Looking as if he'd stepped out of an M&S catalogue in a sludge-green pullover, boyishly disarming, he could have been a disaster. Yet he suddenly spoke from the heart, about what the BBC meant to him, of how its programmes were crafted with pride - he compared them to home-made, carefully prepared food.

It was oddly touching and effective, distinctive in a sea of self-serving guff. Greg Dyke, then chief executive of Pearson Television, was in the audience and he was impressed. It was the first time he met Thompson and he thought anyone who could get up on stage with 10 minute's warning and speak so eloquently and effectively was worth noticing. Today, Thompson is handed a beefed-up version of Yentob's job as Dyke's de facto deputy. On such moments careers hang. You need luck, yes. But courage too.

Thompson's amazing skill is to have succeeded under Birt, but to have emerged this week as the confidant to the anti-establishment outsider Dyke, becoming overseer of BBC1 and BBC2 and replacing Alan Yentob as the embodiment of BBC values.

Dyke will announce today that he is diverting an extra £200m into programming from April 2001. That money is aimed at boosting the core services, especially BBC1, through his plans to create a commercially led BBC film operation unit and heavy investment in drama. Those initiatives will, through Yentob, feed through to the main channels, but the extra cash - found through cutbacks in expenditure - will enable Thompson to channel funds where they're needed, to the controllers and the commissioners. He will actually have the control.

So Thompson takes yet another glittering prize, and picks up the mantle of heir apparent - assuming power without appearing to snatch it, or threaten anyone.

Old BBC hands are quick to point out that he is a classic BBC man, straight out of the Alasdair Milne school of "brahmins" and would have prospered under any regime. "He reminds me of the old BBC, the people who were brilliant at the politics, very intelligent, but bland," says a contemporary. Aged 42, he is tall - six foot three - white, upper middle class. In these rough and ready days of portable careers, short-term contracts and dot.com floats he's a bit of a throwback - having only ever worked for the BBC. Educated at public school - Stonyhurst, the Lancashire Catholic college - and Merton College, Oxford, he edited Isis and took a first in English literature.

Then it was straight to the corporation in 1979 on a coveted production traineeship. He did stints on Watchdog and the launch of BBC Breakfast News in 1982, then went to America before joining Newsnight. So far, so establishment for a super-bright young man.

In 1988, John Birt, as incoming deputy director-general, chose him to be editor of the Nine O'Clock News. Thompson was 30. Then two years later he was dispatched to run another Birtist priority, Panorama.

These are two of the most exposed posts in the BBC. And they were doubly troubling in this 1988-92 era because of the high tide of Thatcherism, when every bulletin and programme was pored over for evidence of bias. The charge against him is that he did what was required. "He adapted to the high point of Birtism, because he's not a maverick, and now he will be enthusiastic about Dyke's changes. There is no passion," says one well-placed contemporary.

Thompson's highest-profile post, the job he most visibly enjoyed, was as controller of BBC2 between 1996 and 1998. He seemed to relax under the eye of Will Wyatt, the now-retired chief executive of BBC Broadcast - who, as Birt's unofficial deputy, advanced Thompson's career too.

In his running of BBC2, he displayed a rare lack of personal ego and vanity. He did not try to take on the role of impresario - Yentob's style - or make it a channel in his own image, as the current controller Jane Root is doing. He clearly loved the job to bits, enthused about reading drama scripts on the train to the office, and seemed crestfallen when asked to move upwards on to the board of management.

But his hallmark is to be an enabler, not a TV performer manqué. Says one envious rival: "He was very capable. But I object to him being labelled one of the best controllers BBC2 ever had. Sure, he had an 11% share. But he inherited an awful lot of things from [his predecessor] Michael Jackson and Yentob. Lifestyle programming, Tony Garnett's This Life, popular comedy."

More power, if less glamour, came with the role of director of national and regional broadcasting over the past 18 months, a difficult job which Dyke believes he has performed brilliantly. Thompson likened it to "playing three-dimensional chess". It tested his mix of diplomacy, political wiliness and informal charm to hold the BBC together at a time of devolution - and Scottish revolt over such symbols of union as the Six O'Clock News from London.

His determination to relaunch London's BBC station GLR last week as London Live was pursued with the zeal of an apparatchik, though he's won extra money for local radio, and reversed some daft decisions. He made sure Thames Valley radio was replaced with Radio Oxford and Radio Berkshire, and has set in train the eventual revamping of coverage of London and the south-east.

Yet you can trot out all these bald facts about Thompson, a pale, rangy figure in nondescript suits, and miss the truth. He is posh, on paper, in background. But he doesn't sound posh, and he doesn't act it. Born in London, he grew up in Welwyn Garden City but although he seems quintessentially English, he doesn't feel so. His mother is Irish, and a devout Catholic, his father half Scottish, and an accountant in the plastics division of ICI. They had to make real sacrifices to send him to boarding school.

Fashion has never been a priority: even at the height of Birtist clones, Armani never seemed to infiltrate his wardrobe. He wears suits with the carelessness of the little prep boy forced into them from the age of seven. He remains a devout Catholic - and is married to a beautiful American Jewish academic, Jane Blumberg. He describes with amusement how, before they married, she accompanied her future husband and mother-in-law on a trip to Bruges and was horrified to see them kneel down to kiss a sacred shrine.

They have three children, aged between two and eight, who are being brought up as Catholics, and like several other senior broadcasting figures, he has chosen Oxford as his home. He gives every sign of having a grounded life, switching easily from the finer points of devolution to the appeal of BBC2's cult Robot Wars and Pokemon cards. An ex-Panorama executive says he's never seen him panic, only flustered, suggesting that this is the key to his rise. While editing Panorama, for example, he had to cope with the huge embarrassment in 1991 of being told to withhold the Iraqi Super Gun programme which was then trumped by ITV. He gave just enough hints to indicate his unhappiness with the Birtist thought police above him.

"His programmes were very straight, you might say dull. But he managed them well," says this source. "He's done fantastically well, without being a visionary but by being a very, very good manager."

Of course, he's blazingly ambitious. He is rated for his ability to work, to throw himself into problems. But he doesn't seem to have trampled on others too publicly. "He is much too sophisticated for that," snaps an envious observer.

The thinking now is that if you have creative, buzzy channel heads such as Jane Root at BBC2, Peter Salmon at BBC1 and BBC Choice's Stuart Murphy, you need a figure like Thompson to take a calm, longer view. The signs are that he's been doing that. When the furore blew up last year about Root "axing" One Man & His Dog, Thompson confessed it had been his decision. "Behind the scenes he's been very supportive to both Jane and Peter," say senior BBC sources.

Indeed a few weeks ago, Thompson and his family spent the weekend with Root at her house in Suffolk. This suggests that he has absorbed the new Dyke gospel: the BBC has to be a "communal" organisation, where people co-operate and socialise. And at last month's Royal Television Society programme awards, he was genuinely thrilled as BBC2 programmes stormed home, culminating with one for the Naked Chef, Jamie Oliver - one of his finds.

One incident last summer, before Dyke had officially taken over as director-general gave the first clue to the rise of the new director of television. After a predictable debate about the BBC at last year's Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival, Dyke, who had been sitting in the audience, turned to Thompson, and asked him if he'd like to share a cab back to the airport. It was one of those small but interesting signs of a growing rapport.

Dyke's view of his number two, friends say, reveals much of his thinking about the old BBC. "He's got great skills and is the classic BBC guy, but still everybody likes him." It's unlikely that Thompson is ever going to match Dyke in coming up with quickfire one-liners. But he's exactly the kind of clever, reassuring figure to stand beside him at the Select Committee grillings, and that may be enough.

Your guide to Dyke's BBC: what to say

Birtspeak

Key vocabulary:
Distinctiveness; bimedialism; producer choice; business units; centres of excellence; transparency; mission to explain; restructuring; liberating resources (sacking people); delayering (sacking people); downsizing (sacking people); outsourcing (making it possible to sack people).

"The BBC will address the agenda of the day."

fields.bodyText: It was an otherwise unremarkable September afternoon at the 1997 Royal Television Society convention in Cambridge when Mark Thompson's career was made. All the biggest names in broadcasting were gathered, the BBC's digital plans had been unveiled by John Birt and the hushed assembly waited to hear from one of the corporation's biggest names, Alan Yentob. But Yentob had broken a tooth on an unscheduled toffee, so instead it was the relatively junior exec Mark Thompson who stepped up to speak, unscripted, about the essence of BBC values. Looking as if he'd stepped out of an M&S catalogue in a sludge-green pullover, boyishly disarming, he could have been a disaster. Yet he suddenly spoke from the heart, about what the BBC meant to him, of how its programmes were crafted with pride - he compared them to home-made, carefully prepared food. It was oddly touching and effective, distinctive in a sea of self-serving guff. Greg Dyke, then chief executive of Pearson Television, was in the audience and he was impressed. It was the first time he met Thompson and he thought anyone who could get up on stage with 10 minute's warning and speak so eloquently and effectively was worth noticing. Today, Thompson is handed a beefed-up version of Yentob's job as Dyke's de facto deputy. On such moments careers hang. You need luck, yes. But courage too. Thompson's amazing skill is to have succeeded under Birt, but to have emerged this week as the confidant to the anti-establishment outsider Dyke, becoming overseer of BBC1 and BBC2 and replacing Alan Yentob as the embodiment of BBC values. Dyke will announce today that he is diverting an extra £200m into programming from April 2001. That money is aimed at boosting the core services, especially BBC1, through his plans to create a commercially led BBC film operation unit and heavy investment in drama. Those initiatives will, through Yentob, feed through to the main channels, but the extra cash - found through cutbacks in expenditure - will enable Thompson to channel funds where they're needed, to the controllers and the commissioners. He will actually have the control. So Thompson takes yet another glittering prize, and picks up the mantle of heir apparent - assuming power without appearing to snatch it, or threaten anyone. Old BBC hands are quick to point out that he is a classic BBC man, straight out of the Alasdair Milne school of "brahmins" and would have prospered under any regime. "He reminds me of the old BBC, the people who were brilliant at the politics, very intelligent, but bland," says a contemporary. Aged 42, he is tall - six foot three - white, upper middle class. In these rough and ready days of portable careers, short-term contracts and dot.com floats he's a bit of a throwback - having only ever worked for the BBC. Educated at public school - Stonyhurst, the Lancashire Catholic college - and Merton College, Oxford, he edited Isis and took a first in English literature. Then it was straight to the corporation in 1979 on a coveted production traineeship. He did stints on Watchdog and the launch of BBC Breakfast News in 1982, then went to America before joining Newsnight. So far, so establishment for a super-bright young man. In 1988, John Birt, as incoming deputy director-general, chose him to be editor of the Nine O'Clock News. Thompson was 30. Then two years later he was dispatched to run another Birtist priority, Panorama. These are two of the most exposed posts in the BBC. And they were doubly troubling in this 1988-92 era because of the high tide of Thatcherism, when every bulletin and programme was pored over for evidence of bias. The charge against him is that he did what was required. "He adapted to the high point of Birtism, because he's not a maverick, and now he will be enthusiastic about Dyke's changes. There is no passion," says one well-placed contemporary. Thompson's highest-profile post, the job he most visibly enjoyed, was as controller of BBC2 between 1996 and 1998. He seemed to relax under the eye of Will Wyatt, the now-retired chief executive of BBC Broadcast - who, as Birt's unofficial deputy, advanced Thompson's career too. In his running of BBC2, he displayed a rare lack of personal ego and vanity. He did not try to take on the role of impresario - Yentob's style - or make it a channel in his own image, as the current controller Jane Root is doing. He clearly loved the job to bits, enthused about reading drama scripts on the train to the office, and seemed crestfallen when asked to move upwards on to the board of management. But his hallmark is to be an enabler, not a TV performer manqué. Says one envious rival: "He was very capable. But I object to him being labelled one of the best controllers BBC2 ever had. Sure, he had an 11% share. But he inherited an awful lot of things from [his predecessor] Michael Jackson and Yentob. Lifestyle programming, Tony Garnett's This Life, popular comedy." More power, if less glamour, came with the role of director of national and regional broadcasting over the past 18 months, a difficult job which Dyke believes he has performed brilliantly. Thompson likened it to "playing three-dimensional chess". It tested his mix of diplomacy, political wiliness and informal charm to hold the BBC together at a time of devolution - and Scottish revolt over such symbols of union as the Six O'Clock News from London. His determination to relaunch London's BBC station GLR last week as London Live was pursued with the zeal of an apparatchik, though he's won extra money for local radio, and reversed some daft decisions. He made sure Thames Valley radio was replaced with Radio Oxford and Radio Berkshire, and has set in train the eventual revamping of coverage of London and the south-east. Yet you can trot out all these bald facts about Thompson, a pale, rangy figure in nondescript suits, and miss the truth. He is posh, on paper, in background. But he doesn't sound posh, and he doesn't act it. Born in London, he grew up in Welwyn Garden City but although he seems quintessentially English, he doesn't feel so. His mother is Irish, and a devout Catholic, his father half Scottish, and an accountant in the plastics division of ICI. They had to make real sacrifices to send him to boarding school. Fashion has never been a priority: even at the height of Birtist clones, Armani never seemed to infiltrate his wardrobe. He wears suits with the carelessness of the little prep boy forced into them from the age of seven. He remains a devout Catholic - and is married to a beautiful American Jewish academic, Jane Blumberg. He describes with amusement how, before they married, she accompanied her future husband and mother-in-law on a trip to Bruges and was horrified to see them kneel down to kiss a sacred shrine. They have three children, aged between two and eight, who are being brought up as Catholics, and like several other senior broadcasting figures, he has chosen Oxford as his home. He gives every sign of having a grounded life, switching easily from the finer points of devolution to the appeal of BBC2's cult Robot Wars and Pokemon cards. An ex-Panorama executive says he's never seen him panic, only flustered, suggesting that this is the key to his rise. While editing Panorama, for example, he had to cope with the huge embarrassment in 1991 of being told to withhold the Iraqi Super Gun programme which was then trumped by ITV. He gave just enough hints to indicate his unhappiness with the Birtist thought police above him. "His programmes were very straight, you might say dull. But he managed them well," says this source. "He's done fantastically well, without being a visionary but by being a very, very good manager." Of course, he's blazingly ambitious. He is rated for his ability to work, to throw himself into problems. But he doesn't seem to have trampled on others too publicly. "He is much too sophisticated for that," snaps an envious observer. The thinking now is that if you have creative, buzzy channel heads such as Jane Root at BBC2, Peter Salmon at BBC1 and BBC Choice's Stuart Murphy, you need a figure like Thompson to take a calm, longer view. The signs are that he's been doing that. When the furore blew up last year about Root "axing" One Man & His Dog, Thompson confessed it had been his decision. "Behind the scenes he's been very supportive to both Jane and Peter," say senior BBC sources. Indeed a few weeks ago, Thompson and his family spent the weekend with Root at her house in Suffolk. This suggests that he has absorbed the new Dyke gospel: the BBC has to be a "communal" organisation, where people co-operate and socialise. And at last month's Royal Television Society programme awards, he was genuinely thrilled as BBC2 programmes stormed home, culminating with one for the Naked Chef, Jamie Oliver - one of his finds. One incident last summer, before Dyke had officially taken over as director-general gave the first clue to the rise of the new director of television. After a predictable debate about the BBC at last year's Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival, Dyke, who had been sitting in the audience, turned to Thompson, and asked him if he'd like to share a cab back to the airport. It was one of those small but interesting signs of a growing rapport. Dyke's view of his number two, friends say, reveals much of his thinking about the old BBC. "He's got great skills and is the classic BBC guy, but still everybody likes him." It's unlikely that Thompson is ever going to match Dyke in coming up with quickfire one-liners. But he's exactly the kind of clever, reassuring figure to stand beside him at the Select Committee grillings, and that may be enough. Catchphrases: "The BBC will address the agenda of the day." "The BBC will act as a civilising force, a trusted guide to viewers and listeners in the digital age." fields.headline: Trust me, I'm a comic
fields.standfirst: As Alan Partridge, Steve Coogan mocked brain-dead TV suits. But now he's crossed the floor and set up a company to scout comedy talent for the BBC.  Victoria Coren  asked him if he's serious
fields.trailText: As Alan Partridge, Steve Coogan mocked brain-dead TV suits. But now he's crossed the floor and set up a company to scout comedy talent for the BBC. Victoria Coren asked him if he's serious
fields.body:
Steve Coogan believes there's something out there. Somewhere in the atmosphere, it's lurking... new comedy talent. He is on a mission to befriend this alien, speak its language and harness its power. Or more specifically, sign it up for his new production company, Baby Cow.

"I'm not interested in empire building," he says. "I just want to make good programmes with good people. I don't want to take over the world just yet." So he and partner Henry Normal have set up base in Brighton, started work on a selection of scripts and are currently scouting for writing-performing talent.

The BBC also believes there's something out there. The corporation has done a development deal with Baby Cow, supplying Coogan with a six-figure sum to develop several new comedy ideas in return for a first-look commitment. Meanwhile, the BBC is running its own £5m new talent drive, with the comedy side taking the form of a competition.

Somehow the BBC initiative is less confidence-inspiring. Corporations can occasionally behave like crazed Kansas farmers, gripped by the faith that Something's Out There, convinced that if they stand in a field long enough it will simply land on the porch. Can these Unidentified Funny Objects really be lured by the simple, rural ruse of a comedy competition?

There's a huge industry in talent-seeking competitions, workshops and festivals. The Edinburgh Festival has so many rival stand-up contests that you can hear 30 young men pointing out the hilarity of their girlfriends' foibles before you've managed to locate your revolver. And I personally have sat in at least 20 "New Writers' Workshops" where dozens of young men in polo necks have pitched their brilliant idea for a sitcom in which two lads share a flat and talk about girls. That's the risk in just inviting people to come along with their humour. You know your ghastly uncle who says "Something hilarious happened to me last week" and then bores you for an hour? That's who's going to turn up.

Steve Coogan's big break came when he joined Radio 4's On The Hour team (later BBC2's The Day Today) which included Armando Iannucci, Patrick Marber, David Schneider, Rebecca Front, Stewart Lee and Richard Herring, who had all chanced to be at Oxford together. Coogan himself had been at college with John Thomson, and their own mates in Manchester included Henry Normal (later co-writer of The Royle Family) and Caroline Aherne. That is a quirk of geography and circumstance; a giggling baby boom. It's the secret of comedy: timing. You can launch all the New Talent Initiatives in the world but you can't fake that.

But Coogan's own approach is more sensible. Yes, he is opening his arms to young wannabe-Coogans; fledgling Partridges. "I want to say to any young people who have got good scripts which need a spit and a polish, and a reader who can bend the right ear at the BBC... we're here."

It's not always so direct with performer-led production companies. If you go to Talkback you won't be dealing with Mel Smith and Griff Rhys Jones, nor with Rory Bremner at Vera. Steve Coogan will be busy in the next few months - in June he starts shooting a feature film, produced by Andrew McDonald and Duncan Kenworthy, in which he plays a parole officer who robs a bank. Next year there will be a new Alan Partridge series, in which we may see the hapless Alan in improved circumstances. "Perhaps he'll be working as a regional newscaster, back on his feet but not quite at the dizzy heights of network television. I can see his dress sense changing slightly: you might see a leather bomber jacket and running shoes... and perhaps a new car. But not a Rover. He'd distance himself from Rover as a career decision."

So plenty of performing projects on the go - nevertheless, if you send scripts to Baby Cow, "Henry and I will read them". But he is also doing specific talent-targeting. The BBC has already green-lit two series from Baby Cow: a sitcom "in a documentary style" about dysfunctional couples, and a comedy drama (starring Coogan himself) about an English architect in Glasgow. Both involve writers (Julia Davis, Rob Bryden and Annie Griffin) contacted by Coogan because he had seen and admired their work. He also has his sometime co-writer Peter Baynham developing an animation series.

He is clearly relishing the opportunity to talent-spot across the airwaves and clubs; but he knows it's not enough just to find the talent. That's the mistake that TV executives make, and Coogan is "on the side of the performer". The crucial requirement is to use it properly.

"When you get involved in television you can get bogged down in the mechanics and lose sight of the basics, like quality of material. Stand-ups are often just plonked on TV - the producer points a camera at them and hopes they'll be funny. But something happens when it goes down a cathode ray tube: sucks the comedy out of an idea."

Asked for an example he cites Johnny Vegas, who was rushed on to Channel 4 after storming the 1998 Edinburgh Festival. "I'm a huge fan of Johnny Vegas, but that show shouldn't have been aired. It should have been a non-broadcast pilot to help him in the learning process. You need time to think through the rules of this particular medium."

The other way that young comics are misused is to be "put in a sitcom that doesn't do them justice. You can't really impose an idea on a comic. You need other people around to stop them making mistakes. I want to be one of those people."

For Steve Coogan himself, "those people" have been Marber, Normal and Iannucci. What he would like to recreate, in his new role at Baby Cow, is Iannucci's skill in assembling the Day Today team. Sure, he got lucky in his classmates at Oxford - but it was inspired producing to introduce both Coogan and that broadcasting genius Christopher Morris. The quality of the team enabled them all to shine, rescuing them from the Johnny Vegas fate of working alone too early.

Any chance of another series of The Day Today? "I would love to work with them again. Chris was modest enough to play a farmer in the last series of Alan Partridge: it was quite funny telling him what to do. I don't think many people get to do that. But the ethos behind The Day Today was that we knew we were cutting edge, and we've all gone in different directions. To re-form now...it would be pissing on the chips that we so nicely fried seven years ago."

Coogan's own attempt to form a team of promising new talent is a sketch show idea for BBC1. A pilot has been commissioned, to be co-produced with Avalon. "One area that has been neglected in TV is solid, quality, one-nation comedy. There's a lot of very good esoteric stuff, such as Big Train, Smack The Pony and The League of Gentlemen, but we want to make a mainstream sketch show which isn't just brainless."

There are those who will say that the production company is a vanity deal; that Coogan is an unproved producer and the BBC is supplying him with development money to keep him sweet as a performer. He is the first to admit that the haemorrhaging of other Corporation stars, which saw the likes of Frank Skinner and Des Lynam skipping down the steps of White City tube and getting the first money train outta there, was "probably helpful for me".

But the development money is not a ludicrous amount and, in truth, Coogan has proved his grasp of televisual mechanics in his career as a performer. His was the first pure television generation.

In the old days, it was always said (and rightly) of performers such as Ken Dodd, Mike Reid and Bob Monkhouse that you could never fully appreciate their art without seeing them live. On stage was where they excelled.

For Coogan's gang, the opposite was true. Coogan is a fine live performer but anyone who has seen him (or Patrick Marber, or Armando Iannucci or Caroline Aherne) doing stand-up would turn to their neighbour and say "Ah... but you should see what they can do with television."

They were born for that medium. The Day Today, Alan Partridge, Mrs Merton - and of course, Brass Eye - were crafted from perfect observation of the workings of TV, its stars and clichés. What better way to demonstrate a masterful understanding of programme-making than with a finely executed pastiche?

Coogan, one therefore senses, is to be trusted. "I've got the ear of the BBC, and also a certain amount of respect from young performers because they like my work," he says. "I know from my own experience as a young comic that there's a lot of mistrust about people in suits telling you how to do comedy. I'm trying to be a producer who doesn't wear a suit. And they can't say I don't know how to do comedy, because I've done it. It's as simple as that."

fields.headline: You couldn't make it up
fields.standfirst: Last week Times editor Peter Stothard announced he is taking an unscheduled sabbatical. The wild speculation that ensued reveals the media's obsession with conspiracies, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Last week Times editor Peter Stothard announced he is taking an unscheduled sabbatical. The wild speculation that ensued reveals the media's obsession with conspiracies, says Roy Greenslade
fields.body:
Without wishing to add to the tribulations of Times editor Peter Stothard by returning to last week's unhappy episode, I don't believe we can afford to ignore the implications. We cannot excuse that embarrassing event as an aberration, a one-off never to be repeated. Nor should we avert our eyes, pretending it never happened. It's too important, dammit, and we need to feel the heat on our red faces once again, and perhaps often, to bring us to our senses. It raises all sorts of questions about modern journalism.

First, seen in the context of the public who are both the objects and the subjects of our work, should we not consider that if we can do this to one of our own, to a distinguished and decent man, then what do we do routinely to other people every day? Second, have we turned "speculation" into an art form, relying on the use of non-attributable sources and mischief-making gossips, all with agendas of their own, to publish material which uncannily fits our own preconceptions? Third, in this era of practised spin doctors, are we now so consumed with conspiracy theories that we cannot accept anything at face value? Fourth, are we not guilty of rushing to judgement too often? Fifth, are we losing all sense of balance and responsibility because of the pressures created by intense commercial rivalry? In other words, the Stothard affair goes to the heart of journalistic ethics. To illustrate the point, let's examine what happened in a little detail.

When Stothard initially announced, in a hesitant statement last Tuesday, that he was "taking time off to work on special projects", the media's legions of conspiracy theorists were quickly at their task. Throughout the afternoon, telephones hummed between newspaper offices as the rumour-mongers built their fantasies. Radio news and current affairs producers decided it was an important story. I received three calls from radio researchers asking me to speculate on what the announcement might mean.

Friends at the Times offered me their opinions. Most thought it was a device by Rupert Murdoch to remove Stothard from the editorship. But one, much the most sensible and experienced among them, cautioned me against such a view. Murdoch liked Stothard. After a long campaign, he had acceded to Stothard's request to spend millions reconfiguring presses to allow him to publish the Times in a new structure. He said: "Why would he ditch him now? It doesn't make sense."

But he did concede that the claim that Stothard was taking a sort of sabbatical while researching the internet didn't ring true either. Late in the afternoon I got a call about "the latest rumour". It was being suggested that Stothard had cancer. Seconds later, a Radio 4 researcher called. Would I be prepared to comment on "the real reason Stothard was being removed"?

And what was that? Well, she said, there were two "theories". One was that Murdoch was sacrificing Stothard in some unspecified - and, on reflection, inexplicable - deal to placate Tory treasurer Michael Ashcroft, who settled a high-profile libel action with the paper in December. The second was even more far-fetched, suggesting that Murdoch wanted to move the Times closer to the Tory party in the run-up to the next election and didn't think Stothard the man to reposition the paper's politics.

I dismissed the latter out of hand, asked for clarification of the former and told her she should consider two other possibilities: that the announcement was, even if clumsy, true; or that Stothard might be ill. I then called Wapping's corporate affairs office to mention the cancer rumour. It was not denied or confirmed and, despite my years of experience in the ritual of divining what PRs mean when they don't say no and they don't say yes, I didn't "read" that conversation with the clarity I should have done.

But it did make me suspicious enough to turn down all requests for radio interviews. Similar non-denials and even denials didn't halt the wilder shores of speculation elsewhere, including the Guardian. A front-page story said the future of the Times editor was "in doubt" and the Ashcroft gossip was rehearsed inside. Both the Guardian and the Independent speculated on possible successors to Stothard.

Next morning Radio 4's Today programme - unable to find an outside commentator willing to broadcast - enlarged on the speculation with an "interview" between presenter James Naughtie and one of the BBC's own political correspondents, John Kampfner.

It was clear that the cautious Kampfner was consistently pushed further than he wished to go by Naughtie, who gave the impression of being convinced that Stothard was being ditched as editor.

Perhaps he was influenced by the knowledge that some of the Tory hierarchy were letting it be known that the Ashcroft affair had played some part in Stothard's supposed downfall. Some journalists were briefed to that effect. "I had no conversations with Central Office," said Kampfner. But he concedes that "a tip" had been given to "someone" at Today and that "the place was rife with people pretending to know the inside story".

At least one close friend of Ashcroft, building on rumours from sources within the Times, was prepared to tell journalists that Stothard's leave of absence was entirely due to the Ashcroft affair.

The fact that it was written by a reputable journalist known for his fairness and objectivity says much about the direction journalism has taken. It's too quick to think, too ready to speculate on the flimsiest of evidence and too prepared to accept a conspiracy theory rather than the mundane truth.

The Standard piece was pulled from later editions once Stothard, realising that his attempt to keep his illness private was no longer tenable, broke the news of his treatment for a neuro endocrine tumour of the pancreas. He was upset by the allegation that he had been "eased out of the editor's chair at the instigation of Mr Ashcroft, his acolytes and satellites".

This poignant announcement prompted the Sun's editor David Yelland to sign a leader raging against papers that "do not care about facts" and calling for apologies and corrections. We need no lessons on press ethics from the Sun. Yelland also conveniently overlooks pertinent realities. Editors are now public figures who cannot escape the scrutiny of the rest of the media. In that sense, Stothard was naive, as were his News International bosses. They should have realised that an editor cannot leave his post without inciting intense interest.

But that is certainly no excuse for the resulting journalism. Once the truth emerged, we might have expected a period of silence while we pondered what we had done. But competition knows no morals. So the Daily Telegraph took the opportunity on Friday to hypothesise about what acting editor Ben Preston might do to the Times if he was eventually made editor.

Similarly, the Spectator's Stephen Glover, who has made a fetish out of decrying the works of Stothard, couldn't resist delivering a barb or two while wishing him "a speedy recovery".

He, indeed all of us, would do better to remember what happened on the day a sick man tried to leave his post with dignity and ended up mired in a welter of media muck.
