fields.headline: No agency required
fields.standfirst: For years it refused to make TV ads and all promotion is devised in-house. Yet advertising made The Gap the world's biggest clothes store. As its new campaign arrives here,  Stephen Armstrong  looks at how the retailer sells itself
fields.trailText: For years it refused to make TV ads and all promotion is devised in-house. Yet advertising made The Gap the world's biggest clothes store. As its new campaign arrives here, Stephen Armstrong looks at how the retailer sells itself
fields.body:
Ask the people at The Gap why their white T-shirt with a single pocket is the world's best-selling garment, and they burble on about the way the brand values of the company permeate every aspect of the business, from in-store to online.

Rubbish. It's number one because the ads are great. There was the Khakis a-go-go ad with everyone raving like demented 60s pixies, the country ad with models line-dancing to Crazy Little Thing Called Love, and the Christmas ads with ice skating kids merging in and out of each other to a mixed-up seasonal soundtrack.

Mark Ratcliffe, who runs youth consultancy Murmur, says that every time he runs youth focus groups Gap campaigns always come out in teens' and twentysomethings' top 10s. Their TV work "has a fantastic feel-good factor - it's warm and accessible, doesn't put itself on a pedestal and emphasises the collective," enthuses Crawford Hollingworth, director at marketing consultancy Headlightvision, which owns online brands and consumer culture webzine globalstreetscape.com. "There's something about their body language and the way they look at you directly that's extremely involving and personal. It's like seeing a bunch of mates having a great time and wanting to be a part of it. It reminds you of friendship, good times and group bonding. When you relate it back to society, which is cold and lonely with extended and disjointed families, this celebration of friends is incredibly attractive."

They're not just popular. They seem to work. The Gap stopped advertising on television in the 1960s and concentrated on print work, using the celeb-heavy Individuals of Style campaign. Over the past 10 years, however, the classic white background with the not-too-modelly models sporting this season's Gap apparel took over the print and posters work. Finally, three years ago, the brand went back to TV and 18 months ago overtook Levi's as the world's biggest clothing manufacturer.

Now there's a new campaign, which premiered in the US in the first ad break of the Oscars and arrived in the UK this weekend in the breaks in the Hollyoaks omnibus and Blind Date. Using a West Side Story soundtrack, the commercials have a camped-up, showbizzy feel that wasn't there before.

The campaign is in three parts - Khakis Cool, Denim America and Are You A Jean Or A Khaki? Khakis uses Boy, Boy, Crazy Boy as the theme with khaki-clad Jets clicking their fingers and grooving around. Denim gives us la-la-la-la-la America and the flamboyant Shark routines, then there's the nightclub mambo face-off and a huge synchronised dance number that would make the movie's choreographer Jerome Robbins proud. Significantly, The Gap's signature white environment has gone, replaced by backlit reds, yellows and blues. What, no white?

"I think minimalism is over now," explains Jim Nevins, Gap's executive vice-president of global marketing. "We've all been there and done that. People are into sheer exuberance and entertainment. We've never done something from the theatrical tradition before so we've returned to this vast entertainment concept." But doesn't that look terribly camp? "Well, there's a wink to it all. We've been criticised for being too serious in the past so we've turned to this theatricality to provide that wink. It just looks refreshing."

Curiously, and perhaps tellingly, The Gap has made these ads itself. It has refused to use an advertising agency since the 1960s. "Why would we get outsiders and have them tell us who we are?" says Nevins. "The strongest brands in the world have a much clearer idea of their own image than any advertising agency ever could." Instead, the company's marketing department creates all its adverts, from print to television.

"We're structured a little like an agency," Nevins admits, "with art directors, editors and account managers. On the creative side, therefore, we operate like one. We also try to keep abreast of popular culture in a way that lots of agencies don't manage and we've always been concerned with creating a signature style that goes through the ads and into the stores. It's far easier to do that if the people making the ads work for the same company as the people in the stores. We don't see our ads as hard sell, we see them as pieces of entertainment and pieces of popular culture."

Not having an advertising agency is heresy in adland. "Where's that sort of behaviour going to get people?" the argument goes. "You need proper advertising professionals to create professional advertising. What's the benefit of doing something that important yourself?" Well, for one thing it's bought The Gap global dominance at a seriously discounted rate. Last year, across all its brands including Old Navy and Banana Republic, the company spent $4.5m worldwide on advertising, less than half Coca-Cola's spend.

The Gap's advertising thus helps it achieve something unusual on the British high street. It enables it to stay securely in the mid-market as the spending patterns in British fashion retail split wide apart. These days, British punters love designer labels and discounted goods, often buying discounted gear to put money aside for one or two really fancy bits of clobber. The old idea of solid, respectable mid-market clothing is vanishing. They call it the democratisation of style: retail analysts, such as Richard Hyman at Verdict Research, believe it's likely to become permanent as clothes-buying motivation increasingly shifts from need to want. Hence the problems besetting British Home Stores and Marks & Spencer, which traditionally benefited from their ability to be solid and reliable.

"The Gap set out as a reliable, cheap clothing store, but the ads have somehow managed to give it a cool, non-confrontational image," says Johnny Davis, editor of the Face. "Their celebrity endorsements put Calvin Klein to shame. Getting Missy Elliott for last winter's press work was inspired. There's absolutely no shame in wearing a Gap T-shirt, but that's not true of the more fuddy-duddy British high street stores and that's showing in their sales."

Curiously, as M&S embarks on a bid to claw back its vanishing customers, it appears to be ignoring the lesson of The Gap. The store chain employed an external consultant, Interbrand Newell & Sorrell, to redesign its brand over 12 months - the kind of outside interference that sends Nevins pale with fear. Last week, Interbrand reported back, suggesting new fronts for all stores, a new font for the M&S logo, several new types of carrier bag, including a paper carrier and a duffel-style bag, and a tweak in the bags' colour. At the same time, M&S is beginning a trawl of advertising agencies.

I asked to speak to the person concerned with the whole M&S brand including the appointment of the ad agency. That wasn't possible, I was told. These are two separate jobs. One person looks after the stores' brand image and another looks after the advertising. And you can't speak to the advertising person anyway.

Nevins found the division of jobs incomprehensible but has problems of his own. "We're the Madonna of advertising," he grimaces. "People keep expecting us to come up with original ads. It's a struggle." His advice for M&S? "We wish them luck. We find this stuff hard enough ourselves without butting in on other people."

webTitle: Nato seizes Bosnian Serb leader over war crimes

fields.headline: Nato seizes Bosnian Serb leader over war crimes
fields.trailText: Nato forces today seized a senior Bosnian Serb leader, the highest-ranking suspect yet to be arrested for alleged war crimes, in a dramatic dawn raid in the Serb stronghold of Pale.
fields.body:
Nato forces today seized a senior Bosnian Serb leader, the highest-ranking suspect yet to be arrested for alleged war crimes, in a dramatic dawn raid in the Serb stronghold of Pale.

French peacekeepers arrested Momcilo Krajisnik after blowing open a door to his home with explosives. "They took my Dad away," Mr Krajisnik's son Milos, 21, said. He said he managed to see seven or eight soldiers before he and his brother, Njegos, 19, were tied up and their faces turned towards the floor. Mr Krajisnik's father, Sretko, ridiculed the use of force. "If they had knocked on the door, I would have opened it," he said. Mr Krajisnik reportedly was led away still in pyjamas and barefoot.

Mr Krajisnik, a former member of Bosnia's tripartite presidency, was arrested on a secret indictment and is to be extradited to the Hague to be tried by the UN war crimes tribunal. Nato secretary general Lord Robertson said in a statement in Brussels that Mr Krajisnik was arrested at 3.17am local time and was being processed for transfer to Holland.

"He is accused of genocide, crimes against humanity, violations of the laws and customs of war and grave breaches of the Geneva convention including murder, wilful killing, extermination, complicity in genocide, deportation and inhumane acts. It is good news for justice and good news for the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina," said Lord Robertson, adding that the net was closing on those suspects who remained at large.

Still at large are Mr Karadzic, the foremost war crimes suspect in Bosnia, and his top general, Ratko Mladic. Mr Krajisnik, Mr Karadzic's senior aide for most of the Bosnian war, replaced him as the leader of Bosnia's Serbs after Mr Karadzic was forced to give up public functions because of his indictment by the war crimes tribunal.

In the Hague, tribunal spokesman Paul Risley said Mr Krajisnik was one of "the individuals who ran illegal operations that resulted in the deaths of thousands of Bosnians. He was present at every meeting where political and military actions were decided upon that resulted in deportations, illegal arrests, ethnic and the deaths of thousands of Bosnians."

Nicknamed "Mister No" by foreign mediators who met him early in the Bosnian conflict, Mr Krajisnik is in his mid 50s. An economist by training, he was an executive of the largest company in Bosnia, Energoinvest, which made parts for Russian nuclear reactors.

Mr Krajisnik became speaker of the Bosnian parliament in 1990, before Serbs walked out and the war began. After the war ended in 1995, he served as the Serb representative on the three-member Bosnian presidency, along with a Croat and a Muslim. Like other leaders in the Bosnian conflict, he was rumoured to have enriched himself through illegal dealings during and after the war.

Amor Masovic, head of the Muslim commission for missing persons, described Mr Krajisnik as "one of the masterminds of the genocide and ethnic cleansing in Bosnia." When Mr Karadzic dropped from sight following the war to avoid arrest by NATO peacekeepers, Mr Krajisnik inherited his mantle as the Serbs' hardline nationalist leader, becoming the senior figure in Bosnia's semi-autonomous Serb republic.

Monday's operation was Nato's 19th detention of Bosnian war crimes suspects since the first such arrest was carried out by British troops in 1997. However more than 20 publicly indicted suspects remain at large. The arrest, coming ahead of next weekend's Bosnian municipal elections, heightened concerns that the voting could be marred by incidents or give a boost to radical nationalist Serbs opposed to reconciliation in Bosnia.

webTitle: The time for internet ventures making mistakes is rapidly running out

fields.headline: The time for internet ventures making mistakes is rapidly running out
fields.standfirst: Part four of their old-media diary finds our two proto-entrepreneurs musing on the motives of their contemporaries
fields.trailText: Having spoken to a number of people who have founded internet businesses, it appears that it is not a simple lust for wealth that drives them - though the desire to share in some of the economic value that is created is obviously real. Instead, most of the enthusiasm appears to stem from the irresistible urge to make an impact.
fields.body:
Since we assembled the core team and began to see our vision take on tangible form, it has become easier to see why entrepreneurs put up with the great stress and emotional ups and downs that come with setting up a business.

The buzz is fantastic and when we went to test the Rools proposition out with potential business partners, we could see a similar thing in some of the people that we talked to.

We want to offer customers as much choice as possible by developing a network of partner retailers for our secure service to young people to shop online independently.

We approached a mixture of established companies that had expanded on to the net from the high street and pure online players. When we meet with the latter it is always with people with a significant stake in the business, often the founders themselves.

Their determination to succeed and the confidence they have in their ability to do so seems to set the tone for the whole organisation, making them appear innovative and exciting places to be.

Having spoken to a number of people who have founded internet businesses, it appears that it is not a simple lust for wealth that drives them - though the desire to share in some of the economic value that is created is obviously real. Instead, most of the enthusiasm appears to stem from the irresistible urge to make an impact.

Indeed focusing on an eventual flotation may distract a new business; even when the shareholder's personal (paper) wealth is doing a Martha and is subject to amazing levels of public interest, it does not appear to be particularly relevant.

More traditional retailers, whose employees are unlikely to have such significant shareholdings nor to have the opportunity to make a massive difference to the business, are having to compete with these highly incentivised and hugely motivated teams. Some of these big businesses appear afraid of this challenge; others are meeting it head on. Freeserve is a good example of how it can be done.

For us, it is the retailers' appreciation of the opportunities presented by the internet and the pace with which they can make things happen that makes them attractive partners. So far we have found that it is the new kids on the block and the more entrepreneurial traditional retailers that are a little quicker to respond. The reaction from these retailers has been over whelmingly positive - one of the founders of a very successful online business even said that he wished he had thought of it first. They see the Rools service as a way of accessing a valuable new market and developing relationships with their customers.

We have had to back away from a few of the retailers who still appear to be grappling with their internet strategies. The good news for some of these businesses is that start-ups still get it wrong - less around the con cept and motivation, and more around the execution. A number of high profile start-ups have seen poor technology, fuzzy marketing and bad customer service.

However, with the capability, resourcefulness and increasing levels of capital investment available to most start-ups, big business cannot afford to wait. Internet start-ups will not be making mistakes for much longer.

webTitle: Dyke unveils his vision for 'one BBC'

fields.headline: Dyke unveils his vision for 'one BBC'
fields.standfirst: The BBC memo in full
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the new director general of the BBC, today told top executives that his aim is to create "one BBC", with less internal competition and less duplication so that staff could concentrate on making programmes.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the new director general of the BBC, today told top executives that his aim is to create "one BBC", with less internal competition and less duplication so that staff could concentrate on making programmes.

In a memo, Mr Dyke told senior staff that the result of taking out a complete level of management means a "flatter and more inclusive" BBC that would result in more collaboration and less internal competition.

"Our aim is to create one BBC, where people enjoy their job and are inspired and united behind the common purpose of making great programmes and delivering outstanding services," Mr Dyke told his top aides before unveiling his plans for reform after the John Birt era.

The new head of the BBC plans to cut the amount of money currently spent on running the corporation from 24% of its total income to 15% over a five-year period.

This will free up £200m a year to be spent on programmes and will help meet the government's target for the BBC of £1.2bn worth of savings over the next seven years.

Most of the £200m will be devoted to producing new drama, entertainment and feature films to increase the profile of BBC1, which has struggled to match its rivals' budgets in recent years.

"Cutting duplication across the BBC should makes us more agile and more flexible, giving us more money to put into the heart of the BBC - the programmes," Mr Dyke said:

Over the next seven years, the BBC will receive an extra £1.4bn in licence fee income under the settlement agreed in February.

Mr Dyke is keen to get away from the management culture that became rampant under John Birt, and wants a return to the BBC's main focus - making programmes.

Although keenly interested in sport programmes, Mr Dyke is anxious to improve the BBC's production of drama and entertainment.

As part of the BBC's overhaul, which will involve cuts in the BBC bureaucracy, Mr Dyke will lead a new executive committee of 17 directors, bringing him closer to key editorial and programming staff.

Of the 17, nine will be broadcasting and programming heads, compared with four in the existing structure. The BBC said this was a deliberate shift in the balance at the top towards the programme and creative interests of the organisation.

The plans are a result of a four-month review. The new structure takes effect from today and is to be implemented fully by the autumn.

fields.headline: From peasant to president
fields.standfirst: Robert Gabrial Mugabe began life as a cowherd but went on to become prime minister and, later, president of Zimbabwe. Derek Brown examines the African leader's rise to power and the increasingly unpopular measures he has employed to cling to it
fields.trailText: Robert Gabrial Mugabe began life as a cowherd but went on to become prime minister and, later, president of Zimbabwe. Derek Brown examines the African leader's rise to power and the increasingly unpopular measures he has employed to cling to it
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe has ruled Zimbabwe for twenty years, taking it from modest prosperity to the brink of economic meltdown. He came to power after the old white-rule regime collapsed, and although he has preached national reconciliation, the country remains deeply divided on ethnic lines - not just between whites and blacks, but between the majority Shona people and the powerful Ndebele and other minority groups.

Throughout his rise to power and since, Mugabe has radiated strength and steely determination. Born on February 21, 1924, he was raised in the north of what was Southern Rhodesia, on a mission settlement in Mashonaland. There he received a Jesuit education, and worked as a cowherd before qualifying as a primary school teacher. Later, he studied at Fort Hare university in South Africa, gaining a BA degree in 1951 followed be a spell of teaching in West Africa, where he acquired a passionate interest in Marxist theory.

In 1960, the year British prime minister Harold Macmillan spoke of the "wind of change" blowing through Africa, Mugabe entered politics, joining the National Democratic Party headed by veteran independence campaigner Joshua Nkomo.

The NDP was banned, and subsequently replaced by the Zimbabwe African People's Union (ZAPU). But soon Mugabe split with Nkomo, and set up his own Zimbabwe African National Union (ZANU). Both parties were quickly banned by the white-rule government.

Mugabe and Nkomo were arrested shortly before Rhodesian prime minister Ian Smith declared unilateral independence from Britain in 1965. Mugabe used his ten years behind bars to study law. By the time he was released in 1974, ZAPU and ZANU had formed a joint guerrilla army, the Patriotic Front, to fight the illegal Smith regime.

The war was vicious and prolonged. In 1980 Rhodesia briefly reverted to British colonial rule and elections were held for the first time with universal suffrage. Many British officials believed that Nkomo, the father of the freedom struggle, would be rewarded by the liberated voters. But Nkomo's power base was in the south, in Ndebeland. Mugabe had the support of the much larger Shona people, and won a landslide victory.

He has ruled ever since, as prime minister and (since 1987) as president. In the beginning, he formed an all-party government, but as early as 1982 he fell out with Nkomo and sacked him from the cabinet. The increasingly autocratic Mugabe has browbeaten, dismissed and intimidated his rivals, to the extent that in the presidential election of 1996, none dared oppose him.

Though the press has remained free, there have also been barely-veiled attempts to stifle criticism of the ZANU-PF ruling party. Radio and television are government controlled, and slavishly pro-Mugabe.

In recent years there has been a rising tide of protest against the authoritarianism and corruption of the regime. Discontent has been fuelled by the parlous state of the economy, where inflation rages and more than half the workforce is unemployed. To add to the nation's misery, an estimated 250,000 people were left homeless by disastrous floods in February and March.

The flashpoint issue now is Mugabe's support for the seizure of white-owned farms by landless peasants - his own kind. Last month the voters of Zimbabwe delivered a stinging rebuke to their president, and voted against the land seizures. Mugabe now says he will go ahead anyway. He has also postponed elections due this spring.

Even more inexplicably, Mugabe has committed a large part of the Zimbabwean army to the support of the Congolese president, Laurent Kabila. The operation is costing £1m a day, and is wildly unpopular. But the peasant boy who became president apparently no longer cares for popularity. He is interested only in clinging on to power.

fields.headline: No place to hide
fields.standfirst: How big a price can a woman pay for standing by her man?  The partner of exiled MI6 whistleblower David Shayler lives and loves on the run - with Big Brother watching her every move
fields.trailText: How big a price can a woman pay for standing by her man?  The partner of exiled MI6 whistleblower David Shayler lives and loves on the run - with Big Brother watching her every move
fields.body:
Annie Machon and her boyfriend, David Shayler, the former MI5 officers now living in Paris, have got used to feeling watched. Their phone plays up. Their emails go missing. Even the walls of their flat seem to look down on them. If they want to discuss "an issue", they find a safe cafe to do it in. A different one each time? "Of course," says Machon with a slight curve to her lips. And in bed? "We have discussed that, yes," she says. "You just try and blank it out and get on with your life."

She is poised and controlled. She remains cool even when recalling "sweaty coppers" reading out her love letters in the course of an interrogation. Even when describing the state of her underwear ("inside out, with the crotches turned up as if they'd been sniffing them") after their flat in Pimlico had been searched.

Machon, who is 31, has been at Shayler's side since he fled to France in 1997 to escape prosecution for breaking the Official Secrets Act when his claims of MI5 incompetence were first published in a Sunday newspaper. They packed for a fortnight. They've been gone two and a half years.

Shayler is a straightforward love or hate figure. He is either the whistleblower, fired by moral purpose to draw attention to bungling within the intelligence services, from revelations that they monitored "subversives" including such threats to national security as Harriet Harman and the reggae band UB40, to his more recent allegations that MI6 was behind an illegal assassination attempt on Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan president. Or, as MI5 would have it (in an interesting mélange of contradictions), he is the traitor, the self-publicist, the breaker of official secrets, the fantasist.

Machon has remained a much more enigmatic figure. At first she was just "Shayler's girlfriend". With her blonde hair and big blue eyes, she looked like a deb, a nursery school teacher, caught up in events beyond her control. A former MI5 officer herself, she made no direct allegations while supporting Shayler in his. But this may not have been caution so much as sound management.

Unlike Shayler (who spent four months in jail before extradition proceedings failed; he is now being sued in the civil courts) she is at liberty to come and go in Britain. "It's important that I remain free to travel, important I remain out of reproach."

Machon was in London to deliver to Scotland Yard a dossier supporting Shayler's Gadafy claims (an MI6 file recently posted on the internet also appears to confirm the allegations). She holds press conferences. She meets with MPs. With lawyers. She wants accountability. She wants freedom of expression. She wants amnesty. She wants Shayler to be listened to. Taken seriously. To be allowed home. Then she wants to be left alone.

We meet at Vauxhall underground station, close by the MI6 building, although she doesn't want to hang around long. The closest cafe is too close. She walks very fast to the next. She doesn't look over her shoulder once. She sees connections where others might see blank walls. There are advertisements for laptops nearby. She refers to the recent stories of the mugged MI5 officer, whose laptop was nicked and the drunken MI6 officer who mislaid his. "What a coincidence," she smiles sardonically. If she and Shayler win their case, she says she doesn't think they'll ever come back to London. "Dave would feel quite uncomfortable living here," she says. "I would too. It's just that sense of unease all the time."

She is all in black, although her nails are gold. She is pale and slim, unlike Shayler whose plumpness in photographs can make him look like a yob. ("He put on weight at MI5, actually. Socialising after work - that drinking culture he talked about - and also a sense of unease. He eats when he's feeling stressed. He's joined a health club now. He swims nearly every day.")

It's not the only reason they seem an unlikely couple. A Middlesbrough boy, with working-class roots, Shayler is said to be chippy about public-school Oxbridge types.

Machon, who is the daughter of a pilot turned newspaperman, and from an old Guernsey family, went to a private girls' school and then to Cambridge, where she studied classics. "Yes, yes, I know. I think he did think I was a bit posh at first, but he squared it with the fact that I was a scholarship girl. Also we both moved around a lot when we were young. We had that in common."

Machon says that as soon as they met in an MI5 library they made each other laugh and that their relationship is "passionate". There are hints of that in her story. The night before she came back to England for the first time, suspecting she would be arrested, but not sure whether they would confiscate her passport, they lay in bed and held each other and cried, "not knowing when we would see each other again". Then, after 10 months in hiding at a farmhouse in south-west France, when he was suddenly taken into custody, for days she walked around with "no one's hand in mine".

Interestingly, too, while Machon looks as though butter wouldn't melt in her mouth, she found out soon after joining MI5 (after sitting the foreign office exams), that psychological profiling had marked her out as a maverick. "I was having a bit of a debate with my manager in the office and she said, 'I've been warned about you'." She smiles enigmatically. "I was quite flattered."

She and Shayler had already left MI5 when Shayler decided to go public, both had nice well-paid jobs as management consultants. They had a nice social life, nice Pimlico flat. She didn't want him to go to the papers. "It wasn't so much doubt as fear. I knew they'd come after us and I knew what they could do against us. If you've worked for MI5 it doesn't help your paranoia, put it that way."

She slips a lighter out of her cigarette packet and lights up. "And I must say I was shown to be right. Not that I'd ever say I told you so to Dave."

The papers ran the story on a bank holiday weekend. Machon and Shayler got the last plane out of Heathrow on the Saturday night, to Amsterdam. They braced themselves. Then Diana, Princess of Wales was killed. "In one sense it was a relief because the pressure was taken off us. In another it was terrible. An injunction had been put on the paper and if she hadn't died, Fleet Street would have been up in arms about gagging the free press, they would have been more balanced in their assessment of Dave, demanding inquiries. As it was, there were a lot of backroom briefings against him, saying he was a loudmouth, unbalanced, and we were buried there."

She uses the word "buried" a lot. It's hard to tell whether it is a good thing or a bad thing for someone who needs publicity ("it's our only protection") and yet longs to hide. On the run, they "buried themselves" in the French countryside, a different hotel every night, paying cash.

After that they were "buried" again in a remote farmhouse near Perpignan, "freezing cold, miles from the shops", living off their £40,000 newspaper earnings, where Shayler wrote his novel (it has since been banned) and she kept house. The British government pretended to negotiate with them, she says. "They thought we'd run out of money and rot abroad. They wanted to bury us."

It was only when Shayler was in prison, when the worst had happened, that she got her confidence back. "I found I was tougher than I thought. Dave had always been the more ebullient character. And suddenly when he was arrested, even though I was desperately lonely, it was, 'Right, you've got to do it.'"

Actually, there was worse to come: an approach by an armed Libyan a week after Shayler's release. He offered a six-figure sum in exchange for names linked to the Gadafy plot and evidence on Lockerbie (Shayler had been an expert). He followed them when they refused. A few nights later their buzzer rang for five minutes in the night: "We cowered in the corner with our kitchen knives." They reported the incident to MI5, and were told it was a matter for the French, who told them it was a matter for the Brits.

What does Machon hope for now? She says she can't think what to do with her life. "I'm a different person to the one I was two years ago." Maybe an old house in Normandy: Shayler could continue writing, novels, his column for Punch.

What about children? "I don't want those. Neither of us does. We never have. I'm not at all maternal. I've never felt the desire. My brother is 11 years younger and I don't have a romantic view of children. I know what they're like."

I was going to suggest that when she hits her mid-30s she might change her mind, but then I saw the look in her eye and changes of mind didn't seem to come into it.

As it was, there were a lot of backroom briefings against him, saying he was a loudmouth, unbalanced, and we were buried there." She uses the word "buried" a lot. It's hard to tell whether it is a good thing or a bad thing for someone who needs publicity ("it's our only protection") and yet longs to hide. On the run, they "buried themselves" in the French countryside, a different hotel every night, paying cash. After that they were "buried" again in a remote farmhouse near Perpignan, "freezing cold, miles from the shops", living off their £40,000 newspaper earnings, where Shayler wrote his novel (it has since been banned) and she kept house. The British government pretended to negotiate with them, she says. "They thought we'd run out of money and rot abroad. They wanted to bury us." It was only when Shayler was in prison, when the worst had happened, that she got her confidence back. "I found I was tougher than I thought. Dave had always been the more ebullient character. And suddenly when he was arrested, even though I was desperately lonely, it was, 'Right, you've got to do it.'" Actually, there was worse to come: an approach by an armed Libyan a week after Shayler's release. He offered a six-figure sum in exchange for names linked to the Gadafy plot and evidence on Lockerbie (Shayler had been an expert). He followed them when they refused. A few nights later their buzzer rang for five minutes in the night: "We cowered in the corner with our kitchen knives." They reported the incident to MI5, and were told it was a matter for the French, who told them it was a matter for the Brits. What does Machon hope for now? She says she can't think what to do with her life. "I'm a different person to the one I was two years ago." Maybe an old house in Normandy: Shayler could continue writing, novels, his column for Punch. What about children? "I don't want those. Neither of us does. We never have. I'm not at all maternal. I've never felt the desire. My brother is 11 years younger and I don't have a romantic view of children. I know what they're like." I was going to suggest that when she hits her mid-30s she might change her mind, but then I saw the look in her eye and changes of mind didn't seem to come into it.

fields.headline: The BBC memo in full
fields.trailText: The BBC's Director-General, Greg Dyke, has today unveiled both the BBC's new management structure and the names of the senior executives who will drive the BBC forward in the early years of the 21st century.
fields.body:
The BBC's Director-General, Greg Dyke, has today unveiled both the BBC's new management structure and the names of the senior executives who will drive the BBC forward in the early years of the 21st century.

The key things the changes are designed to bring over the next few years are:

 More money into programmes and services - at least £100m in the new financial year with our proportionate spend in this area moving from 76% up to 85% . We have tough savings targets set by government - at least £1 for £1, needing £1bn over 7 years. This is an extra £490m over our existing, challenging savings plans.

 Programmes, creativity and channel interests come closer to the heart of the organisation - 4 representatives currently, up to 9 on the new top team.

 "One BBC" - a flatter, more inclusive structure. More collaboration, less internal competition, less management.

 We become more agile, flexible and adaptive with speedier responses and faster decision making to cope with the speed of change in the market.

 Broadcasting and programme production come closer. Programme guarantees are introduced for in-house production, including in the Nations and Regions; plus re-integration of commissioning and production in Sport, Childrens and Education. This frees in-house production departments to focus on creativity, while accepting the best ideas from independents as part of our 25% television quota.

Further information:

Greg told BBC staff in a special session this morning that his aim in the next five years is to reduce the amount of money currently spent on running the BBC from 24% of its total income to 15% over a five year period. This will free up an additional £200m a year to be spent on programmes and will help meet the government's savings target for the BBC of £1.2bn worth of savings over the next seven years.

Greg also announced that the BBC will be spending at least £100m more on BBC programming and services in the coming year.

Greg said: "As a result of the review we have taken out a complete level of management in the new structure. It's flatter, inclusive, and will result in more collaboration and less internal competition; more leadership and less management. We are also rationalising our support services, which have expanded markedly in recent years.

"Our aim is to create One BBC, where people enjoy their job and are inspired and united behind the common purpose of making great programmes and delivering outstanding services."

BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland has explained that Greg's plans have been discussed at length and in detail with the board of governors over the last six weeks.

Sir Christopher said: "We need to adapt our organisation structure to encourage creativity, to speed up our decision-making, to communicate more effectively internally and externally, to obtain significant savings and to enhance the value we provide to licence fee payers in a highly competitive world. We believe that Greg's plans will achieve these objectives."

Greg will lead a new executive committee of 17 directors, bringing him closer to key editorial and programming decisions and bringing the creative community closer to him. Of the 17, nine will be broadcasting and programming heads, compared with four in the existing executive. This is a deliberate shift in the balance of the top level committee towards the programme, creative and channel interests of the BBC.

Six professional service divisions are created to be responsible for all administrative services across the BBC.

Greg said: "Cutting duplication across the BBC should make us more agile and more flexible, giving us more money to put into the heart of the BBC - the programmes."

A new leadership group, involving the top 50 or 60 people in the BBC, will foster greater cross fertilisation of ideas and provide a forum where they can learn more about developments across the whole organisation and the outside world.

The plans are the result of a four-month review undertaken by a small team that listened to the views of many people throughout the BBC.

Key changes include:

 the creation of four programming divisions:
- Drama, Entertainment and Children
- Factual and Learning
- Sport
- News

 abolition of Broadcast and Production directorate HQs

 in the areas of sport, childrens and education, commissioning and programme-making will be re-integrated

 a New Media division will develop the BBC's interactive television and online activities

 TV genre commissioners in drama, entertainment and features. These commissioners will work with the television channel controllers to strengthen the BBC's output in these areas the

 disbanding of the Independent Commissioning Group. The BBC values the contribution of independents, but in future they will take the same commissioning routes as in-house producers

 output guarantees for in-house departments, including Nations and English Regions, and longer-term commissions to enable better planning and greater focus on creativity

 BBC Radio takes over full responsibility for Radio 5-Live commissioning

 Music Production moves into the Radio Division to work more closely with the networks they serve. They will also produce classical music programmes for television

 simplified internal trading - the business units will be reduced from 190 to 50

 the Corporate Centre, including Policy and Planning and Corporate Affairs, disappear. Instead, six Professional Service Divisions will support the BBC overall. They are: Public Policy; Human Resources and Internal Communications; Distribution and Technology; Finance, Property and Business Affairs; Marketing and Communications; and Strategy

 reporting structures in the Nations and Regions are unchanged but the division moves one step closer to the Director-General with the director sitting on the Executive Committee

 in Birmingham, Bristol and Manchester one operational head will be asked to lead the BBC's activities in each centre.

 News, apart from the move of Radio 5-Live commissioning, remains unchanged. BBC Worldwide, BBC World Service and BBC Resources are largely unchanged.

 The new structure takes effect from today (April 3rd). An implementation team will work with each director to draw up detailed plans within two months, for full implementation by the autumn.

fields.headline: Reality belies proud statistics
fields.standfirst: China Tough problems undermine undoubted achievements
fields.trailText: The sight of cheerful children heading to and from school is one of the strongest testimonials to China's success in promoting education under communist rule since 1949. No matter how remote the rural village or how depressed the urbanenvironment, the kids invariably have shoes on their feet and book-bags on their back.
fields.body:
The sight of cheerful children heading to and from school is one of the strongest testimonials to China's success in promoting education under communist rule since 1949. No matter how remote the rural village or how depressed the urbanenvironment, the kids invariably have shoes on their feet and book-bags on their back.

In March the ministry of education (MOE) got to grips with a problem that has been worrying the country - the risk of strained backs among China's young.

The MOE cut the amount of teaching material children at primary and secondary school are supposed to study and reduced the homework requirements. It said this was not only an effort to shift teaching away from the traditional Chinese emphasis on textual study: it was also designed to "lighten the student's bags".

Most developing countries would say that China should be lucky to have to deal with such problems. They would also concede that with an official illiteracy rate of only 5.5%, and primary attendance of 98%, China is in a different class altogether.

Yet the figures do not always tell the whole truth; China has considerable problems. Some of them have been created by the rapid changes of the post-Mao society, but others reflect long-standing disadvantage among those who remain deprived.

In the arid north-west province of Gansu, the official rate for primary attendance is the national 98%, but the real rate may be only 60-70%. Schools in one rural county where water is scarce have even offered the children bottles of water to lure them to class.

Four poor rural counties in Gansu are now being targeted in a basic education project funded by the British Department for International Development (DFID).

One project manager said: "Only 25% of the kids who enrol make it through to the grade 4-5 of primary. In one of the counties, where the population is Muslim, none of them are girls."

School material is poor to non-existent; the nominal equipment budget is a mere six renminbi (45p) a term, and it hardly ever reaches the school.

"They have a kind of blackboard and some have pencils, but they very rarely have paper," the project manager said. "They practise writing characters with sticks in the dust."

Gansu's difficulties may be at one end of the scale, but they illustrate common problems throughout the system. Too often the official statistics are massaged by local officials to achieve targets set from above.

"Everyone is enrolled for the first day of school and the school gets properly certified. But no one investigates when the rate goes down," a consultant to the DFID said.

The problem of under-funding is widespread, to the point where headteachers think it important to mention that "here our teachers get paid in full and on time!"

In 1985, responsibility for education was handed from central government to the province, and then to the county and township. But even when local authorities got the same funding, there were temptations to divert it.

As teachers lost prestige, it became harder to fill posts in rural schools. The MOE has only begun to reverse this trend in the past two years.

Higher education has been largely liberated from the ideological straitjacket of the cultural revolution and can now provide avenues for advancement. But parents who wish their children to succeed must pay substantial sums and the competitive pressures for college places are intense.

In February, the case of a secondary school student in Zhejiang province who killed his mother because she nagged him to work harder hit the national headlines.

As a result, President Jiang Zemin weighed in with a speech saying that the students' workload must be reduced. Parents and teachers, he said, should pay more attention to turning young Chinese into "healthy adults".

Such exhortations will hardly reduce the pressure in a system where only 10.5% of young people aged 18-24 have access to higher education. A new target has now been set to raise this to 15%.

Students also complain that entrance standards to prestigious colleges, such as those in Beijing and Shanghai, are lowered for local entrants.

In the past a bright applicant from rural Gansu had an equal chance with the offspring of the urban middle class; in deed, during the cultural revolution he or she even had a better chance, because of reverse discrimination in favour of "workers and peasants".

Student fees, which were once nominal, can now be a heavy burden, even on parents with only one child. The latest survey shows that in urban China, secondary school students must pay 800-1,440 renminbi (£60-110) for each of the two school terms. College students can pay up to £370 a term.

In rural schools, though fees are still low, textbooks cost £5-£9 each term - significant sums in communities where annual income for each person may range from £23-£140.

China has also abolished the "two guarantees" under which college students enjoyed free tuition and maintenance - and were then assigned a job.

"Students used to say that once I enter the gates of university, I shall be taken care of by the state," says a college pro fessor. "Now we have broken this pattern and expanded the choices of both students and society."

They must now find their fees and compete for jobs.

There is considerable debate now in the MOE about what should be done in disciplines which have less "market value". One proposed strategy is to shift the balance away from general to vocational education, which will produce students with more marketable skills.

A modest start is at last being made to diversify the national curriculum, which so far has been uniform throughout the country. The MOE has initiated a more flexible system, with an 80% national core and 20% local choice. But objectors say that only rich communities with money and resources can take advantage of this: poor schools simply stick to the core.

"The best way of developing the economy is to develop education," said an education minister at the recent national people's congress. "Without knowledge, what can we rely on?"

But the problem is for education to keep pace with economic change. China has so far found it easier to allot money to costly new construction projects and encourage entrepreneurs than to modernise schools and give teachers an adequate reward.

Numbers tell the story vedufacts In the 1997/8 economic crisis in East Asia the big donors mobilised $100bn (£62.9bn) in a few months to save the tiger economies.

Education for All would cost $7bn a year - less than Americans spend on cosmetics. Governments with large debts can not move towards Education for All. Tanzania is not untypical in spending six times more on debt repayments than on education.

Sub-Saharan Africa, where education is in deepest crisis, receives less than 10% of the World Bank's education lending. The bank's education lending in Africa dropped from $400m in 1993 to $50m in 1997, $300m in 1998. Disbursements dropped from $400m in 1994 to $200m in 1998.

In or after armed conflict, reopening schools is the first step to giving children a sense of normality in the midst of chaos.

Erosion of salaries in Africa means that primary school teachers often receive less than half the amount of a household on the absolute poverty line.

What you can do to help

Write today to Tony Blair asking him to launch a global plan to generate the $7bn needed each year to get every child into school by 2015

Get involved now in the global week of action (April 3-10). Ring 01865 313123 to find out more

Sign the e-petition to Tony Blair on www.oxfam.org.uk/ educationnow/

See more on literacy at www.educationunlimited.co.uk with interactive graphics, extensive links and a photo gallery of classrooms around the world

female 95%

reaching grade four 92%

Literacy

male 89%

female 72%

Chances of being illiterate

60-year-old 60%

10 to15-year-old 6%

fields.headline: The Enigma machine
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the second world war encryption device on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the second world war encryption device on the net
fields.body:
1. 81223 251521 851184 2085 1452319? The Enigma code encryption machine has been stolen from Bletchley Park.

2. The Enigma is one of only three examples of its type in existence. The thief outwitted Bletchley Park's volunteer staff to reach the machine, opened its glass case and left via the only exit in the building.

3. Breaking the Enigma code was Bletchley's major piece of intelligence work in the second world war. It enabled the allies to discover German U-boat movements and the information gleaned was used in the battle of the Atlantic.

4. Enigma differed from previous codes in being mechanically generated. Messages were typed into a keyboard and encoded by activating three rotors, which could be set in a number of different positions.

5. This meant that a message could be encoded in 150 million million million ways. It was only by intercepting German broadcasts of the settings that the code could ever be broken.

6. A 'Turing Bombe' was built at Bletchley to run through thousands of possible combinations each second and assist in the decrypting process. This computing machine led to the development of the first computers.

7. The man who led the project was Alan Turing, a scientist whose took his own life after the British establishment attempted to 'cure' his homosexuality.

8. He predicted that by the year 2000 it would be difficult to distinguish between the replies of a human and a computer.

9. Other encoding machines exist but none was so hard to break as the Enigma. Long-established codes such as the Morse could not approach its sophistication.

10. Modern-day codebreakers might like to try the GCHQ challenge or the Codebreaker Crossword online.

fields.headline: Waiting for Warne
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we ask a county cricketer what he's been up to in the close season. This week we talk to Hampshire offspinner Shaun Udal
fields.trailText: Hampshire offspinner Shaun Udal, 31, has played ten one-day internationals for England. He made his county debut in 1989 and now lives in Basingstoke with his wife, Emma, and two children, Katherine (seven) and Rebecca (four).
fields.body:
Hampshire offspinner Shaun Udal, 31, has played ten one-day internationals for England. He made his county debut in 1989 and now lives in Basingstoke with his wife, Emma, and two children, Katherine (seven) and Rebecca (four).

"I'm just on my way back from Wales where we've been getting ready for the season. We've been down at the Celtic Manor Resort just outside Newport for four days which is an absolutely amazing place. The facilities are just incredible and even the weather's been all right. We couldn't have asked for a better start before we get outside in the nets on Monday.

I've been running through the valleys and over the hills, doing all that stuff which the coaches love. It was a real laugh going paintballing, orienteering and playing golf - all in the name of team-building. I really enjoyed the golf down here because I don't usually get a chance to play enough to get my handicap down from 14.

The paintballing was good and you have to really think, as well as make sure you don't get shot. You've got to think about sneaking up on the enemy and taking them by surprise. Something we'll hopefully be using on the cricket field. My team came second behind the Judge's [Robin Smith]. But he didn't do too well when it came to the orienteering. He was very much last in the competition and kept on getting lost. But what do you expect when you let a South African loose in Wales? He probably kept on bumping into sheep out there.

I was able to enjoy all this running around much more this year because I've been on an intensive six-week gym session with a personal trainer. I've realised that it's even more important to keep fit as you get older. I've been doing a lot of cardio-vascular and strength work. It's good to have someone watching over you who makes you do it. I never used to like it but now it's all part of the job. Jimmy Cook [Hampshire's new coach] is really keen on it as well, so I don't have a choice.

I made sure that I spent a lot of time with my family over Christmas, which was really important to me. I just had a quiet time at home. I was lucky to be able to go back to the printing firm [7 Corners Printing Group] where I worked as a salesman last winter. They've been really understanding and want me back next year. I've managed to fit everything in and juggle the two careers pretty well. Although I wasn't able to go on Smithy's tour to South Africa. The tours are a real laugh and I was a bit disappointed not to go. I just couldn't fit it all in, not with my family as well.

I'm looking forward to the season, we're all really excited about Warney coming over. I spoke to him on the phone last week and he can't wait to get here. He seems to be a big fan of Hampshire already and we're determined to give him a number-one welcome for the world No. 1. We're going to have a dinner and then a few beers the night that he arrives. It's going to be great bowling with him and he's certainly going to pull in the crowds."

fields.headline: How the geeks got chic
fields.standfirst: Print magazines about the net used to be nerdy and dull. But a hip new breed of glossy titles from the US is set to change all that.
fields.trailText: Print magazines about the net used to be nerdy and dull. But a hip new breed of glossy titles from the US is set to change all that.
fields.body:
Marketspeak Lament is a poem by a tortured Silicon Valley soul which appears in the first issue of Slam, a new arts magazine for e-heads launching on the US west coast. Set up by Arthur Zawacki - who made enough money from the sale of his electronic gaming business Origin Systems that he need never work again - Slam will be an outlet for businessmen and women in cyberspace aching for something a little more real. The debut issue also features an acrylic painting of a sheep by hi-tech venture capitalist Tim Draper.

Sadly, while it is only too plausible, Slam doesn't exist. Its one and only appearance, in the latest edition of US technology magazine Red Herring, is an elaborate spoof - and proof that while British press coverage of the digerati is still in a lather about all those young bucks earning paper millions, the US has clearly moved on. As Marketspeak Lament illustrates, a keen sense of cyber-irony is emerging across the Atlantic.

According to ABC figures, the British market for consumer internet magazines doubled in total circulation last year. But those aimed at the web community remain po-faced - little more than regurgitated press releases put together with postage-stamp headshots of men in suits.

But that could be about to change. Red Herring and its rival monthly Business 2.0 are to the internet industry what Wallpaper was to interior design - and both are coming to Britain. The latest issue of the beautifully produced Red Herring pays homage on its front cover to Vanity Fair's annual movie issue, with a line-up of entrepreneurs photographed in black and white by Helmut Newton.

Red Herring, which began life in 1993 as a trade magazine for Silicon Valley venture capitalists, opened a London office and gained distribution across Europe with its December edition. The European edition has its own front cover, although the content is the same as the US.

"Technology publications used to be geeky," notes Red Herring's international editor Kenneth Cukier. "Sure, some of these guys may have spent 10 years in front of a computer screen and couldn't get a date. But now they are it . They've become the coolest guys around. Technology has become mainstream; that's why we can get the likes of Helmut Newton."

Red Herring and Business 2.0 represent a significant change to the coverage of technology in this country and, if they succeed, will say much about the maturity of the new economy. Like Wired or Fast Company, these magazines have become publishing phenomena in the US, and other titles with similar production standards are rushing to market. Cukier compares the Herring - with its features on the European mobile phone scene, online gambling and the marriage of the internet and Hollywood - with Forbes or Fortune.

Business 2.0 - the name is a play on the titles of software upgrades - is owned by the British publishing company Future Networks. It launched in the US in July 1998 and is already on course to become the company's biggest earner. It has a track record that a dot.com start-up could only dream of. Revenues in its second year should reach $50m, blue-chip advertisers include IBM and Cisco Systems, and it is forecast to move into profit in the next 12 months.

Like Red Herring - which has doubled in size in the past year - Business 2.0 is bulky, with the current edition weighing in at a back-breaking 450 pages. Far from seeing new media flattening traditional media, magazine houses are finding the internet is a launch pad for new titles. Business 2.0's circulation rose last year from 137,500 to 210,000 and its frequency is about to be doubled to once a fortnight. Red Herring' s sales are around 300,000.

The launch editor of the UK edition of Business 2.0 is Mark Halper, an American who has spent the past five years in Silicon Valley as a contributor to the US edition. The UK market, generally held to be two years behind the US in the internet, is ripe for the launch, he says. "I've been here for six months and seen how the internet economy is catching on. You can hear the buzz just walking around London.

"This title is a general business publication with the internet as a unifying theme. But there is an element of lifestyle - and one of the reasons is that in the new economy people's lives do seem to be intertwined with their work. They like working for new economy companies for the lifestyle."

From the outset, 60% of the content of Business 2.0's British edition will be provided by the local editorial team; and where the US edition has Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos on its advisory board, the UK board will include Freeserve's chief executive, John Pluthero. Future also hopes to launch German and French editions in the autumn.

The company thinks it can build Business 2.0 into a global brand - and a glance at its advertisers helps explain its confidence. Companies buying space across the titles include Anderson Consulting, Chase Manhattan, Goldman Sachs and Sun Microsystems - plus lifestyle companies such as clothing retailer Banana Republic, hoping to woo all dot.com millionaires with money to burn.

For those of us who missed out on the millions, it seems a shame that the spoof magazine Slam doesn't really exist. It would be nice to think that behind all that cash and hard work those entrepreneurs are looking for something a little more real. But perhaps that is why the internet-literate are flocking to buy such an old-fashioned object as a magazine.

A magazine, Halper adds, can give a sense of stability in a world which by its nature is changing constantly. "I still think people want a magazine to save and read and inhale, whereas the stuff they read on the web is more here today, gone tomorrow."

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Joshua Jackson talks politcs, Ewan McGregor trailer online, Jakie Chan loses popularity contest, Erin Brockovich still on top, and Jennifer Lopez and Faye Dunaway on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Joshua Jackson, star of this week's US release The Skulls, talks politics. The film is inspired by a real-life Yale University society of which George Bush Snr and Jnr were once members. Jackson tells Entertainment Weekly that the society's rituals were kinkier than even the film depicts: they included "getting shot up with Sodium Pentothal, lying naked with another member for
a round of Liar's Hell [a prolonged game of Truth], and 'the actor's favourite' masturbating in a coffin". Says Jackson, "if George W. becomes president, I won't be able to look at him without laughing. I mean, c'mon, he was wankin' in a coffin at Yale".

 A trailer for Natural Nylon's film about James Joyce and his wife Nora Barnacle, which stars Ewan McGregor as the eye-patched scribe, has gone at line at Empire's website. Click here to view it.

 Jackie Chan has lost his popularity crown to Chow Yun-Fat in a Hong Kong-based poll, the BBC reports. This year's version of the annual poll awarded the Anna and the King star 18 percent of the vote, while Chan could muster a pifling 7 percent. Experts - they take these matters seriously in Hong Kong - speculate that a well-publicised affair, which resulted in an illegitimate child, may have lost the Chan crucial percentage points. "The drop in Jackie Chan's ranking may or may not be related to his recent scandal", says Anthony Lau, chairman of the Hong Kong Advertisers' Association that sponsored the survey.

 The Julia Roberts vehicle Erin Brockovich remains top of the US box office for a third week. DreamWorks' animated The Road to El Dorado is second, beating out the campus thriller The Skulls. Stephen Frears' Nick
Hornby adaptation, High Fidelity, starring John Cusack, is in fifth spot.

 Gwyneth Paltrow is to star in a film co-written by Jennifer Jason Leigh and camp Scottish star Alan Cumming . Leigh and Cumming starred together in the Broadway musical Cabaret, directed by Sam Mendes, and are to co-direct their own screenplay, The Anniversary Dinner. The duo play a childless married couple who celebrate their sixth wedding anniversary together with friends and family. Wow - sounds crazy.

 Jennifer Lopez is to star in Gregory Nava's Bordertown, a thriller in which a female journalist investigates a string of murders near the American-owned factories on the Juarez/El Paso border.

 Faye Dunaway is to star in The Biographer, the movie about Princess Diana's confidante Andrew Morton. Dunaway, star of Chinatown and Bonnie and Clyde, plays a journalist covering the Royal Family.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
You just can't keep the staff these days, particularly if they happen to be new-media chiefs in traditional-media companies.

Martin Dunn, who resigned as editor-in-chief of Associated New Media to set up Front of Mind, says, "Traditional media companies face a problem that a new industry has sprung up around them". He says their brands have been ambushed by the financial might of start-up dotcoms, many of them information-providers.

Ellis Watson, who left News International after launching CurrantBun.com and is now chief executive at start-up Talkcast, says traditional media boardrooms "don't encourage an entrepreneurial spirit because they don't want to take people off their existing workload. They need to unlock their best human assets and make them work across all media. They need to be platform-agnostic rather than platform-dependent."

Watson doesn't buy the argument that traditional media companies can't match the sort of salaries for their staff which are being offered by dot-coms. "It's not about venture capital, it's about operational energies. At least half of all venture capital is pissed up the wall on what already exists anyway."

 Ravi Chandiramani in Revolution www.revolution.haynet.com

Why has media criticism flourished online? In part, it's because magazines of media criticism have not been especially aggressive in their approach to the Web.

Secondly, the Web has helped bring many traditional media analysts to a wider audience. This includes not only mainstream critics, such as The Washington Post's Howard Kurtz, but also organizations that devote themselves to media analysis.

There has also been a proliferation of media reporting and criticism that exists solely on the Net. Both Slate and Salon are saturated with media-focused stories and tidbits, but true junkies turn to Jim Romenesko's MediaNews.

One tremendous advantage online media critics enjoy is timeliness. On the internet, as soon as you're ready to publish, you can publish. "You never have to worry about being scooped," says Susan Lehman, who edited and wrote media stories for Salon.com for three and a half years.

Still in its infancy, the internet has yet to produce a single source of media criticism as popular as, say, Matt Drudge. No site has yet combined the most compelling advantages of the Net with intelligent, vibrant criticism - and the reporting resources needed to back it up.

 James Ledbetter in Columbia Journalism Review www.cjr.org

fields.headline: Zimbabwe in crisis
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, is meeting Zimbabwean ministers in London, to discuss British aid for land reform as a way of defusing the violence in the country. Mark Tran, Derek Brown and Guardian foreign editor Ed Pilkington look at the deepening political crisis
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, is meeting Zimbabwean ministers in London, to discuss British aid for land reform as a way of defusing the violence in the country. Mark Tran and Guardian foreign editor Ed Pilkington look at the deepening political crisis
fields.body:
What are today's talks about?
Britain has said it is willing to offer an extra £36m in aid for Zimbabwe's land reform programme provided the Harare government restores order. London wants the squatters to leave the land they have occupied and insists that the government pay fair prices for farms it wants to buy for redistribution.

Why is that any concern of Britain's?
President Robert Mugabe says Britain has a moral responsibility because of its colonial history to pay for land transfers. Britain did fund a land redistribution programme in the 1980s but stopped in the 1990s, saying it was being used to benefit Mr Mugabe's cronies and government supporters. British aid to Zimbabwe, most of it currently channelled through non-governmental organisations, has fallen from £17m two years ago to £12m this year.

What is the white farmer issue about?
Land, one of the key issues on which the war against Rhodesian rule was fought in the 70s. Since independence in 1980, Mr Mugabe has carried out limited redistribution, buying white-owned farms and turning them over to poor blacks. But in past weeks, hundreds of white-owned farms have been occupied by black squatters claiming the land as their own. It is widely believed that the campaign is orchestrated by the government through the secret service and clashes have broken out. Mr Mugabe refuses to grant compensation to the white farmers, saying it should come from Britain.

What is the pattern of land ownership?
About 4,500 white farmers own 11m hectares of Zimbabwe's prime agricultural land, while about 1m blacks own 16 million hectares, often in drought-prone regions. Where they do exist side by side, huge, modern, mechanised estates are divided by a mere fence from subsistence farmers living in mud huts. The situation dates back to colonial times when blacks were forced off their ancestral lands. In the current crisis, about 600 white-owned farms have been occupied by a mixture of war veterans, unemployed urban youths and peasants.

How is the economy doing?
Inflation is running at 60%, unemployment at 50% and there are severe shortages of fuel. A big drain on resources is the civil war in Congo, where the president, Laurent Kabila, is fighting rebels backed by Uganda and Rwanda. Harare has devoted 11,000 troops to shore up Mr Kabila - at a cost of about £1m a day. From being the "hope of Africa", Zimbabwe is sinking into poverty. Mr Mugabe's campaign against white farmers threatens to make the economic crisis worse.

Who are the squatters?
About 15% are veterans of the Rhodesia war and the rest are Zanu-PF supporters and unemployed youths. Many are being paid Z$50 (83p) a day to occupy the farms, according to Zimbabwe's Financial Gazette newspaper. Government vehicles are also reportedly delivering supplies to the squatters.

What do Zimbabweans think of Mr Mugabe's policy on white farms?
Earlier this year, Mr Mugabe put the redistribution of white-owned land to a referendum. Zimbabweans voted against, in a victory for the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition movement, led by Morgan Tsvangirai.

Who is Mr Tsvangirai?
Mr Tsvangirai leads the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), the most serious challenger to Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the general election that has been postponed until May. A relentless critic of the government he describes as "top-down, centralised and not accountable to the people", he has built up a huge following through his leadership of the ZCTU, an umbrella of 27 unions with 400,000 registered members, or about a third of the labour force. He says of the current situation: "The people say they are suffering and the government tells them to shut up."

What is MDC's attitude to the occupation of white-owned farms?
Tendai Biti, a lawyer prominent in the MDC, says: "Zanu-PF sponsored and masterminded the farm invasions. We have come to expect that madness and lack of respect for rule of law by Zanu-PF." But Mr Mugabe shows no sign of easing up on his policy. He is desperate to win the vote of rural Zimbabweans, estimated to be about 65% of the country's 12m people.

Land, one of the key issues on which the war against Rhodesian rule was fought in the 70s. Since independence in 1980, Mr Mugabe has carried out limited redistribution, buying white-owned farms and turning them over to poor blacks. But in past weeks, hundreds of white-owned farms have been occupied by black squatters claiming the land as their own. It is widely believed that the campaign is orchestrated by the government through the secret service and clashes have broken out. Mr Mugabe refuses to grant compensation to the white farmers, saying it should come from Britain. What is the pattern of land ownership? About 4,500 white farmers own 11m hectares of Zimbabwe's prime agricultural land, while about 1m blacks own 16 million hectares, often in drought-prone regions. Where they do exist side by side, huge, modern, mechanised estates are divided by a mere fence from subsistence farmers living in mud huts. The situation dates back to colonial times when blacks were forced off their ancestral lands. In the current crisis, about 600 white-owned farms have been occupied by a mixture of war veterans, unemployed urban youths and peasants. How is the economy doing? Inflation is running at 60%, unemployment at 50% and there are severe shortages of fuel. A big drain on resources is the civil war in Congo, where the president, Laurent Kabila, is fighting rebels backed by Uganda and Rwanda. Harare has devoted 11,000 troops to shore up Mr Kabila - at a cost of about £1m a day. From being the "hope of Africa", Zimbabwe is sinking into poverty. Mr Mugabe's campaign against white farmers threatens to make the economic crisis worse. Who are the squatters? About 15% are veterans of the Rhodesia war and the rest are Zanu-PF supporters and unemployed youths. Many are being paid Z$50 (83p) a day to occupy the farms, according to Zimbabwe's Financial Gazette newspaper. Government vehicles are also reportedly delivering supplies to the squatters. What do Zimbabweans think of Mr Mugabe's policy on white farms? Earlier this year, Mr Mugabe put the redistribution of white-owned land to a referendum. Zimbabweans voted against, in a victory for the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition movement, led by Morgan Tsvangirai. Who is Mr Tsvangirai? Mr Tsvangirai leads the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), the most serious challenger to Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the general election that has been postponed until May. A relentless critic of the government he describes as "top-down, centralised and not accountable to the people", he has built up a huge following through his leadership of the ZCTU, an umbrella of 27 unions with 400,000 registered members, or about a third of the labour force. He says of the current situation: "The people say they are suffering and the government tells them to shut up." What is MDC's attitude to the occupation of white-owned farms? Tendai Biti, a lawyer prominent in the MDC, says: "Zanu-PF sponsored and masterminded the farm invasions. We have come to expect that madness and lack of respect for rule of law by Zanu-PF." But Mr Mugabe shows no sign of easing up on his policy. He is desperate to win the vote of rural Zimbabweans, estimated to be about 65% of the country's 12m people. webTitle: Jaws author sides with great white

fields.headline: Jaws author sides with great white
fields.trailText: The man most responsible for creating a fear of great white sharks with his novel Jaws is now campaigning to save them. He hopes to "de-demonise" the creatures whose numbers are falling dramatically.
fields.body:
The man most responsible for creating a fear of great white sharks with his novel Jaws is now campaigning to save them. He hopes to "de-demonise" the creatures whose numbers are falling dramatically.

Peter Benchley is the author of Jaws, which was both a best-selling novel and, in 1975, a box-office hit film directed by Steven Spielberg. The haunting theme music has become synonymous with fear. Now, 25 years on, Benchley says that he could not "in good conscience" have written the book today, having discovered much more about the true nature of the beast.

"Great white sharks have survived, virtually unchanged, for millions of years," he writes in the latest edition of National Geographic. "They are as highly evolved, as perfectly in tune with their environment as any living thing on the planet. For them to be driven to extinction by man, a relative newcomer, would be more than ecological tragedy; it would be a moral travesty."

Benchley says that, contrary to what was believed when he wrote his book, sharks attack human beings only by accident, mistaking them for its normal prey. "Back then, we thought that once a great white scented blood, it launched a feeding frenzy that inevitably led to death," he writes.

"Now we know that nearly three-quarters of all bite victims survive, perhaps because the shark recognises that it has made a mistake and doesn't return for a second bite." Great white sharks have been responsible for only 74 deaths in the past 100 years, according to International Shark Attack File.

It was acceptable in 1975 to demonise an animal, especially the shark, says Benchley, "because man had done so since the beginning of time and, besides, sharks appeared to be infinite in number". Now they faced "serious, perhaps even catastrophic, decline". Some scientists who have specialised in the area estimate that populations of some species of shark have dropped by 80%.

Benchley believes that sharks get a bad press, compared to the dolphin and the whale, because they are not "cute", do not appear to "talk" to one another and so are harder for people to identify with. There has been no "save the shark" campaign and if the creatures appear on T-shirts it is as a joke rather than a plea for their survival.

The World Wide Fund for Nature is also anxious about the dramatic decline of shark populations. It says that since 1991 the number of sharks killed around Hawaii simply for their fins has increased by 2,000% per cent. It is feared that they are no longer reproducing at a sufficient rate to maintain their population.

But while Jaws may have increased the fear of sharks, Benchley feels that the book also did some good because it generated a fascination and eventually an affection for the creature. He receives more than 1,000 letters a year from young people who were not alive when the film first came out but who want to know more about sharks.
