webTitle: Listen, do you want to know a secret?

fields.headline: Listen, do you want to know a secret?
fields.standfirst: Ex-Beatles write a book to put the record straight on why they split
fields.trailText: It was John Lennon's fault ... The three surviving Beatles are to lift the lid on their time together in a candid first-person book which is expected to reveal that it was Lennon who triggered the band's split in 1970 and not Paul McCartney.
fields.body:
It was John Lennon's fault ... The three surviving Beatles are to lift the lid on their time together in a candid first-person book which is expected to reveal that it was Lennon who triggered the band's split in 1970 and not Paul McCartney.

The Beatles Anthology, expected to make £1bn worldwide, will hit the bookshops this autumn, priced £50. Publishers are hoping for total sales of 20m copies and are planning to translate the book into many languages, including Chinese.

Sir Paul, George Harrison and Ringo Starr have decided that Yoko Ono, Lennon's widow, will receive an equal quarter share of the profits despite little involvement in compiling the book.

It will contain 1,200 mostly unpublished photographs and be the size of a single volume of Encyclopedia Britannica.

The reuniting of the group as hardback, rather than paperback, writers, follows their frustration at inaccuracies in the hundreds of books about them.

Sir Paul is reported to have convinced Harrison and Starr to write the book by saying: "It will dispel some of the myths and put the record straight, as every Tom, Dick and uncle of a friend of the milkman has been writing books on the Beatles since 1963."

The former Beatles have spent six years on their account of how the group came to dominate pop music. It is expected to detail the group's drug taking and tensions.

Lennon's part in the book will come from hundreds of statements unearthed by researchers and knitted into the story.

Insiders say that the book will reveal that Sir Paul, 57, Harrison, 57, and Starr, 59, were offered £113m to reform in 1996 for a series of international gigs.

The part that will most interest the millions of fans will be the account of what lay behind the group's split 30 years ago. Although it was Sir Paul who announced the group's demise on April 11 1970, he had been most keen to continue, with Lennon being the first to quit, the book will reveal.

Starr writes: "After [John Lennon's] Plastic Ono Band's debut in Toronto we had a meeting in Savile Row where John finally brought it to a head. He said, 'Well, that's it lads, let's end it'."

Sir Paul, reports the Sunday Telegraph, writes about how he tried to keep the group to gether: "I'd said 'I think we should go back to little gigs - I really think we're a great little band, we should find our basic roots, and then who knows what will happen, we may want to fold after that, or we may really think we've still got it.'"

"John looked at me in the eye and said: 'Well I think you're daft, I wasn't going to tell you until we signed the Capitol deal, but I'm leaving the group.' We paled visibly and our jaws slackened a bit."

The book reveals that Lennon had effectively quit months before the official announcement, leaving the other members in limbo. The role Lennon's affair with Yoko Ono had in the band's split will also be examined.

Sir Paul's spokesman, Geoff Baker, said: "You've got to remember, there have been 300 to 400 books about the Beatles written, and in all but a few exceptions, the authors have never even met any of them. This book answers all the questions and dispels a lot of the myths."

Mr Baker said the book was "the last word" on the Beatles: "We're talking a huge volume of work, it's encyclopedic - it weighs something like two kilos.

"It is about the Beatles as a band, the music, but it deals with everything else - the tours, the drugs, the disputes."

Mr Baker confirmed it dealt with the group's break-up at some length.

"They hope it will put the record straight on a few things, for example the break-up of the band, that Paul was actually the last to leave."

fields.headline: My mother, myself
fields.standfirst: Only when her mother died did the novelist  Clare Boylan realise she had never really known the woman who had done most to shape her. And that, at last, she was free
fields.trailText: Only when her mother died did the novelist Clare Boylan realise she had never really known the woman who had done most to shape her. And that, at last, she was free
fields.body:
After my mother's funeral, my sisters and I sat in a Japanese restaurant, three middle-aged orphans sniffing over the sushi. We were middle-aged before this small, stubborn, sexy woman dropped out of our lives. But motherhood carves a space in time where the child who was once the wonder of the world can stay forever young. Only a month before, when my mother was dying, I dashed in to see her after a hellish day's work. Her face creased with concern. "Oh, you're tired," she said. "Look at your poor little dotey face!"

On her deathbed, she looked like a stranger. After more than 50 years of passionate motherhood, she had handed in her cards. As pain and love and worry left her face, she seemed as serene and selfish as a cat. One got the feeling that she was suddenly fed up with the whole enterprise, that she was off to live her own life now.

People try to reclaim the dead with anecdotes, but as we swapped stories about our childhood, a peculiar truth emerged. It became clear that we were each talking about a different person. To each of us, she had been a different mother. She had allotted separate roles to every daughter. Anne was the capable one, on whom she depended. Patricia was the sister in whom she confided. I was the baby whom she would keep for herself.

It came as a shock to think that I had never really known her. I had just known "mother". She was the only person I have ever met whose face actually lit up when she saw me. She was my life's biggest influence. She was the woman who had bred me to be her second chance - her replacement self. If I did not know her, then how could I know myself?

Years ago, I remember feeling startled when a close friend told me that the death of my mother would bring a sense of release.

Yes, there was relief she was now free from suffering, but when the first stunned feeling of grief began to recede, there was another, slightly shameful, sensation. Apart from a blinding rush of love, which had been largely inaccessible in her lifetime, I felt the stirring of a sense of freedom. Now I could stand on my own two feet. Now I could find out who I was. Now I could find out who she was.

Towards the end of her life, she said that if she had her time over again, she wouldn't have children. "Children use up your life," she said. "If I had another chance, I'd focus on a career."

But Nicola Horlick had children, I thought; Mary Robinson, Margaret Thatcher. It wasn't the having of the children, nor even the raising. It was the intense focus she brought to the job, the determination to live her life through them, to fulfil in them her own ambitions.

My mother was one of a generation of women who were like Chinese intellectuals in the reign of Mao Zedong, silenced and sentenced to peasant work. An avid reader, a free and radical thinker, she liked bohemian dress and food and interesting conversation, accompanied by cigarette smoke and cocktails. She had no education and no money. She did what nearly all of her generation did - found a man, got married and went into domestic service for a husband and family.

Ma wanted to be a writer. She wrote several novels and hundreds of short pieces, most of which were published. But she did not have a career. Her writing was a covert thing, while her husband was at work, when the children were in bed, after the dishes were done.

Why writing? Because (like most writers) she wanted to wield her influence on her own terms. For this her family was also a perfect forum - three wide-eyed little girls who believed that she was wise and wonderful, that she had been (as she claimed) a peerless femme fatale, until subdued by family life.

But despite her claim that all she ever wanted in life was to have children of her own, she became increasingly depressed. Eventually the writing stopped. She claimed that a psychiatrist who had treated her depression had told her to stop writing for the good of her mental health. As this was in the early 1960s, it was probably true.

From the time I was nine or 10, she focused her ambition on me. If I expressed an opinion, she'd say, "Write it down." That I did what she set out to do was only a partial triumph. It upset her when I turned up to visit, dressed in standard literary kit of stretch leggings, fleece jackets and trainers. Was that all I/she had to show for it? She would have liked me to be like Jackie Collins, with a fox fur and false eyelashes. Then everyone would know I was a success. And, although she took pleasure in my books, she would sometimes suggest, as tactfully as possible, that it was time I wrote something popular. She could not understand what had gone wrong. She had inadvertently turned me into that most unglamorous of creatures - a committed writer. What she had wanted for her daughter/herself was a career in which there was money and respect, but, most importantly, a place in the limelight.

In The Second Sex, Simone de Beauvoir wrote of the hazards for a woman in trying to make her daughter her replacement. "The double is a dubious personage, who assassinates the original, as we see, for example, in Poe's tales and in Wilde's The Picture of Dorian Gray. Thus, in becoming a woman, the daughter condemns her mother to death. . ."

From the time I entered my teens, a battle of wills commenced. She furiously tried to force feed me all that was important to her - religion, feminism, a mistrust of men. I furiously resisted, flinging it all back in her face, like a toddler, splattering back the mashed carrots. The uneasy, exhausting, although deeply loving, relationship masked a terror in each of us. If we failed in our separate struggles, then one of us must disappear.

When she was old, she often talked about her grief and disappointment that children grow up and leave you (although she sometimes said that "children turn against you"). "I think it's a pretty fair bargain," I'd say. "Children love you unconditionally for at least seven years. That's more than you get out of most love affairs."

"You haven't got children," she'd say. "You don't know what love is like."

"But you left your mother," I'd argue. "You must have known your children would have to leave." She shook her head, totally unable to accept that what she had made with her body and her will might be at the disposal of others.

Now that she has gone, I have to look at the space she occupied and the gap left behind. I no longer see her as the disappointed old lady nor the passionate, ambitious mother, but a lost girl. She was very pretty when young and she entered into motherhood with such pure delight and generosity that women who were once children on our street still talk of how they loved to come to our house, where they were allowed to make sweets or cakes or do anything they liked. Studying her photographs now, I am amazed that she looked as innocent at 80 as at 18.

I miss her more than I can say. I miss the hug we always had after we'd been to lunch. She did not embrace me but waited for her hug and then rested mutely in my arms, in the way a dog does. "Ah, that's nice," she'd say.

Now that she has gone, I can clearly see the real and enormous influence she effected. She made me feel that I was capable of anything and worthy of love. That I became a writer is not only due to her, but also to other influential relationships. But the kind of writer I became is all her own work. In the end, the relationship, which dominated much of my life, became the substance and motivation of my fiction. All of my books, in one way or another, concern mothers and daughters. Even my latest novel, Beloved Stranger, which set out as an analysis of marriage, turned into a voyage of discovery for a married woman and her unmarried daughter.

The relationship of motherhood is not the one of tender sentiment portrayed by Victorians, nor a cosy girlie friendship, but a briefly perfect love affair that becomes, as Anne Leaton puts it in the anthology Mothers by Daughters "a closed door through which others may not enter". But as the lifelong struggle for influence on the mother's part and approval on the daughter's part comes to a close, one finally appreciates the sheer spiritual intensity of the union.

Soon after my mother died, I sat down and read again through the letters of sympathy I had had, many of them from women. They were not so much saying they were sorry for my loss, as wailing about the loss of their own mothers. "I don't think you ever get over the death of your mother," one woman wrote. "Another talked of how, years later, she still misses her: "And she seems to be around quite a lot still - it's rather as if she's in another town and we hadn't visited recently."

I don't feel that Ma's in another town. I think she's gone. I really feel (and hope) that she's taken flight and is finally in pursuit of her own destiny. And I feel sure that, wherever she is, she is urging me on to mine.

In Mothers by Daughters the writer and publisher Margaret Busby wrote that only with the passing of her beloved parent did she feel she could turn into an adult. "With my mother's death, I felt I had reached the head of some reluctant queue."

It is there - still missing her, but armed with the gifts she gave me - that I find myself today.

Clare Boylan's latest novel, Beloved Stranger, is published by Little, Brown at £16.99.
fields.bodyText: After my mother's funeral, my sisters and I sat in a Japanese restaurant, three middle-aged orphans sniffing over the sushi. We were middle-aged before this small, stubborn, sexy woman dropped out of our lives. But motherhood carves a space in time where the child who was once the wonder of the world can stay forever young. Only a month before, when my mother was dying, I dashed in to see her after a hellish day's work. Her face creased with concern. "Oh, you're tired," she said. "Look at your poor little dotey face!" On her deathbed, she looked like a stranger. After more than 50 years of passionate motherhood, she had handed in her cards. As pain and love and worry left her face, she seemed as serene and selfish as a cat. One got the feeling that she was suddenly fed up with the whole enterprise, that she was off to live her own life now. People try to reclaim the dead with anecdotes, but as we swapped stories about our childhood, a peculiar truth emerged. It became clear that we were each talking about a different person. To each of us, she had been a different mother. She had allotted separate roles to every daughter. Anne was the capable one, on whom she depended. Patricia was the sister in whom she confided. I was the baby whom she would keep for herself. It came as a shock to think that I had never really known her. I had just known "mother". She was the only person I have ever met whose face actually lit up when she saw me. She was my life's biggest influence. She was the woman who had bred me to be her second chance - her replacement self. If I did not know her, then how could I know myself? Years ago, I remember feeling startled when a close friend told me that the death of my mother would bring a sense of release. Yes, there was relief she was now free from suffering, but when the first stunned feeling of grief began to recede, there was another, slightly shameful, sensation. Apart from a blinding rush of love, which had been largely inaccessible in her lifetime, I felt the stirring of a sense of freedom. Now I could stand on my own two feet. Now I could find out who I was. Now I could find out who she was. Towards the end of her life, she said that if she had her time over again, she wouldn't have children. "Children use up your life," she said. "If I had another chance, I'd focus on a career." But Nicola Horlick had children, I thought; Mary Robinson, Margaret Thatcher. It wasn't the having of the children, nor even the raising. It was the intense focus she brought to the job, the determination to live her life through them, to fulfil in them her own ambitions. My mother was one of a generation of women who were like Chinese intellectuals in the reign of Mao Zedong, silenced and sentenced to peasant work. An avid reader, a free and radical thinker, she liked bohemian dress and food and interesting conversation, accompanied by cigarette smoke and cocktails. She had no education and no money. She did what nearly all of her generation did - found a man, got married and went into domestic service for a husband and family. Ma wanted to be a writer. She wrote several novels and hundreds of short pieces, most of which were published. But she did not have a career. Her writing was a covert thing, while her husband was at work, when the children were in bed, after the dishes were done. Why writing? Because (like most writers) she wanted to wield her influence on her own terms. For this her family was also a perfect forum - three wide-eyed little girls who believed that she was wise and wonderful, that she had been (as she claimed) a peerless femme fatale, until subdued by family life. But despite her claim that all she ever wanted in life was to have children of her own, she became increasingly depressed. Eventually the writing stopped. She claimed that a psychiatrist who had treated her depression had told her to stop writing for the good of her mental health. As this was in the early 1960s, it was probably true. From the time I was nine or 10, she focused her ambition on me. If I expressed an opinion, she'd say, "Write it down." That I did what she set out to do was only a partial triumph. It upset her when I turned up to visit, dressed in standard literary kit of stretch leggings, fleece jackets and trainers. Was that all I/she had to show for it? She would have liked me to be like Jackie Collins, with a fox fur and false eyelashes. Then everyone would know I was a success. And, although she took pleasure in my books, she would sometimes suggest, as tactfully as possible, that it was time I wrote something popular. She could not understand what had gone wrong. She had inadvertently turned me into that most unglamorous of creatures - a committed writer. What she had wanted for her daughter/herself was a career in which there was money and respect, but, most importantly, a place in the limelight. In The Second Sex, Simone de Beauvoir wrote of the hazards for a woman in trying to make her daughter her replacement. "The double is a dubious personage, who assassinates the original, as we see, for example, in Poe's tales and in Wilde's The Picture of Dorian Gray. Thus, in becoming a woman, the daughter condemns her mother to death. . ." From the time I entered my teens, a battle of wills commenced. She furiously tried to force feed me all that was important to her - religion, feminism, a mistrust of men. I furiously resisted, flinging it all back in her face, like a toddler, splattering back the mashed carrots. The uneasy, exhausting, although deeply loving, relationship masked a terror in each of us. If we failed in our separate struggles, then one of us must disappear. When she was old, she often talked about her grief and disappointment that children grow up and leave you (although she sometimes said that "children turn against you"). "I think it's a pretty fair bargain," I'd say. "Children love you unconditionally for at least seven years. That's more than you get out of most love affairs." "You haven't got children," she'd say. "You don't know what love is like." "But you left your mother," I'd argue. "You must have known your children would have to leave." She shook her head, totally unable to accept that what she had made with her body and her will might be at the disposal of others. Now that she has gone, I have to look at the space she occupied and the gap left behind. I no longer see her as the disappointed old lady nor the passionate, ambitious mother, but a lost girl. She was very pretty when young and she entered into motherhood with such pure delight and generosity that women who were once children on our street still talk of how they loved to come to our house, where they were allowed to make sweets or cakes or do anything they liked. Studying her photographs now, I am amazed that she looked as innocent at 80 as at 18. I miss her more than I can say. I miss the hug we always had after we'd been to lunch. She did not embrace me but waited for her hug and then rested mutely in my arms, in the way a dog does. "Ah, that's nice," she'd say. Now that she has gone, I can clearly see the real and enormous influence she effected. She made me feel that I was capable of anything and worthy of love. webTitle: Unravelling the tangled web of electronic graffiti

fields.headline: Unravelling the tangled web of electronic graffiti
fields.trailText: If somebody scrawls offensive graffiti about me on a property owner's wall (Net firm pays out for alleged libel, March 31) and I make repeated requests to the owner to have it removed and he fails to do so without offering a reasonable explanation for his inaction, I could reasonably assume that the owner does not wish to dissociate himself from the statements made by the graffitist, and I would be justified in taking the owner to court for allowing the graffiti to be published.
fields.body:
If somebody scrawls offensive graffiti about me on a property owner's wall (Net firm pays out for alleged libel, March 31) and I make repeated requests to the owner to have it removed and he fails to do so without offering a reasonable explanation for his inaction, I could reasonably assume that the owner does not wish to dissociate himself from the statements made by the graffitist, and I would be justified in taking the owner to court for allowing the graffiti to be published.

The internet provides an infinity of walls for electronic graffitists to scrawl on, and it would be impractical to insist that internet service providers (ISPs) should be responsible for anything and everything that appears in their newsgroups postings. ISPs should be regarded as the objective, non-judgmental carriers of the statements and opinions posted by its contributors - until somebody cries "foul".

It is at this point that the ISP must decide whether a statement which somebody regards as offensive should be deleted, or whether to let it stand and thus, by implication, support the statement's content. That, surely, is the only reasonable interpretation of the settlement in the Demon case.
John Smedley
Sevenoaks, Kent

 Is there any reason why I should not libel myself anonymously on the internet and then sue the service provider?
Paul Hartmann
Otley, West Yorkshire
guycroft@clara.co.uk

 I'm fed up with hearing about lastminute.com and all these other "great" websites which can go on making huge losses without hassle. Where were all these column inches three or four years ago when I and many others were setting up websites with our own money?

We weren't in a position to make losses with other peoples' money, even the bank wouldn't provide a loan for the development of a website to complement our 70-year-old existing business. They didn't think any of our customers would want to buy goods on the internet!

We now have a site on its "second edition" and about to be revamped into its third. It has paid its development costs and now makes money, but do we get all these mentions in the press? There are lots of us out here who have risked all, have not become dot.com millionaires, but have provided the bedrock for these sites that are now given endless free publicity by the press.
Brian Parkin
London
augustflorist@cableinet.co.uk

fields.headline: Rabbie, and a' that
fields.trailText: What is it with some of your English contributors that they must have a go at putting down Burns, our national bard? First Roy Hattersley and now Neil Pearson (Letters, March 30). Why can't they just leave Scotland and the rest of the "civilised" world to appreciate Burns, a great poet of democratic ideals whose song A Man's a Man was sung at the opening of our Scottish parliament last year in a very dignified and moving ceremony.
fields.body:
What is it with some of your English contributors that they must have a go at putting down Burns, our national bard? First Roy Hattersley and now Neil Pearson (Letters, March 30). Why can't they just leave Scotland and the rest of the "civilised" world to appreciate Burns, a great poet of democratic ideals whose song A Man's a Man was sung at the opening of our Scottish parliament last year in a very dignified and moving ceremony.

It is to be hoped that in the discussions now beginning about identity, citizenship, nationality, and the reality that the British isles consists of four nations and their distinctive cultures and some shared values, these elements of English insularity will end and there could begin some appreciation of other eminent Scottish poets and writers such as the shamefully neglected Hugh McDiarmid along with McCaig, Sorley McLean, Morgan and Goodsir Smith.
John Kay
Glasgow

 I can't say for sure that Neil Pearson's insightful comments are due to a thorough research of our world renowned national product, but that's how it reads.
J McBride
Edinburgh

 It sounds like Neil Pearson needs a nice quiet holiday to get his blood pressure down and become a happier person. I believe there is a Buddhist monastery in the Scottish Borders offering week-long retreats.
Jennifer Clinch
Barking, Essex

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: Planet Football Sylvain Wiltord wants to join Arsenal. "I want to prove I can compete with the best strikers in the world and they all play in England," said the Bordeaux striker. "My preference for Arsenal is obvious. There is the French connection with Arsene Wenger and all the French players. It will be easy to fit in. I know Wenger is aware of my qualities, but I have to be patient." Wiltord, the current French footballer of the year, would cost Arsene Wenger £10m.

"My preference for Arsenal is obvious. There is the French connection with Arsene Wenger and all the French players. It will be easy to fit in. I know Wenger is aware of my qualities, but I have to be patient." Wiltord, the current French footballer of the year, would cost Arsene Wenger £10m.

Teamtalk Fulham are likely to announce the appointment of Joe Kinnear as their new manager within the next 48 hours.

Norwegian striker Ole Martin Aarst is a £1.5m summer target for Tottenham. The Gent striker, who has scored 24 goals in 21 games, said "I had a meeting with an English agent last Sunday. The firm he works have connections all the way to the top at Tottenham." Southampton and Leeds are also said to be interested.

Meanwhile, George Graham has assured Spurs fans that he will not buy Pierre van Hooijdonk, who has expressed an interest in moving to White Hart Lane. "I won't bring in potential problems if it is going to harm the team," he said.

This is London Alex Ferguson will not be making a bid for Tottenham captain Sol Campbell in the close season, choosing instead to wait until the player is available on a Bosman free. But the Manchester United manager, speaking at a meeting of the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association, admitted that he made a £17m move for the player earlier this season.

webTitle: Prayers in a vale of tears

fields.headline: Prayers in a vale of tears
fields.trailText: How sad that Matthew Norman (Diary, March 29) was deprived of the prayers of Jonathan Aitken and one other. I will, of course, immediately begin a novena for him, and the rest of the Guardian staff.
fields.body:
How sad that Matthew Norman (Diary, March 29) was deprived of the prayers of Jonathan Aitken and one other. I will, of course, immediately begin a novena for him, and the rest of the Guardian staff. If it may move you from the anti-Church of England stance which seems to be editorial policy at the moment (Farm must bear cost of church repairs, March 29, etc) it will be time well spent.
Rev Horace F Harper
Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs

 Surely the size codes for Matthew Norman's "Oooh, you amaze me!" T-shirts should be the other way round: Frank (L) Ken (XLabour).
Richard Paul-Jones
Brighton
rpj@jones.co.uk

 Up to 100 foreign nationals fighting in an onion field (Two stabbed, April 1). It was bound to end in tears.
Rev Tony Bell
Glapwell, Derbyshire
tonybell@glapwell.f9.co.uk

 Paul Weaver ('We lurch from crisis to crisis', April 1) confidently asserts that the last time Scotland beat England at rugby, Nelson Mandela was "still in chokey". Mandela was released on February 11 1990, so had enjoyed one month of freedom before Scotland's victory.
Douglas McKelvie
Edinburgh

 I recall reading something similar (Letters, March 29) in Rolfe's 1904 novel, Hadrian the Seventh. It went something like: "In every fat bishop there is a thin martyr trying to get out".
David Pollard
Hove, East Sussex
dpol@cwcom.net

 A skilled, if risky, gloss on Cyril Connolly's bon mot was making the rounds in Dublin 20 years ago: "Outside every slim woman there's a fat man wildly signalling to be let in".
Bernard McCabe
Ludlow, Shropshire

fields.headline: Flora's holiday
fields.trailText: Your piece about Mrs Flora Langstaff (The good life of a laboratory OAP, April 1) is as heartwarming as it is of potentially immense importance. It shows how a humble, and otherwise unremarkable person, can be of great value to society, to science, and ultimately to herself.
fields.body:
Your piece about Mrs Flora Langstaff (The good life of a laboratory OAP, April 1) is as heartwarming as it is of potentially immense importance. It shows how a humble, and otherwise unremarkable person, can be of great value to society, to science, and ultimately to herself.

It has given me food for thought, and I should be delighted to volunteer my wife - who admittedly has not reached Mrs Langstaff's venerable age, but is getting near - for similar work. Unfortunately I have no idea how one would go about this, and would be delighted to have an opportunity of discussing it with that fine lady. At the same time I could find out from her where to book a Caribbean or Mediterranean cruise for about £465.
Marc Schatzberger
York

 You failed to mention the laboratory OAP's favourite holiday cruise destination - the beautiful island of San Seriffe.
Peter Daish
Northampton
PETERDAISH@aol.com

 I know how hard the government is working to attract and retain conscientious teachers in our schools. So I was not in the least amused by your spoof article (Teachers fight rule to encourage 'snooping', April 1) and the piece about three hours a week extra curricular activities for all pupils. As for me, a recently retired teacher, I'm off to Leeds to test a new drug for Alzheimer's disease with Flora Langstaff.
Steve Lupton
Manchester
shlpictures@eggconnect.net

 The only April fool spoof I could find in Saturday's Guardian was the two-page advert for Rover cars.
Ivor Yeloff
Norwich
ivoryeloff@classicfm.net

fields.headline: FA announce internet rights revolution
fields.standfirst: FA's decision will change the way you watch football
fields.trailText: As the Premier League announced plans to shake up football broadcasting with the introduction of pay-per-view matches, the FA went one step further by announcing that it will allow separate bids for the rights to show FA Cup football on the internet from the 2001/2002 season onwards. "The bidding process is open to all, and companies will be able to bid solely for the internet rights", FA spokesman Steve Double told Football Unlimited. "We are open-minded about the process. Ultimately we will choose the deal that is best for football."
fields.body:
As the Premier League announced plans to shake up football broadcasting with the introduction of pay-per-view matches, the FA went one step further by announcing that it will allow separate bids for the rights to show FA Cup football on the internet from the 2001/2002 season onwards. "The bidding process is open to all, and companies will be able to bid solely for the internet rights", FA spokesman Steve Double told Football Unlimited. "We are open-minded about the process. Ultimately we will choose the deal that is best for football."

It means that while one company - say Sky - could have the rights to live FA Cup football, another might have the exclusive rights to show matches on the internet. Up until now the FA has only allowed bids for internet audio transmissions.

Three of the biggest sports websites in the UK, Sports.com, Sportal and Soccernet are all expected to bid for the internet rights, along with Sky. So far these companies have pumped millions into their web pages, without much to show in the way of profit.

But securing an deal with the FA could change all that. Sky's fortunes improved dramatically after they won the contract for live Premiership football in the early 1990s - and the dot.com companies realise that these rights could make or break them.

Andrew Croker, Director of Sport for Sportal said: "It's good to see that the FA recognise the internet as a separate distribution platform. The FA's traditional broadcast deals and commercial programmes will remain the key in the short-term, but the internet will have an increasingly important role in adding value and raising interest levels."

Internet analyst Peter Bradshaw of Merrill Lynch told Football Unlimited the bidding for the contract would be high. He said: "Sport is one of the killer areas for content on the web. And football is the one sport that all the big companies are after."

The FA's traditional broadcast deals and commercial programmes will remain the key in the short-term, but the internet will have an increasingly important role in adding value and raising interest levels." Internet analyst Peter Bradshaw of Merrill Lynch told Football Unlimited the bidding for the contract would be high. He said: "Sport is one of the killer areas for content on the web. And football is the one sport that all the big companies are after."

fields.headline: First stop for refugees
fields.trailText: Alan Travis correctly identifies the high number of asylum seekers who have presented themselves in Northampton (From refugees to political footballs, March 30).
fields.body:
Alan Travis correctly identifies the high number of asylum seekers who have presented themselves in Northampton (From refugees to political footballs, March 30).

Lorry drivers travelling from channel ports often take their first "tachograph stop" in Northamptonshire. Nearly all of the asylum seekers coming to Northampton are "in country" applicants which means that they make their first claim for asylum with us rather than at a port of entry. The flow of 30 new asylum seekers a week is continuing.

The phased implementation of the new Home Office arrangements from today means that we will continue to have responsibility for supporting these "in country" applicants.

We have explained our position to the Home Office and we are making further representations to be allowed to disperse asylum seekers so that we are dealing with our fair share rather than a disproportionate number.

The fact that there are marginal seats in the area is not a consideration.
Cllr John Dickie
Leader, Northampton borough council

 Those of us who have been standing up for asylum seekers since 1996 are deeply grateful for your persistent excellent coverage (Leader, April 1) - unfortunately, of course, you preach to the converted. We need Guardian readers - and others - to join us in frontline areas such as Kent in trying to reach the unconverted, the vast majority of whom, even in Dover, are not active racists but decent, ordinary, baffled folk who don't know what to believe from what they read in the tabloids.

Ann Widdecombe's detention pronouncement last week brings back worrying memories of elections past and the full realisation that in this area the next one will be fought on this issue.
Gill Casebourne
Kent Refugee Action Network
gillian.casebourne@which.net

fields.headline: Councils at the barricades
fields.trailText: Jeremy Beecham's muted defence of local government (Warning shots from the frontline, March 31) is mounted from almost the last barricade. He well knows that New Labour's concept of Best Value will soon produce measures of how well each council is doing in delivering central government policy. Some have already seen years of retrenchment as more and more people have gone without, or crossed to neighbouring areas to get the services they need, and central government grant has been cut. Best Value will find these services so bad that local electors will cry out for their council to be abolished.
fields.body:
Jeremy Beecham's muted defence of local government (Warning shots from the frontline, March 31) is mounted from almost the last barricade. He well knows that New Labour's concept of Best Value will soon produce measures of how well each council is doing in delivering central government policy. Some have already seen years of retrenchment as more and more people have gone without, or crossed to neighbouring areas to get the services they need, and central government grant has been cut. Best Value will find these services so bad that local electors will cry out for their council to be abolished.

The good councils will be forced to put more and more services in the hands of other "providers". The requirement for a mixed economy will have the same effect across all services as we already see in those which the Tories forced councils to put out to tender, such as council tax collection and housing benefit payments. A small number of very large firms will quickly grow huge profits, on the backs of former council staff, and quietly fail to deliver. In most places, these firms have recruited new starters at wages so low that councils cannot afford the increase in costs of bringing the work back in and paying staff now at the private sector's mercy.

Who will want to be a councillor, a mere superintendent of continued decline into squalor, is another matter.
Tom Snow
London

 I will soon be standing down after nine years as a city councillor, the last two as social services committee chair. Throughout this time government ministers have criticised local government, although earlier onslaughts have thankfully diminished. In their place is a ministerial view closer to that attributed by Richard Crossman to his permanent secretary, Dame Evelyn Sharp: "Wanting improvement and social justice quite passionately and yet a tremendous patrician... regarding local authorities as children which she has to examine and rebuke for their failures".

With the current managerial approach to government it is essential that public deliberation over decisions is not replaced by centrally imposed targets and performance indicators. The search for quality and national standards is all well and good, but the achievement of this will ultimately depend upon effective organisational forms at local level. This must include genuine democratic processes. Institutional sclerosis has developed in parts of local government, and new forms of public engagement need to be found. This cannot be achieved by central directive.

During my time as a councillor I have worked with colleagues who have shown enormous commitment to improving local services, often in the face of enormous obstacles. Criticising people such as these as part of the problem simply makes solutions more difficult to find.
Dr Mike Sheaff
University of Plymouth
M.Sheaff@plymouth.ac.uk

 Underlying Sir Jeremy Beecham's fears about creeping centralisation lies another story of persistent underfunding and neglect. The Local Government Association has calculated that the chancellor needs to find another £9bn to bring local government services up to scratch. Staff at the cutting edge are only too aware that the rhetoric of quality services has hidden another agenda of cuts, competition and privatisation.

It was Nicholas Ridley who first floated the notion of the "enabling authority", where services are bought in and the private sector reaps the profit. What is needed now is a commitment to a real investment in the frontline. The democratic vision of top quality services delivered through creative local leadership can be realised - but only if central government is prepared to commit both resources and trust.
Malcolm Wing
Head of local government, Unison

webTitle: Muppet joins stars in wild animal lobby

fields.headline: Muppet joins stars in wild animal lobby
fields.trailText: Kermit the Frog has teamed up with Hitchcock star Tippi Hedren and infrequently dressed actress Bo Derek to back proposed legislation to regulate the possession of wild animals
fields.body:
Kermit the Frog has teamed up with Hitchcock star Tippi Hedren and infrequently dressed actress Bo Derek to back proposed legislation to regulate the possession of wild animals, according to the BBC. "We need to pass this bill to prevent the continuing abuse and cruelty toward exotic animals in this country", said the Muppet.

Hedren, the star of Hitchcock's The Birds, runs a refuge called Shambala Preserve in California. "Many accidents have happened by having wild animals as pets", said Hedren, sitting next to the green frog puppet. "I believe that anyone taking in a wild animal as a pet is making a very grave error".

Her daughter Melanie Griffith revealed she was attacked by a lioness on a film set when she was 19. "I knew these cats and they knew me and it was a friendly thing. But if people are allowed to have these wild animals in their homes and they don't know how to deal with them, they will get much more than a scratch", she warned, keeping a straight face. Bo Derek was attacked by a lion while filming Tarzan, the Ape Man in the sea. She said a huge wave saved her from more serious injury. And Kermit nodded sombrely beside her.

webTitle: Bond claimant left shaken, stirred, and defeated

fields.headline: Bond claimant left shaken, stirred, and defeated
fields.trailText: The 40-year row over rights to the James Bond franchise ended this weekend when a federal judge dismissed Kevin McClory's long-standing claim to a share of MGM's profits
fields.body:
The 40-year row over rights to the James Bond franchise ended this weekend when a federal judge dismissed Kevin McClory's long-standing claim to a share of MGM's profits. US District Court Judge Edward Rafeedie ruled that McClory had delayed too long "four decades, to be exact" before claiming to be the co-creator with Ian Fleming of the cinematic Bond.

Rafeedie dismissed the case on the ground of laches - the legal term for excessive delay. MGM lawyer Pierce O'Donnell said the ruling was "a total vindication" for the studio.

This should be the final chapter in a saga that has featured at least three major lawsuits involving McClory and the Bond rights. In 1997, Sony announced it had purchased McClory's rights and would use them as the basis for a competing Bond franchise. MGM sued, triumphing over Sony back in March 1999. McClory fought on until now, when Judge Rafeedie found that he had delayed at least 36 years in bringing his ownership claim, despite numerous opportunities to do so. Rafeedie adjudged this delay to be detrimental to MGM's chances of establishing their sole right to the franchise, because most of the witnesses who could "potentially help untangle McClory"s web of allegations and intrigue are long dead".

fields.headline: Cup clipboard
fields.trailText: 90 minutes in 30 words Dull, tedious, boring, uninteresting, insipid, uneventful, coma-inducing, humdrum, colourless, flat, unenjoyable, stale, stupefying, monotonous, grey... where's my thesaurus?
fields.body:
90 minutes in 30 words Dull, tedious, boring, uninteresting, insipid, uneventful, coma-inducing, humdrum, colourless, flat, unenjoyable, stale, stupefying, monotonous, grey... where's my thesaurus?

Boy done good Lee Hendrie kicked the ball once and scored. That's got to impress the folk in charge of the computer at Opta.

Two left feet Paul Merson worked, but nothing he tried did.

Magic moment Eidur Gudjohnsen rampaged Heskey-style down the left flank, rounded the advancing David James with ease and took three Villa defenders out of the equation with a slide-rule pass to set up Dean Holdsworth who...

Mr Sitter ...inexplicably hoofed the ball over a gaping goal.

Shiver the timbers It wasn't poor Dean's day - a minute before his slapstick show, his curling free-kick pinged off James's left-hand post. But the luck levelled out minutes later when Jussi Jaaskelainen pushed a Dion Dublin pop onto the back stick (if you were looking at it from where Big Ron was sitting).

Cheered When news of Stan Collymore's broken leg thundered over the Tannoy before the game, the Villa end erupted. The Bolton fans would later cater for those who appreciate a more touchy-feely attitude - they did their best to cheer up Allan Johnston and Michael Johansen after their shoot-out shocker.

Jeered John Gregory wasn't a popular man when he hauled Benito Carbone off midway through the second half - every claret and blue pair of lungs in Wembley immediately bellowed a long and loud musical paean to the diminutive Italian trickster. An impassive Gregory sat motionless for many seconds.

Turning point Holdsworth's moment of madness had 'turning point' written all over it in letters - ooh - twenty foot high.

Ref-er-ee! A subdued performance from David Elleray - only X yellow cards and one sending off. But to be fair, he didn't have much choice when Mark Delaney, already on a caution, hacked down Allan Johnston when the Bolton winger was bearing down on goal. Out came the inevitable card - reluctantly displayed without a flourish, as you'd expect.

Terrace talk
Villa: "We're through to the FA Cup final! Hold on... have you been drugging our half-time tea?"

Wanderers: "Ah well, it could be worse - we could follow international rugby union too."

fields.headline: £1m arson damage to school
fields.trailText: Arsonists are suspected of causing a £1m blaze which destroyed the core of the high school at one of Britain's two "millennium villages" at the weekend.
fields.body:
Arsonists are suspected of causing a £1m blaze which destroyed the core of the high school at one of Britain's two "millennium villages" at the weekend.

More than 100 firefighters failed to save the main block of Brigshaw High at Allerton Bywater, near Leeds, where the government and private developers are planning to build 600 futuristic homes.

Two boys aged 16 and 14, both from Allerton Bywater, were arrested yesterday and questioned in connection with the blaze.

School security cameras recorded intruders in the main building in the early hours of Saturday morning. The fire broke out soon afterwards but had taken hold by 1.40am when crews from 12 fire stations arrived.

Brigshaw's headteacher, Peter Laurence, called the damage "absolutely devastating" for the 1,100 pupils, their parents, staff and the community. "The school looks like a war zone but we will bounce back," he said.

A steady stream of pupils, some in tears, visited the site where mobile classrooms will be installed this week.

The blaze is the latest in a series of blows for the millennium village which, like its counterpart at Greenwich in south-east London, has been dogged by controversy and protests that local people's wishes are being ignored.

A meeting on the issue at Brigshaw high in November ended in a brief fracas and the village's Remembrance Day ceremony the same month was marred by claims that an official wreath had been vandalised.

webTitle: Ambitious Waugh declares the best is yet to come

fields.headline: Ambitious Waugh declares the best is yet to come
fields.trailText: Steve Waugh, after watching his Australians chalk up their 10th consecutive Test win yesterday, was never going to let the throbbing pain in his left arm distract him from his next ambition: to prove that his team, according to one set of statistics at least, is the greatest ever.
fields.body:
Steve Waugh, after watching his Australians chalk up their 10th consecutive Test win yesterday, was never going to let the throbbing pain in his left arm distract him from his next ambition: to prove that his team, according to one set of statistics at least, is the greatest ever.

Within moments of beating New Zealand by six wickets in the third Test at Hamilton the Australian captain turned his sights to next November, when his side will attempt to equal the world record of 11 straight wins held by the West Indies team of the mid-80s.

"We can play better cricket," Waugh threatened. "We dropped some catches here and our batting can be a lot more consistent. I think we are on the verge of something special; this is just the beginning."

Waugh's injury was the legacy of a sharply rising delivery from the debutant New Zealand paceman Daryl Tuffey, which forced him to retire hurt on the final morning.

The architects of the win were Adam Gilchrist - who added 10 catches to his first- innings 75 - and Justin Langer, whose run-a-ball unbeaten 122 turned a tense contest into a walkover. "At the moment he is the best batsman in the world," said Waugh of his No3.

 West Indies' revival continued when Wavell Hinds' unbeaten 116 led them to 41-run one-day win over Zimbabwe at Sabina Park.

fields.headline: Eberhard Bethge
fields.standfirst: Theologian who took Bonhoeffer's message to the world
fields.trailText: The German theologian Eberhard Bethge, who has died aged 90, subordinated his reputation to that of his friend and colleague Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the Christian anti-Nazi who was hanged in April 1945, a few days before the end of Hitler's reign of terror. He became the editor of Bonhoeffer's works, his biographer and his interpreter to the world.
fields.body:
The German theologian Eberhard Bethge, who has died aged 90, subordinated his reputation to that of his friend and colleague Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the Christian anti-Nazi who was hanged in April 1945, a few days before the end of Hitler's reign of terror. He became the editor of Bonhoeffer's works, his biographer and his interpreter to the world.

Born into a Lutheran parsonage in the Saxon town of Warchau, he studied theology in Konigsberg, Berlin, Vienna, Tubingen and Halle-Wittenberg. As a young man, he was a member of the Hitler Youth. But he soon became disillusioned and joined the Confessing church, the Christian movement in Germany that opposed those who accepted the support Hitler promised to subservient churches.

In 1935, Bethge volunteered, as a mature student, to go to the seminary for theological students within the Confessing church. It was there that he first met Bonhoeffer, the seminary's director and just three years his senior. The two men began in a very primitive, empty bible school in Zeist, on the Baltic, later moving to Finkenwalde, near Stettin, and developed a close friendship. When the Gestapo closed the seminary in 1937, Bethge became the student inspector for the scattered student groups, which until 1940 illegally continued their studies throughout Pomerania under Bonhoeffer's direction.

When Bonhoeffer was ar rested in 1943, he kept in touch with his friend by smuggled letters - which Bethge preserved. While his friend was in prison, Bethge married Bonhoeffer's niece, Renate Schleicher, and a year later their first child, Dietrich, was born. Bonhoeffer had sent a sermon for their wedding, and now he sent, also from prison by hand of the jailer, a sermon for the child. It was one of Bonhoeffer's most important pieces of writing, condemning his church for fighting only for its own preservation.

Bethge was conscripted into the German army in 1943 and was serving in Italy when the assassination attempt on Hitler was made in July 1944. He was arrested and imprisoned in the notorious Gestapo prison in Berlin, only to be freed on the arrival of the Russians in 1945, a couple of weeks after Bonhoeffer's execution.

The letters that Bonhoeffer wrote to Bethge changed the direction of theology in the western world, and have not been not without significance in Asia, Africa and Latin America. Bethge responded to these letters, and stimulated his friend, because they both estimated the real contribution which the other could make to the advancement of the church in the postwar world.

After his release from jail, Bethge held various positions as student pastor at Humbold University and the technical high school in Berlin. From 1953 until 1961, he was minister to the German-speaking congregation in London, a post which Bonhoeffer had held between 1933 and 1935, and, for the next 15 years, he was director of a pastoral college of the church of the Rhineland in Rengsdorf.

This was a very minor post for so distinguished a scholar, but it gave Bethge time to complete a definitive biography of Bonhoeffer, which was published in 1967. When Collins asked in 1970 for an English version of this book, which was of mammoth proportions, I sat with Bethge in Rengsdorf fighting to preserve every cut. After this, many books followed on different aspects of Bonhoeffer's thought - patriotism, martyrdom, friendship and, especially, the unfinished work he had entrusted to Bethge on ethics. fields.headline: Cook attacks Harare violence
fields.standfirst:
President Mugabe surprises observers by setting off for Cairo to attend the first EU-Africa summit
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, strongly condemned the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, yesterday after the violent break-up of a demonstration against his government on Saturday.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Andrew Meldrum in Harare and  Mona Eltahawy  in Cairo
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, strongly condemned the president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, yesterday after the violent break-up of a demonstration against his government on Saturday.

Mr Cook, speaking on the eve of the European Union-African summit in Cairo, criticised Zimbabwe's police for failing to protect the demonstrators and called on Mr Mugabe to honour a promise to set a date for a general election.

Mr Mugabe, dispelling initial doubts about whether he would attend the summit, left Harare for Cairo last night. The Foreign Office said a discussion between Mr Cook and Mr Mugabe would not be possible last night but, as the two men would be sitting near each other during the summit, it was likely to take place today or tomorrow.

The proximity of the two teams is a potential flashpoint, given the strong language being used by both during the past fortnight of unrest in Zimbabwe. Mr Mugabe left behind an increasingly fraught country.

Fifteen people were injured on Saturday when 150 people, alleged to be linked to his party, Zanu-PF, forcefully broke up a march comprising 4,000 peaceful demonstrators in the capital, Harare.

And the tension is set to increase: a coalition of Zimbabwean civic groups vowed yesterday to intensify demonstrations to press Mr Mugabe to uphold the rule of law.

In the aftermath of Saturday's march, Mr Cook issued an uncompromising statement yesterday morning criticising Mr Mugabe's regime, which he expanded on during interviews throughout the day. He accused Mr Mugabe of flouting his own courts and chastising Britain in an attempt to win re-election.

He expressed concern about delayed parliamentary elections, initially scheduled for April but now though to be set for July, and the failure of police to protect demonstrators or carry out court orders to stop the illegal occupation of white-owned farms by Zimbabwe's black veterans of the Rhodesian war against white rule in the 70s.

The Foreign Office conceded last night that the issue of Zimbabwe was unlikely to be raised officially by Mr Cook at the summit, which begins today, claiming the meeting was about "sectoral" rather than specific issues.

The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, hinted that putting Zimbabwe on the agenda would open a can of worms. He said the summit, the first between the EU and Africa, would then face the prospect of every crisis in Africa being raised in future.

Instead, Mr Cook will raise Zimbabwe at a meeting of EU foreign ministers in Luxembourg next Monday. He will urge the EU to "offer election-monitoring officials to help establish that the forthcoming elections in Zimbabwe are free and fair".

Mr Mugabe devoted much of a speech on Friday to criticising Britain's involvement in Zimbabwe's internal affairs.

An uncompromising Mr Cook said: "I very much regret that President Mugabe ap pears to have based his pitch for re-election on attacking Britain. He has now been in power for 17 years and he has to accept himself the responsibility for the current state of the economy of Zimbabwe."

In Harare, opponents of Mr Mugabe promised further protests. "For the next 100 days we will organise public demonstrations to promote peace and the rule of law," said Brian Kagoro, spokesman for the National Constitutional Assembly, which organised Saturday's ill-fated march. "We cannot accept the government's violent intimidation."

More than a dozen people ended up in hospital. One man, British citizen David Reed, was beaten unconscious and remained in intensive care yesterday. The violent attackers armed themselves with crude weapons at Zanu-PF's headquarters, according to video footage taken by a local filmmaker.

webTitle: Blair rejects rescue plea from thousands of Longbridge workers

fields.headline: Blair rejects rescue plea from thousands of Longbridge workers
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was urged yesterday to take personal responsibility for the crisis at Rover despite ruling out any move by the government to rescue the ailing car firm in the wake of its sell-off by BMW.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was urged yesterday to take personal responsibility for the crisis at Rover despite ruling out any move by the government to rescue the ailing car firm in the wake of its sell-off by BMW.

The day after 80,000 demonstrators marched through Birmingham to protest against the sale of Rover to the venture capital firm Alchemy, the prime minister ruled out government intervention to save the threatened jobs.

Alchemy has said it intends to cut the number of jobs at Rover's Longbridge plant to about 4,500 from 9,000. A total of 50,000 people could be affected in the Midlands if the sale goes through.

In an article in Sunday Business yesterday, Mr Blair wrote: "If governments in the past, of both major political parties, have been drawn towards 'rescuing' a company in difficulties, we see our role now as helping to equip people and businesses for the new economy."

Downing Street yesterday insisted the government was not leaving workers in the lurch but saw its role as "managing transition" rather than intervening to bail out businesses.

Transport union negotiator Tony Woodley said the sale of Rover and subsequent loss of jobs "was the most serious industrial issue for 20 years". He denied that he had opened talks on redundancy terms with Alchemy, and said the potential loss of £400m in taxes and social security revenue should persuade the government to support rescue efforts.

Photograph John Cassidy

fields.headline: Cyclone menaces Madagascar
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique fears the storm will also dump rain in its swollen rivers
Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: Possibly the most powerful cyclone of southern Africa's rainy season was bearing down on Madagascar last night, threatening to compound the destruction from earlier storms and raising the spectre of further devastating floods in Mozambique.
fields.body:
Possibly the most powerful cyclone of southern Africa's rainy season was bearing down on Madagascar last night, threatening to compound the destruction from earlier storms and raising the spectre of further devastating floods in Mozambique.

Madagascar's meteorological office said Cyclone Hudah covered hundreds of square miles and was thought likely to bring winds of 200 mph when it hit the very area in the north-east of the Indian Ocean island which was severely damaged by cyclones Eline and Gloria in late February and early March.

The two earlier cyclones caused considerable damage and loss of life, killing more than 200 people in mudslides, destroying tens of thousands of homes and leaving about 130,000 people dependent on food aid.

Radio Madagascar yesterday broadcast warnings to residents of the main towns in its path, principally the country's largest port, Toamasina, to shore up their homes or take shelter in brick buildings.

It is too early to say whether Cyclone Hudah poses a severe threat to Mozambique. Large parts of the centre and south of the country are still under water after two months of storms and overflowing rivers.

The previous cyclones developed in different ways after hitting Madagascar: Eline retained much of its force and went on to batter Mozambique's coast. Gloria largely dissipated, but still dumped heavy rains on southern Africa.

The principal danger is not from Cyclone Hudah's winds, but that more rain flowing into the region's swollen rivers - especially the Limpopo and Incomati - will wash down to the parts of Mozambique hit by flooding. It could compound the considerable damage done by rains in northern parts of South Africa and southern Zimbabwe.

Several hundred people drowned in the floods in Mozambique, although the final death toll will not be known until after the waters have receded. Even then, many victims are believed to have been washed out to sea.

The World Bank estimates that damage to Mozambique's agriculture, roads and manufacturing industry will cost the country about US$1bn (£625m) in relief and reconstruction costs.

About 600,000 people are dependent on food aid. More than 250,000 are housed in temporary camps.

Even with tens of millions of dollars in emergency humanitarian aid pouring into Mozambique, the country is still struggling to distribute food and medical supplies.

Save the Children said it had seen malnutrition among young children in Chibuto, Chicambane and Manjacaze districts.

The government's disaster management office said malaria cases have risen sharply, accounting for nearly half of all hospital patients.

webTitle: Black, white and red alert: a nation in crisis

fields.headline: Black, white and red alert: a nation in crisis
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: For almost 50 years, since the wind of change first gusted uncertainly through colonial Africa, there has been one constant. Whenever there has been trouble, whatever fate might befall the local white inhabitants, you could be pretty certain that the black popula tion would suffer far worse.
fields.body:
For almost 50 years, since the wind of change first gusted uncertainly through colonial Africa, there has been one constant. Whenever there has been trouble, whatever fate might befall the local white inhabitants, you could be pretty certain that the black popula tion would suffer far worse.

Just over a thousand white soldiers and civilians died in the 1970s in the futile defence of old Rhodesia.

That figure is a tiny fraction of the total death toll from political violence before and after Zimbabwe established its independence. This has been the pattern across the continent: Africans have to die in thousands before making the television news or panicking the tourist industry.

This weekend, as Zimbabwe's first president, Robert Mugabe, continued to fight like a cornered, wounded and very ill-tempered lion for his political life, the old rules began to alter.

The organisers of Saturday's anti-government march in Harare, the National Constitutional Assembly, said yesterday that the motley crew of alleged war veterans who attacked them specifically targeted the white protesters, who made up about 15% of the marchers. Four of the five people detained in hospital were white. There is evidence that their assailants emerged from, and returned to, Mugabe's party headquarters.

The assembly itself ratcheted up the already feverish rhetoric here when its spokes man said that they feared the possibility of civil war. If this happens, it will not be a distant, forgettable affair in remote countryside, as the conflicts in Congo or Sudan have been. Britain would be inextricably involved; the tangled 110 years of history since Cecil Rhodes arrived with his pioneer column would see to that.

The assembly's spokesman also called the attack "murderous" and "a bloodbath". Actually, there have been bloodier days in Trafalgar Square. But in a country where the regime has lost interest in every detail of governance except its own day-to-day survival, a real bloodbath is a horrific possibility.

There is now some panic but it seems greatest close to the top, where - if even a fraction of the anecdotes are true - many officials have reason to fear not just defeat if the scheduled elections are ever held, but long jail terms for corruption. The hoteliers, overwhelmed by empty rooms, are not far behind.

And there are a few signs of alarm from the more rootless whites. An elderly lady rang a British diplomat and said she had heard that the last Hercules airlifting citizens to Britain would be leaving on Friday. "That's nonsense," he said.

"But there's a red alert!" she screeched.

"Madam, what is a red alert?"

"I don't know," she replied, "but it sounds frightful."

It was perhaps a mistake for Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, to talk of the contingency plans for evacuation. Obviously, in a place with political instability and a great many expats, such plans exist but Zimbabwe - with its biased and rudimentary news media - has always been a country of wild rumour.

There was only one topic of conversation round the swimming pools in the suburbs yesterday, but almost everyone is trying to carry on insouciantly.

Rightly so, because there is no evidence that any of the hatred exists on a day-to-day level - another sign that Mr Mugabe no longer has much sway, at least over the urban electorate.

There is deep concern, though. Whatever happens to the Harare stock market today, it should be a bumper week for the city's security firms, gunsmiths and locksmiths.

But it can look worse on the television news than it does close-up. One white woman got a call on Saturday from her family in Australia. "We've been trying to reach you for hours. Are you all right?" they asked. "Yes," she replied. "I've just had a lovely round of golf. What's the matter?"

This is a country with many old-fashioned touches. Perhaps it is to do with being landlocked; it feels insulated against the world. For instance, almost everyone is elaborately courteous, something that has no place in the new South Africa.

Even Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi, who appears now to be commandant of Mr Mugabe's private army of irregulars, smiles engagingly. Carole Pearce, whose architect husband was one of eight people arrested on Saturday - all of them the attacked, not the attackers - said the police were being "absolutely charming".

Nonetheless, Mick Pearce, 62, was in jail yesterday and will appear in court today, charged with ignoring a police order to disperse. The funny thing is that Mr Pearce, who was born here, is a well-known liberal who left the country during Ian Smith's illegal independence and returned in delight when Mr Mugabe took over.

This country's last civil war was fought when the old Rhodesians staged their doomed struggle against the future. Now 76-year-old President Mugabe is fighting against the future: his own mortality, the growing sophistication and exasperation of the electorate; and the expec tations of the outside world, which will no longer stand by and watch a country revert to dictatorship.

Among the white farming families, there is a pattern. The new generation, too young to have fought for Rhodesia, have studied agriculture abroad and introduced new scientific ideas, and, from time to time they are inclined to excoriate their fathers over the wasted war. For the moment, the fathers are saying "I told you so".

However, a similar pattern also seems to exist among the young blacks. They have heard all their lives about the chimurenga - the war of liberation - and about the war veterans, some of whom now swagger around under the patronage of Mr Mugabe and "Hitler" Hunzvi.

One suspects these under-40s get bored with war stories too. They see a discredited and rapacious government as the enemy of their economic liberation - not the farmers or the British.

The police, perhaps bemused by the difference between their responsibilities and their orders, did not intervene to stop the violence on Saturday.

But there were no reports of animosity towards the protesters. Instead, the opposition thought they could detect hidden waves of sympathy.

If civil war comes, Mr Mugabe might just find himself rather short of friends.

fields.headline: The Frau's fresh start
fields.standfirst:
Germany's CDU needs Angela Merkel

German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: The health of pluralist democracy depends on the parliamentary vigour with which rulers are opposed. In federal and proportionally-represented Germany Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrat-Green coalition was never going to enjoy Tony Blair's hegemony, whatever the state of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) after Helmut Kohl's resignation as party leader. But that party's collapse subjected the German political system to strain; the disclosure of Kohl's role as a glorified bagman for illegal contributions shook confidence further. Wolfgang Schäuble's enforced departure threatened a protracted period of weak opposition; it certainly helped Schröder's recovery in the recent Schleswig-Holstein elections.
fields.body:
The health of pluralist democracy depends on the parliamentary vigour with which rulers are opposed. In federal and proportionally-represented Germany Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrat-Green coalition was never going to enjoy Tony Blair's hegemony, whatever the state of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) after Helmut Kohl's resignation as party leader. But that party's collapse subjected the German political system to strain; the disclosure of Kohl's role as a glorified bagman for illegal contributions shook confidence further. Wolfgang Schäuble's enforced departure threatened a protracted period of weak opposition; it certainly helped Schröder's recovery in the recent Schleswig-Holstein elections.

The moral and electoral recovery of the CDU is good for Germany but will take time. A start has been made by the election of general secretary Angela Merkel as leader. It is partly her gender. Germany has some excellent women parliamentarians but the top echelons of both major parties have been all too masculine. It is partly her provenance. She is an eastern Protestant, heading a party which, despite electoral success in the east after the wall fell, remains heavily western and Catholic.

Frau Merkel's ultimate success will depend upon her willingness to deal harshly with ex-Chancellor Kohl, 70 this week. There are too many unanswered questions about its (his) income. The CDU's long-run interest requires her, as the Germans put it, to slay the parent. Beyond that she has immense work to do in re-fashioning the Christian Democrat perspective - on welfare, industrial subsidy, labour market flexibility, immigration and the old alliance with the Bavarian and worryingly Austrophile Christian Social Union. Her obligations are not just to her party but to Germany. If she needs a lesson from the UK, it is terse. The more effective the opposition, the higher the quality of the government.
