fields.headline: Sit down and be counted
fields.standfirst: Advertisers need to find out who is using the web. But are their covert methods threatening personal privacy?  Nick Rosen unveils the net snoops
fields.trailText: Advertisers need to find out who is using the web. But are their covert methods threatening personal privacy? Nick Rosen unveils the net snoops
fields.body:
Once we believed that one of the advantages of interactive media would be that the audience would be measurable to the last infinitesimal detail - and then sliced, diced, dissected and reaggregated to suit any marketing strategy. How wrong we were. We can't even count the number of people who look at the Guardian's home page. The only thing of which we can be certain is the behaviour of those who register on the site. The practical problems are multiple: no one has yet worked out how to count the exact number of internet users, of websites, of visits to websites, of emails or even of the total amount of information flowing around the net.

In a way this is a testament to the glorious anarchy of the internet. But measurement is going on, however unreliable, and the ethical issue of what happens to the resulting information is becoming more pressing as sophistication increases.

The difficulty with accurately counting the number of visitors to websites (and therefore the amount advertisers should pay) is caused by proxy servers, computers which are scattered about on the internet like radio booster stations. They allow internet service providers (ISPs) to give customers a much faster service, while simultaneously reducing the requirement for bandwidth needed to route the information around the internet. If many people are asking for the same web page it will be automatically stored on a proxy server.

At the biggest ISPs, such as AOL or Cambridge University, this means that a proxy server will register only one download from a given site, even though dozens or perhaps hundreds of people have called up the page.

There are complex arrays of proxy servers, which means that a single web page might be stored on multiple machines - the logo on one, text on another, audio on a third machine and so on. It has been impossible to count users of proxy servers without direct access to their log files, which are held by the owner of the server.

The number of users registered with a website might seem like a better statistic to hang on to. Once someone has registered it is much easier to follow his or her behaviour. Registration is not a panacea, however. Companies float on the stock exchange claiming they have "a million subscribers", and are valued on that basis. But how many of these subscribers are duplicates, or people who haven't bought anything?

Services such as Nielsen Netratings and MMX employ a traditional approach involving panels of users to count the number of viewers of the top few hundred websites. The highly fragmented website market means the panels cannot be used to monitor the whole net. There are too many sites which receive less than 0.1% of the audience.

Other services monitor changes in the usage of hardware and software. Network Wizards and Statmarket in the US and Netcraft in the UK all publish data on the types of servers on the Internet, the amount of traffic they have monitored and so on.

For intensive tracking, expensive "content management" software such as Broadvision or Vignette can tail users. Broadvision has an "observation engine" which monitors individual progress through all stages of a site from browsing to purchase. The Microsoft Commerce server with personalisation and membership has the advantage of costing only $10,000 (about £6,000) plus about $50,000 to customise. It has the disadvantage that it only works with Microsoft products.

Most of the services count only the top few hundred sites. What is needed now is an internet equivalent of the National Readership Survey which uses tried and trusted survey techniques to quantify national surfing habits. Only then will advertisers and publishers have data on which to base proper planning.

It is easy to forget that the web is not the internet - many use email without using the web. And email has become an important advertising and direct response tool. Amazing amounts of customer information can be collected from electronic direct marketing systems. Kana Connect, for example, can track a vast amount of information on recipients, including whether they open messages, click on links or make purchases. By tracking responses and transactions on an individual level, companies pinpoint valuable customers and determine how best to reach them in the future.

Kana can also be used to analyse the effectiveness of the customer support operation - such as average response times, message volume and individual or team performance levels - which leads to ethical questions about the use of the data that can now be collected.

The right to privacy is already being stretched by leading internet companies. Amazon, the online bookshop, caused protests last year when it released very limited details of the book-buying habits of small groups, such as Microsoft employees.

In the US, courts are examining some of the issues. Employers worry about "time-theft" as staff shop for groceries online in office hours. Staff believe that their digital personality belongs to them, not to their employer - but can they choose to go ex-directory? A cat-and-mouse game has begun, with the tools to count users becoming more refined and software also being launched to allow individuals to remain uncounted if they wish.

Individual privacy was supposed to be protected by the anonymity of the database. If I asked to be sent an ad on a particular subject, no one would know I had requested it. Only the software would keep the details of my preferences. This seemed like a fair model to most internet users - a contract where the individual provides information in return for information.

But that internet contract has been broken by companies such as Doubleclick, an advertising sales and hosting service. Doubleclick has tried to match anonymous statistics with actual consumer data to produce individual profiles which it can then sell to advertisers. Although the individuals are still, strictly speaking, anonymous, it is clearly overstepping the mark to use items of information about them in this way without their explicit permission.

Macromedia, which produces software for high-speed animation on websites, and Real Media, which specialises in audio and video on sites, also tracked the way their software is used. Net heads who do not read their agreements carefully miss the chance to opt out of the data-collection process. The software then records how it is used and the type of file being viewed. Periodically this data was sent back to corporate headquarters, much to the disquiet of civil libertarians who have launched a $500m lawsuit against Real Media.

Web publishers also use tiny pieces of software with the innocent-sounding name of "cookies", which are downloaded to the users' machines and sit there recording visits to the site in question. The technically adept have access to defensive software: WebWasher, for example, which filters out unwanted adverts by barring downloads from certain sites, and CookieWasher, which deletes cookies from files hidden in the bowels of the computer.

Ultimately, the only defence a publisher has is to give customers what they actually want, and to be quite explicit about what will happen to any information they glean.

 Nick Rosen is director of the Online Research Agency: nick@online-agency.com

fields.headline: Truman Show comes to town
fields.trailText: LaGrange, an industrial town beside the Chattahoochee River in Georgia, is an unlikely laboratory for a technological revolution. But its 27,000 residents are set to become America's first completely wired community.
fields.body:
LaGrange, an industrial town beside the Chattahoochee River in Georgia, is an unlikely laboratory for a technological revolution. But its 27,000 residents are set to become America's first completely wired community.

Arguably the oddest addition to the queue to become a free internet service provider (ISP), LaGrange's local government plans to provide free internet access for all residents via cable television. In doing so, it stepped straight into one of the most fiercely competitive areas of the communications industry.

Every home, school and company is to be connected to a high-speed network by autumn. The network, a combination of the town's existing fibre-optic pipes and coaxial cable, will be provided by Charter Communications, the company controlled by Paul Allen.

Mr Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft and one of the world's richest men, has long espoused his vision of a "wired world" in which we can rely on everyone we know being hooked up to the web. LaGrange is providing him with a real-life Truman Show, one in which everyone knows they are being watched.

Crucially, the bill for the experiment is being met by local government. Some $300,000 (£187,000) is going to be spent connecting homes which currently do not have a basic cable television service - about 20% of LaGrange's 11,000 households - as well as providing set-top boxes and keyboards. The interactive TV service provided by Worldgate, a Charter partner company, will be free for the first year.

Joe Maltese, director of community and economic development for the local authority, said that it rejected Charter's suggestion of a joint venture in which local residents paid a monthly fee. Afraid that the town's low-income families could not afford internet access, the council decided to foot the bill for everybody.

LaGrange has unusually large coffers for a local authority. It laid its own broadband fibre-optic cable network in 1992 and has been collecting money from users ever since, much to the chagrin of telecommunications companies.

Its prescience means it is not using local taxes to pay for its internet largesse, but the unusual nature of such an arrangement has not prevented town governments from as far afield as Bulgaria phoning for information about the scheme.

Officials say they decided to use city funds to pay for interactive television because, keen to attract hi-tech jobs to the area, they were concerned about the increasing divide between those who have internet access and those who do not. "As a community we are very concerned about the digital divide," said Maltese.

The reasons for the council choosing TV rather than personal computers were cost and convenience. The town, described as a "cross-section of America" by Mr Maltese, is neither rich nor poor.

About a third of its households own a personal computer, whereas 97% own televisions. Internet access is also divided along similar income levels to the rest of the country. US department of commerce figures show that households with annual incomes of $75,000 (£45,000) and above are 20 times more likely to have access to the internet than those at the lowest income levels.

Maltese hopes the service will lead to more community interaction. It could also test whether emails will replace the telephone completely and whether the cinema will need to employ ticket sellers if people can check what's on and book seats online.

Greater commercial involvement is expected to follow a review of the scheme a year from now. Some analysts, such as Josh Bernoff at Forrester Research, believe that it could be financed by e-commerce if it really takes off. That is, cable companies will be keen to join the free ISP rush if they can make a fat profit from how much is spent online as well as from advertising. Such analysis is behind the involvement of media and technology companies such as Charter, of course.

LaGrange provides a perfect controlled experiment with its sample-sized community, unique because the initial outlay comes from the local authority. In the UK, where the use of interactive television is already more common than in the US, BSkyB provides a prime example of the reverse - a company offering free or cheap equipment in order to reap the financial rewards of greater usage. Still, just 7% of its satellite subscribers have actually bought something through Open, its interactive service, even on its best estimates.

The LaGrange experiment is set to reveal the extent of any differences between a purely commercial approach and one which is universally applied. For residents currently forced to pay for an internet service, it could justify the town's trademarked slogan: LaGrange, Smart Move.

fields.headline: Need to know: Russ Freeman
fields.trailText: Age: 32.
fields.body:
Age: 32.

Who's he? Managing director of Gipsy Media, parent company of Digiguide. Formerly a tax and financial software developer at Digita Open Systems.

What's the clever idea? "Digiguide is an interactive smart searching tool that analyses upcoming TV listings based on a user's preferences and prepares a customised viewing schedule. We have the only product that offers online, offline, Wap and Avantgo [palm pilot] services."

What's the thinking behind it? "My colleague would come in every day and say, 'I watched a really brilliant programme last night,' and I would think, 'Wouldn't it be great if I had a mechanism to tell me about something coming up that I would want to watch?'"

How does it work? We go around different broadcasters and gather their different formats of data. This goes into a database which gets a little bit of manipulation to process updates to the schedules.

"We then categorise it and add keywords to the programmes - this took a while at the beginning, but we now have 25,000 programmes already categorised in our database.

"Thanks to Sky, there are so many repeats: channels like UK Arena and Paramount are a breeze for us to do. Once we're happy with the quality of the data, it gets uploaded to our website.

"The user each week clicks on a link to download updated schedules, and the other media update automatically. You feed it your preferences, tell it what programmes you like, and then it will highlight them for you.

"It will also remind you with a spoken word alert through your PC or a text alert through a Wap phone."

Shortcomings? "It only runs on a PC. If we had it on Linux and on Mac we would clean up, but we don't have the personnel in place yet who have the skills to programme on Macs and Linux. It's not as automatic as we'd like it to be, and there are other features that we would like to add, like a better ability to choose channels, but we have only just upgraded to version 3.1, and the magic bits will go into the version after that."

What's next? "It would be really nice if Sky used our electronic programme guide instead of their system.

"There are other companies such as NTL and Cable & Wireless which have their own systems as well. Or we could hook up with a hardware manufacturer and make our own version and get some of the early adopters buying our product.

"The service is also not in the right place physically for me to get the most out of it. My TV, my computer, they are the wrong place. There's a better place for it to go, and that's where we want it, but I can't tell you yet where that place is."

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 13: Post-it Notes
fields.trailText: Way back in the days of the cold war, popular wisdom had it that a pair of Levi 501s could get you a bigger flat and a brand new Trabant on the other side of the Iron Curtain. A good deal for the jeans trader, you might think. In fact, he woz robbed. Consider the case of the woman who went to Siberia to adopt a baby, but found herself faced with a belligerent Russian official and a shortage of cash. Her way to grease the wheels? Offer him a packet of Post-it Notes. Much to her amazement, it worked.
fields.body:
Way back in the days of the cold war, popular wisdom had it that a pair of Levi 501s could get you a bigger flat and a brand new Trabant on the other side of the Iron Curtain. A good deal for the jeans trader, you might think. In fact, he woz robbed. Consider the case of the woman who went to Siberia to adopt a baby, but found herself faced with a belligerent Russian official and a shortage of cash. Her way to grease the wheels? Offer him a packet of Post-it Notes. Much to her amazement, it worked.

There are many strange tales surrounding obscure pieces of office equipment, but this must be one of the strangest. Certainly few would dispute the value of little repositionable memos - how else would one attach abusive messages to a colleague's computer screen? But a bargaining tool for a child?

Post-it Notes truth is almost stranger than fiction, however. The inventor of the "low-tack" notepad, an American scientist called Art Fry, might even ascribe his discovery to divine inspiration, since he hit on the idea while singing in his local church choir. A meticulous chap, Art would mark each week's hymns in his song book, but found that the markers kept falling out. "I thought, what I really need is a bookmark that would attach and detach lightly, wouldn't fall off but wouldn't hurt the hymnal either," he recalled recently. Must have been a particularly boring sermon.

On Wednesday, Post-its will celebrate their 20th anniversary, and while the little sticky labels are now available in 30 different colours, the original shade of pale yellow is still the most popular. This was first chosen because they were originally intended to be the same shade as legal notepads. Lawyers, the manufacturers clearly reckoned, had more cause to leave abusive messages than the rest of us.

A meticulous chap, Art would mark each week's hymns in his song book, but found that the markers kept falling out. "I thought, what I really need is a bookmark that would attach and detach lightly, wouldn't fall off but wouldn't hurt the hymnal either," he recalled recently. Must have been a particularly boring sermon. On Wednesday, Post-its will celebrate their 20th anniversary, and while the little sticky labels are now available in 30 different colours, the original shade of pale yellow is still the most popular. This was first chosen because they were originally intended to be the same shade as legal notepads. Lawyers, the manufacturers clearly reckoned, had more cause to leave abusive messages than the rest of us.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: How did companies manage before databases? Card files are all very well, but for an organisation with 2.7m members, something more comprehensive is needed. "We have a brilliant database," says Thomas Bolton, membership assistant at the National Trust. "It was installed by CMG, an external company, and it makes the endless enquiries I receive far easier to deal with."
fields.body:
How did companies manage before databases? Card files are all very well, but for an organisation with 2.7m members, something more comprehensive is needed. "We have a brilliant database," says Thomas Bolton, membership assistant at the National Trust. "It was installed by CMG, an external company, and it makes the endless enquiries I receive far easier to deal with."

The Trust has an entire office in Bromley, Kent, dedicated to membership issues. Bolton deals with more complicated questions as they arise, and ensures the system as a whole runs smoothly. "For each of the names on the database, we store as much information as possible," he says. "I input everything - when each member joined, any special events they attended, donations they have made."

He believes that the massive capacity of the database allows him to give individual attention to each member. "The more information you have, the better service you can give. I can enter any membership number and see if there is anything they are particularly interested in, if they have ever complained or praised something specific - we can target them with mailshots that might be of interest and know a little about them if they phone with a query."

Many of the queries that come in are standard, so alongside the membership database there is another comprising 700 standard letters. "I've spent the past six weeks revising every one," says Bolton. Many were written some time ago, in quite formal business language, and I've tried to make them more friendly and less like a standard letter." Queries cover an endless array of subjects, from asking about education programmes to knowing where to find bluebell fields.

Although he was given a basic induction, Bolton believes that the only way to increase your knowledge of a database is to use it constantly. "Ours is based around function keys, and as soon as you know which does what you're off and running. People tend to think they're incredibly complicated, but actually they are extremely simple. The only downside is having to input the information in the first place - it can be extremely dull - but it's worth it in the end."

The most important thing, he says, is ensuring you input everything you should. "It's hugely annoying if you've cancelled your membership and still get newsletters, or you've asked for your details to be changed and they haven't been. It's important to make a proper list of everything you have to input and cross it out when it's done - that way you don't miss anything - and you don't get annoyed phone calls!" He has the following tips:

* Remember the database is there to serve the public not you, so ensure you input every detail - it will help you in the long run.

* Maintain a good relationship with the department/company which installed the database - you may need to turn to them for technical advice and support.

* Don't store up data to input - if you have to spend a whole day doing it, it can be mind-numbingly dull. Put aside some time each day and clear the whole backlog.

fields.headline: The low down
fields.standfirst: Internet exclusion
fields.trailText: Incredible as it may seem to the mobile-carrying middle class, there are parts of the country where 50% of households do not have a telephone. It goes without saying that living without a telephone prevents them doubling their giros by day-trading on Nasdaq. And as more facilities go online, including training in IT, there is a danger that the communications revolution will bypass large parts of the population.
fields.body:
Incredible as it may seem to the mobile-carrying middle class, there are parts of the country where 50% of households do not have a telephone. It goes without saying that living without a telephone prevents them doubling their giros by day-trading on Nasdaq. And as more facilities go online, including training in IT, there is a danger that the communications revolution will bypass large parts of the population.

Last week, however, a report from the government's social exclusion unit found grounds for optimism. Televisions are widespread, and the introduction of digital TV ought to give the excluded a second chance to jump on the internet bandwagon. But training will have to be given in the community, and it may be hard to find suitably qualified local volunteers.

There is also the problem of where training should be sited. People with literacy problems may not be keen to frequent the library, and community centres can be equally forbidding. One promising suggestion is to use local sports centres - genuinely popular facilities where the principle of catering for special groups is established. If you have over-50s keep fit, why not an over-50s computer night? This explains the otherwise surprising involvement of the national playing fields association in IT training. Founded 75 years ago to provide sporting facilities in inner cities, the association is leading the initiative to make the internet more widely accessible, armed with a millennial grant and support from Microsoft.

Community IT centres are already established in Hackney, Newport and Birmingham, with plans underway for another six. This is an opportunity to use community spaces to bring truly universal access to the net.

fields.headline: Milburn warned on nursing exodus
fields.trailText: Nurses are resigning their posts as fast as the NHS is filling others, the leader of the Royal College of Nursing said last night after a survey showed that nurses rank inadequate staffing as the biggest obstacle to improving care.
fields.body:
Nurses are resigning their posts as fast as the NHS is filling others, the leader of the Royal College of Nursing said last night after a survey showed that nurses rank inadequate staffing as the biggest obstacle to improving care.

Christine Hancock, the RCN general secretary, said nurses were walking out of the job in despair at being unable to give patients proper care.

"It's the failure to address retention that makes the problem worse and worse," she said in Bournemouth, where the RCN congress opens today.

Her words served as a warning to Alan Milburn, the health secretary, who will address the congress this week, that he cannot expect a wholly smooth ride since the government gave the NHS an instant £2bn.

The Mori survey, conducted among more than 1,200 RCN members, offers Mr Milburn some encouragement: three in four nurses say improving pay is very important or critical to patient care.

But pay comes only fourth among "critical" issues, after getting the right numbers or types of nurses, "employee friendly" policies, and well funded or supported professional development.

fields.headline: Poor nations' rights are wronged
fields.trailText: There are many irritating aspects to the so-called Third Way, but what particularly grates is its endless capacity to spawn meaningless catchphrases. Right up there when it comes to vacuity is "rights and responsibilities", the notion that in a something-for-something world you only have rights if you show responsibility.
fields.body:
There are many irritating aspects to the so-called Third Way, but what particularly grates is its endless capacity to spawn meaningless catchphrases. Right up there when it comes to vacuity is "rights and responsibilities", the notion that in a something-for-something world you only have rights if you show responsibility.

The philosopher kings of the Third Way are inordinately fond of this phrase, and there is no doubt that it sounds fine in theory. Translating the theory into practice is quite a different matter. There was no sign, for example, of any Third Way guru in Birmingham on Saturday to explain "rights and responsibilities" to those protesting about what has happened at Longbridge. As far as the Rover workers are concerned, you don't need to be a philosopher king to understand that in a world of footloose capital, BMW has the rights and Rover workers bear the responsibility.

An even more egregious example of the shortcomings of "rights and responsibilities" comes from the failure of the rich creditor nations and the multilateral institutions to make good their pledges on debt relief. With a few striking exceptions, developing countries have put their economies in order, have pledged to use debt relief on anti-poverty programmes, and have agreed to independent auditing to ensure that funds do not end up in Swiss bank accounts. So, plenty of responsibility. Now they expect something in return.

Sadly, this is not happening. Amid an orgy of self-congratulation last year, world leaders announced that the original heavily indebted poor country initiative was too limited and too slow. The answer was HIPC2, which would be faster, more generous and apply to more countries. But nine months on from the Cologne G7 summit and six months after the details were sorted out at the annual meetings of the World Bank and the IMF, it is clear that the souped-up HIPC2 looks very much like HIPC1.

In Britain, at least, alarm bells have started to ring. At the end of last year, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, said he hoped to see four countries through HIPC2 by the end of January, 11 by Easter and 26 by the end of the year. Not a single country had been granted debt relief by the end of January, only three have received it now and a maximum of five will have been processed by the time of the spring meeting of the World Bank and the IMF later this month. Brown and Clare Short, the development secretary, accept that at the present rate of progress there is not a chance of getting two-thirds of the 41 eligible countries into the process by the end of the year.

Brown and Short are not to blame for this. Indeed, Britain's record on debt relief - under the Conservatives as well as Labour - has been admirable. The real problem is in Washington, where the attempts of the US treasury to throw sand in the wheels of the HIPC process are being aided by the institutional torpor and rigidity of the World Bank and the IMF. As an added complication, it is Japan's turn to chair the G7 this year, and Tokyo had to be dragged kicking and screaming into supporting HIPC2.

The danger now is that the whole process starts to unravel. Japan has put a miserly $10m into the HIPC trust fund, which is supposed to be raising cash so that the World Bank and the regional development banks can write off their share of the debts owed by some of the world's poorest countries. The Clinton administration has only managed to persuade Congress to stump up two-thirds of the $600m pledged by the White House last year, and until it does the European Union will not release the $1bn it agreed to find from the European development fund.

Later this month, there will be an op portunity for another bout of rich-country grandstanding at the UN conference on education in Senegal, when fountain pens will be flourished with élan so that politicians can sign up to targets for ensuring primary education for every child on the planet by 2015. But at the moment this looks like a case of putting the cart a long way before the horse.

Debt relief is obviously not the only factor necessary for developing countries to build up a basic social infrastructure, but it is a key ingredient in any realistic package. As the UN secretary general Kofi Annan says today: "Let us be clear that without a convincing programme of debt relief to start the new millennium, our objective of halving world poverty by 2015 will be only a pipe dream."

Dying on its feet

Jubilee 2000 says that the five countries that will have scraped through HIPC2 by Easter - Uganda, Bolivia, Mauritania, Mozambique and Tanzania - will have had their debt burden reduced by 40% on average rather than the 90-100% write off that was promised. The quintet will still be paying more than half a billion dollars every year to foreign creditors - almost as much as they spend on healthcare. Uganda has one of the highest levels of HIV infection in the world, which has already orphaned 1m children. In Bolivia, 60% of the population has no access to basic sanitation; Mauritania has an adult literacy rate of 62%. Everybody knows what has been happening in Mozambique. Try telling the people there about rights and responsibilities.

Finding a way out of this mess does not require rocket science. Clare Short has been warning for months that the HIPC2 process has been dying on its feet because countries are being forced to submit absurdly detailed anti-poverty programmes before they secure debt relief. She says that all countries need at the outset is a rudimentary road map, and that the rest can be inked in later.

The Americans seem intent on slowing up HIPC2 at every turn. While the Clinton administration has made the right noises about debt relief publicly, inside the Bank and the IMF it has been pernickety about conditions that countries will have to abide by if they are to receive debt relief, arguing that states should have poverty reduction plans in place for a year before anything happens.

Campaigners say that one of the other great breakthroughs proclaimed last year - full consultation with civil society over poverty reduction strategy papers (PRSP) - has proved to be a bit of a joke. "The IMF told Mozambique and Mauritania that they could obtain rapid approval for debt relief under HIPC only if they did not put the PRSP out for public consultation."

As things stand, only 14 countries are likely to qualify for HIPC2 debt relief this year. Clearly this is nowhere near good enough, and it is now time for the Jubilee 2000 campaign, the churches and the others to help Brown and Short put pressure on the laggards among the G7 later this month.

Annan will throw his full weight behind the campaign to speed-up HIPC2 today, with a call for donor countries and the international financial institutions to consider wiping off their books all official debts of the heavily indebted poor countries in return for those countries making demonstrable commitments to poverty reduction. He will also outline a new approach under which there would be immediate cancellation of the debts owed by countries that have suffered major conflicts or natural disasters, expanding the number of countries in the HIPC scheme by allowing them to qualify on grounds of poverty alone, pegging debt repayments at a maximum percentage of foreign exchange earnings, and establishing a debt arbitration process to balance the interests of creditors and sovereign debtors and introduce greater discipline into their relations.

But none of this will happen without political will. Now is the time for some real leadership that accepts that everybody has the right to clean water, basic healthcare and an education, and those with the power and financial clout have a responsibility to ensure that they get them.

webTitle: Oxfam calls for asylum voucher boycott

fields.headline: Oxfam calls for asylum voucher boycott
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Oxfam has pulled out of the government's voucher scheme for asylum seekers and appealed to Sainsbury's, Asda and other major retailers not to take part until the home secretary, Jack Straw, drops a "penny-pinching clause" not to give change to people shopping with the vouchers.
fields.body:
Oxfam has pulled out of the government's voucher scheme for asylum seekers and appealed to Sainsbury's, Asda and other major retailers not to take part until the home secretary, Jack Straw, drops a "penny-pinching clause" not to give change to people shopping with the vouchers.

The decision by Oxfam, which runs 840 charity shops, is a blow to Mr Straw's new asylum laws which come into force today and which he hopes will cut the numbers coming to Britain and curb damaging political criticism.

The launch of the Oxfam "No to no change" is an embarrassment to Labour ministers. Sodexho Pass, the company which has the contract to run the national voucher scheme, has told potential retailers that as a cash incentive to take part they can keep any change due to asylum seekers when they use the vouchers to shop. So far 4,411 retailers with 10,789 shops, including some major chains, have signed up to take part in the scheme.

The scheme is being introduced today as asylum seekers have been banned from claiming welfare benefits while they wait an average of 13 months for a decision on their asylum claims. More than 50% of those whose applications were considered in detail were given refugee status or exceptional leave to remain in Britain last year. A single adult is expected to pay for all their essential living needs with vouchers worth £35 a week.

"Jack Straw must immediately remove this terrible 'no change' clause," said Oxfam director David Bryer. "We can't pinch pennies from poor people and this means Oxfam shops will not participate in the scheme until this is changed. Major retailers should not be party to a scheme that could lead to asylum seekers paying more for their shopping than other customers.

"Providing vouchers instead of cash already restricts where asylum seekers can shop. Refusing retailers permission to provide change when asylum seekers shop with them is unreasonable, unfair, and discriminates against these people at a time when they are most vulnerable," he said.

A mock voucher drawn up by Oxfam claims it entitles the bearer to "racist abuse, press hostility and government neglect" and that Mr Straw has bypassed the traditional British values of compassion, tolerance and fair play.

The home secretary said yesterday that the vouchers had already been shown to work and he believed the package of new measures, including the dispersal throughout the country of 30,000 applicants each year who apply as soon as they land in Britain, will defuse public criticism of asylum seekers.

"We have a very significant problem of huge pressure which has fallen very unfairly on Kent and some London boroughs. If people are genuinely fleeing asylum they won't mind at all going to a perfectly civilised city like Glasgow or my own constituency of Blackburn."

Mr Straw said the asylum laws, which include £2,000 fines on lorry drivers who bring in clandestine entrants, will help to get numbers of asylum applicants down.

Nick Hardwick of the Refugee Council warned the new asylum clampdown would prevent genuine refugees as well as economic migrants getting to Britain because the government had now made it so difficult for them to travel to Britain.

"If you are a victim of Saddam Hussain's Iraq the only way to get here now is by entering illegally and by paying vast sums of money to the criminal gangs who organise the trafficking business."

fields.headline: Two fingers to cannabis juries
fields.trailText: One of the glories of the jury system, and one of its great virtues, is that every now and again a jury comes up with a "not guilty" verdict when the evidence and the law point to guilty. It's a "perverse" verdict, to use the legal jargon, but perverse in the most honourable way possible. The jury is saying: "We do not think this prosecution should have been brought. Never mind what the law says, we think this case is wrong and oppressive, and we mark our disapproval by acquitting the defendant".
fields.body:
One of the glories of the jury system, and one of its great virtues, is that every now and again a jury comes up with a "not guilty" verdict when the evidence and the law point to guilty. It's a "perverse" verdict, to use the legal jargon, but perverse in the most honourable way possible. The jury is saying: "We do not think this prosecution should have been brought. Never mind what the law says, we think this case is wrong and oppressive, and we mark our disapproval by acquitting the defendant".

Juries have done this through the ages, from the acquittal of William Penn in 1670 (for which the judge sent the jurors to prison) to more recent examples such as Clive Ponting and the two men, Randle and Pottle, who helped the spy George Blake escape. Most recently a number of juries have acquitted people brought to court for possessing and sometimes cultivating cannabis when the accused, a sufferer from multiple sclerosis, claims that he only smoked the drug to alleviate his pain and distress.

That is not a defence to the charge (except by unrealistically stretching the defence of necessity); but it has allowed juries to demonstrate their displeasure with the prosecution. The government has now made it clear that it does not intend to relax the law to exempt such sufferers. So we might have expected that juries would continue to show their feelings by more acquittals.

But hang on. These cannabis offences are "either-way" crimes, from which Jack Straw is trying to remove the accused's right to trial by jury. If he gets his way, not only would defendants be denied their choice; juries would lose their centuries-old right to put two fingers up to government. A jury, the great Lord Devlin wrote, is "an insurance that the criminal law will conform to the ordinary man's idea of what is fair and just. If it does not, the jury will not be a party to its enforcement." Except when Jack Straw says otherwise.

Lord Saville, the law lord, has already spent two years preparing for the Bloody Sunday inquiry, which started last week. The taking of evidence will last another year or two, following which he'll have to devote many months to writing his report. By the end, Bloody Sunday will have taken four or five years out of his life. It will also have deprived the highest court in the land of his services for that long period.

Lord Phillips, another law lord, will have spent two years on the BSE inquiry. Saville and Phillips were appointed law lords because of their judicial excellence in deciding important cases. There are only 12 law lords, and two of them have largely been out of action since they were appointed. This is unacceptable. Apart from the loss of their talent, their absence has had a significant effect in increasing delays in the hearing of House of Lords appeals. The law has suffered.

The argument in favour of using law lords for national inquiries is that they are the best people to do a job which requires, basically, the sifting of evidence. But appeal court judges can do that just as well (Taylor on football ground safety, Scott on arms to Iraq, for instance) and there are three dozen of them to choose from - two absent ones would not cause difficulties and delays.

There's another aspect. Until quite recently judicial inquiries tended to take weeks or a few months. Now, for all sorts of reasons, they take many months, or years. It is unfair and contrary to all our interests to divert such valuable judicial resources as law lords for so long.

Unless you count Ally McBeal (please don't) there's been a lull in legal drama on television recently. Not for much longer. In June, Ross Kemp (Grant of EastEnders) appears as a gritty barrister-turned civil liberties solicitor in In Defence, a four-parter from Granada. Channel 4 is shooting a sort of Leeds version of That's Life, the series that provoked hundreds of young people to make inquiries about joining the legal profession in the mistaken (I think) impression that the sole purpose of lawyers was to get drunk and laid.

Most welcome of all, the funniest-ever radio comedy about the law, Chambers (written by Clive Colman), transfers to television in the summer, with John Bird reprising his radio role as a pompously inept barrister.

fields.headline: Visit your one-stop advice network
fields.standfirst: From today a new community legal service will deliver help and representation in civil cases.  Clare Dyer explains how it operates
fields.trailText: Pop into your local supermarket and along with the loo rolls and baked beans you may soon be able to pick up tips on how to deal with the noisy neighbours or what to do about the bully at work.
fields.body:
Pop into your local supermarket and along with the loo rolls and baked beans you may soon be able to pick up tips on how to deal with the noisy neighbours or what to do about the bully at work.

Under a pilot scheme run by the East Riding of Yorkshire council, shoppers at Safeway in Willerby will have the chance from this summer to put their legal problems to a network of solicitors, citizens advice bureaux, Humberside law centre, the local council and voluntary services through an interactive kiosk. A video-link will allow them to discuss their problem face-to-face with an advice worker.

Another kiosk to be set up in the village square at Easingham, a remote coastal village, will link people with the advice services which cluster in towns. The project, supported by a grant of £500,000 from the lord chancellor's department, has been spawned by a partnership between the local authority, solicitors, advice agencies and government as part of the new Community Legal Service. The project could provide a blueprint for advice services nationwide.

Around the country, partnerships have been coming up with bright ideas since they were launched in the first six pioneer areas - Kirklees, Liverpool, Norwich, Nottinghamshire, Southwark and Cornwall - in December 1998. The Community Legal Service will be officially launched at 11 o'clock this morning when Cherie Booth presses a button and its impressive website, www. justask.org.uk, goes live.

The new service has not been widely heralded but it marks a revolution in the way publicly funded legal services are delivered. Some 50 years after its birth, legal aid has been abolished, though the term will no doubt take time to die out. The legal aid board has been replaced by the Legal Services Commission. Through the commission, the Community Legal Service will deliver advice, help and representation in civil cases.

If you need help with a court case, you will no longer get legal aid, but "litigation funding". The changes are not just semantic. Public funds will no longer act as what the lord chancellor's department minister David Lock calls "a subsidy for ad hoc private litigation".

The government will no longer bankroll lawyers to do the work that lawyers want to do. Instead, the aim will be to deliver the services people need, through lawyers in private practice but also through skilled advice workers. With hindsight, the original legal aid scheme was too legalistic, too focussed on court-based solutions. Under the old scheme, if you had a legal problem you could go into any solicitor's office and claim legal aid if you passed the means test. Now only solicitors with a contract or franchise can do state-funded work. Their numbers have dropped from 11,000 or so to only 5,500.

Instead of just paying for whatever work lawyers decide to do, the government has set priorities. From April 1, legal aid has been withdrawn from personal injury cases; these will now be handled by lawyers under no-win, no-fee deals. Funding will still be available in most of the traditional fields, including divorce. But priority will be given to social welfare cases, covering people's basic entitlements to social security benefits and a roof over their heads; cases of fundamental importance to the people affected, including adoption, childcare and domestic violence; and cases with a wider public interest, such as challenges to the actions of public bodies.

But in local areas partnerships are setting their own priorities. Some areas, as one former minister put it, are advice deserts, others advice mazes. Traditionally, while agencies referred cases to solicitors, few referred clients to other agencies. Whether someone with a problem found the right helper was largely a matter of chance.

Last November Paths to Justice, the largest survey of the ways the public tries to solve legal problems, painted a picture of people floundering about trying to find help and often giving up in frustration. The Community Legal Service aims to change that picture. Partnerships now operate in 70 areas, covering one third of the population of England and Wales. By April 2002 the aim is to cover 90%.

A key task of partnerships is to set up effective local referral networks so people with problems will end up in the right place, no matter at what point they enter the system. In Derby, Wendy Endsor went to her local law centre when she encountered difficulties at work.

"I worked as an after-sales manager for a company bringing in cars from the Continent. I went off sick to have an operation and was told I would have to work as a receptionist when I came back. The law centre said they couldn't do that - what they were proposing was constructive dismissal. I sent in my notice and said I was leaving due to my demotion."

Carol Lambert, an advice worker at the law centre, represented her at the tribunal, supervised by Jon Jarvis, a law centre solicitor. Endsor won the case and was pleased to get £2,500 compensation. "I hadn't really thought about money. I just didn't want them to do to somebody else what they'd done to me."

Using the Just Ask website's powerful search engine, anyone with a problem will be able to key in a simple cry for help - such as "I am being evicted. Help me" - and come up with an answer from among 400 other sites. There is also an electronic directory of 15,000 sources of help including solicitors, advice centres and specialist resources, which will produce a list of the nearest helpers speaking a particular language and knowledgeable about the particular area of law. From today, commuters and shoppers will be able to access the website at TownPages information booths in train stations and supermarkets around the country.

Hazel Genn, professor of socio-legal studies at University College, London and author of the Paths to Justice survey, said: "My book ended by saying there's a huge need for information and help. If the Community Legal Service is capable of delivering early advice so it can get in and knock problems on the head before they become huge, I think it's an incredibly good idea. We will have to watch and see how it's used."

fields.headline: Hardball with Microsoft
fields.standfirst:
Maybe fines would concentrate its mind

Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft is in the digital version of the last chance saloon. Over the weekend the judge mediating between the Seattle-based colossus and the US government confessed that differences between the two sides over how to break its monopoly grip "were too deep-seated to be bridged".
fields.body:
Microsoft is in the digital version of the last chance saloon. Over the weekend the judge mediating between the Seattle-based colossus and the US government confessed that differences between the two sides over how to break its monopoly grip "were too deep-seated to be bridged". Unless Microsoft offers much deeper concessions then nemesis will follow: the company will either have severe legal constraints put on it or else be broken up into smaller legal entities or "Baby Bills".

Microsoft is a brilliantly successful company and most of its customers seem happy with the way it popularised desktop computing and established de facto standards both on operating systems (of which it has over 90% of the world market) and popular software like Word and Excel where its market share is similar. But it is also a monopoly and has, as the Justice department has found, exploited its position to attempt to snuff out competition - as when it struck exclusive agreements with internet service providers to display only Microsoft's browser. Mainly as a result of this, rival Netscape's market share (once 80%) has slumped to under 27% and Microsoft's has soared to 77%. Microsoft has offered some concessions - like allowing other software makers to see more of its key Windows code - but the mediator has rightly rejected them. Meanwhile Microsoft turned down overtures from the justice department for Microsoft to develop a version of its Office software for the (free) Linux operating system.

Unless - which is possible - there is an eleventh hour agreement, Microsoft is likely to appeal against the verdict thereby keeping it in the courts for another few years while business goes on as usual. But if Microsoft is guilty of monopoly abuse then one consequence is that its prices - and therefore profits - have been far too high. (It makes a net 40% return on sales.) These "excess" profits have financed strategic investments in key areas like cable television and wireless. Without that money, Microsoft's strategy might have been more modest, leaving more opportunities for competitors. In natural justice it surely ought to "repay" profits earned from an abuse of its monopoly power. It may prove too difficult to backdate any restitution. But, if Microsoft were told that from now on excess profits will be paid back with heavy interest, it might concentrate its mind most singularly. We might even get a settlement by Friday.

fields.headline: Africa is getting worse
fields.standfirst: What is needed is political commitment
fields.trailText: For years to come the image which will define Africa will be one from the Mozambique floods: a woman clinging to a skinny tree, surrounded by muddy water, her arm outstretched for a rescuing helicopter crewman. It graphically illustrated the desperation experienced by millions of Africans in different crises all over the continent. Unfortunately, it also reinforced an erroneous and common impression of the passivity of Africans in such situations and the heroic superman role in which the developed world likes to cast itself.
fields.body:
For years to come the image which will define Africa will be one from the Mozambique floods: a woman clinging to a skinny tree, surrounded by muddy water, her arm outstretched for a rescuing helicopter crewman. It graphically illustrated the desperation experienced by millions of Africans in different crises all over the continent. Unfortunately, it also reinforced an erroneous and common impression of the passivity of Africans in such situations and the heroic superman role in which the developed world likes to cast itself. So, fact and fiction are muddled in our perceptions of a vast continent which, as Kofi Annan pointed out in his speech to the Commonwealth Institute last month, presents the international community with its biggest test in the 21st century.

The truth is that Africa is struggling to deal with a coincidence of crises. First, ecological catastrophe means floods, droughts, desertification, falling yields and soil erosion; this weekend, the UN warned of a massive famine in the Horn of Africa. Second, Aids has slashed life expectancy in many countries, killing the most economically productive generation and leaving behind millions of orphans and unsupported elderly. Yet the capacity of many African countries to deal with either of these crises is crippled by war, internal conflict and political corruption.

But what is largely fictional is the notion that the international community - Cairo is currently hosting the first ever European Union-Africa summit - is making serious efforts to help Africa. The initial burst of generosity when we see a distressing image on our television screens is quickly replaced by indifference. This government has done more than its predecessors; it has reversed the long decline in the aid budget and Gordon Brown has pushed for debt relief. But even that achievement is now in danger of coming seriously unstuck, as our economics editor points out in his column today.

What everyone agrees on is that the key to the continent's development is primary education. Exhaustive studies have shown that the single most effective development policy is the education of girls. Primary education increases agricultural productivity, reduces infant mortality and improves the distribution of wealth and political stability. But far from reaching the 2015 target of universal primary education, illiteracy in Africa is increasing, enrollment is lower than in 1982 and, if current trends are not reversed, Africa will account for three-quarters of all primary school age children not in school by 2015. This is not for lack of African investment in education - they spend more in proportion to their GDP than other countries - but because a combination of slow economic growth and expanding populations have crippled their efforts to keep up.

At the end of this month, Dakar's Education for All conference is supposed to approve the blueprint showing how the target of universal primary education by 2015 is to be achieved. There is increasing danger that it will achieve nothing but the kind of warm words and unachievable targets which give international conferences a bad name. What is desperately missing is political commitment and leadership from Tony Blair (who is not planning to attend) which might prevent our children having to dig ever deeper, ever more frequently into their pockets, for crises in an impoverished continent. Surely this is at least as great a test of his doctrine of international community, enunciated in Chicago a year ago, as Kosovo ever was.

fields.headline: Fishermen drown after night out
fields.trailText: Two fishermen drowned off the Isle of Skye yesterday after a man fell into icy waters during stormy weather and his friend tried to rescue him.
fields.body:
Two fishermen drowned off the Isle of Skye yesterday after a man fell into icy waters during stormy weather and his friend tried to rescue him.

The pair had returned to their trawler moored at a small jetty in Loch Harport off Carbost on the island early on Sunday after an evening in the local pub.

Murdo Morrison, 45, fell into the water and his companion, Donald John Macleod, 33, jumped in to try to save him but they got into difficulties in force 7 winds and heavy snow showers.

A third crewman also dived in, but he was saved by Alex Murdo Macleod, skipper of the 60ft trawler, Astra, who threw down a rope and hauled him back on board.

The coastguard launched an air and sea search while police and local volunteers searched the coastline. Both bodies were recovered yards away within hours.

The Astra - a shellfish trawler registerd in Stornoway, on the island of Lewis - was one of seven vessels to berth in Carbost on Saturday night to shelter from gale-force winds.

A spokeswoman for the coastguard said: "The conditions were horrendous, with wind, rain and snow." Angus MacIver, Stornoway coastguard watch manager, said: "Given the time of the night, the temperatures and the wind chill factor, the water would have been very cold."

Mr Morrison, who was married with a five-year-old son, and Mr Macleod both lived on Lewis.

Mr Macleod had been a member of the crew for about a year, and Mr Morrison, a mechanic, was covering for another crew member.

Relatives of the dead men were comforted yesterday by port missionary John Hamilton of the Royal National Mission to Deep Sea Fishermen.

The coastguard launched an air and sea search while police and local volunteers searched the coastline. Both bodies were recovered yards away within hours. The Astra - a shellfish trawler registerd in Stornoway, on the island of Lewis - was one of seven vessels to berth in Carbost on Saturday night to shelter from gale-force winds. A spokeswoman for the coastguard said: "The conditions were horrendous, with wind, rain and snow." Angus MacIver, Stornoway coastguard watch manager, said: "Given the time of the night, the temperatures and the wind chill factor, the water would have been very cold." Mr Morrison, who was married with a five-year-old son, and Mr Macleod both lived on Lewis. Mr Macleod had been a member of the crew for about a year, and Mr Morrison, a mechanic, was covering for another crew member. Relatives of the dead men were comforted yesterday by port missionary John Hamilton of the Royal National Mission to Deep Sea Fishermen.

webTitle: BT ready to put up retirement age to over 70

fields.headline: BT ready to put up retirement age to over 70
fields.standfirst: Shortage of management skills prompts rethink
fields.trailText: British Telecom is poised to be the first company to raise the retirement age beyond 70 because of a growing shortage of management skills at senior level, highlighting a growing issue throughout British industry.
fields.body:
British Telecom is poised to be the first company to raise the retirement age beyond 70 because of a growing shortage of management skills at senior level, highlighting a growing issue throughout British industry.

The company, where the official retiring age is 60, has been examining the problem for the past year. It is particularly concerned that it has lost many valuable senior managers between 50 and 60, and cannot easily replace them.

Although the company said yesterday that "it is not an issue at the moment", sources within BT said last night that the company was increasingly having to draw upon outside consultants because the pool of senior management skills was diminishing. In some cases a retirement age of up to 74 was being considered.

A source said: "This is very much a live issue at BT. Senior staff retention is extremely important. Because of early retirement many of them sometimes leave for larger salaries outside, and we just cannot afford to lose them. We will have to take a decision."

Sources said that the first person to be affected by the move could be BT's chief executive, Peter Bonfield, who is approaching 60. They said that BT's employment rules made no provision for him to stay on beyond 60.

The crisis at BT comes as the government is about to launch its performance and innovation initiative designed to get people over the age of 50 back to work.

The inactivity of older workers is estimated to cost the British economy £26bn a year in lost production, one fifth of the gross domestic product over the next five years.

Margaret Hodge, minister for employment and equal opportunities, said: "The government believes that wasting talent by displaying age prejudice in the workplace is bad for the economy and unfair on the individual.

"But we cannot tackle age prejudice on our own. With the help of our partners in industry, we can make sure that more people wake up to the message that it is damaging society as a whole."

The CBI said that "a change of culture" was under way on early retirement. It added that many of its members were struggling to find ways of retaining older staff, a situation which was being exacerbated by the buoyant labour market.

Several other leading companies apart from BT are campaigning to give older people better opportunities in the work place. They include the BBC, Boots, Dixons, B&Q and Sainsbury's.

Helen Garner, campaigns director of the Employers' Forum on Age, an employer-led organisation to promote a mixed-age workforce, said: "We have come to view our ageing work force as a burden, not an asset. But this ignorance and prejudice is costing us dear."

Ms Garner said that most employers did not seem able to grasp that a "demographic time bomb has exploded in the UK" and that there had been a significant shift in the working population. She said that 28% of men over 50 were inactive compared with 7% in 1975.

Within five years, 36% of the labour force would be over 45, and by 2010 the figure would have grown to 40%, yet only 17% of those at work in five years will be aged between 16-24.

Research by Reed Skills Index shows that 56% of companies are experiencing skills shortage in recruitment. The company said that it made "strong commercial sense to increase the size of the pond and bring in many people who are excluded from the workplace simply because of age".

Sainsbury's said that it was actively pursuing a policy of recruiting older people. Although their productivity was lower than younger people's, they were extremely reliable and flexible.

The company said it employed 1,486 people over the age of 65, of whom 10 were over 80. One of its 80-year-olds is a former managing director, and a 72-year-old worker is a former City banker.

fields.headline: Reprieve for historic jet fighter
fields.trailText: Defence secretary Geoff Hoon has stepped in to save a potent symbol of the Thatcher years - the last of the Anglo-American Phantom jet fighters that defended the Falklands.
fields.body:
Defence secretary Geoff Hoon has stepped in to save a potent symbol of the Thatcher years - the last of the Anglo-American Phantom jet fighters that defended the Falklands.

Mr Hoon has ordered a stay of execution on three Phantom FGR-2s mothballed at RAF Leeming in North Yorkshire, the last left after the type was replaced by Tornados. His order, sent less than 10 days before the planes were to be handed over for scrap, follows a campaign by the Yorkshire air museum, at Elvington airfield near York, whose desire to restore and exhibit a Phantom had been frustrated by a Pentagon ban on sale of military aircraft other than to governments.

Ian Richardson of the museum said yesterday: "The outcome is by no means certain but Mr Hoon now has time to look at our case and, we hope, intervene with the Ministry of Defence and the US embassy."

The FRG-2 was built in the US by McDonnell Douglas but was fitted with Rolls Royce engines, electronics and avionics by British Aerospace at Brough, near Hull.

The fighter, as well as being a mainstay of Britain's cold war air defence, was based on the Falklands to deter further hostilities by Argentina following the islands' recapture.

webTitle: Chart topper sets record for Westlife

fields.headline: Chart topper sets record for Westlife
fields.trailText: Irish boy band Westlife made pop history yesterday by becoming the first group in the UK to see their first five singles enter the charts at number one.
fields.body:
Irish boy band Westlife made pop history yesterday by becoming the first group in the UK to see their first five singles enter the charts at number one.

As Fool Again hit the top of the charts the quintet earned record-breaking status and an entry in the Guinness Book of Records. The band, which is on a promotional visit to New York, was planning to celebrate the news with a bottle of champagne

Band member Kian Egan said: "It's like a dream come true. Who would have ever imagined two years ago that we would be making chart history?"

Boyzone singer Ronan Keating, who is co-manager of Westlife, has helped the group achieve success far more quickly than his own Irish boy band.

Although Boyzone has so far attained six number one singles, these were spread over six years.

The Spice Girls made number one with their first five singles, but they did not all enter the charts at the top.

webTitle: 'I'm 93, but quitting job would drive me off my trolley'

fields.headline: 'I'm 93, but quitting job would drive me off my trolley'
fields.trailText: Jim Dowd, 93, perhaps the oldest working man in Britain, was taking a rest yesterday from his six-day week as a trolley supervisor at Sainsbury's.
fields.body:
Jim Dowd, 93, perhaps the oldest working man in Britain, was taking a rest yesterday from his six-day week as a trolley supervisor at Sainsbury's.

Mr Dowd, a retired motor fitter, said he might put his feet up and watch television, "but it's usually very boring and I prefer to work." At Sainsbury's Finchley Road branch, north London, he pushes trolleys from bays in the car park to the store for customers. He works a 33-hour week Monday to Saturday, and said he was fit as a fiddle, apart from a slightly gammy knee. "I intend to go on working until I drop.

"There is nothing else to do, and I love it." He joined the company eight years ago, having returned to work at 69 because he was bored and missed his job repairing cars.

Sainsbury's allowed him to cut the tape when the store opened several years ago because he was so popular with customers.

The manager, Jim Rutledge, has offered him a job in the store, but Mr Dowd said: "I have refused it. The only job I want inside is his, and he won't let me have it."

Mr Rutledge said: "Customers are very fond of Mr Dowd, although they sometimes ask how long he can go on working. He is always cheerful, and we value his contribution."

He travels to work by bus from his sheltered accommodation in Hampstead. His wife died five years ago. He spends most of his six weeks of holiday in the Lake District, driving 300 miles to a farm near Cockermouth.

He does not go walking but admires the lakes "by driving round all the passes".

fields.headline: Warning by Mandelson to Unionists
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday warned Unionists against "raising the bar" of their expectations if republicans were to disarm.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, yesterday warned Unionists against "raising the bar" of their expectations if republicans were to disarm.

Mr Mandelson also said the peace pact was in danger of slipping away if the difficulties in the political process were not overcome.

Speaking during a visit to County Antrim's Corrymeela Centre, set up 35 years ago to foster reconciliation across Ulster's sectarian divide, the minister said paramilitary disarmament was essential for a return to the powersharing government that was suspended seven weeks ago.

But he added: "Unionists have got to convince republicans that if they do deal with the arms, they [Unionists] are not going to ask for more, raising fresh obstacles to make it harder for people to reach accommodation."

Mr Mandelson had a stern message for those opposed to the political process: "Those people who are refusing to reach agreement and enable both sides to come together, they will have a lot of responsibility on their heads if we lose just one more life in this conflict." He said, however, that he remained optimistic that the impasse would be overcome, and he was working every day to find new ideas that would be acceptable to all sides.

webTitle: Memories of Morris Century-old bedspread goes on display

fields.headline: Memories of Morris Century-old bedspread goes on display
fields.trailText: A unique bedspread, as immaculate as the day it was made by the William Morris workshops more than a century ago, has been given to the National Trust and has just gone on display at Standen, an arts and crafts house near East Grinstead, West Sussex.
fields.body:
A unique bedspread, as immaculate as the day it was made by the William Morris workshops more than a century ago, has been given to the National Trust and has just gone on display at Standen, an arts and crafts house near East Grinstead, West Sussex.

Although the bedspread has never been displayed before, the owner rented it out to film designers in the 1940s and 1950s, and it appeared in several British black and white films.

The owner, now in her 90s, cannot remember which films. The trust's property manager at Standen, Ruth Gofton (with the bedspread, right), plans to trawl through films of the period to try to spot it.

Morris, artist, author and philosopher, was an influential designer of the 19th century. Specialists at the Victoria and Albert museum believe the bedspread is a one-off, entirely made by professional embroiderers.

The donor, herself an expert at needlework who wishes to remain anonymous, was given the bedspread by a client more than 60 years ago on condition that it eventually went on display.

fields.headline: TV adverts 'make men look silly'
fields.trailText: Women are being made to look intelligent, assertive and caring in television adverts while men often appear pathetic and silly, according to research for the Chartered Institute of Marketing.
fields.body:
Women are being made to look intelligent, assertive and caring in television adverts while men often appear pathetic and silly, according to research for the Chartered Institute of Marketing.

It showed that while woman have escaped the stuffy home environment of the Oxo adverts of old, men are increasingly the butt of advertisers' jokes.

In the survey of 1,019 adults, 38% thought "gullible" was the characteristic most likely to be associated with men in adverts, with only 12% thinking men came across as caring and 14% as intelligent. By contrast, more than 25% said women had a caring, assertive or intelligent image.

The image of men as beer drinking football fans and of women as clothes and make-up shopaholics was seen by 39% and 48% of viewers respectively as a frequently used but inaccurate stereotype.

The group was asked about the advert for the Fiat Punto in which a man explains that the car features capacity for 94 shopping bags, 24 pockets for make-up and a girlie button for power steering. A woman explains it features a navigational system, "because if you can't find your way around a woman's body you won't be able to find your way around Birmingham".

Of those that had seen the commercial, 26% found it patronising to women and 17% patronising to men. Despite this, more than half the men and 39% of the women found it amusing.

webTitle: Donor appeal girl, 6, has new heart

fields.headline: Donor appeal girl, 6, has new heart
fields.trailText: A six-year-old girl who had been given just hours to live was last night clutching at a new chance of life after undergoing an emergency heart transplant.
fields.body:
A six-year-old girl who had been given just hours to live was last night clutching at a new chance of life after undergoing an emergency heart transplant.

Sally Slater was described as "still very poorly but progressing" in the intensive care unit at the Freeman hospital, in Newcastle upon Tyne.

"It's still very early days but she is stable and we are hoping for the best," added a hospital spokeswoman.

Sally's father Jon later said: "We saw her a couple of hours ago. She is under sedation and there is a long way to go. But we never thought we would get to this stage. We feel a mixture of apprehension and big hope at the moment."

The operation came barely a fortnight after the previously healthy youngster was struck down by cardiomyopathy - caused by a virus that attacks the muscles of the heart.

Her condition swiftly worsened, and on Friday Mr Slater and his wife, Bridget, both 36, launched an 11th hour appeal for a donor.

Speaking of his "wonderful, wonderful girl", Mr Slater, an independent financial adviser, from Malham, North Yorkshire, said: "We are asking a lot. We want people to think of Sally even while their own child is dying or has died.

"Perhaps saving the life of another child might be a small compensation for someone who has lost their own daughter or son."

Early on Sunday morning a team of surgeons began their battle to save Sally.

Speaking after the operation, Mr Slater said the family was told a donor heart had been offered at 9pm on Saturday but they had to wait until 11.30pm to learn whether it was suitable. "From then on it has been a nerve-wracking time for us," he added from the hospital, where he and his wife were keeping a vigil.

Mr Slater, who has two other children, Joe, five, and Charlie, three, said he could never express his gratitude strongly enough for the donor's family, whose identity is not being revealed by the hospital. "There is a family who have lost someone and our thoughts are with them," he added. "We would not have the hope we have now if it was not for them."

Thanking the media for their help in publicising Sally's case, he added: "It is impossible to tell whether the national appeal helped bring this heart forward. And we may never know if the appeal directly caused the heart to become available - but it won't have done any harm."

The hospital is one of three in England that performs heart transplants. The family, who appeared cautious after the surgery, were warned that the first 48 hours after any operation are critical.

"It's too early to say one way or another but we are optimistic," said a Freeman hospital spokeswoman. She said it would be at least a week before the child was out of intensive care. "Without this operation, we simply don't know how long she would have survived."

webTitle: Will the line stretch to crack of doom?

fields.headline: Will the line stretch to crack of doom?
fields.trailText: A group of students from Leicester university will next month attempt to set a world record by staging the complete works of the Bard back to back.
fields.body:
A group of students from Leicester university will next month attempt to set a world record by staging the complete works of the Bard back to back.

Three actors will appear in every one of the 40 plays, getting little or no sleep for five days. At an average of 19 lines of iambic pentameter a minute, the students predict they should be starting into Shakespeare's last play, Henry VIII, by lunchtime on day four.

Seb Foot, 21, who hopes to stay the full course, said they had been employing a rigorous training programme of late nights to prepare for their ordeal. "We're not all mad though I think this is going to test our sanity. It might be the 250 lines from the fragment of Sir Thomas More that pushes us over the edge. We're hoping we finish in time to go out to celebrate on the fifth night, then I think we'll sleep for a week."

Roger Scoppie, who runs the university's theatre, said the record attempt was made possible because of the recent inclusion of Edward III in the canon. "Up to now it has been seen as one of the apocryphal texts and attributed to an unknown author."

Lord Attenborough, who was brought up on the campus, hailed the attempt as "great and extravagant folly".

The continuous readings will start with Shakespeare's first play, A Comedy Of Errors, and continue chronologically right through to the little-known late plays such as The Two Nobel Kinsmen which Shakespeare is believed to have penned in collaboration with other playwrights.

The student union next to the university theatre will be kitted out with camp beds so that "the actors can put their heads down for an hour between parts", he said. Only one play, As You Like It, will be performed from memory; the rest will be read.

Dr Scoppie said he would be enforcing an alcohol ban. Pharmacological stimulants would also be frowned on.

Without a hint of irony, the students also hope a high street bank will sponsor their Merchant Of Venice.

Money raised from the marathon, which starts on May 1, will go towards paying for the university's staging of As You Like It at the Shakespeare Youth 2000 Festival in Vilnius, Lithuania, later this year.

Only one play, As You Like It, will be performed from memory; the rest will be read. Dr Scoppie said he would be enforcing an alcohol ban. Pharmacological stimulants would also be frowned on. Without a hint of irony, the students also hope a high street bank will sponsor their Merchant Of Venice.
