webTitle: Enigma wrapped up in a mystery

fields.headline: Enigma wrapped up in a mystery
fields.standfirst: Professional gang suspected as Nazi code machine is stolen from Bletchley Park
fields.trailText: The theft of a unique German Enigma code encryption machine from Bletchley Park was masterminded by a professional gang stealing to order, trustees at the world war two intelligence centre said yesterday.
fields.body:
The theft of a unique German Enigma code encryption machine from Bletchley Park was masterminded by a professional gang stealing to order, trustees at the world war two intelligence centre said yesterday.

Police are investigating how thieves overcame tight security to steal the machine worth more than £100,000 during a daring afternoon raid.

Bletchley Park, codenamed Station X during the second world war, is now a museum run by a charitable trust. Its director Christine Large said she believed at least four people were involved in the theft. Suspicion of a sophisticated plan grew because the machine was supposed to be under tight guard and checked every 15 minutes. Furthermore all people on site needed security passes and there was only one exit for the thief.

Mrs Large said: "This operation was carefully planned. Some of the gang were involved in distracting the volunteers overseeing the area at the time, while the machine was carried out."

Bletchley Park had recently been advised by the security services to beef up anti-theft measures, and was due to implement the suggestions later this month.

The Buckinghamshire station was set up to break the Enigma code used by the German high command to transmit top secret messages. Cracking the code is credited with shortening the war by two years as it gave the Allies advance knowledge of Nazi military manoeuvres.

The machine, stolen during an open day on Saturday, is believed to be the only one of its kind, having belonged to German SS intelligence - the Abwehr - and having a different internal design to others of its type and producing a more advanced form of the Enigma code.

It was kept in a side room in a mansion house on the site and housed in a glass display case. Police confirmed that no broken glass was found at the scene, suggesting that a glass panel was removed and then replaced by the thief.

One senior figure at Bletchley said someone could have removed the machine from its display case by posing as a workman carrying out maintenance work or pretending to be relocating the machine to Bletchley Park's archives.

Police said there was no evidence that the machine was stolen for sale on the lucrative Nazi memorabilia market.

Security was due to be stepped up as attention on the crucial wartime work at Bletchley Park intensified. As well as a major television series last year, two feature films are in production, one starring Harvey Keitel and Jon Bon Jovi.

Rolling Stones frontman Mick Jagger owns an Enigma machine and visited Bletchley Park recently.

Michael Smith, author of the book Station X, said: "I can't believe the Enigma has been stolen to order. The trouble someone would have in selling this would be immense."

From 1939 Bletchley Park was home to a maverick team built to crack the Enigma code. Up to 10,000 people were employed, comprising mathematicians, linguists, chess champions, cryptologists, anthropologists, crossword puzzlers and Egyptologists, augmented by hundreds of personnel listening to enemy communications.

Winston Churchill called the staff at the top secret establishment "the geese that laid the golden eggs and never cackled".

By breaking the Enigma code, which the Germans had thought impossible, vital intelligence was gained by Allied forces. Some military historians say that if it were not for Bletchley park's work, the D-Day landings would have had to have been delayed until 1946, rather than 1944.

Cracking Enigma became crucial as the war in the North Atlantic escalated. Allied convoys began to suffer heavy losses as U-boat squadrons, commanded by messages encrypted on Enigma machines, attacked seemingly with impunity. With no clue as to what the Germans were saying to each other, the allies were operating blind, and the war was being lost.

The efforts of the codebreakers at Station X were led by the genius of Alan Turing, father of the modern computer.

Having established that the source of Enigma was essentially mechanical, Turing oversaw the construction of "bombes", large computing machines capable of running through large numbers of possible positions in a short period of time.

By 1941 Enigma was being cracked with regularity and in the following year the German Navy's version of the Enigma code was cracked, with the intelligence gleaned used in the battle of the Atlantic.

As fast as the bombes offered solutions, however, the Germans changed the settings of the Enigma machines. The secret of regularly cracking Enigma lay in recovering a machine and the code books distributed to German operators.

The legacy of Bletchley is enormous. It was the birthplace of the modern computer, and the myriad of surveillance techniques perfected during the cold war had their genesis at Station X. But perhaps most remarkable of all was the secrecy. Its very existence was only revealed in 1974.

Mr Smith said: "Thousands and thousands of lives were saved by the work done at Bletchley and the Enigma machine is a centrepiece of the type of work that went on there. I just hope it's returned safely."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Cost of burial rises to £2,000
The average charge of a burial is £2,048, up 25% on two years ago, according to an internet survey of undertakers for the friendly society Oddfellows.
fields.body:
Cost of burial rises to £2,000
The average charge of a burial is £2,048, up 25% on two years ago, according to an internet survey of undertakers for the friendly society Oddfellows.

It said some of the rise was due to council cemeteries charging more for a plot, but also cautioned the charges were estimates and the final bill might be more. Cremation now costs an average £1,215 - 12% up in two years.

'Too few' women councillors

Women hold only 27% of seats in local government, according to a report by Labour MP Harriet Harman.

One council of 442 in England, Scotland and Wales had a majority of women members - Aylesbury Vale in Buckinghamshire, with 57% female councillors. Scotland had the lowest pro portion, 21.8%, and the South-west the highest, 29.2%.

Schoolboy dies in quarry fall

A body brought up by a rescue team from a ledge 100ft down a quarry at Penmaen Head in North Wales, was identified yesterday as Mark Jones, 14, who lived less than a mile away.

His mother had thought he had been staying with a friend on Friday night after a birthday party.

Doctorate for David Hockney

David Hockney, 63 and born in Bradford, is to receive an honorary doctorate of letters from the University of Leeds at a ceremony on June 8, when Lord Melvyn Bragg, TV presenter and author, will be inducted as the university's chancellor.

Ten share £10m on lottery

Ten tickets each won £1m in Saturday's lottery, with winning numbers 3, 9 11, 19, 25 and 30; bonus 16. In the Thunderball game, no tickets matched winning numbers 2, 6, 13, 22 and 25, and Thunderball number 1.

webTitle: Hague makes pitch for the 'mainstream majority'

fields.headline: Hague makes pitch for the 'mainstream majority'
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader accuses ministers of arrogance and dishonesty
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday accused Tony Blair's government of such arrogance, dishonesty and incompetence that it has forfeited the trust of Britain's "mainstream majority" which put Labour into power in 1997.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday accused Tony Blair's government of such arrogance, dishonesty and incompetence that it has forfeited the trust of Britain's "mainstream majority" which put Labour into power in 1997.

In a speech which combined scornful language about the prime minister and his chancellor, Gordon Brown, with an optimistic assessment of the Tories chances at the coming election, Mr Hague effectively set out his manifesto strategy.

"Remember this, that we not only can win, we must win," the Conservative leader told 1,000 supporters at his party's spring conference in Harrogate, North Yorkshire, where senior shadow ministers struggled to deflect attention away from Michael Ashcroft's peerage and towards Labour's problems.

He received a two-and-a-half-minute standing ovation from grassroots activists who are beginning to regain their confidence after the 1997 massacre as they see Tory gains at local elections and the shine coming off some of Labour's successes.

Mr Hague explained: "As every day goes by this Labour government drifts further and further away from the values, expectations and opinions of middle Britain. This failure, this drift provides [us] with our greatest political oppoprtunity for many years. We are going to punish Labour for abandoning middle Britain."

Mr Hague's text contained at least 17 references to "middle Britain," "mainstream Britain" or the "mainstream majority". He used his keynote address at lunchtime yesterday to weave them into familiar themes which the Tories will deploy between now and likely election day in May or June 2001.

They ranged from Labour's stealth taxes - "for every pound of tax cuts, £9 of hid den tax increases" - and its alleged plans to take Britain into the EU single currency to its failure to deliver on its promise of better public services - notably the newly-cash-rich NHS. Mr Hague also promised to stop releasing sex offenders from prison.

But the speech was conspicuous for personal vituperation against Mr Blair and Mr Brown and for confirming what the chancellor predicted during Friday's strategy meeting at Chequers: that Mr Hague will seek to break Labour's winning coalition between low and middle income voters - the "mainstream majority" whose allegiences decide modern elections.

Downing Street and Millbank believe that Mr Hague's repeated error is to sacrifice long-term gain for short-term advantage and that yesterday's rightwing language about Labour's record on asylum-seekers, crime and red tape, will leave him outside the mainstream by election day.

Last night the chief secretary to the Treasury, Andrew Smith, countered by charging the opposition with promised tax cuts that do not add up. "The truth is they would cut public spending and undermine public services," he said.

Mr Brown was accused of a dishonest budget speech, full of half-truths and evasions - cheered by "the useful idiots on the Labour benches" - in which the "sneakiest and stealthiest chancellor of all time" re-announced bits of good news, but omitted to re-announce bad news which raised taxes.

But his real venom was reserved for Mr Blair, whom he called "a remote and out-of-touch man who still thinks he is a president", not a prime minister, someone who had tried and failed to unite and control his party, "a control freak who has lost control".

Mr Hague declared: "The very strengths this prime min ister was keenest to boast about have been revealed instead as the seeds of his decay and his destruction. He sought to rise on the back of support that is a mile wide, but he will fall as he finds that his support is an inch deep".

Voicing what Tory MPs and activists increasingly say about the Blair style, Mr Hague added: "He sought to present himself as everyman believing in everything and standing for everyone, but now we know he leads a bunch of nobodies who believe in nothing and stand for no one."

The Tory leader, who will be pressing his case in a rare visit to the Royal College of Nurses (RCN) conference tomorrow, savaged Labour over the section 28 row and over devolution - where the "so-called devolved government (in Scotland) won't put one foot in front of the other until it's been told to do so by Downing Street".

In a tendentious rendering of the Livingstone-Dobson battle to be Labour's candidate for London mayor, Mr Hague suggested that the former GLC leader's only offence was that he "did not agree" with Mr Blair.

The Lords had stood up to the government, he added. He then accused Mr Blair of rigging the Lords, too.

fields.headline: -and she scores!
fields.standfirst: Tabloid readers are usually spared details of the negotiations behind the kiss 'n' tell stories that appear on their front pages. A new documentary will change that. About time too, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: Television money has put a high price on footballers. Some men out there are worth £30 million or more in the transfer market. But that is the cost of their whole body. In Cutting Edge - Kiss 'n' Sell (Tuesday, 9pm, Channel 4), Sue Bourne's bouncy documentary about why and how people go to the press, 21-year-old Emma Padfield, described by the Sunday Sport as a Serial Soccer Shagger, crisply puts a price list on the part they keep in their shorts and show in the communal showers.
fields.body:
Television money has put a high price on footballers. Some men out there are worth £30 million or more in the transfer market. But that is the cost of their whole body. In Cutting Edge - Kiss 'n' Sell (Tuesday, 9pm, Channel 4), Sue Bourne's bouncy documentary about why and how people go to the press, 21-year-old Emma Padfield, described by the Sunday Sport as a Serial Soccer Shagger, crisply puts a price list on the part they keep in their shorts and show in the communal showers.

The average Premiership footballer is £10,000, explains Emma. "And if you have two or three Premiership footballers at the same time, it's £20,000."

Emma should know, because she has scored what serial soccer shaggers presumably refer to as a hat-trick. It's a soccer convention that if you put in three on the pitch, you get to keep the ball. But after Emma's put in three off the pitch, she takes theirs, calling up a tabloid reporter with a blow-by-blow account of what went on.

In serial soccer shagging, as in the sport she services, training and preparation are all. Emma carries a dictaphone to record their conversations - often disappointing because, she laments, "footballers are really thick" - and a camera to collect visual evidence when they fall asleep afterwards. It's a bit like being a spy. In fact, it's entirely like being a spy.

Most people have a guest list for their 21st birthday party. Emma had a wish-list. "I'm inviting football teams, journalists, photographers and television companies," she confided to the documentary crew which she had also invited to follow her on this intimate occasion.

She should probably also have invited a neurologist, because any footballer who had turned up would have needed his head examined. And, showing that footballers are not really as thick as she might have dreamed, Emma went to bed at 21 without any further opportunity to discuss the offside trap.

Emma was the co-star of the film; the other was Emma. A critic once pointed out that an essential difference between factual and fictional writing is that, in novels, you never get two characters with exactly the same name. Kiss 'n' Sell had two serial soccer shaggers, both called Emma. One operated in Yorkshire, the other in Surrey. Well, to be fair (as footballers like to say in interviews), there are 92 clubs in the league. A single serial soccer shagger would simply be playing too often.

The two scorers disagreed over tactics. While the Northern Emma knew her goal when she made a pass, the Home Counties one claimed only to blow the whistle when she was fouled. Of her current squeeze, she confided: "I'm pretty sure I'm going to sell a story on him soon." The director asked why. "Because the relationship isn't going anywhere." Yorkshire Emma's calls to the press were simply business. Surrey Emma's were unfinished business.

But - although it has two characters with the same name - it's still hard to be certain that this film is fact rather than fiction. As none of the men in question took part, Bourne is left relying on witnesses well used to amplifying their narratives for effect. You sometimes wonder if the Emmas are simply Match Of the Day viewers with lively imaginations.

You would be more willing to bet your replica shirt on the evidence of Lisa - a Tyneside pizza waitress who was once alternately dating Paul Gascoigne and Ruud Gullitt - and sold her story to the Star after details had been revealed. The best moment is her revelation that the Star reporter had assumed the silky Dutch play-maker would be better in bed than the porky Geordie. When she called the game the other way he "seemed disappointed". A Euro-sceptic newspaper politically, the Star is apparently in awe of the continent erotically.

Dave - the Star reporter who handled Lisa's case - is a shave-head in a pinstripe. He resembles the detectives seen on Crimewatch and sees himself as a moral policeman. When he called Gullit's mobile to reveal that he knew Ruud had been taking away the waitress as well as the pizza, the star shouted at the Star. Dave calmly told him that he should save his breath for home and "try to patch up your marriage".

The story of Nick - an old friend of Sophie Rhys-Jones who sold pictures from a holiday to the News Of The World - makes the documentary's main anthropological point: that there are now no social barriers to telling tales to tabloids. The duke and the dustman both know the Wapping phone numbers. Experience is an investment to be cashed in later.

It was clear that I had an opportunity to sell my soul, recalls Sophie's friend Nick of his meeting with the News Of The World. Bourne's film is best on the cost of a soul. Most tales of tabloid payment seem to be exaggerated. On this evidence, the going rate is the price of a smart new car to drive away fast from those you've betrayed.

Yorkshire Emma ends the film by announcing that her next target is Glenn Hoddle. If he falls for that one, he deserves to come back as a slug. But perhaps Hoddle could settle the theological question of what the next life of the Emmas, Lisas and Nicks will be when they've already been rats this time around.

But perhaps Hoddle could settle the theological question of what the next life of the Emmas, Lisas and Nicks will be when they've already been rats this time around.

fields.headline: Click here
fields.trailText: Many of the claims made for the way in which the internet has changed culture are fanciful. But one genuinely influential aspect of the web has been the development of information paths.
fields.body:
Many of the claims made for the way in which the internet has changed culture are fanciful. But one genuinely influential aspect of the web has been the development of information paths.

The way in which sites contain links connecting users to stores of material on similar themes is aped in newspapers by the printing of a box at the end of pieces which directs the reader to websites on associated topics. Context and memory - two factors which tend to be absent from daily journalism - are now provided by computer databases.

Such cross-referencing is increasingly common in television. For some years, schedulers on the networks have screened earlier works of a director or actor to coincide with the release of the latest.

The BBC1 Controller Peter Salmon has started to use his programmes in the same way. His arts series Omnibus (tonight, 10.40pm, BBC1) screened a profile of Mrs Gaskell to coincide with the channel's adaptation of Wives And Daughters, and BBC1's version of The Great Gatsby is now followed by a documentary about the history of Fitzgerald's novel.

Some critics have complained that these tie-in films are puffs or advertising. But they are surely being used in precisely the way that a reader of Fitzgerald's novel might now search for a website about him.

The spread of digital channels will expand the use of television link-sites. A new Alan Bleasdale serial could coincide with a reshowing of an earlier one on digital. It's well known that readers who come to a writer late will often read the previous books. At the moment, television viewers with the same historical curiosity need to use a video shop.

The Internet has had many baleful effects - encouraging pornography, risking the bankruptcy of credulous investors in dot.com companies - but in nudging culture to develop a memory it has been entirely benign.

fields.headline: Florida Woman, where are you?
fields.standfirst:
She drives an estate car, married a man named Melvyn and holidays at Disney World. And senior Tories believe she is key to their success in the next general election. But does such a person really exist? Julian Borger tries to track her down in Orlando

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: She drives an estate car, married a man named Melvyn and holidays at Disney World. And senior Tories believe she is key to their success in the next general election. But does such a person really exist?  Julian Borger tries to track her down in Orlando
fields.body:
Long before I was through describing the kind of woman I was looking for, Jan Nichols began to laugh and shake her head in an appreciative manner, as if she found my quest entertaining, albeit slightly pathetic.

"I don't think you'll find anyone like that in here," she shouted above the music. We were in the Hard Rock Cafe, the gigantic Orlando branch where Jan is a manager. She was from Hull and would try to help me, although she didn't think I stood much of a chance. This was proving much, much harder than I had expected.

All I wanted was a woman over the age of 33 with an income over £20,000, probably married with kids that she would pile into the back of the estate car sitting in the drive. Or perhaps it was a 4x4 or a minivan.

I had been told she would bring the whole family here, to the Sunshine State, to escape temporarily from the pressures in Britain - the second-rate education system, the worsening hospitals and the smug government with its preachy, holier-than-thou Prime Minister.

Her name would be Anthea or Glenys, or perhaps Geeta if she had Asian antecedents. But when I met her I would know her simply as Florida Woman. Where was she?

The Conservative party has supposedly discovered that there are tens of thousands like her - enough to win the next election, even. They have identified her as their paradigm target voter, the Conservative answer to Tony Blair's Mondeo Man of 1997. In fact, it seems quite likely that Florida Woman has married Mondeo Man, and is now poised to turn him away from the stealth-socialism of New Labour in the name of William Hague.

I had spent the better part of a uncomfortably hot, humid Orlando Saturday approaching strangers in car-parks, shopping-malls and theme-parks, and I had yet to find a single Florida Woman.

We - the photographer Vasha Hunt and I - had started out at the Delta Orlando Resort, where my research had predicted Florida Woman would be plentiful. And indeed, when I ran through the Identikit checklist (age, income, likely attitude and attributes), a helpful American woman listened carefully and nodded. She was sure there were plenty like that in the hotel, but right now they would be out enjoying what the state had to offer.

Florida is the world's biggest playground. The attractions fan out in all directions from the state's heart at Orlando - Disney World, Universal Studios, car racing, aquaria, alligator swamps. By the time you reach the Kennedy Space Centre in the east, it seems like another theme park, with solid fuel booster rockets in place of giant mice named Mickey.

Maybe this is what gives Florida Woman her special identity. She is drawn to Florida because it is a monument to capitalism. Only an unbridled economy could be productive enough to turn an area the size of England into a funfair, with enough parking for the rest of the world. An Eden of leisure where everything works and service comes with a smile.

From the Delta Orlando Resort, we drove a short distance to Universal Studios, a pastiche city built in homage to cinema, ringed by reputedly the biggest multi-storey car-park in the world. We left the car in the King Kong section and - at Vasha's prompting - wound up in the Hard Rock Cafe with the helpful and friendly Jan.

"You won't find Florida Woman here," she said, chuckling.

The customers we talked to more or less proved her point. Katie Murray had come on holiday with her parents, Barbara and John Stormont, her husband Lionel, and Joseph, her two-year-old. They were all originally from the London area, although the Stormonts had moved out to Dorset. John was a sales director and Lionel was a publican. Katie and Barbara were both housewives.

Like Florida Woman, Katie and Barbara both voted Labour in 1997 but now agreed that the Blair honeymoon was over. Just as we began to hope we had found what we were looking for, they both insisted that their state of mild disappointment did not leave them pining for William Hague.

"He's a real non-starter, a real non-entity," Katie said. "Even with Portillo, though he's a right-winger, they'd do better. At least he's got a bit of character."

Barbara agreed with her daughter's withering assessment. "Even getting married hasn't improved him," she said.

Anyway, mother and daughter agreed, things were not nearly bad enough to make them wander from the Labour fold. There were problems in the state schools, but the comprehensive Katie had been to had after all provided a good education. And yes, the National Health Service was creaking, but Labour had just earmarked a whole pile of new money for the hospitals.

Seeing our disappointment, Jan intervened to say lunch was on the house and tried to cheer us up by announcing that she had strong Tory leanings. Her father had been a policeman and successive Conservative governments had looked after him well. She had had her baby at Orlando's Arnold Palmer Hospital, and thought it was a thousand times better than the NHS. She did not think private health insurance was that expensive and most Americans who did not have it had probably opted not to spend money on it.

Unfortunately for Hague, however, this instinctive Tory had no plans of going back to Britain to vote, not in the next election, probably not ever. Jan had gone beyond the bounds of Florida Woman's template and had decided to stay.

If we wanted Florida Women, she suggested, we should try Orlando's famous shopping malls, where British tourists congregated in the afternoon after a day's baking in the sun. "You'll see them all in their black shorts and socks," Jan predicted.

There were no Brits in black shorts and socks at the mall, but the British were still clearly identifiable at a hundred paces. It was partly the sunburn, though there were sunburnt Americans too, and partly the unassuming way that the Britons walked and shopped - as if they expected their consumer rights to be stripped from them at any moment.

Margaret Tvedt and Irene Watson were having a great day's consumerism at the almost endless open air mall at the end of Orlando's International Drive. Prices for most well-known clothes brands were less than half what they would be back home, and Margaret was taking the opportunity to buy some new kit for her son, Chris, who was working as a waiter at the British pavilion in Disney World. At work he said he wore our traditional national costume: a yellow shirt, blue plus-fours, white knee-socks and black shoes.

Neither Margaret nor Irene seemed promising material for Hague. They were both Scots, for one thing. Margaret, a 46-year-old who drives a BMW cabriolet at home, had voted Conservative in 1997 and probably would again, so did not represent a net Tory gain. Irene, meanwhile, was wavering, but in the opposite direction from Florida Woman. She had voted Conservative last time, but had been encouraged by all the money New Labour said it was going to put in the NHS, and would wait and see if it went towards financing "more bodies in beds" rather than just bureaucracy.

When asked what they thought about William Hague, both women said "Not a lot" at the same time.

"He doesn't have much charisma or stature and that puts a lot of people off," Margaret said. "He's not attractive to look at, and that seems to count for a lot these days, unfortunately."

In the end, the nearest candidate to Florida Woman we found in Orlando was called Jill. Jill Robinson was from Cobham in Surrey and she was crazy about Florida. This was her third time in Orlando with her husband, Martin, and their sons, Tom and Harry.

They had moved away from the London borough of Wandsworth partly to escape the benighted state schools there, they said. Martin, an architect, thought Blair was doing a creditable job but Jill held a different, much tougher view (an encouraging, Florida Woman-like trait).

"The health service is in a terrible mess," she said. "And I think he's slowly putting up the cost of living. It's such a gradual process that we're being hoodwinked."

Moreover, Jill had good things to say about the young Conservative leader. "He's a very good debater. There are no two ways about that. And he does seem to be listening to what people in the party are saying," she said. "They are still sorting themselves out as a party, but I feel at the moment the Conservatives are in a better position to improve things."

Unfortunately, Jill Robinson was not an exact fit for Florida Woman's glass slipper. She drove an old Toyota Celica, not a Jeep or an estate. And she was not a repentant Blairite. She was an instinctive Tory who had simply not voted in 1997. Still, I was in no mood to be fussy. After all, she represented a net electoral gain for Hague. Martin agreed that his wife was about as close as we would find.

But the fact remains that, after scouring the state's tourist hub for a whole day, we had found only one Florida Woman. It seemed unlikely that she was a new, unstoppable force in British politics. It was more like tracking down a rare and fragile species in the wild.

Perhaps that is the way things are with these political safaris. Maybe Tony Blair's Mondeo Man and Worcester Woman seemed equally exotic in their day, only to breed into trampling herds of Labour voters when the election came around. Could Florida Woman be doing the same thing, gathering strength at the home of Mickey Mouse until she is strong enough to crush New Labour with a single blow? Don't hold your breath.

Most wanted: the floating voters they tried to woo

Florida Woman

Name: Glenys, Anthea or Geeta. Married to Melvyn, Rod or Ajay.

Age: 33-55

Earnings: Combined income of £20-50,000, mostly brought in by Melvyn, an accountant or plumber.

Habitat: A semi-detached or former council house in East Anglia, the London suburbs or the north-west.

Markings: Two kids, an estate car and some Asda carrier bags. Hall table laden with PTA letters, a programme from a recent trip to Miss Saigon and brochures for package holidays in Disneyworld.

Politics: Naturally Tory, but wooed and won by Labour in the last election. Glenys now worries about class sizes and NHS funding - and occasionally asks Melvyn if the Tories might be worth another try.

Essex Man

Name: Derek or Barry

Age: 25-45

Earnings: £12-20,000 from the day job as a builder, though he may top this up moonlighting on Fridays as a bouncer at Sparkz nightclub.

Habitat: Housing estate in Basildon.

Markings: Ford Capri with go-faster stripes, furry dice and a personalised plate. Used to wear shell-suits but now prefers to dress down in jeans and West Ham shirt. Sports gold jewellery bought in duty free on the flight back from Benidorm.

Politics: Formerly a Labour voter, he swung firmly to the Thatcherite right in 1979. He calls the former PM "Mrs T" and laments that the country has gone to the dogs since her departure. Strongly in favour of Clause 28, though may not know much about it.

Worcester Woman

Name: Debbie, Paula or Carolyn

Age: 25-40

Earnings: £15-18,000 from her job as a clerk at the Halifax, but stopping work to have kids put a serious dent in the family finances.

Habitat: Three-bedroom detached Barratt house in Worcester.

Markings: Never leaves the house without makeup and has her highlights done every two months. Reads the Daily Mail.

Politics: Debbie never voted Labour in her life until 1997, when she decided Tony Blair looked pretty genuine. The Conservatives had gone a bit far with the poll tax, after all. Beginning to wonder whether Labour are all they are cracked up to be, and strongly believes they need to spend more on the NHS.

Mondeo Man

Name: Gary, Martin or Brian

Age: 30-55

Earnings: £18-30,000 from his job as a medical rep or estate agent.

Habitat: Semi-detached house at a new development in Didcot.

Markings: Enjoys polishing the car at the weekend, dressed in jeans and a T-shirt from Burton. Feels like he spends much of his life stuck in traffic jams on the M25, when he passes the time listening to Pink Floyd CDs and Capital Gold.

Politics: Naturally suspicious of anything too lefty, but decided New Labour really had changed and might be just be worth trusting on the economy.

fields.headline: Sail of the century
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV
fields.trailText: "Full fathom five Thy father lies."
fields.body:
"Full fathom five Thy father lies."

A lovely landscape with a liberal topping of twaddle goes down nicely on a Sunday. There are quiet days when you would rather not have your emotions stirred up as with a mighty spoon. That's why the Wednesday play was on a Wednesday. Deceit (BBC 1), a two-part psychological thriller, has oxygenating Suffolk seascapes. All that dazzle on the water, all that superfluous sky make you feel you've had the day at the seaside you were vaguely considering.

Clare Francis's area of expertise is ships, as Dick Francis's is horses, so there is a good, strong skeleton to the story, based on her novel.

Which is that Harry Richmond and his yacht have vanished without trace leaving Ellen, a beautiful, consolate widow (Francesca Annis), a couple of children and a fine tangle of debts and skullduggery.

Red herrings are laid out neatly nose to tail. Harry has been having an affair with a blonde. He seems to have embezzled a quarter of a million from an orphans' charity. His own money has softly and secretly vanished away.

Det Inspector Thing assumes - as one would - that Harry is even now in Acapulco with the blonde.

Several men are sniffing around Ellen and there is someone with respiratory problems lurking unseen in the shrubbery. (This somehow reminds me of Frank Benson, a famous Hamlet in his day, who, when his memory failed, would say "Crouch we awhile and mark!" to the horror of his Horatio.)

The nautically named Jack (Peter O'Brien) , handsomest and most assiduous of the sniffers, discovers that Ellen herself was seen taking Harry's yacht to sea on the day he disappeared.

She tells him that Harry committed suicide and she took the boat to sea and scuttled it ("Sever all the waste pipes! Open the sea cocks! Close the hatches!") to hide the body. I greatly admired the way Francesca Annis leaped from boat to boat, apparently doing her own stunts. It was a gripping sequence because it was based on solid, nautical sense but otherwise it made no sort of sense at all.

I am pretty sure I can guess the real reason for Harry's death and disappearance without reading the book. It is just amazing how many bestsellers I haven't read.

Bob Martin (ITV) is an all-too plausible comedy about the host of a tired game-show. Michael Barrymore as Bob seemed unusually subdued but Terry Wogan as, well, Wogan, made a meal of a media monster, shrouded in shadow and cigar smoke. It was as though Barrymore was determined not to be mistaken for himself. And so was Wogan.

The plot was that Bob Martin wanted to present the Eurovision Song Contest. In Top Ten: Eurovision (Channel 4), Wogan gave a battle-scared commentary from the front. (Should that be battle-scarred? Not necessarily). Luxembourg was a particularly fraught assignment. Wogan said: "You couldn't get anywhere near the hall for motorised vehicles and special forces and uzis and machine guns, machine gun nests, tracker dogs, razor wire. You had to beat your way in and, on the night, I'll never forget the floor manager saying to the audience: "Please do not stand up to applaud or you may be shot by the security forces." Shooting the audience is a novel twist. In Israel, when Dana International fell off her high heels, security thought she had been shot and flung themselves on her in heaps to take the second bullet. Or that's what they said afterwards.

The Last Of The Summer Wine (BBC 1) is a series about second childhood, a second chance to be carefree and a nuisance to your neighbours. In age Foggy, always Foggy to me, Clegg and Compo reverted to the boys they had once been, though, strictly speaking, Compo had never verted in the first place. Ivy, who ran the cafe, said of him "You'd think every day was playtime." To become as little children is a holy thing or, of course, in Compo's case, holey.

They were often shot from afar, to seem smaller in the vastness of the landscape, affecting not to hear the hard-hatted, big-busted women calling "William! Come here at once and get washed!"

Compo's real name, by the way, was William. Like Bill Owen.

Which is that Harry Richmond and his yacht have vanished without trace leaving Ellen, a beautiful, consolate widow (Francesca Annis), a couple of children and a fine tangle of debts and skullduggery. Red herrings are laid out neatly nose to tail. Harry has been having an affair with a blonde. He seems to have embezzled a quarter of a million from an orphans' charity. His own money has softly and secretly vanished away. Det Inspector Thing assumes - as one would - that Harry is even now in Acapulco with the blonde. Several men are sniffing around Ellen and there is someone with respiratory problems lurking unseen in the shrubbery. (This somehow reminds me of Frank Benson, a famous Hamlet in his day, who, when his memory failed, would say "Crouch we awhile and mark!" to the horror of his Horatio.) The nautically named Jack (Peter O'Brien) , handsomest and most assiduous of the sniffers, discovers that Ellen herself was seen taking Harry's yacht to sea on the day he disappeared. She tells him that Harry committed suicide and she took the boat to sea and scuttled it ("Sever all the waste pipes! Open the sea cocks! Close the hatches!") to hide the body. I greatly admired the way Francesca Annis leaped from boat to boat, apparently doing her own stunts. It was a gripping sequence because it was based on solid, nautical sense but otherwise it made no sort of sense at all. I am pretty sure I can guess the real reason for Harry's death and disappearance without reading the book. It is just amazing how many bestsellers I haven't read. Bob Martin (ITV) is an all-too plausible comedy about the host of a tired game-show. Michael Barrymore as Bob seemed unusually subdued but Terry Wogan as, well, Wogan, made a meal of a media monster, shrouded in shadow and cigar smoke. It was as though Barrymore was determined not to be mistaken for himself. And so was Wogan. The plot was that Bob Martin wanted to present the Eurovision Song Contest. In Top Ten: Eurovision (Channel 4), Wogan gave a battle-scared commentary from the front. (Should that be battle-scarred? Not necessarily). Luxembourg was a particularly fraught assignment. Wogan said: "You couldn't get anywhere near the hall for motorised vehicles and special forces and uzis and machine guns, machine gun nests, tracker dogs, razor wire. You had to beat your way in and, on the night, I'll never forget the floor manager saying to the audience: "Please do not stand up to applaud or you may be shot by the security forces." Shooting the audience is a novel twist. In Israel, when Dana International fell off her high heels, security thought she had been shot and flung themselves on her in heaps to take the second bullet. Or that's what they said afterwards. The Last Of The Summer Wine (BBC 1) is a series about second childhood, a second chance to be carefree and a nuisance to your neighbours. In age Foggy, always Foggy to me, Clegg and Compo reverted to the boys they had once been, though, strictly speaking, Compo had never verted in the first place. Ivy, who ran the cafe, said of him "You'd think every day was playtime." To become as little children is a holy thing or, of course, in Compo's case, holey. They were often shot from afar, to seem smaller in the vastness of the landscape, affecting not to hear the hard-hatted, big-busted women calling "William! Come here at once and get washed!" Compo's real name, by the way, was William. Like Bill Owen.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Getting High: The History Of LSD
fields.body:
Getting High: The History Of LSD

6pm, History

"Like a genie released from the bottle, it was capable of great good, and terrible evil," begins the narrator, on what turns out to be an enlightening trip into the world of one of the most fascinating drugs of all time. It shows how acid evangelist Timothy Leary led the countercultural deification of the drug and delves into the history of the CIA's early experiments. The government agency gave it to New York strippers to slip into the drinks of their customers, then watched the results through one-way glass.

On The Waterfront

(Elia Kazan, 1954)

4pm, Sky Cinema

Classic lesson in method mumbling from Marlon Brando as Terry Malloy, the pug turned stevedore struggling against Lee J Cobb's corrupt dockers' union. Meaty cast also includes Rod Steiger as Terry's so-disloyal brother, Karl Malden's upright priest and Eva Marie Saint. Kazan wanted Arthur Miller to do the script, but he was put off by Kazan's testimony to the HUAC committee. Budd Schulberg's writing wasn't bad, though: "And what do I get?" Terry accuses his brother, "A couple of bucks and a one-way ticket to Palooka-ville."

Jefferson In Paris

(James Ivory, 1995)

8pm, FilmFour

A classic Merchant-Ivory job on Thomas Jefferson and his time as US ambassador to France, just before the revolution. Nick Nolte, though not entirely comfortable in period costume, makes a powerful, thoughtful figure of the president-to-be, although the subject here is affairs of the heart. And a fine performance from Greta Scacchi as his lover.

Misery

(Rob Reiner, 1990)

10pm, Sky Cinema

William Goldman's script weaves dark humour into a black tale. James Caan is a romantic novelist who finds himself in Stephen King-land when he is rescued from a car crash and imprisoned by psychopath fan Kathy Bates. Tension mounts as she persuades him to stay - with the aid of her trusty ol' mallet...

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Jim Carrey in Peggy Sue Got Married (Francis Ford Coppola, 1986)
fields.body:
Jim Carrey in Peggy Sue Got Married (Francis Ford Coppola, 1986)

Who? Carrey may have started his career talking out of his butt, but he's come a long way. Not shy of discussing his psychological issues (at length), Carrey has said, "I tend to stay up late, not because I'm partying but because it's the only time of day when I'm alone and I don't have to be on, performing." Fond of recounting the details of his terrible youth - working as a janitor, living in a trailer - Carrey's teenage misery spurred him on to join the exclusive ranks of those actors who can get over $20million a film. He still yearns for recognition as an actor , but failed to get an Oscar nomination for either of his "proper" films, The Truman Show and the upcoming Man On The Moon. Carrey's talents are most effectively used by the genius Farrelly brothers (Dumb And Dumber) with whom he has just finished split-personality comedy Me, Myself and Irene.

The role: Walter Getz, a nerd in high school with the titular Peggy Sue (Kathleen Turner), and later a successful dentist.

Best Line: At the high school reunion which opens the film, Walter is shown doing cocaine. "That's the best thing about being a dentist," he remarks. "Pure pharmaceutical grade. A couple of lines of this and I could drill my own teeth."

Cringe factor: Low. He does a spot of gurning, which is indicative of things to come in his career, and therefore not particularly embarrassing at all.

Other wannabes: Helen Hunt and Joan Allen.

Critical judgement: According to Paul Attanasio of The Washington Post, the film "seamlessly combines screwball comedy with get-out-your-handkerchiefs heart." Whatever that might mean.

Also not starring in: Introducing Janet, as Tony Moroni (aka Rubberface) in 1983.

Peggy Sue Got Married, Carlton Cinema, Saturday April 8, 9pm.

webTitle: Straw hints at debate over easing drug law

fields.headline: Straw hints at debate over easing drug law
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday offered a glimmer of hope to campaigners for drug laws to be relaxed when he said he was ready for a debate on the issue.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday offered a glimmer of hope to campaigners for drug laws to be relaxed when he said he was ready for a debate on the issue.

The home secretary, who has taken a tough line on drugs, acknowledged that there was a "coherent argument in favour of legalising cannabis". He accepted campaigners' contention that making it legal would not necessarily greatly increase addiction to hard drugs such as cocaine and heroin.

In the News of the World yesterday he wrote that he still believed the case for legalising cannabis was "fatally flawed", but his willingness to enter a debate will raise campaigners hopes slightly.

It follows a flurry of calls for a rethink on the issue from establishment voices, including the Daily Telegraph, which last week called for cannabis to be legalised.

The Daily Mail, too, urged a "mature and rational debate" on drugs in response to last week's report from the Police Foundation charity, which recommended decriminalisation of cannabis and downgrading of ecstasy from a class A to a class B drug.

The government said such a move would send out the wrong signals, but Home Office sources said the report was well regarded and had not been "dismissed".

Yesterday the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, said that while he was opposed to legalising cannabis his officers could work within a framework of decriminalisation.

Speaking on a fact-finding mission in New York, he said: "We are, as police officers, all about enforcing the law. In London, with robberies and murders up, cannabis cannot be a priority.

"If cannabis was legalised we'd be fine with it, because that's a policeman's job. I'd work with it. I'm not saying legalise it. If policemen start querying laws, we're in trouble."

While Scotland Yard moved swiftly to scotch suggestions that Sir John was in favour of decriminalisation, campaigners for law reform will see his remarks as another example of an establishment figure acknowledging the possibility of a more tolerant stance.

A relaxation of the law on soft drugs is already supported by a significant minority of MPs, according to a survey by BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Forty-two said they would like to see a change, and another 39 said they would like to see the law changed only to allow the medicinal use of cannabis by people with serious illnesses such as multiple sclerosis.

Those who wanted to see some change - mainly Labour MPs but including members of all parties - represented about half of those surveyed.

In his article yesterday, Mr Straw said of the debate on the use of cannabis as a medical treatment: "I have no problem whatever with this in principle."

In the past 10 years the Home Office had licensed nine research projects on whether it could be safely used as a medical drug."If the experts give the go-ahead it will become available on prescription."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, said on LWT's Jonathan Dimbleby programme yesterday that he believed he detected signs that the government might be moving on the drugs issue, and that his desire for a royal commission on it might yet be realised. He himself had an open mind on law reform, he said.

Home Office sources insisted that, while Mr Straw was keen to show he was willing to listen, he was not persuaded of the arguments for change. However, he had been irritated by suggestions that his position on drugs was designed simply to pacify the rightwing press, when he believed he had a clearly argued case backed by evidence.

In his article yesterday, he argued that legalising cannabis would risk making Britain the centre of the European drugs trade. The government would continue to take a "cautious" approach to proposals for drugs law reform.

Paul Flynn, Labour MP for Newport West and a campaigner for reform, described Mr Straw's claims that legalisation would attract drug tourists to Britain as "ill-informed scare-mongering".

webTitle: Ministers 'on the ropes' over freedom of information bill

fields.headline: Ministers 'on the ropes' over freedom of information bill
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The government is this week facing a Commons rebellion of up to 60 Labour MPs demanding further strengthening of freedom of information law.
fields.body:
The government is this week facing a Commons rebellion of up to 60 Labour MPs demanding further strengthening of freedom of information law.

Senior party figures who maintain the freedom of information bill is too weak despite the government's concessions, will today meet the home secretary to press for an extension of the right to know amid claims that ministers are "on the ropes" over the issue. MPs are expected to give the bill a rough ride when it reaches report stage in the Commons this week, and some Labour peers are forecasting more serious clashes in the Lords.

Those supporting further change believe Tony Blair is failing to deliver a manifesto promise to lift the veil of secrecy from central government and public bodies, leaving too many decisions on disclosure in the hands of ministers.

Mark Fisher, former arts minister and Labour MP for Stoke-on-Trent Central, told BBC1's On The Record that between 40 and 60 backbench Labour MPs were unhappy about the issue.

The dissenters could include those chairing select committees. Critics of the bill claim it has too many loopholes, giving public bodies opportunities for keeping information secret. Concessions announced by Jack Straw, the home secretary, have failed to appease critics - while he has moved to amend the bill to allow the information commissioner to order disclosure in the public interest, this move could still be vetoed.

Speaking of the BSE cattle crisis and how it only became public knowledge in the 1990s, Tony Wright, chairman of the public administration select committee, said on the BBC programme: "The public want to know how they could have been duped for so long."

Lord Peter Archer, Labour chairman of the Lords select committee on the bill, warned: "If there is no concession at all I'm pretty sure there will be a pitched battle in the Lords."

And Lord Richards, former Labour leader in the Lords, predicted the bill would "ping pong" around parliament, forcing the government to make concessions.

Mike O'Brien, Home Office minister, said the bill was about balancing "a right to ensure we have a government which is efficient, against a right to ensure that in a democracy the people know what the government is doing".

fields.headline: Genocide group to be executed
fields.trailText: A Rwandan court has sentenced eight people to die and 14 to prison terms after finding them guilty of planning and executing the 1994 genocide, the state-run Radio Rwanda reported yesterday.
fields.body:
A Rwandan court has sentenced eight people to die and 14 to prison terms after finding them guilty of planning and executing the 1994 genocide, the state-run Radio Rwanda reported yesterday.

Of 28 individuals charged in the massacre of more than 500,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus, six were acquitted and seven received life in prison, the radio said. Three others received 20-year prison terms, and two got 15 and 11 years each. It is not known how the remaining two were sentenced. Reuters, Kigali

Health worry for Japanese PM

Keizo Obuchi, 62, Japan's prime minister, was taken to hospital yesterday after complaining of feeling unwell, but his advisers denied that he had suffered a recurrence of heart trouble, for which he has a pacemaker.

"Tests are still being conducted to find out what is wrong, but this has nothing to do with his heart," the prime minister's spokesman, Akitaka Saiki, said. "We think it is just exhaustion." AP, Tokyo

webTitle: Turks pursue Kurds inside northern Iraq

fields.headline: Turks pursue Kurds inside northern Iraq
fields.trailText: In what has become an annual event that marks the arrival of spring, thousands of Turkish troops have crossed the border into northern Iraq during the past few days to hunt down members of the rebel Kurdistan Worker's Party (PKK).
fields.body:
In what has become an annual event that marks the arrival of spring, thousands of Turkish troops have crossed the border into northern Iraq during the past few days to hunt down members of the rebel Kurdistan Worker's Party (PKK).

Military sources say that the troops, supported by American-made attack helicopters, are being deployed to prevent PKK infiltration into Turkey.

Almost anywhere else in the world, thousands of heavily armed soldiers crossing an international border would be a big news. But this latest Turkish incursion into Iraq will be greeted with barely a murmur in the west, while condemnation from Baghdad and other Arab capitals is unlikely to have much effect.

On Turkey's side, military sources say the latest operation was launched because evidence emerged that the PKK was re-establishing positions close to the border.

For several days last week reports emerged of a big build-up of troops in south-eastern Turkey. Tanks and helicopters were on the move and some sources said mobile bridges had been constructed across the river that marks the border. Now the first wave of troops is reported to have advanced several miles into Iraqi territory.

Northern Iraq has not been controlled by President Saddam Hussein's government in Baghdad since the end of the Gulf war in 1991. With US and British planes providing protection from the air, the mountainous north is run by two rival Iraqi Kurdish groups, one of which is allied with the Turks in their fight against the PKK. Every year when the snow begins to melt, the Turkish military launches a cross-border operation to try to hit the PKK in its isolated camps. Nato's second largest army has become adept at fighting a guerrilla war in the mountains.

The difference this year is that the PKK's jailed leader, Abdullah Ocalan, has declared a ceasefire from his prison cell and it appears that the majority of his followers have agreed to give up the armed struggle against the Turkish state.

There are thought to be only about 300 PKK fighters still on Turkish soil. The rest have withdrawn into northern Iraq and Iran, where Ankara still considers their presence a threat.

The Turkish military has said it will continue to pursue the war until the last member of the PKK has been killed or has decided to surrender. Negotiation, the generals stress, is out of the question.

As long as Iraq remains a pariah state in the west, Turkey's army is unlikely to come under pressure to end its cross-border activities. It already maintains a semi-permanent military presence in northern Iraq, while insisting that it strongly supports Iraq's territorial integrity.

It is this power vacuum in the region, Turkish analysts say, which has forced Ankara to act. That in turn is another reminder of the failings of western policy in effecting change in Iraq.

Nearly a decade after President Saddam ordered the invasion of Kuwait, he is still in power in Baghdad - isolated but defiant - while Iraq's people, Arabs and Kurds alike, suffer under the dictatorship.

webTitle: Search for truth  Uganda tries to find 'diabolical leaders' of death cult

fields.headline: Search for truth  Uganda tries to find 'diabolical leaders' of death cult
fields.trailText: The vice-president of Uganda, Wandera Specioza Kazibwe, laid a wreath yesterday on a mass grave at the headquarters of the western Ugandan cult at whose hands at least 700 people have died, and she promised that the government would do "all it can to bring the leaders to book".
fields.body:
The vice-president of Uganda, Wandera Specioza Kazibwe, laid a wreath yesterday on a mass grave at the headquarters of the western Ugandan cult at whose hands at least 700 people have died, and she promised that the government would do "all it can to bring the leaders to book".

"I believe the cult leaders are alive, and the whole world must help catch them," she said, as she toured the abandoned compound in the town of Kanungu with government officials.

Dr Kazibwe was in Kanungu to attend a prayer service for the hundreds of people who have died at the hands. A number had sold their property at the behest of cult leaders.

At least 330 people died in a fire at the Kanungu headquarters of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult; a further 395 bodies have been found in the last two weeks buried in properties operated by the sect.

The police have temporarily halted exhumation because of lack of facilities, but say they believe there could be more cult victims buried in other sites around the region.

Only one of the cult leaders, Father Dominic Kataribabo, is known to have died in the fire. There have been several eyewitness reports that the leader, Joseph Kibwetere, and principal prophetess, Credonia Mwerinde, are still alive.

"At first it appeared to have been mass suicide. Now there is overwhelming evidence that what happened at Kanungu was not normal religious practice. They were callously well orchestrated mass murders perpetrated by a network of diabolic, malevolent criminals," Dr Kazibwe told the congregation gathered inb a field to pray.

She apologised on behalf of the government for allowing the cult to elude detection - and said that those who knew about the cult's activities, and failed to act, will be punished.

One person has so far been arrested - a district official who was accused of suppressing negative information about the group.

webTitle: Warmer Arctic puts 12m birds under threat

fields.headline: Warmer Arctic puts 12m birds under threat
fields.standfirst: Peril in the tundra. Migrating geese and waders are critically endangered as their breeding grounds start to vanish
fields.trailText: Five million geese and 7.5m sandpipers and other wading birds are threatened by global warming in the Arctic, a report warns today .
fields.body:
Five million geese and 7.5m sandpipers and other wading birds are threatened by global warming in the Arctic, a report warns today .

An estimated 10m geese and 14m sandpipers, dunlins and stints breed in the Arctic before migrating to Asia, Britain, Europe and North America.

Released by the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), the study says that in a warmer world more than half of the Arctic tundra could be taken over by forests by 2070, removing vital breeding grounds from critically endangered birds such as the red breasted goose, the tundra bean goose, the spoon-billed sandpiper and the emperor goose.

The study is published as leading scientists from northern nations head for an "Arctic summit" this week in Cambridge to assess the problems of climate change for life at the edge of the ice. Its authors, Christoph Zockler and Igor Lysenko of the World Conservation Monitoring Centre in Cambridge, looked at the impact of temperature change on the nesting success of geese, and the effect of warming on the birds' natural habitat.

They found that the Greenland white fronted goose, which winters only in the British Isles and numbers only 33,000, could be in serious trouble, with the western part of Greenland getting colder and tundra disappearing. Another British visitor bird, the knot, could flourish in warmer weather but would be affected by the sea level rises.

The two scientists considered two scenarios. In one -where the planet's average temperature warms by 1.7C by 2070 - the red breasted goose would lose 50% of its habitat. But if the worst fears of climate scientists are realised, and the planet's average temperature rises by 5C, the red breasted goose would lose 99% of its nesting places.

Governments are under pressure to limit discharges of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, which fuel global warming. Ute Collier, of WWF's climate change programme, said: "Birds do not have political boundaries, they are global, breeding in the Arctic and migrating elsewhere."

There are about 10,000 species of birds. About 1,000 of these are at risk of extinction already. So far, most concern has been about temperate and tropical forest birds. But the Arctic is sensitive to any climate change, and many predictions of global warming expect temperature rises in the sub-Arctic regions to be much greater than in the tropics.

Winter is in retreat. The growing season in Europe is 11 days longer than it was 35 years ago. Sea levels have crept higher throughout the century. Six of the 10 warmest years ever recorded occurred in the 1990s; the other four all happened in the late 1980s.

Arctic birds are vulnerable even when their breeding conditions improve. With an earlier spring and higher June temperatures, they could do well and so could trees moving up from the south. But the following year, with more birds competing for fewer nesting spaces, robust species would survive while others perished. The study predicts the spoon-billed sandpiper, which numbers only up to about 2,800, will lose 56% of its habitat.

Dr Collier said: "There is still a lot we can do. If we get emissions down in the next 20 to 30 years, we will probably only see about half the increase in these temperatures. Species can adapt to slow change. It is an important message."

fields.headline: War traps Sri Lanka villagers
fields.trailText: Thousands of local people are caught in fighting between government troops and Tamil rebels at a strategic causeway in northern Sri Lanka, a senior administrator said yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of local people are caught in fighting between government troops and Tamil rebels at a strategic causeway in northern Sri Lanka, a senior administrator said yesterday.

More than 12,500 villagers who live in the Pallai area near the Elephant Pass causeway, 180 miles north of Colombo, are trying to flee after fighting killed 78 combatants during the weekend, said K Shanmuganathan, who is the top civil official on the Jaffna peninsula.

The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, who are fighting for a separate Tamil homeland in the north of the country, want to take Elephant Pass in hopes of cutting off the northern Jaffna peninsula from the rest of the country.

Soldiers found the bodies of 34 rebels after a confrontation that began on Friday, a defence ministry statement said. It said another 27 insurgents were killed in other clashes near the causeway, and four in skirmishes elsewhere in the north. Government losses numbered 17, the ministry said. Independent figures are impossible to ascertain. AP

webTitle:
Latinos flexing political muscle 
in California

fields.headline:
Latinos flexing political muscle 
in California
fields.trailText: Several thousand of the mainly Latino men and women who clean the most valuable properties in the United States are threatening to walk off the job in Los Angeles today. Their action comes as politicians hurry to pass legislation that would honour Cesar Chavez, the late labour leader described as the Latino Martin Luther King, with a state holiday.
fields.body:
Several thousand of the mainly Latino men and women who clean the most valuable properties in the United States are threatening to walk off the job in Los Angeles today. Their action comes as politicians hurry to pass legislation that would honour Cesar Chavez, the late labour leader described as the Latino Martin Luther King, with a state holiday.

The strike and the holiday are both signs of an emerging Latino-led radicalism in the US. A book to be published in May suggests that such moves could redraw the political map of the country.

The planned strike by 8,500 caretakers in Los Angeles is the latest sign of the power of Latino-dominated unions covering those who carry out many of the lowest paid and dirtiest jobs in the US.

Ten years ago, the Justice for Janitors campaign first drew attention to the pay and conditions of the people who cleaned the toilets of corporate America. Since then the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) has been trying to fight the corner for these workers.

The Los Angeles strike is the first of several planned actions this month in Chicago, New York, Portland and San Diego.

Meanwhile, tens of thousands of mainly Latino activists were yesterday celebrating the birthday of Cesar Chavez, who as the United Farm Workers leader helped to organise immigrant fruit-pickers in the 60s and 70s. The movement gained support well beyond its California core, with western boycotts of non-union produce.

Chavez, a modest man who asked not to be proposed for a Nobel Peace Prize, died in 1993. Though vilified by the authorities in his lifetime as a left-wing agitator, he has folk hero status in the Latino community, making politicians anxious to pay homage with a bill proposing an official holiday in his name. California's state assemly votes on the bill this month. There is also pressure for his life story to become part of the official cur riculum in schools. "The long history of political marginality is finally coming to an end," writes Mike Davis in his new book Magical Urbanism: Latinos Reinvent the US City. "Latinos, all political pundits agree, are the sleeping dragon of US politics."

Mr Davis, who is best known for his acclaimed history of Los Angeles, City of Quartz, said yesterday that politicians were now aware that they had to court the Latino vote because of this community's growing numbers. The Spanish-surname population in the US is increasing by 1m annually- 10 times faster than the Anglo population. In Texas, where the Republicans' presidential hopeful, George W Bush, is governor, one in five voters this year will be Latino.

In 1997, 235,000 Mexican immigrants became US citizens, smashing the previous record of one-nation immigration held by the Italians in 1944.

Mr Davis argues that many immigrants from south of the Mexican border "as well as transporting their local saints and madonnas northward have also transplanted their traditional village governments en bloc to specific inner-city Catholic parishes".

He adds: "What is most striking is the cultural unity and blue-collar solidity of Mexican Los Angeles. The Anglo conquest of California in the late 1840s has proven to be a very transient fact indeed."

The growth of the radical movement has been hidden from much of mainstream America, argues Davis.

"When more than 75,000 young Latinos, protesting anti-immigrant Proposition 187 [which banned children of undocumented immigrants from attending school and excluded them from health care benefits] marched out of their high schools throughout California in 1994 - the largest student protest in that state's history - it was virtually ignored by the media networks, although a comparable uprising by black or white students would have become a national sensation."

Mr Davis believes that chambers of commerce now recognise that they have to negotiate with the low-paid workers as "union activists have hammered home the message that labour militancy is the only viable moral alternative to poverty-driven explosions of rage" in the form of riots.

Speaking from New York, where he now lives, Mr Davis suggested that the energy of the new Latino activists has also allowed them to take control of previously conservative, white labour federations. These unions can no longer afford to be exclusive white bastions, because their memberships are falling.

webTitle: Young girls sold as sex slaves in US, CIA says

fields.headline: Young girls sold as sex slaves in US, CIA says
fields.trailText: Around 50,000 women and children are being brought into the United States every year to work as prostitutes or as virtual slaves, according to an unpublished report by the CIA. Among those sold into forced labour are girls as young as nine, it claims.
fields.body:
Around 50,000 women and children are being brought into the United States every year to work as prostitutes or as virtual slaves, according to an unpublished report by the CIA. Among those sold into forced labour are girls as young as nine, it claims.

Women who answer advertisements for jobs as au pairs, secretaries or waitresses find themselves forced to work as prostitutes or strippers and some are sold outright to brothel owners, the report says.

The women and children are being brought from a variety of countries, with Thailand, Vietnam, China, Mexico, Russia and the Czech Republic heading the list. The report suggests that an increasing number are coming from the Philippines, Korea, Malaysia, Latvia, Hungary, Poland, Brazil and Honduras.

There has been a huge rise in the sale of women into servitude because such trafficking is booming in eastern Europe. According to the report, traffickers in the former Soviet Union have been particularly aggressive in taking advantage of young women who are desperate to enter western countries and unaware of what type of work awaits them.

Girls as young as nine from Asian and African countries have been sold into slavery in the US "for less than the price of a toaster", according to the survey, the first of its kind. Girls from countries where female children are not highly valued are among the most vulnerable and may be forced to work in what the report describes as "an indentured sexual servitude arrangement".

Although the justice department does not have accurate figures, it is estimated that over the last two years prosecutions have been brought in only 250 out of a possible 100,000 cases. In one case last year, involving 70 Thai workers forced to work 20-hour days, the punishments for their seven employers ranged from four to seven years.

"These low penalties and the long, complicated and resource-intensive nature of trafficking cases tends to make them unattractive to many United States attorneys," concludes the report by a CIA analyst, which was published by the New York Times yesterday.

One problem in prosecuting offenders has been that the women often speak no English and are more frightened of the police than their employers. In addition, such cases often appear to fall between different departments, such as the FBI, the immigration service and the labour department.

The women found working in brothels without proper documentation are usually deported rather than allowed to stay and testify against brothel owners or the traffickers, the report says.

Among the women and children cited in the report are a Latvian woman who was forced to dance nude in Chicago, Mexican teenagers bullied into servicing migrant workers at a brothel and Chinese-Korean women made to work as indentured labour at such low wages that they could not extricate themselves from the situation.

The report says immigration authorities have found evidence of 250 brothels in 26 cities where victims of trafficking are working.

Some Nigerian traffickers have profited doubly from the trade, charging parents as much as $10,000 to bring their children to New York for "better educational opportunities" and then selling the children into forced domestic labour.

Worldwide, the problem is increasing, the report concludes. It estimates that between 700,000 and 2m women and children are victims of the growing trade in human forced labour.

webTitle: Fake cleric puts France in holy disorder

fields.headline: Fake cleric puts France in holy disorder
fields.trailText: A 23-year-old man will appear in court in Grenoble today charged with the little-known but very French offences of neglecting to pay the bill in restaurants, defaming the name of the holy mother church, and defrauding the general public by unlawfully impersonating a priest.
fields.body:
A 23-year-old man will appear in court in Grenoble today charged with the little-known but very French offences of neglecting to pay the bill in restaurants, defaming the name of the holy mother church, and defrauding the general public by unlawfully impersonating a priest.

The alleged exploits of Philippe Ferrand - aka Father Fruchard, Father Bourg, Abbot Frucheau and Curate Villefranche - began last January in Nantes. Posing as an itinerant monk, he spent five nights at an up-market religious retreat, said a couple of word-perfect masses at a nearby church, and walked off with the sexton's chequebook.

A month later the ecclesiastical conman resurfaced in Tours, dressed in a clean cassock and carrying a missal. He presented himself at Saint-Gatien cathedral as a chaplain from Chartres, celebrated a baptism, blessed a marriage and retired to a hotel in the town centre.

"We didn't think twice," the hotel's owner, Gilberte Said, told the local press. "He was so charming. He ordered whisky as an aperitif, said a splendid grace in the dining room and for dinner had rillettes and te de veau washed down with a bottle of Gamay. Then he left without paying."

Funding his travels with £1,200 in collection and candle money from the Tours cathedral safe, the imposter next showed up in the central town of Limoges on March 6. There he said a few words at a funeral ceremony and picked the pockets of the local curate.

Mr Ferrand - who despite being only 23 has collected 13 previous convictions for fraud - then allegedly moved on in a stolen car to Vichy, where the police were waiting. But hoisting his robes, he scaled a cloister wall and made good his escape, taking refuge in the presbytery of Saint Louis.

After he had helped himself to £1,000 from a church collection box in Aix-les-Bains and spent a night for free at a luxury hotel in Chambery, Mr Ferrand's luck finally ran out in Grenoble when a chambermaid discovered, besides his curate's collar and cassock, some suspiciously irreligious pornography in his luggage.

"The sad thing is, he was utterly believable," said Abbot Mercier, one of the many duped clergymen.

"He knew the sacred texts inside out and was fired with enthusiasm.

"It's a shame he was a scoundrel - he could have been an asset to the church."

webTitle: Landless movement tries for a remake

fields.headline: Landless movement tries for a remake
fields.trailText: When Dan Baron Cohen arrived in Brazil two years ago, he read a magazine article about the country's mass movement of dispossessed rural workers. "It was my first knowledge about them," he says. "And I immediately wanted to know more."
fields.body:
When Dan Baron Cohen arrived in Brazil two years ago, he read a magazine article about the country's mass movement of dispossessed rural workers. "It was my first knowledge about them," he says. "And I immediately wanted to know more."

Little did the Welsh drama lecturer realise that soon afterwards he would be swept up by the landless cause. Mr Baron Cohen is now leading one of the main cultural projects of the Landless Movement (MST), a radical organisation representing several million poor Brazilians that fights for social justice in a country with huge extremes in the distribution of wealth.

Mr Baron Cohen's official role is to coordinate the building of six monuments to act as a counterpoint to the official celebrations of Brazil's 500th birthday this year. Under the banner "The Other 500 years", the monuments are meant to show the resistance history of the Indian, black and poor communities since the arrival of the former Portuguese colonialists In South America.

But while the sculptures will be Mr Baron Cohen's most visible contribution to the organisation, his involvement also represents an MST attempt to change its culture. It wants a more human face than the one conveyed by the hatchet-waving Marxists who have run some of its takeovers of little-used land.

Since it emerged 16 years ago the MST has revolutionised land reform in Brazil by organising mass squats on unproductive farms and refusing to leave until the government awarded the squatters title.

Using this technique - which often resulted in violent conflict with landowners - the MST says it has settled 250,000 families on reclaimed land. It became an international cause celebre and the largest social movement in Latin America.

Inevitably, however, as the landless have become landowners their needs and priorities have changed. Despite the estimated 4.8m families still without land, the movement risks losing its constituency unless it acquires new values.

Irma Brunetto, a national coordinators, says: "We need to show that we are not just fighters for land, but also that we are human beings. We need to change our way of being, our way of producing, our way of organising. We have to change all our practices."

Mr Baron Cohen, a specialist in community theatre who worked with Sinn Fein in Ireland, says: "The legacy of repression and poverty has meant that the landless only have a vocabulary of resistance and struggle. The MST can motivate people to occupy land. Now they are facing the difficulties of creating a new society. Without a cultural revolution the movement will die."

Mr Baron Cohen's work is seen as part of this "cultural revolution". Last year he organised a piece of MST art - a huge sculpture of 19 burned-out trees on a site where 19 landless peasants were murdered. The sculpture was built by 500 members of the victims' community.

After this Mr Baron Cohen, 42, became closer to the MST and was asked not only to coordinate the six monuments for the alternative anniversary of Brazil but also to train 500 "cultural activists". The first monument is being built on the land where the Portuguese first came ashore, near Porto Seguro, opposite a huge iron cross that is the government's official monument for the 500- year celebrations.

"The cross has offended the local Pataxo Indians, who own the land, because they were not consulted," says Mr Baron Cohen.
