webTitle: Law star returns to defend squatter leader

fields.headline: Law star returns to defend squatter leader
fields.standfirst: As Brazil plans its 500th anniversary celebrations, a land activist is back in court and millions of peasants are still without a patch to farm
fields.trailText: Brazil's shaky criminal justice system comes under scrutiny today with the high-profile retrial of a landless leader accused of murdering a wealthy landowner and a military policeman.
fields.body:
Brazil's shaky criminal justice system comes under scrutiny today with the high-profile retrial of a landless leader accused of murdering a wealthy landowner and a military policeman.

Jose Rainha was sentenced to 26 years in prison for the killings in 1997, despite evidence that he was hundreds of miles from the crime scene.

The case has received attention from human rights groups which claim vested interests were trying criminalise the leadership of Latin America's largest popular movement.

Rainha will be represented by Brazil's most famous barrister who, at 88, is returning to the courtroom 21 years after he retired. Evandro Lins e Silva said he was persuaded to take the case after appeals by the Portuguese writer Jose Saramago, who won the Nobel prize for literature in 1998.

"This is an exceptional case in the history of Brazil. It is irrefutably political. The entire world is interested in the outcome," said Mr Lins e Silva.

The case arises from the conflict between the Landless Movement (MST) and the landowners. A quarter of a million families have gained land by squatting in the past 16 years. Often landlords use violence to stop them, though the landless movement too has been accused of some killings.

In June 1989 a group of about 100 MST families invaded a farm in Espirito Santo, a coastal province north of Rio de Janeiro. Three days later the landowner and a military policeman, both armed, went to the site. Both men were shot and several landless people were wounded.

Rainha was one of the main activists in Espirito Santo. MST alleges that several attempts had already been made on his life and that before June 1989 he had been moved to another state.

fields.headline: No: 1607 NUS
fields.body:
Age: 78.

Description (official): Nationwide body representing and campaigning on behalf of all students in higher and further education.

Description (unofficial): Increasingly irrelevant hotbed of Blairite opportunists, preposterously dull far-left factions and mad people.

Real raison d' etre: Cheap beer and 10% discounts at Topshop.

Specialisms: Handwringing debates on identity politics; well-intentioned but toothless motions condemning human rights abuses overseas; self-destructive bickering.

A fast track to power? For the Blairites, yes: former presidents include Jack Straw, the MPs Lorna Fitzsimons, Stephen Twigg and Phil Woolas, and Trevor Phillips.

For the rest? A fast track to standing in the rain on a Saturday morning failing to sell Socialist Worker.

But it's fading fast? Student unions are falling over themselves to disaffiliate - preferring to spend their subs on widescreen TVs in the union bar - and after a 19-year reign, Labour Students aren't even fielding a candidate for annual conference in Blackpool, which starts today.

Didn't they get their forms in on time? It's more serious than that: they're petrified by the prospect of humiliating defeat. Ever since then-president Jim Murphy engineered an end to the union's flat-out objection to student loans in the early 1990s, members have muttered that Labour Students are New Labour stooges.

Paranoid nonsense, presumably. Murphy did join parliament within a year of leaving his post, but coincidence is a funny thing.

And the choices this time? Alison Angus (hard left), Mark Tweedale ("genuine independent") and Owain James (leftish independent), all of whom oppose tuition fees. "This is the least ideological election for many years," says outgoing president Andrew Pakes, which isn't, frankly, saying much.

The nation's campuses must be paralysed with tension. Put it this way: if they are, it's because they're waiting for the results of interviews at McKinsey and Arthur Andersen.

Not to be confused with: Paris, 1968.

fields.headline: Railtrack declares war on regulator
fields.trailText: Railtrack is adopting a deliberate "culture of defiance" against the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, to prevent civil action being taken against it, the company admitted last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack is adopting a deliberate "culture of defiance" against the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, to prevent civil action being taken against it, the company admitted last night.

The revelations come as Railtrack gets ready to defy the regulator in the latest of a series of spats it has been having with Mr Winsor on performance and its development of the £5.8bn west coast main line project between London and Glasgow.

Following remarks made last week by Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, that it was defying the regulator as a matter of policy, a company spokesman confirmed yesterday that if it did not take such an attitude, it might lay itself open to third-party action.

A senior Railtrack executive said that the board demanded that it did not go soft on the regulator because it might upset some of its clients. These include the train operating companies and track infrastructure firms.

This would account for the uncompromising position taken by Mr Corbett on the company's peformance. It has failed to meet a 12.7% improvement target set last year by the regulator, and has been told to make up the shortfall next year.

The regulator's office said last night that Railtrack's attitude was "news to us."

A spokesman said that Mr Winsor wanted to have a sensible relationship with the company, but "this attitude beggars belief".

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, may have to intervene in such a delicate issue.

Ministers would not be pleased with an explanation from Railtrack that it must protect its position against a regulator who was trying to carry out his statutory duty.

Mr Corbett is already upset with Mr Winsor for imposing a £10m fine on Railtrack, the largest corporate penalty ever imposed on a British company, for failing to achieve the 12.7% improvement.

Several members of Railtrack's board have ordered senior managers not to make up the shorfall required, which is why Mr Corbett is insisting that the slate should be wiped clean.

Mr Winsor has applauded Railtrack for its efforts to improve performance but says it has only achieved 10% and the shortfall must be made up with a new target of 5% next year.

Railtrack will have to pay the £10m fine, which will be ploughed back into the industry. But Mr Winsor has made it clear that legal action he is proposing to take over delays to the completion of the west coast main line will not lead to a fine.

Mr Winsor says that court action will be enough to make Railtrack buck up its ideas. But he is not confident that Railtrack can deliver its upgrade by May 2002 to allow tilting trains to run between Manchester and London at speeds of up to 125 mph.

fields.headline: £2bn TV auction under way
fields.standfirst: Premier League will offer new packages of rights
fields.trailText: The auction of the next set of broadcasting rights for football's Premier League begins today in a contest which could have profound implications for the TV groups vying for a slice of the action.
fields.body:
The auction of the next set of broadcasting rights for football's Premier League begins today in a contest which could have profound implications for the TV groups vying for a slice of the action.

Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore will meet the 20 club chairman this morning to outline the tender document which will be sent to broadcasters. It will need approval from at least 14 clubs beforeit can be made available.

The total package is expected to generate a windfall of £2bn for the clubs.

The rights are expected to be divided up into more packages than in 1996 when live rights were awarded to BSkyB and highlights to the BBC, reflecting the advent of new technologies and a growing number of interested broadcasters.

One main block of live rights is expected to be auctioned and smaller secondary packages could also be on offer. One broadcaster could have rights over Sunday afternoon matches for instance while another may have access to midweek games.

Clubs are also expected to be allowed to broadcast matches on their own TV channels and the internet. A growing band of clubs are setting up their own channels alongside media partners. BSkyB owns stakes in five clubs, NTL in three and Granada in one.

It is widely believed that snatching the Premier League from terrestial TV in 1992 was the key turning point for BSkyB and sport remains the key driver for subscriptions in pay-TV.

At the last round there were eight main cable companies. Now there are just two, with the largest, NTL, supercharged by shareholders that include France Telecom and Microsoft.

ITV is also now in a stronger position through Granada and Carlton's joint ownership of OnDigital, providing the network with a pay-TV platform. ITV is reported to have offered £100m for a highlights package which could spell the end of the BBC's Match of the Day. Channel 5 may also make a bid for highlights.

webTitle: Warning shot a reminder that UK bribery laws need a quick fix

fields.headline: Warning shot a reminder that UK bribery laws need a quick fix
fields.trailText: The government is heading for a rough ride at the next OECD ministerial in Paris in June unless it acts soon to toughen up its anti-corruption laws.
fields.body:
The government is heading for a rough ride at the next OECD ministerial in Paris in June unless it acts soon to toughen up its anti-corruption laws.

A peer review group, led by France and the Netherlands, has concluded that they do not comply with an international convention to prosecute company executives who bribe foreign officials to win contracts. In an unpublished report, it is urging Britain to introduce legislation.

Of the 20 countries which have ratified the convention so far, Britain is the only one not to have adapted its laws. Most countries have amended their laws that criminalise bribery of domestic officials to cover foreign bribery. Others, such as Korea or Australia, have a stand-alone law. Even the US, which has had the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act for over 20 years, made amendments to that law to reflect some principles of the convention.

But the government has been dragging its feet, arguing that UK law, based on the combination of a 1906 statute and common law, is adequate, a position hard to sustain since there has never been a prosecution. There may be other countries with poorer records, but there is a problem of British companies paying bribes to win business. The World Bank has a list of firms and individuals ineligible for Bank-financed contracts because they have violated fraud and corruption rules. Of the 53 on the list as of February 29, 36 were based in the UK.

Countries, such as America and Australia, are angry at the UK for placing their companies at a competitive disadvantage in places where "commission" is common practice. An ex-CIA chief says industrial espionage is justified to catch the culprits.

Latterly, the government appears to have woken up to the fact that UK law may need some updating. A white paper is promised and it may include proposals to rectify the problem, although senior civil servants are reported to be urging ministers not to change the law.

But any new legislation will only be sufficient if it assumes that the offence of bribery should be based on nationality, whatever the jurisdiction. UK nationals can only be prosecuted if the offence occurs within the UK. Since most bribery occurs offshore, it is not surprising no British citizens have been caught. Britain has already accepted the extraterritorial principle in its laws against several other offences, including money laundering, sex tourism, murder, drug trafficking and terrorism. It is hard to see why bribery should be treated more leniently.

While turning a blind eye to it may protect jobs at home in the short term, in the long run it stunts economic development and distorts competition, making mugs of consumers who end up paying higher prices for goods and services.

Corporate governance emphasises the importance of reputation and ethical behaviour. From the government's point of view, it makes a mockery of its so-called ethical foreign policy.

The OECD is often criticised for being little more than a cosy club for the rich industrialised countries but its anti-bribery convention, signed by Britain more than two years ago, is one of its better moves . The government should brush aside objections about lack of parliamentary time and legislate quickly to ensure that it is more than just a paper tiger.

webTitle: Contractors walk out of £750m private motorway

fields.headline: Contractors walk out of £750m private motorway
fields.trailText: The consortium behind Britain's first privately built motorway, the £750m Midands Expressway, is in danger of collapsing because of a row among contractors.
fields.body:
The consortium behind Britain's first privately built motorway, the £750m Midands Expressway, is in danger of collapsing because of a row among contractors.

Midlands Expressway, the group of companies charged with the programme, will today ask for new expressions of interest following the withdrawal of Kvaerner, the civil engineering contractor and Italstrade, the Italian toll-road company.

Midlands Expressway said yesterday it would be asking for new proposals from industry. So far it knew of 30 companies or groups interested in the project.

Opinion in the civil engineering industry has turned against the Expressway amid growing fears that it will cost more than £750m to complete.

The new road will divert traffic from the busy M6 round Birmingham. It is due to be ready by 2003, but the 25 mile scheme is now seriously delayed. Even if a new contractor is found, work on the six-lane motorway will not start until next spring.

The operators of the motorway will be awarded a 56-year concession by the Department of Transport, and have been given consent to charge £2.50 for a car and £5 for a heavy goods vehicle.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is angry at the way the contractors have han dled the project. The government offered considerable support, even though the project was opposed in the high court by protesters, including Friends of the Earth, who said that it was unnecessary.

Ministers believe that the motorway will be popular with business wishing to speed up travel and transport in one of the most congested parts of the country. A road journey between London and Manchester, which should take three hours can sometimes take almost double that time.

The government also hopes to use the project to gauge the reaction of the public to motorway tolls. It has put plans to go ahead with further projects on hold, certainly until after the election.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText:
Sunday Times
Supermarket chain Tesco is expected to say later this month that it plans to split off its fast growing internet shopping business from its traditional stores. The newspaper said analysts believed the move is a precursor to a stock market listing for the company's dot.com interests.
fields.body:
Sunday Times
Supermarket chain Tesco is expected to say later this month that it plans to split off its fast growing internet shopping business from its traditional stores. The newspaper said analysts believed the move is a precursor to a stock market listing for the company's dot.com interests.

The boardroom row at World Online, the Europe-wide internet portal that floated last month, is refusing to die down despite a promise by founder Nina Brink to forgo profits from the sale of her shares. Ms Brink sparked the row when she sold a large part of her shareholding after the float.

Sunday Telegraph
Nuclear waste group BNFL has ordered a clear out of senior managers in an effort to restore confidence in the site and its standards. Two supervisors at the Sellafield plant are expected to lose their jobs and another six will be moved to less sensitive jobs.

Gordon Brown is scheduled to tell business leaders this week that he will not manipulate the sterling exchange rate downward to counteract the effects of the declining value of the euro.

Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson and Gary Rhodes, the chef and restaurateur, have joined forces to become directors of toptable.co.uk, a new internet restaurant booking site.

Mail on Sunday
British Airways' chairman Lord Marshall will make fresh attempts this week to lure Rod Eddington, who runs Australian airline Ansett, to replace ousted chief executive Bob Ayling. Mr Eddington was first asked to take the job two weeks ago. fields.headline: Even Steven
fields.standfirst: Steven Wright, America's king of deadpan comedy, is coming to Britain. He talks to  Michael Ellison
fields.trailText: Steven Wright, America's king of deadpan comedy, is coming to Britain. He talks to Michael Ellison
fields.body:
Steven Wright knocked 'em dead in the Long Island town of Patchogue. I'd like to tell you exactly how he did it, but this must remain a secret between him and those who saw the act. The comedian and his representatives insist that none of the jokes he told at the theatre or in conversation later should be allowed to slip out and alert his London audience.

Wright is hardly short of material, even for a show lasting over 90 minutes, during which he is assisted only by a chair, two stools and a guitar. His talent for surreal one-liners, delivered in a deep, dry monotone, has already won him a headline show at New York's Carnegie Hall; other credits include a Grammy Award-nominated album, and several movie and TV appearances. The Appointments of Dennis Jennings, the short film which he co-wrote and starred in, has also won him an Oscar.

"The new show's not a test," he says later in a Manhattan hotel lobby. "I came up with a bunch of new material and that length of time just seemed right for now. I don't see people getting up and leaving."

Wright's delivery is routinely described as deadpan; the same term might apply to his career. Yes, he is a star, but his is a jeans and motorbike boots stardom rather than a Las Vegas celebrity. He has so far escaped Robin Williams syndrome, the affliction that obliges comedians to transform themselves into lachrymose sentimentalists who are kind to children though not to patrons of cinemas.

Forty-four-year-old Wright started out telling jokes in a Chinese restaurant in Boston and got his big break on the Johnny Carson Show in 1982. Carson couldn't get enough of him: the show practically adopted Wright, inviting him back time and again.

Three years later he made his screen debut in Desperately Seeking Susan; 12 months after that he collaborated with Roberto Benigni and Jim Jarmusch on the short film Coffee and Cigarettes. He has acted in Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers and Mike Myers's pre-Austin Powers comedy So I Married an Axe Murderer, and his laconic voice has been heard everywhere from the Simpsons to Reservoir Dogs.

Although he says that none of his jokes is ever retired, Wright seems reluctant to risk repeating himself, or to do anything so gross as capitalise on success. The Appointments of Dennis Jennings was made in 1988, but his second short, One Soldier, which he also directed, was only made last year. I Have a Pony, his comedy album, was up for a Grammy 14 years ago and he has yet to make another. "I think I should make one every century," he says.

Does he think he should be more famous? "I'm just happy that I draw in an audience. Having come up in the 80s, I feel very fortunate to still be making a living from my imagination."

He isn't thrilled to be described as a comic genius. "I just see myself as a guy who makes things up. I never tire of going on stage," he says, picking carefully at his beard. "TV and movies are exciting when they're finished but they're boring compared with being in front of an audience."

Wright sees no great need to make compromises for tonight's audience in London. As always, he will draw on the foibles of common experience rather than American politics or current affairs. He does not even want to ridicule the presidential candidates. "I don't like politics. Growing up during the Nixon era, I don't believe in politics. I barely believe in civilisation. What I deal with is the stuff in the middle, the stuff that's between dust and the Big Bang."

That being the case, the maxim that humour loses nearly everything in translation somewhere in the middle of the Atlantic should not apply here. "There's only a few jokes that don't work," he claims. "I'm very fortunate in that sense because I talk about such basic things. It's not really cultural. I don't change my act: I change my outlook on life. I try to act as if I'm left-handed while I'm in London. In England they're more abstract and bizarre. It's more conservative in the US, more logical: this is this is this. In Britain I can be more abstract. I think I kind of fit in both categories."

When the word abstract is raised in this context, a paean to Monty Python cannot be far behind. "I loved it right from the beginning. Total insanity. I was hooked. Even now it would be very abstract compared with what's being done on TV." Wright also talks about Dickens and the Beatles. He does not mention Jim Davidson.

He's looking forward to the London show. "It's very special to go over there. It's a rush to perform in another country. I grew up in the States and people in another country are paying to see me in another currency."

Why they might do so is not something he dwells upon. "People say I use one-liners, I talk in a monotone, I'm deadpan - I agree with all that, but it's just how I think. When I started doing it in Boston there was no labelling, no discussion, it just made people laugh. I've had guys really try to analyse it. I don't care: I just think it up and write it down."

He has just thought up something else: "I've got one more thing to say: I think the universe is underrated."

Steven Wright is at the Dominion Theatre, London W1 (0870-607 7446), tonight.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: It's hard to credit how dentists once extracted full sets of perfectly healthy teeth to save trouble in the future
fields.body:
With dentists now officially cautioned against removing even an impacted wisdom tooth, it's hard to credit how they once extracted full sets of perfectly healthy teeth to save trouble in the future. Throughout the week Philippa Dolley looks back on Britain's grim record of Surgery For The Sake Of It? (3.45pm, Radio 4). She hears from doctors and patients how tonsils and foreskins were routinely removed and a D&C prescribed as a matter of course.

The debate about the government's drugs policy is brought into sharp and disturbing focus by Edi Stark's Women Behind Bars (8.0pm, Radio 4). She reports from Cornton Vale, Scotland's only female prison, on the hopeless misery of the many addicts sent there by the courts. Eight have killed themselves in three years, scarring both staff and inmates. The chief inspector of prisons and Cornton Vale's medical officer both say that many of the women should never have gone there at all.

webTitle: History shows ditching pound at this level could lead to disaster

fields.headline: History shows ditching pound at this level could lead to disaster
fields.standfirst: Philip Arestis and Malcolm Sawyer
fields.trailText: In the debate over if and when the UK should join the euro, trivial issues are often focused on at the expense of the important. An important issue, which would determine the economic performance of the UK for years ahead, is the value at which sterling entered the euro.
fields.body:
In the debate over if and when the UK should join the euro, trivial issues are often focused on at the expense of the important. An important issue, which would determine the economic performance of the UK for years ahead, is the value at which sterling entered the euro.

Getting that exchange rate wrong - and in particular setting the exchange rate too high - would promise years, or quite possibly decades. of deflation.

Our argument starts from the view that the value of sterling is currently too high.

A recent estimate of the fundamental equilibrium exchange rate (Keith Church, National Institute Economic Review, July 1999) - based on the Treasury model - was around DM2.30 to the £ for 1997, with the pound 18% overvalued in 1997 and 23% in the second quarter of 1999. Since then, the value of the pound has risen further.

For the purpose of this debate we take the figure of 15% to 20% devaluation from present level to reach the equilibrium exchange rate, which means that the strength of our argument is somewhat understated.

One of the conditions of the Maastricht Treaty criteria for a country to join the euro, and the only one which the UK currently clearly does not satisfy, is at least two years' membership of the Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) - with no significant change in the central exchange rate. But this may not be such a serious hurdle for the UK.

We can draw parellels with the experience of other countries in the case of the Maastricht criteria in May 1997. As with the other criteria for membership, there was a degree of fudge when decisions were made about country membership of the euro.

Finland, for example, had only been a member of the ERM for one year, and yet was deemed to have satisfied this criterion. It could be argued that Finland had satisfied the substantive part of this requirement, namely that it had achieved stability of the exchange rate of its currency against the ECU.

Now consider the implications of these criteria for the UK joining the euro in three years time. It is helpful to consider three possible scenarios, though realising that actual events may well lie somewhere between.

The first is that sterling falls in value substantially over the next 12 months, followed by two years of exchange rate stability (vis-à-vis the euro). Sterling would satisfy the substantive requirement for entry into the euro, and this could be seen as the dream scenario for such entry.

It faces the obvious, but serious, problems of how to engineer the reduction in the value of sterling and the implications of a rapid devaluation for inflation.

A 15% to 20% devaluation overall could be expected to have a direct impact on prices - an increase of the order of 5% to 7%.

This could be more if domestic prices respond, though modified if the euro were to rise against the dollar, leading to a devaluation in the effective exchange rate of less than 15% to 20%.

The second scenario is that the value of sterling gradually declines in value over the next three years to reach a rate appropriate for entry. But how would this be achieved?

The obvious answer is through changes in interest rates, but this could contravene the objective of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) to achieve an inflation rate of 2.5%.

Even if the MPC managed to lower the exchange rate, it would have inflationary implications, which could very well imply an inflation rate above the target set by the Treasury. It would also require bending the criteria of the Maastricht Treaty to allow sterling to join, in terms both of the inflation rate and exchange rate criteria.

The third scenario to be considered is one in which sterling remains overvalued. The Maastricht Treaty requirement of a stable exchange rate against the euro would be satisfied, but entry occurs at an overvalued rate.

This would be the nightmare scenario. Any benefits of lower transaction costs and reduced volatility of the value of the currency would be inconsequential against the cost of entry at an overvalued rate without any exit possibilities, or indeed any other policy to account for it.

The consequences of the entry of sterling into the eurozone at an overvalued rate are clear. The UK would be entering with a deficit in the balance of trade .

The latest figures show that in the last quarter of 1999 the trade deficit on goods and services reached nearly £5bn. Such a position can only be sustained if others are prepared to lend to the UK.

This can take the form of foreign direct investment, but then there is the obvious question of why, under these conditions, multinational companies would suddenly wish to invest in the UK.

The alternative is that prices in the UK would have to fall by say 15% to 20%, with an accompanying fall in money wages. Even if this fall were relative to prices elsewhere in the euro-zone, and could be achieved by lower inflation in the UK compared with the rest of the region, this would be far from painless. Years of deflationary policies to push down inflation (moving into deflation) could well follow.

In the 20th century, the UK suffered two major episodes of joining a fixed exchange rate system at an overvalued rate.

The return to the Gold Standard in 1925 at the pre- World War I parity brought an overvaluation of around 10%. More recently, the UK joined the ERM in 1990 with around 15% overvaluation.

Both these episodes were associated with periods of economic depression, and both ended ignominiously, in 1931 and 1992 respectively. Joining the euro under these circumstances would produce another period of economic recession not dissimilar to those two episodes.

Philip Arestis is economics professor at the University of East London. Malcom Sawyer is economics professor at Leeds University

fields.headline: Freedom fear on website closure
fields.trailText: A radical internet magazine has become the first victim of a libel case which has been seen as a threat to freedom of speech on the web.
fields.body:
A radical internet magazine has become the first victim of a libel case which has been seen as a threat to freedom of speech on the web.

Outcast, which branded itself a "queer current affairs" publication, had its site shut down by its internet service provider, Netbenefit, after a complaint about material posted there. Netbenefit said it had acted "with great reluctance".

Last week, Demon Internet agreed to pay £15,000 damages and £230,000 in legal costs to Laurence Godfrey, a physicist who said he had been defamed by two anonymous messages posted on the net.

Internet firms are concerned about the implications of the Demon case. If it had not been settled out of court, it would have established whether ISPs are subject to the same libel laws as other media. By settling, Demon appeared to concede it was unlikely to win.

Outcast expressed disappointment at Netbenefit's decision. Its editor, Chris Morris, said: "What we do is hard hitting but it is carefully written not to be defamatory." He believed Netbenefit had overreacted, and said the magazine would continue to be published in print.

Netbenefit acted after a complaint by the Pink Paper, another gay publication, about the Outcast site.

Alison Sparshatt, the managing director of Netbenefit, said: "We have no wish to get involved in monitoring websites. We are interested in providing and hosting web services." She added that the Demon case had "far-reaching implications" and the government needed to clarify the law.

Ms Sparshatt compared the role of ISPs to that of a telecommunications firm, saying the latter was not responsible in law for slander over the telephone.

Mike Ross, the Pink Paper's publishing manager, denied stifling free speech and defended his firm's actions.

He said: "Chris Morris contacted us with a range of statements on which he sought comment. We felt they were defamatory and libellous.

"All we did was to send a legal letter to the ISP and his printers. We said that if he printed anything libellous or defamatory, we would take legal action."

fields.headline: Village idiots
fields.standfirst: If John Prescott and co really want to head off a housing crisis, they shouldn't be backing London's latest millennium folly, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: If John Prescott and co really want to head off a housing crisis, they shouldn't be backing London's latest millennium folly, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, and Nick Raynsford, minister for construction and planning, were down on the windswept north Greenwich peninsula in south-east London last week, opening a pair of show flats in what is known as the Millennium Village. I was up in Fairford Leys, a new small town on the fringe of Aylesbury, recording a radio programme about Prescott-era housing. Both the Millennium Village and Fairford Leys are responses to the apparent need in southern England for 3.8m houses over the next few years. Neither is a cynical response, yet both show that we appear to have absolutely no idea of how to build convincing modern housing.

The Civic Trust, meanwhile, has given its award for the "outstanding building of the last 40 years" to Churchill Gardens in Pimlico, central London, a council estate designed and built between 1946 and 1961 along uncompromisingly Modern lines. Churchill Gardens houses 5,000 people in 1,800 flats and is, for the most part, popular among residents. It is a handsome group of buildings owned by Westminster council (half the flats are now leased from it) and designed by the then very young Philip Powell and Hidalgo Moya.

Churchill Gardens is a mix of eight- and 10-floor blocks interspersed with three-storey houses and well-planned gardens. It enjoys a happy location on the Thames and, unlike north Greenwich, is not swept by Arctic winds. Arranged in rows or streets, Churchill Gardens owes as much to the notion of the Georgian terraced housing as it does to the utopian Modern movement housing schemes - cities of sun, light, green and air raised high into the sky over great city parks - pioneered by Le Corbusier from the early 20s. Here is one way of building decent homes on a dense scale in city centres for people on average to low incomes without sacrificing light, air and dignity. Sadly, such homes, or their contemporary equivalents, are unlikely to be built today. Land in Pimlico with river views would now be given over to luxury housing for the wealthy. It would be privately developed. It would be hierarchical, with lavish penthouses set over tiers of "apartments" and "studios". The poor would be excluded.

The Millennium Village is an honest attempt, announced with a flourish by John Prescott in 1997, to create a new riverside community for people from a widish range of incomes. Here was the way we were going to live in the future: there would be homes that could expand as family needs grew; every home would have a computer; this would be a green world in which use of cars would be limited.

The reality will be far more ordinary. The show flats are nicely appointed and well-made, a cut above what we have come to expect from most developers' housing in cities. But the whole development will look much like Docklands domestic architecture to date. It is bricky, slopey and would look more at home in Milton Keynes or on the edge of Stockholm than London (the leading architect, Ralph Erskine, is Swedish; he is also the designer of the Byker Wall housing scheme, Newcastle-upon-Tyne). There is nothing fundamentally urban about this project, even though it offers greater density - more people to the acre - than most recent suburban-style inner-city housing projects. On the other hand, it is called a "village" when it patently isn't.

In that one quaint word, however, lies the heart of so much of our problem with contemporary housing. It's the word that leads us back to Fairford Leys. People who live in affluent, tree-lined districts of London insist on calling them "villages". Picking up on this nostalgic snobbery, those who build new homes (developers) and those who flog them (estate agents) like to label virtually all new housing developments "villages". Which none of them are. How strange that even in the middle of one of the greatest, most teeming, most cosmopolitan cities on earth so many people need to pretend they are living in villages, like Marie-Antoinettes playing milkmaids, far from the madding crowd.

It is what many people want to believe, whether they are living on the north Greenwich peninsula or on the edge of a Buckinghamshire market town given a brutal Modern and postmodern makeover between 1960 and the present day. If the Millennium Village offers one view of how some of the 3.8m new homes planned for south-east England might look, Fairford Leys offers another. Here the architect in charge, John Simpson, a favourite of the Prince of Wales and designer of the new-look Queen's Picture Gallery at Buckingham Palace, has attempted to create an instant old-world village on the scale of a town. Although the houses are twee - their facades packed full of 18th-century-style incident - they are grouped in terraces, secreted down mews and gathered around tiny town squares. Within a couple of years pioneer settlers will be able to shop, go to church and drink in a pub in a brand-new, old-world market square. Simpson's drawings are delightful, whimsical things, but the reality is far less convincing. While it is possible to conjure a convincing-looking Quality Street townscape on paper, it is far harder to build it. And, unlike a traditional village, Fairford Leys seems to be aimed at people drawn from a narrow slice of English society. Furthermore, most will commute to work, many by car.

The whole place strikes the visitor as false. The "sash" windows are not made of wood, nor do they slide up and down in the time-honoured fashion. They are coated in uPVC and open up and outwards. Not quite Georgian. Fanlights are built into doors instead of being set above them. A row of railway cottages is charming, but as there is no railway here, nor ever has been, why the conceit? Mews exist here, even though horses and carriages never have. Some flats are "carved" - as estate agents like to say - from what looks like a converted Victorian chapel but turns out to be a brand-new building masquerading as a conversion. And so it goes on: an implausible, stage-set world.

A far cry from Churchill Gardens. Neither the Millennium Village, with its promise of an ecologically sound way of life, nor Fairford Leys, with its attempt at old-world charm, can beat this 50s estate in terms of economy: easy on land use, easy on the eye. Just as I was about to write this paragraph, a press release announcing the "e.house", the "first steel-framed factory-built house in the UK to be assembled on a residential development ready for occupation and sale" (at Port Regent estate, Eastbourne, East Sussex) landed on my desk. A real house for the future? Not a chance. The steel frame is clad in brick and the whole caboodle looks like any house in any cul-de-sac-filled suburb. Dear John Prescott. Dear Nick Raynsford. Please take a serious look at modern housing before we're all swamped with this village stuff - old, new and, however decent, always indifferent.
